column2: Adolph Cohen, 17 years old, of No. 36 Rivington-street, went into the Jewish Synagogue at No. 44 East Broadway, on Saturday night, and the sexton was aroused at 5 o'clock yesterday morning by Cohen's snoring. Five dollars and a watch-chain belonging to the sexton were missing, and Justice Patterson, in the Essex Market Police Court, held Cohen for burglary.

Ironsides Council, No. 606, American Legion of Honor, elected the following officers on Saturday evening: Commander--George E. Trembley; Vice-Commander--Frank M. Canfield; Orator--William H. Vermilye, (re-elected;) ...

AUGUSTA, Dec. 21.--We were sitting before one of those great fire-places which are still to be found in Northern NewEngland, and my companion, a thoughtful old politician, had been telling stories about the Hon. James G. Blaine.
AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 23.--Sam Williams, the negro minstrel who was acquitted at Lyons on Friday of complicity in the murder of James Hall, came home on a train at 1 o'clock yesterday morning.

"If any one likes fishing through the ice with the thermometer 10 below zero and the wind blowing sometimes at the rate of 25 miles an hour, he can find his ideal sport just now on any of the rivers and inlets along the coast of Maine," said "Mort" Scott, well known in angling circles in this City, who returned on Saturday ...
RUTLAND, Vt., Dec. 23.--William B. Catlin, a farmer, 31 years old, of Goshen, 25 miles from here, died Saturday morning under circumstances strongly indicative of poisoning.

Dr. Peacock, who with John D. Harington and E.W. Corey, is under charges of having conspired to defraud the American Legion of Honor through the medium of "grave yard" insurances, has surrendered to Secretary Phillips, of Union Council, four policies of insurance which were irregularly issued.

The nominating committee of the Bar Association have prepared the following ticket for officers during the ensuing year, and it was posted on the bulletin of the club building on Saturday night: President--James C. Carter; ...

LONDON, Dec. 23.--Messrs. Moody and Sankey concluded their two weeks' mission at Stepney to-day. Five immense meetings were held in their hall, and overflow meetings were conducted in Stepney Church and Beaumont Hall.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Dec 23.--Of six cases of trichinosis discovered here three days ago, that of Carl Gull, German, aged 60 proved fatal to-night. Gull expired in great agony, having suffered four weeks. His son and daughter are suffering greatly, and will die, as will also a German boarder named Frink. The disease was occasioned by eating raw sausage made from pork raised by Gull.

The last district reports for Bengal show no sign of improvement in harvest prospects. It is evident that in the greater part of the Province the late rice crop will be almost a total failure, while, unless rain falls soon, the cold weather crops must also prove very deficient.
BILLINGS, Minn., Dec. 23.--Jack Meyer has rediscovered the bed of the lost Cabin mine, in Montana, which is immensely rich. It is located near the headwaters of the Big Horn River.
The North German Lloyd steam-ship Fulda reached this port yesterday after a stormy passage. Capt. Undutsch reports that the weather was intensely cold off the coast during Satururday night.

Mr. Austin Corbin's philanthropic scheme, whereby he proposed to run a special train loaded with fat Christmas turkeys over the Long Island Railroad and present one of these attractive fowls as a holiday gift to each of his station agents and employes on the route from end to end of the island, was consummated yesterday ...

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 23.--Mr. Howard, the new American Consul, was formally introduced to the City Council yesterday by Mayor Boswell, and was cordially received. He thanked the counsel for its hearty greeting, and stated that his reception at Toronto had thus far been nothing but cordial, and evidenced the hospitality of the city.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 23.--Bob Younger, one of the Younger brothers, and a companion of Jesse James, was arrested yesterday near Warrior, Ala., on a requisition from the Governor of Missouri.

John Johnson, a, Norwegian farmer, came to this country about six months ago, leaving his wife and four children in Norway. His wife died in November, and Johnson got all the money together that he could and bought his ticket for Europe on Dec. 8.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 23.--"Toby" Kelly, who has lived in Camden for a number of years, and who prides himself on being one of the best pugilists in the State, visited the saloon of ...

During the past week a new fish has been brought to the attention of the wholesale trade in Boston. Its appearance here is the result of the United States Fish Commission's efforts to bring to public notice such newly discovered fish as are marketable for food.

At a meeting of the citizens of the village of Edgewater, Staten Island, and of the Supervisors of Richmond County on Saturday evening a committee was appointed to confer with the Boards of Health of New-York and Brooklyn ...
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec. 23.--Last Spring James Dunn, one of the most prominent men and contractors of this city, disappeared, forsaking a beautiful wife and child.
The congregation of St. John's German Lutheran Church, No. 81 Christopher-street, celebrated its first jubilee yesterday. It was established in 1858, and its first Pastor was the Rev. Dr. Held.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23.--With a supply nearly 25 per cent. larger than we have been accustomed to see in the cattle market at this time of year prices for all grades of shipping showed a declining tendency throughout the week just closed.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton preached on "The Traditions of Jacob" in All Souls' Church, in Forty-eighth-street, yesterday afternoon. He began with a few preliminary remarks about Isaac as necessary in linking together Abraham and Jacob.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 23.--On Friday a romance was consummated away up in the Adriondacks which, in tangled plot and novel details, claim equality with the strangest of the many fabulous Christmas tales that are just now being printed.
LONDON, Dec. 23.--The Cairo correspondent of the Observer says the British Government has explicity informed the Egyptian Government that it will not attempt to reconquer ...
A correspondent furnishes the Pittsburg (Penn.) Commercial with some letters written by Stonewall Jackson, including the following, which may have general interest even at this late day:
It is not likely that anything will come of the turmoil made over Police Justice MURRAY'S allegations against the Police Captains. The Justice cannot possibly prove the charges which he has implied.

Of the Bishop of Killaloe, who died last Saturday, a good story has been told. Dr., Whately was holding a visitation of his clergy, and in the hours when clerical matters were not under discussion was impressing upon them the excellence of watercresses.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 23.--The negro, "Big Ike," who, while attempting to rob the bank at Durango last week shot dead Bruce Hunt, son of ex-Gov. Hunt, died last night in the jail at that place from the injuries received in jumping headlong from a 40-foot embankment to avoid being captured. Just before he died he made a confession implicating four others, who are all under arrest.

The police of the Tenth Precinct found time yesterday to notify the Central Office that early on Saturday morning a robbery, or an atrocious attempt to murder a woman, occurred at No. 3 Bayard-street.

JOHNSTOWN, Dec. 22.--J.P. Cole, who is confined in jail at Johnstown under indictment of murder for the killing of Samuel P. Murray, is engaged in constructing different kinds of mechanism for various purposes.

We assume that it is the disgust and weariness of a bluff and honest man under sore annoyance, rather than actual knowledge or even reasonable suspicion, which prompts Mr. JOHN A. WALSH to his outspoken impeachment of the sincerity of the Government prosecution of the Hon. WILLIAM PITT KELLOGG.

NORWICH, Conn., Dec. 23.--The oldest house in Windham County, a large wood colored edifice of the "lean to" period, which greatly antedated the revolution, having been built in 1710, has been burned in Thompson the past week.

STONINGTON, Conn., Dec. 23.--Still another phase has come over the situation, complicated as it already is, at up country Wequetequoc, this time in the shape of a circular giving in full the speeches made at the mass indignation meeting ...

A young man who is supposed to be Peter Hammond, a native of Glasgow, and a fireman on the Atlas Line steamer Alvena, now in dock in Brooklyn, died yesterday morning at the foot of the cellar stairs of Jacob Weeks's tenement-house ...
"If we have two more days of good weather we will have the finest sleighing NewYorkers have had in many years on Christmas Day."
SCOTTDALE, Penn., Dec. 23.--A war against the Hungarians has been begun and tonight the following circular signed "Citizens" was posted throughout the coke country:

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 23.--The receipt of mail matter at the Post Office to-day, consisting mostly of books and packages for Christmas presents, is so large that the carriers began to-night delivering some of the matter in order to make room in the Post Office and to lighten the work on tomorrow.

PARIS, Dec. 10.--It has been a dull week. The interminable debate on the Tonquin question still drags along; the reception at the Academy a few days ago was more privy than such occasions usually are; there have been no new pieces at the theatres, and even the anarchist demonstration on the Place de la Bourse was a fizzle.

Capt. Dorsey, Sergts. Carroll and Roulette, and the rank and file of the Long Island City police waited patiently and with some degree of anxiety, yesterday, for the appearance of the invading detachment of the Salvation Army, an incursion which the authorities had been warned to be prepared for by Francis Cummings, chief of staff.

Wreaths and crosses of hemlock, pine, and holly hung in the windows of hundreds of houses yesterday morning, and people passing through the streets on their way to church found the white snow speckled with tiny bits of evergreen that had been dropped here and there by the enterprising vendors.
The liquor-dealers of the Eighteenth Ward, or most of them, did not keep the resolution yesterday that they were reported to have made to close their saloons on Sunday.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 23.--When the Virginia Legislature reassembles after the Christmas recess an attempt will be made to abolish the present constitutional provision imposing political disabilities upon all persons engaged in dueling, either as principals or seconds.
What is popularly called the Mormon question was discussed at some length at the Brooklyn New-England dinner.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 23.--August Weyler, an employe of the Equitable Gas-light Company, was found dead this morning on the track of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, between Scott and Bayard streets, in this city. The body was terribly mutilated, having evidently been run over by a train of cars.

The concert at the Metropolitan Operahouse last night was thrown into a temporary state of confusion by the illness of Mme. Valleria, which was apparently unknown to the management until a very late hour.

An Iowa Congressman states that hundreds and thousands of the people of his State are preparing to move Southward and settle there. They are chiefly men of means, disgusted with the bleak North-west climate.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 23.--A movement has been started here by the Baptists to secure a separation from the Church of Eastern Canada, because of the apathy shown ...
The eighth annual Children's carnival and ball will take place in the Academy of Music Monday evening, Feb. 11. The programme of the entertainment comprises 16 numbers.

"Well, to think of it! Why, I remember Regulas Rothsay--or Rule, as we used to call him in them days--when he was a little bit of a fellow hardly up to my knee, running about bare-footed and doing odd jobs 'round the foundry.
A special Christmas service was held yesterday afternoon, in the Cooper Institute, by the Manhattan Temperance Association. The hall, which was arctic in temperature, was only partially filled.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 23.--There will be a great deal less iron made in the United States during the next one or two months than the iron-making capacity could produce if all the mills were kept going.
At a meeting of the New-Haven Civil Service Reform Association, held on Friday evening, 14th inst., the following letter from Senator Hawley was read:
RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 23.--Col. David Settle, brother of Judge Thomas Settle, is Clerk of the Superior Court of Rockingham County, and is also a large farmer.

The first floating ice of the season made its appearance yesterday in the North River. There were but few pieces, and these were small. The river pilots, however, fear that if the cold weather continues the rivers will be choked with ice in a few days.

Two fires fatal to horses occurred yesterday morning in the Eighteenth Precinct. The first broke out at 1:15 o'clock in a frame stable in front of the tenement-house No. 336 East Twenty-second-street.

The speeches made at the New-England Society's dinner on Saturday evening by the Mayors of Brooklyn and New-York presented a striking contrast, which must have been appreciated by the intelligent audience.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 23.--In answer to a request from prominent members of the South Carolina Senate as to the working of the Railroad Commission, Capt. W.G. Raroul, President of the Georgia Central system, sent the following:

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 23.--Early this morning an aged lady named Susan Gibbs, residing in a cottage near the Humber River, about three miles from the city, was found brutally murdered in her own house.

ERIE, Penn., Dec. 23.--A New-York surgeon, Dr. Elston, who scratched his finger while assisting in the making of a post-mortem on the body of Spencer Meyer, is dying of blood poisoning. The symptoms appeared the day after the incision was made in his finger two weeks ago. All remedies have proved powerless to drive the poisonous blood of the dead man from the doctor's system.
The news that a hundred Italian priests have held a meeting in Ancona in order to organize a strike in case their demand for increased pay should not be granted is rather startling.

That queer admixture of strong sensuousness and weak philosophy discoverable in "Mr. Isaacs" is still observable in "To Leeward." We might forgive the riot of passion in the Persian because it is a characteristic of the Oriental, but in Mr. Crawford's present story we have to do with English and Italians.

A meeting of the Church Extension Committee was held at the Rev. Dr. Hall's church last evening. After prayer by the Rev. Dr. Wilson, the Rev. Dr. Clark made an address earnestly calling upon the Presbyterians of New-York to advance the cause of church extension, adducing ...
A San Francisco paper notes the departure from that port of a ship destined for Europe loaded with redwood and other finishing timbers of California growth.
Four adventurous boys were turned over to the police of the Second Precinct this morning by Superintendent Foster of the Union Station.

Villa residents in the annexed district, and especially in the neighborhood of King's Bridge, are always annoyed at this season by seekers for Christmas trees, who cut down valuable pines and evergreens without regard to their value or the trouble it has taken to plant and ...

John Otten, a German grocer, sleeps, with his two clerks, in the rear of his store, No. 148 Tompkins-avenue, Brooklyn. About 2 o'clock yesterday morning he was awakened by hearing the alarm of his money-drawer go off.

Many of the parents of the students at the Academy of the Sacred Heart, Classon's Point, West Chester, which is the Junior Department of Manhattan College, and a large number of the friends of the brothers of the Christian ...

The President arrived in this City yesterday morning and was driven directly to the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. He then went to visit Mr. Charles Miller, and in the afternoon, on his return to the hotel, he received George Bliss William Dowd, and Franklin Woodruff.

The new Calvary Baptist Church in West Fifty-seventh-street, near Sixth-avenue, was opened yesterday to the public and every seat was occupied. Since last July the congregation has assembled in the adjoining chapel, to which they came from their old church in Twenty-thirdstreet.

The Rev. Benjamin Staunton was last evening installed as Pastor of the Fort Greene Presbyterian Church, in Cumberland-street, Brooklyn. The installation sermon was preached by the Rev. Dr. Archibald McCullagh, of the Ross-Street Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, ...

Details of a remarkable swimming feat have just come to hand from Auckland, NewZealand. Capt. Haultain, who is 32 years of age, and weighs, we are told, 14 stone, commands a sailing vessel trading on the New-Zealand coast.

Isidor Goldsmidt, a well-known Hebrew, committed suicide on Friday, at his residence, No. 629 Second-avenue, by taking laudanum, and the facts were kept secret by Coroner Martin until they accidentally leaked out yesterday. Mr. Goldsmidt was born in Bavaria in 1828.

PARIS, Dec. 23.--The Governor of French Cochin China reports that the Council of Regency at Hue informed him that Hiephema abdicated the throne of Annam and a new King, 15 years old, was crowned on Dec. 2, under the name of Keinphua.

The trade in bananas, collar-buttons, prickly pears, and suspenders was temporarily dull at noon yesterday in the vicinity of the City Hall station of the elevated road, and the dealers in these commodities were listlessly idling upon the curbstone watching the surging tide of humanity, street cars, and garbage carts that flowed endlessly past.

The will of the late Junius Brutus Booth, proceedings to set aside which, it is said, have already been begun in behalf of his daughter Marion, is a very brief document drawn upon a single page of legal cap, and was allowed by Judge Choate, of the Essex Court of Probate, Oct. 15, 1883.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23.--Anxious members of Congress and equally anxious candidates for clerkships of House committees have been plodding about in the snow to-day to gather up the latest gossip about the standing committees of the House.

DES MOINES, Dec. 23.--Five prisoners, Thomas Lally and Oscar Piper, convicted of burglary; Ed Hannon, sentenced for perjury; Albert Knight, sentenced for larceny, and Charles Adams, sentenced for swindling, escaped from the County Jail to-night.

Julius Boh, janitor at the Tombs, died yesterday morning at 3 o'clock at his residence, No. 504 Sixth-street, of rheumatism of the heart. Mr. Boh had been ill but a short time, and his death was unexpected. He ran for Assemblyman as the candidate of Irving Hall in the Tenth Assembly District at the last general election, and was defeated.

BOSTON, Dec. 23.--Extreme cold weather prevailed last night and this morning throughout New-England. Bangor, Me., reports the mercury at 19 to 20 below zero; Rockland, Me., 18 below and one of the coldest nights ever known on the coast.
TRENTON, Dec. 23.--Active canvassing has been in progress for the last three or four weeks over the organization of the New-Jersey Legislature.

That lightning killed his soil is the belief of a farmer in Newton, Ill. He writes: "This Summer, whenn my corn was two feet high, the lightning struck it, killing a patch about 100 square feet in extent.

During the solemn mass at St. Stephen's Church, in East Twenty-eighth-street, yesterday morning, the Rev. Edward McGlynn stated that in order to accommodate those wishing to make Christmas presents many articles at the fair will be sold at very moderate prices instead of being put up for "shares."
Mr. J. J. Winant, writing to the San Francisco Examiner under date of Dec. 13, says: "During the month of September I was on my way to Honolulu from San Francisco.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 23.--About 9:30 o'clock to-night John Schneider, a machinist, 16 years old, shot and instantly killed his brother Gustave, a blacksmith, aged 23.

--English Lyrics. New-York: D. Appleton, Co. 1884.--Another pretty little volume of the Parchment Library, clad in its frail white covers, and printed with red letters on its title page. The few words of introduction are not signed. The selections have been made with taste.
The Auxiliary Dry Goods Committee of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association has issued circulars for public distribution, giving, a summary of the work performed by the association.
Timothy Crowley, George Roberts, and Lizzie Macy, who were concerned in the mysterious affair at No. 63 Chrystie-street, in which Moriarty was shot, were brought before Justice Patterson, ...

BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 22, via Galveston.-- Mr. Callan, an Irish member of the British Parliament, has arrived in this city. It is believed that the object of his visit is to negotiate for the introduction of Irish colonization into this country. He will leave here on Tuesday next for the colonies of Santa Fe.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 23.--There is at the present time remarkable activity among the Democrats in fixing up things for the new State administration.

The Rev. J.O. Bache preached to his congregation in Grace Church, One Hundred and Sixteenth-street, yesterday morning, for the first time since his reported assault and robbery, on the evening of Dec. 6.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 23.--The sinking of the coal-laden schooner C.S. Baylis, of Bristol, R.I., on Luddington Rock, off this harbor, on Friday night, was caused by the displacement of the buoy on that dangerous obstruction.
The Rev. Dr. L.T. Chamberlain, of the Clason-Avenue Church, Brooklyn, preached last evening upon Mormonism. He described it as paganism, Mohammedanism, and animalism in one.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23.--The retirement of Mr. W.W. Ker from the employment of the Government in the star route cases has not escaped comment here, neither has it excited a great deal of inquiry about what has led the Attorney-General to allow him to go.
At the dinner given by the representatives of New-York in 1783, in the Hotel Brunswick on Evacuation Day, it was suggested that a society should be formed, the members of which ...
The remains of the late Capt. Thomas Barnabas Hanham, who died last week, were cremated at Mainston, near Sturminster Newton, Dorset, last night.

BRADFORD, Penn., Dec. 23.--George D. Westervelt and William McNorton, the former a prominent oil operator, were killed to-day by a boiler explosion at a well near Allentown, Allegany County, New-York. Westervelt's head was torn off and his body was terribly mangled. McNorton was pierced through the chest by an iron pipe.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 23.--I met Mr. John A. Walsh in Baltimore yesterday. He said he was there in connection with business matters, and was in company with some old New-Orleans friends.

Capt. Charles C. Powell, of Oyster Bay, Long Island, has been missing for a week. A week ago yesterday he left Oyster Bay in his sloop Mary Powell with a cargo of oysters. He arrived in New-York and sold out his cargo for $500. The last information obtained of him is from Capt. Phillips, who says he saw Capt. Powell drunk in a saloon on Grand-street displaying a pistol.
Mgr. Capel preached the last of his series of sermons in St. Ann's Church yesterday morning before a large and attentive congregation. His subject was, "Jesus the Bread of Life."
New-Yorkers got a taste of genuine Winter weather yesterday. It was the coldest day so far this season.
Poor Edmond O'Donovan, about whose fate I fear there can be no longer any doubt, had a presentiment that he would never return to England when leaving for his last trip.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 24.--Superintendent of State prisons I.V. Baker, Jr., has received a dispatch stating that the provision department at Clinton Prison burned last night. The entire stock of potatoes and other supplies was destroyed.

A student of human nature, having read some of the complaints of correspondents of newspapers about the snappish manners of young men in the box-offices of theatres, went recently to the office of an up-town theatre for the purpose of observation. The young man in the boxoffice was known to the student of human nature, who thus addressed him:

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Dec. 24.--Gov. Murray arrived here this morning and was met by a large delegation of leading citizens and escorted to his residence. A pleasant reception was given him and many welcoming speeches were made.
In reference to the recent report that he was about to be married, the Rev. Thomas Harrison, "the boy preacher," has printed the following card ina Western newspaper:
A motion was made before Judge Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday for the vacation of an order for the examination of Imre and Bolossy Kiralfy.

At a regular meeting of the Board of Directors of the New-York Eye and Ear Infirmary on Dec.19 a letter was received from Royal Phelps tendering his resignation of the office of President of the board and inclosing a check for $5,000 for the benefit of the infirmary.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 24.--Jefferds, Bailey Co., lounge and table manufacturers, L. Jefferds, partner in the firm and proprietor of axe-works, made an assignment to-day to J.B. Fisher, and Jefferds to F.E. Sessions.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 24.--A gentleman who lives near Moncure Station, Moore county, was here to-day and said that Mrs. Alvin Gunter, an old lady, and her little granddaughter, were murdered on Saturday night last.
The public will naturally scan first and most closely among the committees appointed by Mr. CARLISLE the Committee on Ways and Means.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Dec. 21.--A heavy single-barreled flint-lock rifle, a curiously carved powder-horn, and a round pine stick upon which are cut 99 notches' of different sizes are prized relics in a Sullivan County family.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 24.--T.W. Bicknell, President of the National Educational Association, is in Milwaukee making arrangements for the four days' meeting Of the association in ...

It has not yet been decided what the testimonial from the Catholics of this City to Cardinal McCloskey, on the occasion of his golden jubilee, shall be. An episcopal ring, a memorial window in the Cathedral, a bronze piece, and a pair of vases have been suggested by various parties.

A large section of the rear wall of the two-story building at the north-west corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Twenty-ninthstreet fell yesterday and partly demolished a one-story frame shanty adjoining, which is occupied ...

The funeral of the lata Conrad Poppenhusen, one of the founders of College Point, took place yesterday from the Poppenhusen Institute. There was a large attendance, delegates being present from the Long Island Railroad, College Point Rubber Works, Poppenhusen Institute, and various organizations. During the funeral ceremonies business was suspended in the village.

It is known in a vague way that enormous sums are spent annually by railway companies in promoting and opposing private bill legislation, but few who are not experts will be prepared for the huge aggregate which a return just issued discloses.

It is time that Scientific Persons should ascertain the cause of the unusual sunsets that have attracted attention for the last month. They have been seen all over the world, and the same strange glow that has been more than once mistaken for fire in this City, has been seen in Europe, in India, and in Honolulu.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 24.--The Journal's New-Albany special gives the following account of the wreck at Salem, Ind., to-day: "One of the most disastrous accidents that has occurred on the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago ...
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 24.--That quarter of the city taken up by fashionable boarding houses was this Christmas eve the scene of a triple tragedy.

When Mrs. McKenna, of No. 145 Hudsonavenue, Brooklyn, returned from a shopping tour last evening she saw two rough-looking men leaving her house. Suspecting they were thieves she raised a cry of alarm.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 24.--A compromise has been effected by the Western Union Telegraph Company with the State in the suit for $147,000 for tax on stock dividends for the years 1879 and 1881. The company will pay $50,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24.--The President today transmitted to the House of Representatives the report of the Secretary of State, with voluminous correspondence, in response to a resolution of Dec. 19, calling for communications and ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 24.--The effort to close the drinking saloons in this city on Sunday in accordance with the order of the Police Commission, issued soon after election, is not yet entirely successful, but is making progress.

A dull, leaden sky overhung the City. It was even more dull than leaden skies usually are. It seemed to crowd down with all its weight upon the house-tops, forcing a large portion of its ashen, humid clouds down to the very street pavements, filling the eyes and noses of the people and making them feel damp all over. Under foot the condition of things was lamentable.
NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 24.--Conductor James Searles, of the Harlem River freight train, had a very narrow escape from death by exposure in the storm, at an early hour this morning.
OURAY, Col., Dec. 24.--News has just been received here of a horrible accident at the Virginia Mine, which occurred last Friday.

Reports received in this City state that James E. Temple has been appointed Receiver of the Palo Blanco Cattie Company at Springer, New-Mexico, and an injunction was granted restraining the company from disposing of any property or increasing its stock.

The counting of the receipts yesterday at the box-office of the Pedestal Fund Art Loan Exhibition showed that 1,680 persons had bought tickets on Sunday on entering the Academy of Design, the total sum amounting to $420.
RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 24.--The funeral of the late Col. Benjamin L. Trafford will take place from the First Presbyterian Church, the Rev. F. R. Harbaugh officiating, on Wednesday.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 24.--The strongest leaders among the Ohio Republicans recognize that the coming Senatorial contest at Columbus means far more than the bestowal of an office on one man, and that its outcome shall determine ...

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 24.--The case of the New-Orleans National Bank against W.B. Merchant, the Postmaster, in which the plaintiff asked for a writ of injunction to restrain the Postmaster from interfering with all mail matter ...
PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 24.--At Summit station, 12 miles west of Island Pond, Vt., the Grand Trunk Railway has a crossing for freight and passenger trains.

Immigration Inspector Herrlich found a draft for 1,990 marks on the Inman Pier shortly after the steamship City of Berlin had been moored there yesterday morning. The draft was given to Superintendent Jackson, of Castle Garden, and was subsequently claimed by an immigrant named George Vernoch, who proved his ownership.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 24.--A delegation from the Ontario Millers' Association had an interview with the Government to-day, submitting a second proposal regarding the reduction ...

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 24.--A shooting affray took place at Richmond this evening. Henry W. Johnson, a prominent criminal lawyer, in attempting to shoot one of the firm of Baumer Brothers shot Policeman Wertenburg, inflicting a wound which may prove fatal, and was himself shot in the back of the head by some unknown person. The shooting was the result of a lawsuit between Baumer Brothers and a man named Vaughan, for whom Johnson was attorney.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 24.--The Pittsburg iron manufacturers look upon the Ways and Means Committee as constituted by Speaker Carlisle as an indication of the renewal of the tariff agitation in the present Congress with a view to lower duties.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 24.--A married woman named Van der Linden has been arrested at Leyden charged with having murdered in the last few years 16 persons. Her victims were nearly all members of her own family. She insured their lives first and received the insurance money after their deaths. The woman has confessed her guilt. It is supposed that she poisoned five of her own children.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 24.--The Mayor tonight again vetoed the ordinance granting the right of way into the city to the Chicago and Evanston Railroad, but the City Council passed it over the veto by the requisite two-thirds majority. This is the ordinance in connection with the passage of which the local papers charge wholesale corruption on the part of the Councilmen.

The annual election of the New-York Mercantile Exchange was held yesterday. There were 267 votes cast, the largest number ever polled. The following named gentlemen were elected officers for the ensuing year:

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 24.--The expected lynching of Charles Harvey at Petersburg, Pike County, for the murder of Henry Custil, Jr., Friday night, took place Sunday morning shortly after 1 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24.--Not half of the seats in the Hall of Representatives were occupied this morning when Speaker Carlisle's standing committees were announced, but the galleries were well filled with spectators.
The special committee appointed by the Chamber of Commerce to agitate the subject of preserving the Adirondack forests met for the fourth time yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Dec. 4.--It is arranged that the new play which Mr. Gilbert has written expressly for Miss Mary Anderson shall be played--if it prove successful, of which I think there can be little doubt--after "Pygmalion and Galatea," which is to be produced, with Miss Anderson in the part of Galatea, on Saturday, the 8th.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 24.--Intelligence has been received by Henry Leyerzaph, a journeyman barber of this city, that in a few weeks he will come into possession of $87,000, through the death of friends in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24.--The following it a complete list of the committees of the House of Representatives as announced to-day:
RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 24.--Charles Sutton, son of Mayor John Sutton, died yesterday of typhoid fever after a short illness.

Mrs. O'Donnell, the widow of Cary's slayer, who was hanged in London on Dec. 17, arrived in this City yesterday in the Inman steamship City of Berlin. She was met on the Inman pier by a party of friends, and left in the afternoon for Philadelphia.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 24.--While Miss GabrielleGreely, daughter of the late Horace Greeley, was sleigh-riding with a lady companion to-day her horse became frightened near the pleasantville station and Miss Greeley was thrown out of the sleigh, but received no serious injury.

Henry Gavin, an engineer, of No. 129 Chrystie-street, was attacked last night about 10:30 by three ruffians, at Washington-street and Battery-place, who grabbed him around the neck and body, and in the struggle stole his watch, valued at $50.
BUFFALO, Dec. 24.--At last the crew of the ill-fated vessel S.D. Hungerford have arrived in this city and the mystery is solved. Capt. Robert Drewery and all the crew are here except the cook.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 24.--As the steamer Nonowantuc was on her way to this city from Port Jefferson, Capt. Charles Tooker sighted a coal barge off Stratford Light, with a flag of distress floating at her mast-head.
There is hardly a difference of opinion as to the desirability of prompt action to put an end to the reckless devastation of the forest regions of the Adirondacks.

LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 24.--The Farmers' Northern Market, on North Green-Street, this city, a large brick structure, 244 by 87 feet in dimensions, was totally demolished about 3 o'clock this morning by the weight of snow on the roof.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 24.--A special dispatch to the Times-Star from Fort Wayne, Ind., says: "The rear coach of the Grant Rapids and Indiana north-bound passenger train was struck by a switch engine this morning. Eight persons were seriously hurt, Mrs. Judge Ellison being among them. The accident was caused by the carelessness of the engineer of the switch engine."

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 24.--The case of Edward R. Henderson, charged with manslaughter in the killing of Charles L. Perry, was continued to-day until Dec. 27, to obtain certain medical testimony. Henderson being held in $3,000.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Dec. 24.--James Hooven Sons and J. H. Boone Co., iron manufacturers, of this place, have posted notices in their mills announcing that on and after Jan. 1, 1884, the price of puddling will be reduced from $4 to $3.75 per day, and that the wages of all other employes will be reduced in proportion.

"The walking is pretty bad," said a theatrical manager who returned to the City yesterday from an expedition through the country.

Porter, Crofut Hodgkinson, manufacturers of hats at No. 104 Greene-street and at Orange, N.J., have suspended. The liabilities are currently reported at about $25,000. The business was started about 25 years ago by Porter Crofut, and Mr. Hodgkinson has been a partner for four years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24.--The commission appointed to examine into the advisability of selling the whole or a part of the Brooklyn Navyyard have made a report of a non-committal character.

A dispatch from Vice-President T.F. Oakes was received at the offices of the Northern Pacific Railroad, in this City, yesterday. It was dated St. Paul, and stated that the Bozeman Tunnel was cut through on Dec. 21. Trains are expected to run through about the first of the year.

Naches, the Plute Chief, yesterday received by express a fine overcoat from his sister, Princess Sallie, who is now in Boston. It was a little too large for him, but, with that generosity for which he is noted, he presented it to Lee Winnemucca, who is almost blind and cannot work.
The effects of the storm of Sunday night were felt very seriously by persons living on the otherside of the Harlem draw-bridge at Thirdavenue, who do business in the City, yesterday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24.--The Regatta Committee of the University of Pennsylvania have received from President Sexton, of the Harvard Boat Club, the formal declination of the latter to accept the university's challenge to an eight-oared race, "owing to other engagements entered into with other colleges." The university is bound to have a race if possible, and will go to Cambridge if Harvard will row them.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 240.--While a cage containing 20 convict laborers was descending a shaft in the Pratt mines this morning the engine became unmanageable for a moment, and the cage fell to the bottom, a distance of 204 feet, and rebounded 60 feet. Most of the men fell out. One of them, Joseph Phelan, colored, was killed, and 13 were injured, two of them seriously. Two of the men were whites and the others colored.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 24.--Henry Irving made his first appearance in this city to-night, at the Academy of Music, as Louis XI. The audience was small, but he was very cordially received.
John Schneider, the 16-year-old boy who shot his brother Gustav at their boardinghouse in William-street, Newark, Sunday night, was arraigned before Police Justice Ricord yesterday morning.
PANAMA, Dec. 15.--Mr. Henry C. Hall, United States Minister to Central America, accompanied by his wife, left this city for Gautemala on the 14th inst.
The Presbytery of New-York held an adjourned meeting yesterday afternoon at the Scotch Presbyterian Church, in Fourteenthstreet, the Rev. Dr. J.M. Worrall acting as Moderator.
Detective Sergeants Kush and Tooker arrested Walter E. Kidder at the International Hotel yesterday on a charge of bigamy, made in a telegram signed A.J. Parks, Sheriff of Miami County, Ind.

A State temperance convention is called to meet in Montgomery in the latter part of January. There is no need for any body to get uneasy. The last convention resolved that the temperance question should be kept out of politics, and the next one will be more than likely to do the same thing.
Lizzie Davis, of No. 162 Division-street, was last week defendant in an assault and battery case, and the process--a summons--was served by one Isaacs, a Suffolk-street cigar-dealer.

PARIS, Dec. 24.--The National denies the rumors of mediation between France and China, and says that France is resolved to carry out alone, as the honor of France may dictate, the task she has undertaken in Tonquin, and will only consider her task finished when Annam understands that it is impossible to evade the fulfilment of her treaty obligations.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 24.--Marie R.E. Booth has filed a petition in the Supreme Court in Essex County asking permission to enter and prosecute an appeal from the decree of the Probate Court of Essex County, setting up the will of Junius Brutus Booth and appointing the widow, Marian Agnes Booth Administratrix. The petition cites that the petitioner is a daughter by a former marriage, and thinks that justice demands a reversal of the decree.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24.--Secretary Crew, of the Society to Protect Children from Cruelty, received a letter to-day from Disbursing Agent Lawrence, of the United States Pension Office, informing him that he had in his possession several thousand dollars belonging to Margaret Culiden, a ward of the society, and a daughter of a soldier who fought in the rebellion.

An enthusiastic assemblage of 15 gentlemen gathered in the Knickerbocker Cottage, in Sixth-avenue, last evening, to appropriately celebrate their third anniversary of the holding of the first meeting for organizing the Anti-Monopoly movement.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 24.--Superintendent Robert Stewart has been appointed Acting General Manager of the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company, in place of Mr. George P. Frick, resigned, and Superintendent William H. Trego has been appointed Acting General Manager of the Baltimore and Ohio Express Department. Both gentlemen entered upon their duties to-day.

Surrogate Rollins yesterday appointed George E. Williams, President of the Chemical National Bank, temporary Administrator of the estate of the late Louis C. Hamersley, pending the contest of his will.
LONDON, Dec. 24.--A Rome dispatch to the Exchange Telegraph Company states that the Pope intends to confer upon the Crown Prince of Germany the Order of Christ, first class.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 24.--The evidence in the Higham trial closed to-day. Dr. James Spencer swore that there were no powdermarks on the face or coat of Eames. Mr. Raines will begin summing up the case to-morrow.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24.--Cattle received during Sunday and Monday, 4,300; same time last week, 9,991. There was a good, strong demand on Eastern account, and the market for such grades as shippers seek was higher than the closing days of last week.

Mr. Dwight H. Olmstead appeared before the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday afternoon to suggest Tenth-avenue as a suitable route for surface railroad communication between the lower and upper portions of the City for the special accommodation of the West Side population.

VALDOSTA, Ga., Dec. 24.--News has just reached here of a brutal murder in Echols County on Thursday night. Mr. Frank Coleson was the victim. He was in Valdosta all day on Thursday and reached home a little after dark.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 24.--The colored people of Portsmouth are intensely excited over the murder, Sunday morning, of a colored youth named Edward Corrigan by a negro named Cornelius Collins. The motive for the murder seems to have been jealousy. Collins is still at large. The negroes threaten to lynch him if he is caught.

P.T. Barnum on Saturday executed a codicil to his will. To meet a possible future claim of insanity, directed against his will, he called in his family physician and two other well-known Bridgeport doctors, one a homeopathist and the other an allopathist, all of whom witnessed his signature and made oath that they believed the testator to be of sound and disposing mind and memory.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24.--Henry Derter, a German, about 30 years of age, this morning while laboring under delirium, caused by excessive drink, attacked his wife and father-in-law with a razor, both, however, managed to save themselves from his fury, and the frenzied man then turned the blade upon his own throat and inflicted a deep gash. He was taken to the hospital. The wound is not necessarily fatal.

Einrich Seekeley was sent to Mauch Chunk from Jersey City yesterday on a charge of grand larceny preferred by Victor Klessen. Klessen told a story of woman's perfidy in justification of the arrest. He is an Austrian by birth.

Officers of the Marine Society denied, with considerable warmth, yesterday, that the establishment by the Government of a marine hospital at the Seamen's Retreat, on Staten Island, would endanger the health of New-York or Brooklyn or of Staten Island.
A sneak-thief stole a black beaver overcoat valued at $50 from the basement hall of Park Commissioner John A. Fields's house, No. 300 Schermerhorn-street, Brooklyn, last evening.

Mr. Edwin Chase Ingersoll, a well-known member of the Bar of the District of Columbia, died yesterday at St. Elizabeth Asylum for the Insane, aged 40 years. Mr. Ingersoll was born at Bangor, Me., April 2, 1843, and was a son of the late Hon. George W. Ingersoll, Attorney-General of the State of Maine.

Police Justice P.G. Duffy was visibly moved yesterday afternoon when a policeman came into the Jefferson Market Police Court with a well-dressed man, two negroes, and a handsome black-and-white ticked setter dog.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 24.--It was admitted by a member of the Quebec Government who arrived here to-day that the days of the Cabinet are near an end. It is asserted on the very best authority that Mr. Wurtele, the Treasurer, has virtually resigned.

KOWLAN, Ga., Dec. 24.--The suicide on Friday morning of Possey May was a determined effort. He was 40 years of age. He committed the deed by cutting his throat with a case-knife.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 24.--The losses by country fires in Georgia are phenomenal. The loss by single fires is small, but the aggregate runs up to figures which, to one not knowing the facts, would seem to be incredible.

"Rigoletto" was represented at the Metropolitan Opera-house last evening in presence of an audience which included a great many persons who had evidently never attended an operatic performance before, and by a few persons--these occupying boxes--who, out of consideration for people who care to listen to the singes and band, ought never to attend an operatic performance again.

On Oct. 15, Franz Hollinkay, of No. 198 Rivington-street, answered an advertisement in a German paper to the effect that liberal salaries would be paid to intelligent men while learning the ins and outs of the pursuit of a detective.

PARIS, Dec. 3.--History sometimes repeats itself at the theatre as well as elsewhere. The two performances of the "Rois en Exile" at the Vaudeville have been as roundly hissed as "Rabagas" was on the same stage 13 years ago.

A syndicate was formed by Messrs. Henry H. Porter, David Dows, Roswell P. Flower, John F. Tracy, A.B. Bayliss, Harvey Kennedy, and other capitalists, in 1873, for the purpose of dealing in the stock of the West Wisconsin Railway Company.

At the regular meeting of the Brooklyn Aldermen yesterday the Democrats, with the aid of three Republican Aldermen--Hill, of the Twenty-fifth Ward; Weeks, of the Thirteenth Ward, and Waters, of the Seventeenth Ward-- played rather a sharp trick, by which it is hoped to take $1,000 out of the city Treasury for the benefit of a Democratic ward politician.

Ex-Mayor Charles Seidler had distributed a few days ago among the 3,000 men and women employed in the Lorillard factory at Jersey City a circular notifying them that the sum of $16,500 would be distributed among them in proportion to their average earnings during the year.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 24.--Thomas Rieley, a plumber, 23 years of age, was stabbed in the temple by a knife in the hands of Elias Smith this evening. A man by the name of Kuntz and Smith were fighting, and Rieley happening along tried to separate them, when Smith drew his knife with fatal effect. The blade cut through the skull and pierced the brain. Rieley is unconscious and will die. Smith was arrested.
A stylishly dressed young man called at the United States Sub-Treasury yesterday afternoon and asked for a private interview with Assistant Treasurer Acton.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 24.--At the State Department to-day a charter was issued to the Bloomsburg and Sullivan Railroad Company, the line of which will run from Bloomsburg, Columbia County, to Bernice, Sullivan county, a distance of six miles.

A cable dispatch from Zurich, Switzerland, brings news of the death of Mr. John Syz, who was a well-known importing dry goods merchant in New-York City for many years, up to the outbreak of the war of the rebellion.

The case of Charles A. Hotchkiss against the late firm of Kennedy, Hutchinson Co., stock brokers, was continued before Referee George H. Holmes, in the Mills Building, yesterday morning, after a series of postponements extending for a month back.

Henderson Brothers, agents of the Anchor Line, received a dispatch from Glasgow yesterday, announcing that the steam-ship Bolivia, which went ashore in the Clyde and was afterwards beached, had been floated, and world probably go into the dry dock to-day.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 24.--A triple murder was committed this morning at Chatham Church, six miles from Moncure. The victims were Mrs. Olive Gunter, 80 years old, and her daughter and granddaughter. Each was struck several blows with an axe. Every effort is being made to arrest the murderer, but as yet no clue has been discovered. The community is greatly excited.

MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 24.--The crew of the Swedish bark Squando, Wallsteth, master, while loading below in the bay, mutinied. The Captain telegraphed to the Swedish Consul, and a squad from the revenue cutter went aboard and put the men in irons. They are now locked up in the guard-house.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 25.--The river continues to rise at the rate of four inches an hour. The cold weather to-night has a tendency to check the rise, and it is not expected that the water will reach an extraordinary height. Most of the barges which were torn loose yesterday have been recovered and the total loss may not not exceed $20,000. The river marked 41 feet 3 inches at 10 o'clock to-night.

BOSTON, Dec. 25.--John Moran, of Boston, who was sentenced in 1867 to life imprisonment in State prison for killing his betrothed, was pardoned to-day by Gov. Butler.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 25.--The announcement is made that Reuben R. Springer, famous for his gifts to the public, has bequeathed to the Cincinnati Art Museum his valuable art collection, also the pictures willed him by his niece, Mrs. Mills. It is also stated that he has given $10,000 more to the College of Music for a new building.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 25.--The Hon. Bradford Miller, who is in favor of the enforcement of the prohibitory law and a strict administration of the city's affairs on a business basis has been elected Mayor over the Hon. Allen Sills, representing the liberal clement of the city, which is in favor of deriving a revenue from the saloons. Both men were brought out as non-partisan candidates.

Capt. Kimmings, of the bark James Gough, which arrived yesterday from Natal, reports that he experienced very severe weather during the last week of the voyage. On Dec. 19, in latitude 36 25' and longitude 75 2', a waterlogged two-masted schooner was passed. Her foremast was gone and the bulwarks had been washed away, but the mainmast was standing. The name of the vessel was not ascertained, but she was of about 150 tons burden.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 25.--In some sections of this city, visited by officers of the Society for Protecting Women and Children, it is said that there is as much overcrowding and absolute destitution as in the slums of London. In some small rooms as many as 14 or 15 men, women, and children were found on the floor, with scarcely room to breathe.

J.S. Hartley has just finished two studies --one of John P. Howard of Burlington, Vt. and the other of Lawrence Barrett, the tragedian. The commission for the Howard bust came from an association of Burlington citizens.

Sarah Holland, a colored woman, who lives in a rattletrap frame house in the rear of No. 456 Ninth-avenue, complained at the Twentieth Precinct Station-house on Monday that Alexander Armstrong, a negro, who lived in the same house, had set the building on fire.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Dec. 25.--A freight train on the Passumpsic Railroad was thrown from the track near Barton Landing to-day and the engine and four cars were totally wrecked. No one was hurt. The accident was caused by the removal of a rail by track hand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23.--The President spent a quiet Christmas at the White House. He breakfasted early with his son and daughter, and with them attended service at St. John's Church in the morning. The rest of the day he spent at the White House, and at dinner this evening entertained Secretary Frelinghuysen and Mrs. Taylor. His Christmas presents were a pair of diamond earrings to Miss Nellie and a, check for $150 to Mr. Allan Arthur.

John H. Paine, of Sprinfield, Mo., Recorder of Deeds of Greene County, has received from Lebanon, that State, a letter inclosing a patent to 40 acres of land near Republic, issued by the United States to Albert Ragsdale.

Juries often have strange ideas of duty and the nature of evidence, but the majority verdict of the Coroner's jury in the inquest on the death of McLaughlin is a little the strangest thing of the kind on record.

Thomas Fitzpatrick, a brawny young stevedore, who has a wife and child at No. 842 Greenwich-street, was shot in the breast at 2 o'clock yesterday morning in Ninth-avenue, near Little West Twelfth-street, by Officer George Smith, of the Sixteenth Precinct, and the wound is considered a dangerous one.

The body of a man half covered with snow was found yesterday afternoon by Special Officer McCarthy lying across the grave of a child in the public lots in Greenwood Cemetery, near the entrance at Twentieth-street and Eighthavenue.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 25.--News reached Milwaukee to-day of the death of James Whaling, a well-known hardware man. He was killed in an accident, but the particulars cannot be ascertained.

WASHIGNGTON, Penn., Dec. 25.--Joseph Cowen died very suddenly last night, at his residence, in Scenery Hill. The night before he retired in his usual good health, and was found dead in his bed in the morning.
One of the largest audiences that we have ever seen at a lecture in Augusta gathered at the First Baptist Church last evening, and all those present were amply repaid for their attendance.
DENVER, Col., Dec. 25.--Further particulars of the terrible accident at the Virginia Mine, near Ouray, on Friday last, have just been received by a special messenger.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 25.--For the first time in the history of the politics of Luzerne County the Democracy have fallen in love with an honest man.

Joseph Muller, a tailor, from Johnstown, Penn., complained at Police Head-quarters, last night, that he had been knocked down and robbed near the Desbrosses-street ferry by two ruffians. They knocked him down, choked him, and stole his pocketbook, containing $50, leaving him entirely penniless. His trunk had been seut to the Summitt Hotel, and as he was not there to receive it, it was taken away and he did not know what became of it.

The severe storm doubtless kept a great many people away from the theatres yesterday, but most of the managers claimed last night to have fared better than they expected to when they saw what the weather was to be.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 25.--The following are additional names of the killed and injured in the railroad accident near Salem, Ind., yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25.--Charles Sonder, aged 30 years, residing at No. 433 North Fourth street, committed suicide this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25.--A special dispatch to the Times from Uniontown, Penn., says: "The cashier of the Peoples' Bank, F.C. Breckinridge, is a cousin of James Nutt. Mr. Breckinridge was an important witness for the prosecution at the trial of Dukes last March for killing Capt. Nutt.
The painful parsimony of the Frenchmen who have undertaken to present this City with the statue of Liberty Enlightening the World is simply disgusting.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 25.--The Speakership campaign will begin here actively to-morrow, when one or more of the candidates will open head-quarters.
Travelers by the Suez route must have noticed the picturesque Oriental guards, three in number, who accompany the mail bags through between Alexandria and Suez.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 25.--Eight convicts under sentences ranging from one to five years, arrived here from Washington this afternoon, being the first installment of Government prisoners received at the New-Hampshire Penitentiary under a contract recently made by the Governor and Council for their labor. Among the number were six colored prisoners. The Deputy Warden of the Washington Prison had them in charge.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Dec. 25.--The Erie mail train jumped the track this morning at Sunbury and dashed through several freight cars standings on a siding, uncomfortably shaking up the passengers and demolishing six or seven box cars, two passenger coaches, and disabling the engine. James Wheelan, fireman, in leaping from the train, was severly hurt. The road was obstructed for five hours.

The National Theatre, in the Bowery, near Grand-street, was packed full of men, women, and boys, yesterday afternoon, gloating over the emotional situations in the "Two Orphans." They had just got to the point where the blind girl defies her tyrannical prortectors, and they were stamping and clapping their hands over her determination to beg no more, when a man in the gallery roared out "Fire!"

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 25.--A dispatch to the Times from Washington says: There is method in the invitation given to and accepted by Speaker Carlisle to attend a reception at the Commonwealth Club in Philadelphia.

Mr. James Parker, the well-known antiquarian of Oxford, completed on Thursday the excavation of a Roman villa in an arable field at Frilford, near Abingdon, and succeeded in making a very accurate plan of its formation.
The new impost on slaves in the Province of Ceara, which has been adopted by the Provincial Assembly, must be considered as a virtual act of abolition.

There is to be a tournament for the 15ball pool championship, with prizes amounting to $700, beginning on Jan. 7, 1884, in Madison-Square Hall, No. 948 Broadway.

ROME, Ga., Dec. 25.--For the second time a convict in Bluff Road Camp has been shot dead. For the first murder a man named Freeman is now under sentence of death. For the second offense John L. Lynch has just been committed ...
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 25.--D.G. Gibson, who did all the shooting in last night's tragedy, died during the night at the City Hospital.

Friends of the late M. Gambetta intend to make at Nice on Dec. 31 a great political demonstration, that day being the anniversary of his death. On Jan. 6, the day of his funeral, they Will hold a celebration in Paris.

It is a significant fact that comparatively few Christmas trees were exposed for sale this year. There is a very evident decrease in the demand for them, and this is unquestionably due to the revival of the Christmas stocking.

VIENNA, Dec. 25.--The Political Correspondence says it has learned from Rome that Prince Frederick William, while at the Quirinal, extended an invitation to King Humbert and Queen Margherita to visit the German Court at Berlin, and that the invitation was accepted. The visit will probably be made next Spring.
UTICA, Dec. 25.--The two largest buildings of the Utica Match Company's factory in this city were burned to-day with their contents.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 25.--The baggage of the Tom Keene Company was attached at West Pittston this afternoon, on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, while on the way to Scarnton. The writ was issued at the instance of the manager of the opera-house here for a debt of $60 for failure to fulfill an engagement. The train was, delayed 15 minutes. The matter was finally settled.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 25.--At 1 o'clock this morning, Henry Schroeder and half a dozen friends went into George Ossare's saloon, on the south side, and demanded drinks.

As the Hoboken ferry-boat Hackensack which left her slip at the foot of Barclay-street at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, was nearing the slip on the Jersey side, a fight occurred between Thomas Nugent, a young man living in Hoboken, and another passenger, whose name was not ascertained. The latter, after knocking Nugent down and kicking him in the face, jumped overboard. He was picked up by a Brooklyn Annex boat and taken to Jersey City.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Dec. 25.--Arthur G. Currier was shot by Lena West in the barroom of the Bay State House to-night.

The Washington-street front of Washington Market is devoted to the vendors of holiday evergreens, and the narrow pavement was thronged on Monday with stands and stalls, sellers and buyers, to such an extent that pedestrian progression was practically impossible except at the pace of the indolent snail.
ST. Louis, Dec. 25.--The fire last night in the Cupples Woodenware Company's broom factory extended to adjoining buildings, which were almost totally destroyed.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 25.--The steamer Marengo arrived here this morning with the National Line steamer France in tow, the latter having broken her main shaft.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 25.--M.M. Torr and Phil Mack ran a foot-race of 135 yards this morning at Recreation Park, for a purse of $50. The race was advertised for 10 o'clock sharp.

SING SING, Dec. 25.--The convicts at the prison here fared well to-day. For breakfast they were treated to fricasee chicken, 1,700 pounds of poultry being utilized to provide enough for the 1,500 prisoners.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 25.--The venerable Archbishop Napoleon Joseph Perche of this Roman Catholic diocese is dying. He cannot live many hours longer. The doctors have done all they could for him and have given him up.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 25.--Mr. George M. Pullman this evening, just after his return from New-York, was asked: "What have you to say about the rumors from New-York that the Pullman Company received payment in North River Construction stock for equipment furnished the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railway?"

LONDON, Dec. 25.--The Madrid correspondent of the Times states that he hears from good authority that Chinese troops took no part in the defense of Sontay, and that the French losse in the recent battle there were much greater than was officially stated. Preparations for the defense of the Red River delta by the Chinese continue to be made on a large scale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25.--Most of the few members of Congress who were present in the House yesterday when Speaker Carlisle's committees were announced left this city for their homes, or for New-York, before night, and the capital was very nearly deserted by law-makers.
Six hundred and fifty bottles of wine, bought in different parts of Paris, have been analyzed at the municipal laboratory, and the wine was pronounced pure in only 60 cases.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 25.--The Hon. George Raines occupied from 9 o'clock A. M. to 4:20 P. M. summing up for the people in the Higham murder trial to-day. The Hon. A. M. Mills occupied the remainder of the day for the prosecution. The case will go the jury to-morrow.

LONDON, Dec. 26.--A terrible explosion, supposed to have been caused by an infernal machine, occurred at Birkenhead yesterday. Nobody was killed.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Dec. 25.--This morning, about 1 o'clock, Emanuel Bolich, aged 50 years, a wealthy farmer and horse-dealer, residing at New-Media, Columbia County, was found dead at a hotel at the Lehigh Valley Station with his forehead and face frightfully injured. It is the general opinion that he was assaulted by unknown parties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26.--At the Proteus Court of Inquiry to-day Gen. Hazen submitted a series of telegrams sent by him from Washington Territory last September to Capt. Mills, then Acting Chief Signal Officer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26.--The Appropriations Committee did not organize by the appointment of sub-committees to-day, as Mr. Randall wanted some time to think the thing over. The committee will meet again on Thursday of next week, when the organization will be effected.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26.--Edward Hanlan, the champion oarsman, and George W. Lee rowed an exhibition shell-race yesterday over the new course at Oakland, three miles long. Hanlan won easily in 18:43.
There was a brawl in the saloon at No. 518 Broome-street on Saturday, and Theodore Williams, a negro, of No. 16 Grand-street, was arrested and fined $10.
LONDON, Dec. 27.--The steam-ship Spark, (Br.,) Capt. Wilkinson, from Galveston Nov. 27, has arr. at Liverpool.
Mr. Stephen Preston, the Haytian Minister to the United States, has received the following dispatch:

The Standard Fire Insurance Company of London, England, yesterday reinsured all of its outstanding risks in the United States in the Irving Insurance Company, and discontinued business on this side the Atlantic.
A reduction of 10 cents per 100 pounds on cotton freight rates, from all points to NewYork, was ordered yesterday by Commissioner Fink. The reduction goes into effect at once.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 26.--Major A.M. Brown, of counsel for James Nutt, in an interview to-night, stated that Clark Breckenridge was not the only recipient of threatening anonymous letters.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 26.--William Hughes, aged 19, and his sister Grace were at the Schenectady Railroad station this morning saying farewell to friends who had spent Christmas here. Carrie Marcellus, a young woman, made some remark mentioning Miss Hughes's name in an offensive manner.
The German bark Middlesex, which left this port for Bremen on Aug. 25 last, had not reached her destination at last accounts.
Ex-Judge A.B. Tappen advocated the necessity of increased rapid transit facilities for the section of the annexed district north of High Bridge before the Rapid Transit CommisSioners yesterday.

"Steve Reilly," or " Seddons's mouse," the pugilist who was thrashed by a gentleman on East Fourteenth-street on Monday night, and who left the New-York Hospital yesterday, was found suffering from delirium tremens last night at Fifty-first-street and Eighth-avenue. He was taken to the Roosevelt Hospital.
ALBANY, Dec. 26.--The following railroad reports for the year ending Sept. 30, 1883, have been filed with the Railroad Commissioner:
Terence P. Smith died on Christmas Day at the age of 60 years, at No. 172 East Eightiethstreet.

Alice Virtue and a male companion saw a sleigh, without an occupant, standing in front of No. 56 Stone-street, Newark, yesterday. They leaped into it and drove off. John Burkhardt, who owned the team, followed the runaway couple, but they eluded him. Two hours later the sleigh was overturned in the snow and Miss Virtue and her companion were thrown out. An officer arrested her and she was locked up.

The sleighing was good on "the road" yesterday, although somewhat heavy, and there was a lively display of fast trotters and handsome sleighs after 2 o'clock in the afternoon, all the way from the Park to Fordham. It was damp and chilly during most of the day, but when the sun shone out the air was very mild and pleasant.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 26.--Six miles off the mouth of New-Haven harbor this morning, swinging lazily in the almost Summer-like breeze at her moorings, lay the handsome spruce bark Mohawk, of Quebec, three days out from New-York, with a cargo of cased oils for the Calcutta market.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26.--Henry Moneis, a tall, broad-shouldered criminal, whose prison pallor was made more striking by the blackness of the heavy beard that covered the lower part of his face, was led by two tipstaves at Judge Allison's command to-day from the receiving pen to the little inclosure for prisoners on trial at the foot of the jury box.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 26.--While the George H. Adams Humpty Dumpty troupe were playing at the Standard Theatre this afternoon a panic occurred, caused by smoke pouring from the stage and some one raising the cry of fire.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 26.--Archbishop Tache, of St. Bonifice, Manitoba, is here to remonstrate with the Dominion Government for the alleged interference of its agents with mission schools established by the Catholic Church among ...

DENVER, Col., Dec. 26.--A dispatch from Telluride, via Montrose, Dec. 24, says: "At noon to-day a snow-slide came down Marshall Basin, carrying off the shaft-house of the Mendota mine, in which were 14 men, 8 of whom were killed outright and 2 injured.

President GONZALEZ, of the Mexican Republic, was openly assaulted in the streets of the City of Mexico lately, the peculiar missiles thrown at him being nickel coins. These being soon exhausted, other projectiles were resorted to, and the disturbance assumed alarming proportions.
ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Dec. 26.--A formidable riot occurred at Harbor Grace this evening.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 26.--Mrs. Martha Staves, sister of ex-Sheriff Bullis, of Essex County, died suddenly on Sunday morning, without a struggle, i.e. her church pew, in Moriah, while the congregation was singing.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 26.--It is learned here that the balance of the Fortune Bay award remaining in the United States Treasury is to be paid out to the claimants in the proportion of about 7 per cent. of the amount allotted at the first disbursement, that being the balance after paying lawyer's commissions, 5 per cent. interest on previous awards, and other expenses.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 26.--In the suit of Dr. Edward Griffith against Edward T. Johnson, growing out of events connected with the suicide of the wife of the defendant, plaintiff's daughter, the deposition of Mr. Johnson is being taken before a Commissioner.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 26.--The law establishing differential duties in favor of Mexican vessels, as finally passed, grants the following reductions of duties: Two per cent. on all goods brought by Mexican vessels; 8 per cent. on Asiatic goods brought to the Pacific coast by regular lines; 4 per cent. on occasional Asiatic importations.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 26.--The Most Rev. Napoleon Joseph Perche, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New-Orleans, received the last sacraments of the church this morn ing in the presence of his coadjutor, ...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 26.--The firm of Amos D. Smith Co., cotton goods manufacturers, failed to-day with liabilities estimated at $150,000. The firm has been given a low rating at the Bredstreet's agency since 1879, and it is said that they have been working on a large indebtedness and insufficient active capital.
BOSTON, Dec. 26.--A large crowd was in attendance at the Old South Church this afternoon to witness the unveiling of the Harriet Martineau statue.
The contract for carting packages from vessels to the warehouse in the Appraiser's office in New-York has been awarded to the New-York Transfer Company.

The belief that Officer George Smith, of the Sixteenth Precinct, shot Thomas Fitzpatrick in Ninth-avenue, near Little West Twelthstreet, on Tuesday morning, when he was convinced that his life was in danger, was strengthened yesterday.

Messrs. Stevens Murtha, formerly managers of the Windsor Theatre, and now of the New Park, are negotiating for the purchase of a piece of property in the Bowery, immediately adjoining the Windsor Theatre property, for the erection of a new play-house.

An autopsy was held Tuesday evening at the Presbyterian Hospital upon the body of L. Richard Von Sternberger, the young German who committed suicide at Adolph Hesse's drug store, in Second-avenue, on Monday night.
Friederick Christian Barre was until Dec. 10 a clerk in the Post Office at Ihrhove, near Emden, Germany.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 26.--Gen. Sherman's wife and elder daughter, Miss Rachel, had, this afternoon, a hairbreadth escape from death.

LONDON, Dec. 11.--At last Mr. Gladstone has found a Speaker to succeed Sir Henry Brand, who, it is now understood, in spite of recent rumors to the contrary, had definitely decided not to retain his seat in the chair in the next session of Parliament.
A tale of ill-treatment is told by Mrs. Mary E. Schneider in the papers on which she has begun a suit for a separate maintenance from James Henry Schneider.

Chief Francis J. Reilly, of the Ninth Battalion of the Fire Department, has made a report to the Board of Commissioners "in answer," he says, "to a statement which appeared in one of the daily papers on the 22d inst., relative to the fire which occurred in the City Insane Asylum on Ward's Island on the 21st inst."
A very large congregation was present at the solemn high mass in St. Stephen's Church, in East Twenty-eighth-street, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning.
BOSTON, Dec. 26.--The first performance of Mr. Abbey's Italian opera company to-night was a great success.
RAHWAY, N.J., Dec. 26.--The head brakeman on the 7 o'clock train over the Pennsylvania Railroad had a very narrow escape this morning at Rahway Junction.

A fire, which caused much delay and annoyance to business people and stopped car travel for several hours, occurred yesterday afternoon about 2 o'clock on Fulton-street, Brooklyn. Mr. L.V.D. Hardenbergh, of the carpet firm of Hardenbergh Co., No. 147 Fulton-street, went to his bank about 1:30 o'clock, and when he returned, less than half an hour later, his store was in flames.
BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 26.--Gov. Butler has declined to pardon George H. Hathaway, the Fall River embezzler, now serving a sentence in the State prison.

A number of weary Brooklynites were sitting in the rear car of a "shuttle" train at Chatham-square on Christmas night anxiously waiting until the philosophic conductor should make up his mind to start the train for the City Hall station.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 26.--Early this morning, while a freight train on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad was backing into a siding at Louisa Court-house, a local passenger train ran into it, striking between the tender and engine and killing the fireman of the freight train, who attempted to jump off. There was no other casualty. The engine of the freight train was badly in jured and the passenger train was delayed three hours.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., Dec. 26.--One of the freight trains on the Lehigh Valley Road was wrecked in the yards of the company at Perth Amboy yesterday morning.

The Senior Class of the College of the City of New-York, having become eligible for coat-tails, tore themselves away from their fond mammas and their faithful nurses last evening and went on a sleigh-ride "up the road" all by themselves.
