MACON, Ga., Dec. 26.--There is a good deal of bad blood among Georgia editors on local topics, and several attempts have been made to make the code play a part. The liveliest display has been between the editors of the Waynesboro True Citizen and Sylvanice Telephone.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 26.--The disabled National Line steamer France has been docked at her agents' wharf, where she will be repaired.

YAZOO CITY, Miss., Dec. 26.--One of the most cold-blooded, premeditated assassinations that ever occurred in any community was committed in this town on Monday night at about 10 o'clock, when three men in the prime and vigor of youth were shot down like dogs, and two others, also in the prime of life, were seriously, ...

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment made some further progress in the preparation of the budget yesterday. It received and filed a communication from the Police Department asking for an appropriation for needed extensions and perfections of its telegraph and telephone system.

Several property-owners of New-Jersey, who reside near Orange, who were interested in the Phoebe Paullin murder case, clubbed together in an effort to find out her murderer. They communicated with Detective Pryor, of the FifthAvenue Hotel, who recommended to them his friend, Detective John McPhilips.
MADISON, Ind., Dec. 26.--About midnight of Sunday Hardy Creek suddenly leaped over its banks, and an entire family named Boss, comprising the two parents and five children, were crowned.
PALMETTO, Ga., Dec. 26.--In Fayette County Andrew Lively was sitting by his fireside, when some one crept up to the window and, ...
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 26.--A State Convention of colored men assembled here to-day, in pursuance of a call issued some time since by a number of leading colored men of the State.
Judge Moore, in the Kings County Court of Sessions, yesterday, sentenced the following prisoners to the penitentiary: Jacob Carman, ...
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 26.--Treasurer Rogers, of Lewis County, who has been missing for some time, returned to Lowville last night. He has been rusticating in Canada, his friends say.
TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 26.--Dr. Beatty, Coroner of Lambton, white holding an inquest on the body of Mrs. Gibbs, who was murdered on Saturday, died suddenly to-day.
In Judge Knapp's court, Jersey City, yesterday, a verdict for $5,000 was rendered against the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad and in favor of William Haring, who sued through a guardian.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26.--The Speaker continues to answer questions about the composition of the standing committees of the House, and appears to be extremely anxious to relieve those persons who have obtained the impression that the control of the House has been turned over to the South, with danger to the interests of the country.
There was but one witness examined in the Feuardent-Di Cesnola libel suit yesterday, Mr. Benjamin Braman, a microscopist and expert in regard to the surfaces of Cypriote stone.
The Grand Army of the People, an organization said to be composed of members of all political parties which was founded on the Fourth of July last, has issued its constitution and principles.

BEARDSTOWN, Ill., Dec. 26.--A wealthy farmer named Walton and a steam-boat man named Henry Scebler, whose wife had been carried off by the former, met near the Post Office to-day, when Walton drew his weapon first and shot Scebler through the heart just as he was raising his revolver. Each man had sent word to the other that he would kill him on sight.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Dec. 26.--Niagara River is apparently to be spanned by another railroad bridge at no very distant date. It is stated that Congressman R.S. Stevens, of Attica, who is a railroad builder of extended experience, and Paesident of the projected railroad from Attica, ...
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 26.--In the Higham murder trial this morning the Hon. A.M. Mills concluded the summing up for the people, and at 11 o'clock Judge Merwin began his charge to the jury.

A colored man, who is supposed to be Joseph Valentine, 30 years old, employed as a servant by Princeton College students, died in convulsions last night at the lodging-house of Mrs. Frank, No. 519 Broome-street. In the afternoon he said he was going to take medicine, and what appeared to be quinine pills were found in his pocket.
WARSAW DEPOT, N.Y., Dec. 26.--Among many notable weddings which have occurred in Warsaw this Winter was the marriage this evening of Charles L. Shattuck, of the Drovers' National Bank, Chicago, ...

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 26.--Assemblyman George Z. Erwin, of St. Lawrence County, was the first candidate for Speaker on the ground. He arrived here this afternoon, accompanied by his colleague, Gen. N.M. Curtis, and Senator D. S. Lynde, and at once opened his rooms to the public.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 26.--John Conway and Michael Kehoe, the salvage corps men who met their death at the fire on Christmas day, were buried to-day in Calvary Cemetery. At the inquest on Conway's body Assistant Chief Hester testified:

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 26.--A fight took place early yesterday morning in Plains Township, this county, between Dick Pedlar and Di Bright, two Englishmen, residents of the county, who had an old grudge to settle.

At the meeting of the Directors of three of the railroads of the Vanderbilt system, held at the Grand Central Station in this City, yesterday, dividends were declared as follows: Lake Shore and Michigan Southern, 2 per cent., (quarterly;) Canada Southern, 2 per cent. (semi-annual,) and Michigan Central, 3 per cent., (semi-annual.)
CINCINNATI, Dec. 26.--The danger of losses from the flood in the Ohio has been increased to-day by rising temperature and indications of rain.

The public rehearsal of the Oratorio Society of New-York prefatory to the concert, which occurs this evening, took place at the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon. Haendel's "Messiah" was given under the direction of Dr. Damrosch, and in presence of an audience that filled the house in every part.

The Rev. John O. Bache was seen at his house last night and shown an extract from the Paris News, in which Mr. Stephen H. Tyng said that "although in constant communication with Mr. Bache, the first information that he was ...

LONDON, Dec. 26.--The hull of the steamship Saint Augustin, which was swept by fire on Sunday, Dec. 16, in the Bay of Biscay, while the vessel was on the way from Manila to Liverpool, has been towed into the harbor of Corunna, Spain.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 26.--An unusually severe snow-storm has prevailed over the North-west to-day. It is feared that railway travel will be seriously interfered with, as trains on all the roads are behind time.
Donald Cameron Co, wholesale dealers in provisions and exporters, at No. 116 Broadstreet, have suspended because of their inability to sell their bills of exchange.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Dec. 26.--Yesterday H. H. Tompkins came from Pavilion, in this county, to Batavia to celebrate Christmas. He is Tax Collector for the town of Pavilion, and had in his possession about $515 in cash and two checks amounting to $76 belonging to the town. Tompkins got gloriously drunk and lost all the money. To-day he offers a liberal reward for its return.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 26.--This morning the annual session of the Iowa State Teachers' Association was held at Lewis's Opera-house. The meeting was called to order by the President, L.L. Klinefelter.
Mr. John Austin Stevens, the Secretary of the Committee on the Evacuation Day celebration, returns from Newport, where he passed Christmas with his family, this morning to close ...

The preliminary pool tournament opened last evening at Madison-Square Hall, No. 948 Broadway, with two contests--the first between John L. Leonard, of Philadelphia, and Louis Zimmerman, of New-York, and the second between N. Van Buskirk, of New-Jersey, and Henry Johnson, of Staten Island.
Patrolman Hamilton, of the Thirtieth Precinct, was arraigned yesterday before Commissioners French and Matthews on complaint of Mrs. Gideon Moore, who charged him with cruelty to animals.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 26.--The Committee on the Adirondack Forest Preservation will report against the purchase of the woodland in bulk. The committee consists of Senators Koch, Lynde, and F. Lansing, of Jefferson.

The burglar who was shot in Mark Schriefer's grocery store, at No. 331 De Kalbavenue, Brooklyn, about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, by District Telegraph Officer Wasserman, proves not to have been as dangerously wounded as at first supposed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25.--The organization of the House of Representatives is complete. After the holiday recess business on the inside as well as on the outside of the legislative chambers will begin in earnest. It promises to be brisk.
District Attorney Olney was occupied yesterday in preparing for the proposed changes in his staff of assistants, the nature of which will be made public to-day.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 26.--In an opinion rendered to-day the Attorney-General holds that the sale of intoxicating liquors is prohibited by law within two miles of any incorporated city, town, or village.

Between 2 and 3 o'clock on Monday a tug-boat, with four barges in tow, from Providence, R.I., ran one of the barges on the rocks at Stretford Shoals Light-house. Finding that the boat was hard on, the Captain of the tug ordered the hawser by which the barge with one other was being towed to be cut, and the tug went on its way.

Ex-Judge Fullerton appeared before Judge Cowing, in the General Sessions Court, yesterday, and renewed his motion to dismiss the remaining nine indictments against Charles R, Beckwith, accused of embezzlement by Mr. Babbitt.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 26.--It was given out a few days ago that on Wednesday evening, Dec. 26, at the residence of the bride, on Garnerstreet, Cohoes, would occur the marriage of Frank Cole to Miss N.F. Neary.

Detective Sergeant McGuire, having in custody James J. Wilkins, the forger, arrived from Havana on the steam-ship British Empire last night. Wilkins was arrested in Havana on Nov. 30, on the complaint of George J. Baker, President of the Electropathic Association, at No. 22 East Fourteenth-street, who accused him of having, by forgery and false representations, robbed him of about $2,600.

Sister M. Valeria, of St. Joseph's Academy, in this City, died on Christmas morning, in the sixty-fifth year of her age, and will be buried from St. Joseph's Catholic Church at 10 o'clock this morning.

About 150 feet of the ornamental railing upon the shed at the Sands-street entrance to the Brooklyn bridge gave way yesterday under the weight of snow which had been swept against it by the wind and fell into the street. Fortunately no one was hurt. The damage is estimated at $200.

Police Justice Hugh Gardener, who was stricken with a dangerous illness on the 26th of November, went to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to hold an examination in an assault case which had been adjourned.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 26.--To-night as Collector Jonnard, of the First National Bank, was on the street on his way to the Post Office with a quantity of mail in a sachel he was attacked by several negroes, one of whom struck him in the head with a stone, while ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26.--The following clerks of committees in the House have been appointed: W.D. Boyle, District of Columbia, Foreign Affairs; J.H. Coorey, California, Military ...

Monsieur R. Seriac, who since his defeat of Col. T.H. Monstery at Tammany Hall April 10, 1876, has borne the title of "Champion of the two Americas," is anxious for further honors in the line of sport known as assault at arms.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 26.--The biennial session of the Socialist Labor Congress met in this city to-day, and was called to order by Hugo Vogt, Secretary of the National Executive Committee.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 26.--Alexander Webb, one of the proprietors of the coal mine at Coaling, Ala., was shot and killed to-day by a man named Morrison, who fled to escape arrest. Webb's father offered a reward of $500 for Morrison's apprehension. Several years ago Alexander Webb killed a man named Raney in Birmingham in a dispute about a bar bill which the latter owed him.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 26.--A dispatch from Beverly, Randolph County, gives the following details of a terrible tragedy recently committed in that neighborhood: Elizabeth Somerfield, with two little children, has for some time been living quietly in a cabin on the land of Capt. Parsons, on the eastern slope of Rich ...

A new scientific society--the Society of Naturalists of the Eastern United States--is to hold its meeting at Columbia College School of Mines to-day and to-morrow at 10 A.M. This is the first meeting.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Dec. 26.--Thomas Delbridge, dealer in boots and shoes, made a general assignment of his property to-day to Wilder Smith. The claims of preferred creditors, among whom are numbered his wife, two sons, and the five village banks, amount to $8,366.83. Four notes, aggregating $1,025, were indorsed by ...
PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 26.--Proceedings were instituted to-day by the Commonwealth's Attorney against the Dismal Swamp Canal Lottery Company by the nominal arrest of the company's agent in this city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26.--Gen. Mackenzie, commander of the Department of Texas, is afflicted with mental trouble, occasion by nervous prostration.

GALVESTON, Texas, Dec. 26.--An authentic report from McDade, Texas, the scene of the lynching and sanguinary street fight, says there was no trouble there last night or this morning, and it is thought that there is no immediate danger of more bloodshed, although considerable excitement exists.

A bridge connecting two roofs enabled a dozen Polish Jews of both sexes and all ages to escape from the burning rear tenement-house at No. 28 Suffolk-street, last night. But for the bridge it would not have been possible for all to reach a place of safety. The house is owned by W.H. Mills. It is four stories high, and there are ...

HEBRON, Conn., Dec. 26.--The war in the Congregational Church of Hebron is at an end. At least a truce has been declared. Last Saturday morning a church meeting was held. The express object of this meeting was to decide on the guilt or innocence of the Pastor, the Rev. George B. Cutler, on certain charges which had ...
RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 26.--The funeral of Col. Benjamin L. Trafford took place from the Shrewsbury Presbyterian church this afternoon. Veterans of the Seventy-first Regiment, of which ...
The experiments made with A.H. Mathesius's new grip Monday were considered satisfactory by the gentlemen who rode back and forth on the car. Mr. Mathesius claims that he ...

The Directors and stockholders of the New-York Milk Exchange, limited, held a meeting yesterday afternoon at No. 1 Desbrossesstreet, Pierson E. Sanford in the chair. The price paid for milk during the present month was 4 cents per quart, and a member moved that the price for January be fixed at 3 cents.

Congressman Potter was present at the meeting of the Aqueduct Commission yesterday, and when the Mayor invited discussion for and against the construction of Quaker Dam and as to the proper terminus of the aqueduct in case the dam was built he introduced Mr. Weir, a builder and contractor, who had made estimates as to the cost of the proposed wooden flume.

A wedding took place last evening at the Fifth-Avenue Presbyterian Church, for which 2,000 invitations were issued. The occasion was the marriage of Prof. John R. Paddock, of New-Haven, to Miss Sarah T. Sands, daughter of the late Dr. David Sands, of this City.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 26.--John Furlong, one of the oldest and most prominent residents of Milwaukee, died very suddenly at noon to-day.

The Democratic Party would do well to remember the danger to one who "doth protest too much." It would make a better impression as to its capacity to treat with prudence and decency the interests of the nation if its leaders did not spend so much time in assuring the public that their intentions are harmless.
The following letter, written by George Washington after he gave up the command of the Revolutionary Army and returned to Mount Vernon, has never been published, it is said:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 26.--This morning the steamer B.D. Wood, owned by John A. Wood Son, of this city, while waiting to pass through Lock No. 1 on the Monongahela River, was caught in a strong under current. The tow swept over the dam and the barges sank, but the steamer was saved. The loss is $5,500.

Having shelved Alderman COCHRANE'S sensible proposition to compel owners of vacant lots to clear the sidewalks in front of them of snow, the Aldermen yesterday were at liberty to tackle the "monopolists" who use snow plows, these monopolists being the horse car companies.
MERIDEN, Conn., Dec. 26.--W.J. Hutchins, a prominent meat-dealer, disappeared last week leaving debts outstanding to the amount of about $5,000.

All the indications point to a settlement between the lines represented in the joint Executive Committee and the belligerent Western lines with whom they have been at war regarding the payment of commissions and selling tickets through scalpers and brokers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27.--Soon after the holidays are over Mr. Morrison will be ready to introduce his tariff bill, which will not, he says, be a reproduction of his bill of 1876. The conditions are changed, he says, and call for a different measure of reduction.

HILLSBORO, Ill., Dec. 27.--In the Emma Bond case to-day, counsel for the defense announced that he would have Miss Bond put on the stand again, John C. Montgomery testified that he left his house with his family between 10 and 11 o'clock on the day of the outrage and visited Mrs. Pettus, where they took dinner.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 27.--Private dispatches received from Hanover, Germany, state that Col. Henry R. Rathobone killed his wife at that place on Monday, and then attempted to take his own life. At the last accounts it was thought that he could not live.

SCHNECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 27.--Miss Barbara Piessner, daughter of the late Col. Piessner, and granddaughter of the late Prof. Taylor Lewis, of Union College, was married to-day to Prof. Ira Nelson Hollis, of the United States Navy, in the First Reformed Church. President Potter and the Faculty of Union College and prominent society people of Schenectady, Albany, and Washington were resent.

The other day a Vernon farmer, while feeding his cattle, left one of a pair of mittens near a heifer for n few minutes. When he returned it had been partly consumed by the animal. The farmer undertook to get possession of the rapidly disappearing mitten, when the animal snatched the other from his hand and swallowed both.
The question of heating the cars on the bridge will probably be settled temporarily by Tuesday. Engineer Martin said yesterday that the problem had presented a number of serious difficulties.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 27.--The Trenton Times publishes a dispatch stating that Charles W. Hetzel, a well-known organ manufacturer, of Baptisttown, has disappeared, leaving a large number of creditor.
On Christmas Day John Bobel, living at No. 83 Charlton-street, and Joseph Tate, of No. 372 Hudson-street, became engaged in a quarrel in front of the latter's residence.
Coroner Minn, of Newark, yesterday began his inquest in the case of Gustav Schneider, the young man who was shot and instantly killed by his 16-year-old brother at their boarding-house...
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 27.--The first train crossed the Atchafalaya bridge on the Texas Pacific Railroad yesterday. The structure is now completed and trains are passing over it regularly.

MATAWAN, N.J., Dec. 27.--The Midway Shooting Association held a special prize shoot this afternoon. A large number of the sporting fraternity were present, and prizes to the amount of $130 were distributed. The highest prizes were won by Farrington, Applegate, and Campbell. There was excellent shooting; in several instances seven birds were killed in succession. After the prizes were distributed a collation was served. The club is in good financial condition.
Some stir was caused in the New-York Mining Stock and National Petroleum Exchange yesterday by the fact, and accompanying rumors, of the sale of 3,000 shares of Sonora Consolidated...

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 27.--Intelligence has been received here of the murder of Tuck Barnes in Northampton County, who was shot and killed by his brother, Jack Barnes, on Christmas Day. The murderer was arrested and taken before a magistrate, who committed him to jail. He is believed to be insane.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 27.--Capt. James Hunter, John Stewart, and John E. Mayhem, members of the Salvation Army, were arrested this afternoon on a warrant issued by Posecuting...

All the indications point to a successful hospital collection the present year. Reports from the various trade auxiliaries make it almost certain that the aggregate from these sources will be in excess of past years, and, so far as the church offerings on Sunday next are concerned, there is every reason to expect ...
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 27.--A tremendous thunder-Storm passed over this city at 5:30 this afternoon. The lightning was frequent and sharp and the thunder very heavy.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 27.--The State Bar Association to-day suggested a plan to the Legislature for the organization of Circuit Courts provided for by the constitutional amendment recently adopted. Seven districts and 21 Judges are to be created in the State, the latter at a yearly salary of $4,000, for a term of six years.
The Expiatory Chapel, erected on the spot where the remains of Louis XVI., Marie Antoinette, and Mme. Elizabeth, with their 250...
There was a full attendance of Police Justices last evening at their monthly meeting in the Jefferson Market Police Court Building. Justice Kilbreth presided.

While Henry Bosse, a German, who keeps a grocery store at No. 318 Broome-street, was alone in his place of business on Saturday night, a burly nearo named Theodore Williams entered and immediately commenced an assault upon him.

HAVANA, Dec. 27.--The sanitary condition of Havana is improving. Only 10 persons died from yellow fever in the city during the week ended last night. The fatal cases were scattered among the population, and not as they usually are, confined to the shipping and the military hospitals. The hot weather continues. There hare been only two comfortably cool days in the last two weeks.

The burglars who three weeks ago threw Neuilly into consternation seem, from the confessions and bearing of Marquelet, their leader, to have been as cold-blooded and cynical ruffians as any Parisian realist could desire to study.
A Congregational council was held yesterday in the East Congregational Church, on Tompkins-avenue, Brooklyn, for the purpose of formally dismissing the Pastor, the Rev. William...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 27.--The Government will introduce a bill the coming session for the purpose of excluding all United States mutual benefit insurance associations from doing business in Canada. Canadian associations doing similar business will be placed under the control by the Government Superintendent of Insurance.
The Committee on Design of the Saratoga Monument Association met in Naval Officer Graham's office yesterday afternoon.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 27.--The negotiations looking to the lease of the Pittsburg and Western Railroad to the Jewett interest are stated positively by a stockholder of the former to have fallen through. He also states that if the Pittsburg and Western Road is leased at all the Baltimore and Ohio Company will be the lessee.

Lieut.--Gen. Sheridan has received a telegram from Major-Gen. Pope at Fort Leavenworth saying that it is thought the white boy, Charlie McComas, is with a band of Chiricahua Indians, who are daily expected to reach San Carlos agency.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 27.--To-morrow morning the residents of this city will be surprised by the announcement that one of the best known men in Rhode Island, a member of one of the proudest families in the State, and a man until very recently holding a very responsible place of trust, is a fugitive from justice as a defaulter.

A red flag waved listlessly in the mist over the iron gate which guards the entrance to the State Arsenal at Seventh-avenue and Thirtyfifth-street yesterday morning. The stone floor of the basement of the building was in an unusual state of disorder.
FONDA, N.Y., Dec. 27.--Mrs. Ellen Prufurst, who has been keeping a disorderly house in Amsterdam, refused three men admittance to her house last night.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 27.--The bark Lalla, of Amherst, Nova Scotia, which left Philadelphia June 6, with a cargo of petroleum for Hiogo, Japan, has not yet been reported as arrived at her destination, and is now 214 days out.

At the meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday Robert H. Shannan advocated the claims of the elevated road to be built on the line from Fordham to the Harlem River now used by the surface cars.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 27.--The lottery bank injunction suit was continued to-day, C.W. Moulton appearing for the lottery company and bank and Prof. W.A. Maury, of Columbia College, for the Government. The case went over to 10 o'clock to-morrow morning, when the Hon. Thomas J. Semmes will appear for the lottery company and Attorney-General Brewster will close the case for the Postmaster.

The statement is mockingly made by the Tribune that THE TIMES'S story of the extravagant disbursement of the Croton water fund was a rehearsal of what appeared in the columns of the Tribune eleven months ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27.--A general court-martial has been appointed to meet at West Point, on Wednesday, Jan. 2, for the trial of such prisoners as may be brought before it. The detail for the court is as follows: First Lieuts. Edward E. Wood, Eighth Cavalry; Henry A. Reed, Second Artillery; George B. Davis, ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27.--Judge Buckner, the Chairman of the Committee on Banking and Currency of the House, said to-day that he did not know just how all the members of his committee stood on the national bank and other questions which might come before them, so that he did not like to predict any action they might take.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27.--Capt. Richard Pike, master of the lost steamer Proteus, was examined by the Court of Inquiry to-day. In response to questions by the Recorder, he said there was no disagreement between himgelf and Lieut. Garlington.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 27.--At a meeting today of persons interested in compromising with the creditors of the Round Lake Camp-meeting Association, thus preventing foreclosure, it was...

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment a report was received from Clarence A. Seward, Referee in the case of the Lyddy Brothers, who presented a bill against the City for $15,000 for services rendered in determining the length of the term of office of ex-Surrogate Calvin.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 27.--The Chancellor to-day granted an interlocutory injunction restraining the New-Jersey Zinc and Iron Company from further working the valuable mining properts in Sussex County, the ownership of which is claimed by Charles W. Trotler and others. The case has occupied the courts for several years. The property involved is valued at several million dollars.
Prof. Felix Adler read an essay at the annual meeting of the New-Jersey State Teachers' Association in Newark, yesterday, on "Technical and Art Education as a Means to Mind Culture."...

BRINKLEY, Ark., Dec. 27.--The body of Pexn Girt, a negro preacher, was found, yesterday, six miles from town, beside a hog which he had killed. It is believed that he was shot immediately after killing the hog.

Commissioner THOMPSON, of the Department of Public Works, has prepared a long statement defending himself against charges which have been made against him, chiefly with reference to contracts for regulating and grading streets, constructing sewers, and laying pavements.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 27.--The Democratic State Committee, at their meeting here to-day, resolved to ask the members of that party in the legislature, with other Democrats who may be here then, to meet in caucus Jan. 12 to define a policy regarding sumptuary legislation and to outline a programme for next year's campaign.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Dec. 27.--The Washington Cattle-breeders' and Farmers' Institute is now in session here. The attendance is quite large.

FALL RIVER, Dec. 27.--An insurance agent and a medical examiner from Boston were in town to-day investigating doubtful cases insured in the Massachusetts Benefit Association. In the cases where the medical examination indicated fraud the policies will be canceled.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27.--At the regular monthly meeting of the Naval Institute at the Navy Department this evening Dr. Emil Bessels read a paper on Smith Sound and its explorations, with especial reference to the projected Greely relief expedition.

At a meeting of the Seventeenth District Republican Association at Turn Hall, No. 371 West Forty-seventh-street, last night, ex-Alderman John McClave presided and Police Commissioner Mason spoke on the necessity of peace and harmony, and declared that all the differences in the district had been satisfactorily adjusted and that all would hereafter act in accord for Republican success.
BOSTON, Dec. 27.--The creditors of F. Shaw Brothers at a meeting to-day by a large vote adopted the propositions recently made for a settlement by compromise.

The following letter has been received by the State Department from the American Minister at London relative to the United States Commissioner and Assistant Commissioners representing the fishing interests of this country at the International Fisheries Exhibition:
BOSTON, Dec. 27.--The Metropolis and City of London Insurance Companies have paid $2,000 to the State for alleged violations of the law relating to reinsurance and for alleged false returns.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27.--The American Society of Professors of Dancing held its annual meeting here to-day. Members were present from New-York, Brooklyn, Poughkeepsie, N.Y.;
The performance of "The Mesiah" by the Oratorio Society of New-York, at the Academy of Music, last evening, fulfilled in every respect, the promise of Wednesday's public rehearsal.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 27.--A large number of Hungarians, becoming disgusted with the idea of working half-time in the mines, left today for their native land. They took with them considerable money and were somewhat joyous over the prospect of once more seeing the land of their birth. The English, Irish, and Welsh miners rejoice over the departure of what they call "cheap foreign labor."

LONDON, Dec. 15.--Christmas Day will have arrived by the time this letter reaches you, and I would respectfully venture to wish your readers the "compliments of the season." To address such a greeting to...
William C. Kingsley, President of the Board of Bridge Trustees, made his first report since the structure was opened, yesterday, to Mayor Low. Mr. Kingsley says:

READING, Penn., Dec. 27.--A bridal trip of two fashionably dressed persons of Philadelphia was suddenly interrupted in this city late last night, and their bridal chamber was the Chief of Police's private once in the City Hall. Police Sergeant Kaucher was advised by a telegram from Philadelphia, signed "Robert Lawrence,"
SALAMANCA, N.Y., Dec. 27.--The Freethinkers' Convention was opened here this evening by an address by ex-Rev. J.H. Burnham on "The Philosophy of the Religious Emotions."

ALBANY, Dec. 27.--Less than 25 members of the Assembly are collected in the city. The arrival of Mr. Littlejohn this afternoon has brought together all four candidates for the Speakership under the Delavan roof. Senators Daggett, Veeder, Lansing, and Murphy are also in this city.
Commissioner Hubert O. Thompson sent to Mayor Edson, under date of Dec. 24, a long and elaborate answer to certain published charges against the management of the Department of Public Works.
BOSTON, Dec. 27.--The Board of Aldermen to-day completed the recount of votes for Mayor, Street Commissioner, and Aldermen; also the votes for Common Councilmen in 15 wards.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27.--In the very numerously signed petitions which the whisky distillers have prepared for presentation to Congress asking for the extension of the bonded period of distilled spirits the dealers point out the great impetus given to the production of distilled spirits at the time of the resumption of specie payments and the coincident ...

ALMA, Col., Dec. 27.--A snow-slide occurred near Montezuma on Monday, carrying John Headstrom, John Ablstrom, and John Ling, three miners, half a mile down the mountain. Ahlstrom and Ling were found yesterday badly frozen, and will probably die. Head from, who is still missing, must have been killed.

The games played yesterday in MadisonSquare Hall, No. 748 Broadway, in the preliminary tournament to obtain three contestants for the championship pool tournament were dull and uneventful. The first series in the afternoon was between Manning, of New-York...

The cross-examination of Mr. Benjamin Braman, the microscopist, which was to have occupied the attention of the court in the Feuardent-Di Cesnola libel suit yesterday, was virtually postponed until to-day, when it will be begun at 10 in the morning.

WAVERLY, N.Y., Dec. 27.--Those who have the confidence of Gen. R.A. Elmer, Second Assistant Postmaster-General, and a resident of this village, say it is authoritatively announced from his department that the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad will early in January carry through and way-mails between NewYork City and all points west on the road. It is not stated whether the service will be proportionately discontinued on the Erie Road.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 27.--County Auditor Brewster says he has discovered a frandulent increase of $1,000,000 in the valuations of property for taxes on the books, made for the purpose of getting the fee for procuring the refunding of excessive taxes. He says this has been done since 1880.

The streets of New-York yesterday were the embodiment of all that is disagreeable and discomforting. Pedestrians sought protection in rubber from the mud and slush under foot, but they tried in vain to escape from the deluge overhead.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 27.--Gordon W. Burnham, of New-York, who is largely interested in Waterbury manufactures, has given $10,000 to the Trinity Socicty for a desk and an organ for the new church, which has just been completed, on condition that the society raises another $10,000.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 27.--The mustery attending the murder of William Watkins, near Rolesville, in this county, on Sunday night, Dec. 16, is cleared up. Joe Williams, a young white man, is the murderer.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27.--One of the most remarkable conferences ever known in the municipal history of Chicago was held to-day at the City Hall. Mayor Harrison was formally waited upon by a delegation claiming to be reputable business men, who requested him to give orders to the police to cease raiding the gamblers on the west side.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 27.--The failure of Amos D. Smith Co. will prove disastrous to some one. The assets are not in excess of $600,000, leaving an unsecured indebtedness of between $900,000 and $1,000,000.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 27.--Three thousand employes of the National Tube Works Company, of McKeesport, decided to accept a reduction of from 12 to 25 per cent. in their wages after Jan. 1. The mills will now probably continue operations all Winter.

ERIE, Penn., Dec. 27.--This afternoon James Brandt and George Walker engaged in a stock duel, each believing that his pistol was unloaded. Brundt's weapon exploded, and the ball lodged in Walker's bead, fatally wounding him. The lads are each 16 years old.

PARIS, Dec. 27.--It is reported that the Government has sent a dispatch to Admiral Courbet urging him to follow up his victory at Sontay with the utmost promptness and energy compatible with prudence.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27.--Frederic C. Burchard testified yesterday in the Hill-Sharon divorce case that he was, on April 18, 1881, engaged to be married to Miss Hill. On complaint of that lady he was arrested this afternoon for perjury. He was released on giving bonds.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 27.--The Salvation army is making a vigorous crusade in this city. In two weeks 37 persons have professed conversion at the army's meeting.

Three perfected dudes, accompanied by three accomplished belles, occupied six chairs in the orchestra of Daly's Theatre a few nights ago. Their conversation previous to the rising of the curtain was such as to convince a hearer that they were of the most cultured society.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 27.--The body of William H. Kirk, a dealer in sand, but lately a dealer in horses, was found among the willows alongside of a little stream, near Cumminsville, in the suburbs of this city, to-day.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 27.--Congressmen Paige and Foran arrived here to-night and were met by other prominent workers of teh anti-Pendleton party from different ports of the State.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 27.--At 6 o'clock this evening Abram Gerlinsky was found dead in the Court-house cells. His death was caused by hanging. He had been arrested at the suit of Bessie Beinnan, who charged him with breach of promise. The suit had been withdrawn, and when the Sheriff went to inform Gerlinsky he found that he was dead.
LONDON, Dec. 27.--A Suakim dispatch of the 18th inst. states that the rebels are menacing Riwajeh, and an Egyptain gun-boat will embark the garrison and inhabitants of that place.

Victor Hugo is in excellent health, but suffers from ennui. His deafness, which he does not like to show or to confess, isolates him. The receptions now hardly last 20 minutes, and are still held after dinner. Strangers are not welcome visitors, though courteously received.

There is a new weather prophet who is twice as scientific and three times as bold as Mr. VENNOR. He resides in Rock Island, where he publishes a monthly newspaper, as an organ of himself and his weather.

Dolphins of that size have never been found in Long Island Sound.

Matthew Arnold will lecture upon "Emerson" at Association Hall on Friday evening, Jan. 4, after which he will start on his Western tour.

A heavy fog settled down on the Bay and rivers yesterday morning and continued until late in the evening. At times it was so dense that it was impossible to see more than a dozen yards beyond the pier-heads on either river.

The reports that come in from all parts of the Territory are unanimous in the assertion that the cattle are in first-class condition to start the Winter, come what may. This is a good outlook for the business, seeing that the cattle got through so well last Winter under the worst possible circumstances.

LIVERPOOL, Dec. 27.--Some anxiety is felt here in regard to the White Star Line steamer Celtic, which is overdue. Her owners have sent a powerful tug to Queenstown, where she is to await further orders. The Celtic sailed from New-York Dec. 15 for Queenstown and Liverpool.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 28.--Corporation Counsel Nettleton has rendered an opinion as to the legality of the extensive junketing practiced by memebrs of the city government. He says it is not lawful for committees of the City Council to contract bills on days when said committees are not in session, or for individual members to contract bills for refreshments, wines, liquors, or cigars in the name of the city.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 28.--A large number of prominent citizens, merchants, manfacturers, and one clergymen were arrested today for violating the city ordinance in not cleaning the snow from the sidewalks. All were fined $1, and the fines were remitted. There is much indignation over the summary arrests. It is reported that another batch of arrests will be made to-morrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 28.--C.S. Benham, who was reported as having absconded from New-York owing $200,000 to members of the Mining Stock Exchange is in this city. He denies having left New-York in a surreptitious manner. He is now here on business with his late partners, Warren Co., brokers. He will go from here to New-Mexico, and thence to New-York, when, he says, all his contracts, will be promptly filled.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28.--Mrs. Vincedora Woodlin, a young mulatto woman, was arrested to-day, on suspicion of having poisoned her husband, Jacob Woodlin, also colored. The couple disagreed some time ago and were living apart, but on Monday last, it is alleged, Mrs. Woodlin took a pie to her husband's residence and gave it to him. After eating the pie it is said that the husband became very sick and died last night.

PARIS, Dec. 28.--A decree prohibiting the importation into France, except at three specified ports, of American salted meats will be published to-morrow. Marseilles is to be substituted for Nantes as one of the three ports at which imports may be made for the present, subject to inspection. Havre and Bordeaux are the other two. WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 29.--Yesterday afternoon the dead body of a man was found lying in the snow near the Pennsylvania Railroad track, below Retreat station. The tracks of a bear were plainly distinguished, and the man's clothing and person gave evidence of a terrible struggle. The body was identified this evening by a Coroney's jury as that of John Robinson, a stone-cutter, of Cleveland, Ohio.

BOMBAY, Dec. 29.--A revolt of the Thakoors under their chief, Bhadur Singh, against the Maharajah of Bickaneer, took place about Dec. 10, the rebels occupying the walled town of Bidassur with 2,500 men.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 29.--Lucy Burrell, whose death was announced last night, had reached the ripe old age of 100 years. The old colored woman had lived in this city for many years, and her children have documents attesting her age.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29.--The meeting of the Western railroad managers to consider the discriminations adopted by the Eastern trunk lines was held at the appointed tune, but no business was done beyond listening to the ultimatum formally submitted by Commissioner Pierson.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 29.--Reis Brothers Co., wholesale dealers in foreign fruits, fancy groceries, and canned goods, have made an assignment to Edgar M. Johnson and Mr. Cohen. Bradstreet's reports that the liabilities will exceed $100,000, of which $74,000 are secured.
QUEBEC, Dec. 29.--The child of Mr. Moileau, three months old, residing at La Langue, was to-day frozen to death in bed alongside of her mother. The father has gone in the meantime for firewood.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 29.--The investigation before the magistrate yesterday resulted in the discharge of Baxter Gunter, who was accused of murdering his mother, sister, and child in Chatham County on Saturday, Dec. 22. Gunter's little daughter, who was so badly wounded, is improving. The only hope of discovering the murderer seems now to depend upon what she may be able to tell when she recovers speech.

Tape's father is also implicated. The accused will be tried at the next term of the County Court. No doubts are entertained of his conviction.

The Rev. James S. Bush has resigned as Pastor of the Church of the Ascension, at West Brighton. WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--General orders have been issued to the officers of the army and navy now in Washington to assemble at the War and Navy Departments, respectively, at 11:30 o'clock Jan. 1 next, in full uniform for the purpose of paying their respects to the President of the United States.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 29.--The steamer Carroll, which arrived here to-day from Halifax, brought 60 passengers of the National Line steamer France, from London, for New-York. The France had her shaft broken and was taken in tow by the steamer Marengo, which brought her safely into Halifax on the 25th inst.

HANOVER, Dec. 29.--Col. Rathbone, of Albany, N.Y., who killed his wife and then attempted to kill himself, has recovered sufficiently to permit his friends to take him to a hospital. His ultimate recovery from his self-inflicted wounds is possible.

MACON, Ga., Dec. 29.--Col. Albert R. Lamar, editor of the Telepraph and Messenger, has been ousted from his position and will be succeeded by Col. Peter W. Alexander, a wellknown Southern war correspondent and private secretary of Gov. Smith's Administration.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 29.--H.B. Claffin Co., of New-York, unpreferred creditors of Donald Gordon, dry goods merchant of this city, who recently made an assignment, have commenced suit against him to recover $207,000, the value of 67 promissory notes made by Gordon and remaining unpaid. Claffin Co. claim that Gordon made an assignment for the purpose of shutting out their claim.

CRAWFORD, Ga., Dec. 29.--At the Justices' Court, held here to-day, a case was on trial before Judge J.A. Jewell, in which the veracity of a witness having been questioned the witness and his friends challenged the opposing party. Both sides left the court, followed by a crowd of spectators, leaving the Judge the sole occupant of the court-room. A free fight with fists then took place.

BUFFALO, Dec. 29.--The dispute over the Payments of the bequests of the will of the late William G. Fargo has finally been settled, and Surrogate Ferris to-day ordered a discontinuance of the proceedings.

BUFFALO, Dec. 29.--Mayor Manning, whose term of office expires next Tuesday, today filled the vacant clerkship in the Board of Police Commissioners by the appointment of Leroy Andrus, and the vacant clerkship in the Board of Excise by the appointment of A.A. Vandenburg.

Company C of the Seventh Regiment made its second annual Winter march last night. About 35 men, in fatigue uniform, assembled at the Grand Central Station, where they took the train for William's Bridge.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 29.--The case of the Allegheny Valley Railroad Company against the heir's of William Phillips, who at one time was the President of the company, was concluded to-day, a verdict being rendered in favor of the plaintiffs for $471,000. The company alleged that Phillips had used than sum belonging to them for the purchase of property in his own name. The case will be taken to the Supreme Court.

READING, Penn., Dec. 29.--Jane Schlenke, 6 years old, of Greenwich, this county, was attached by a savage dog to-day, and mangled in a terrible manner. PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30.--About 2 o'clock this morning William Morgan, residing at No. 2,939 Norwood-avenue, beat his wife so seriously that her recovery is said to be doubtful. She was removed to the hospital. Morgan was arrested and held to await the result of her injuries.

LONDON, Dec. 30.--The Hamburg-American steamer Gellert, which arrived to-day at Plymouth, reports that she spoke the white Star steamer Celtic on Dec. 22 in latitude 41 longitude 64 . The Celtic's main shaft was broken.

Stopping at Princeton for a day, by request of the venerable Paul Tulane, I had the pleasure of a long conversation with him about the university he desires to establish in NewOrleans. Mr. Tulane welcomed me cordially.
The White Star steam-ship Britannie, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday, had a stormy passage. On Dec. 24 it blew heavily and a high head-sea was running.

The residence of Mr. G. S. Croker, No. 217 East Eighteenth-street, was entered yesterday morning by burglars, who ransacked the house from top to bottom, leaving everything in the utmost confusion. Mr. Croker, who is a brother of Fire Commissioner Croker, was asleep in the back parlor at the time.

The schooner Katie E. Gifford, which was blown ashore at Sandy Hook, was yesterday floated by the Merritt Wrecking Company and towed to this City by the steamer Rescue.

One of the German newspapers recently called attention to the scarcity of apothecary shops in Berlin, and within a fortnight afterward 13 new shops were licensed and for six others licenses were under consideration by the police authorities.

Capt. Akermark, of the Swedish ship Edward, which arrived yesterday from Havre, reports that on Oct. 24, at about noon in latitude 37 and longitude 12 , he passed a burning vessel, the masts of which went overboard when she was close at hand.
MADRID, Dec. 30.--The supporters of Senor Sagasta, who form a majority in the Chamber of Deputies, are more than ever opposed to the programme of universal suffrage and reform of the Constitution.

CAIRO, Dec. 30.--The Egyptian troops at Dongola, assisted by friendly tribes, have attacked and completely defeated a band of insurgents marching toward Berber. The rebels attacked Gezireh, a town eight miles from Berber.

BRISBANE, Queensland, Dec. 30.--The Swedish brig Natal, Capt. Ernstrom, from Boston July 29, has arrived here. A mutiny occurred on the voyage, in which the Captain and first mate were wounded and the second mate was killed. The Captain shot two of the mutineers and secured three others. The latter are now in prison here.
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 30.--Five men, under charge of United States Marshals, left Atlanta, last night to spend two years in Albany, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30.--The commission appointed by the Secretary of the Navy, in accordance with the provisions of the Naval Appropriations act, approved Aug. 5, 1882, has completed its report.

OWENSBORO, Ind., Dec. 30.--The steamer Carrier sunk at the head of Little Hurricane Island, three miles below this place, at 10 o'clock this morning. She struck during a dense fog, and swinging around, stove in 40 feet of her hull on the starboard side, sinking to over the hurricane deck aft, and to the boiler deck forward. One dockhand and two deck passengers, Italians, were drowned.

HALLIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 30.--Among the passenger on the Parisian, which sailed for Liverpool to-day, was Wallace Ross, the oarsman, who goes to England to prepare for his race with Buhear on the Thames in March. He will remain in England until May or June.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 30.--In the wrestling-match here last night between Muldoon and Bauer, for $1,960 a side and the championship of the world the former won after a three hours' struggle, and was carried in triumph on the shoulders of the crowd.

Walter E. Kidder, the salesman who was arrested on Monday last by Central Office detectives on a telegram signed by A.J. Parks, Sheriff of Miami County, Ind., charging him with bigamy, and who had been held in custody since, wad again arraigned before Justice Duffy at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

DES MOINES, Dec. 30.--The report of the Auditor of the State to the Governor makes the usual routine financial showing, and on his estimate for the next fiscal period there will be a margin of about $500,000 for completing the new Capitol and other purposes.

NORWICH, Dec. 30.--The convention of colored citizens of the State assembled in this city yesterday to discuss the question of civil rights as affected by the decision of the Supreme Court declaring the Civil Rights bill unconstitutional was largely attended by influential delegates from all parts of Connecticut.

It is stated on the best authority that Mr. Henry Villard resigned the Presidency of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company in a letter handed to the Directors on Saturday, upon which no official action was taken.
ALBANY, Dec. 30.--The Railroad Commission is preparing its first annual report and expects to have it ready for presentation to the Legislature by Jan. 15.

COOK'S MILLS, Ill., Dec. 30.--Last Wednesday John E. Barris, a well-to-do farmer, went to his home in an intoxicated condition. Marion, his son, aged 20 years, hit him on the head with a chair, inflicting injuries from the efforts of which he died yesterday. Before his death he stated that his son had frequently threatened to kill him. Opinions differ as to the culpability of young Barris. The old man was always abusive.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30.--About 4:30 o'clock this afternoon a fire was discovered in the three-story building, Nos. 119 and 121 Monroe-street. A disastrous conflagation followed, despite the efforts of the department, and at midnight a few engines were still playing on the ruins.

WILLKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 30.--The past week has been quite an exciting one at the County Jail, an attempt having been made by a prisoner named Leslie to create a strike for wades among those ut the prisoners doing various kinds of labor in the institution.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 30.--The reason that Hanlan asked Stevenson to release him from his engagement to row here is that the former preferred to row at Point of Pines, where there is a better course and where larger receipts could be expected. Hanlan offered. Stevenson $1,000 and his expenses to go East, and the latter has accepted.
BOSTON, Dec. 29.--The Butler party has been defeated twice since it raised its leader to the office which for many years he had been striving to gain.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 30.--Stout Higgins and Thomas Haynes, wealthy farmers, between whom there existed ill-feeling on account of a lawsuit, met at the Greendale Railway station last night. Higgins immediately drew a pistol, and seized Haynes by the collar, whereupon the latter shot Higgins through the lungs. Higgins returned the fire, hitting Haynes once in the left side and once in the ankle. Both men are very dangerously wounded.
BLUNT, Dakota, Dec. 30.--The defendant in the Shaw-Ordway alleged bribery case arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning, accompanied by nearly all the county officers.

SAN ANGELA, Dec. 30.--The Abilene stage was halted last night near the Colorado River by two masked men with drawn revolvers, and the nine passengers, comprising a variety troupe, were robbed of $400. The mails were not touched.

Hattle Carman, aged 15, is employed with several other girls in a paper-box factory at Glen Cove. On Saturday evening between 5 and 6 o'clock she started for her home from the factory.

The Central Labor Union held its usual weekly meeting yesterday afternoon at Oddfellows' Hall, in Second-street. The delegates from the Cigar-maker's Union asked that steps be taken to agitate the eight-hour law.

NEWARK, Dec. 30.--The Messrs. Kolisch will appear before the Court of Pardons to-mor row and endeavor to have the sentence of James B. Graves, who is to be handed on Thursday, commuted on the ground of insanity.
Yesterday things were very quiet in the City, and the policemen unanimously agreed that they had never seen the last Sunday of the year so free from disturbance.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 30.--William Barrett, a boy 11 years old, who resided with his parents in Pittston, met with a horrible death last night. He attempted,to jump on a coal train on the gravity road, when he slipped and fell under the cars. He was dragged a half mile and crushed into a shapeless mass. His brains were scattered all along the track. The remains were gathered up along the track.

ATCHISON, Kan., Dec. 30.--Last night about 10:30 o'clock a fire broke out in the elegant new house of Charles E. Styles, agent of the Missouri Pacific Railroad. Mr. Styles's wife and child perished in the flames and he was quite seriously burned. The origin of the fire is believed to have been the explosion of a gasoline machine in the cellar. The building was totally destroyed.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 30.--Measles are preyailing to a rather alarming extent in this city. There are now upward of 400 cases here, and 16 deaths occurred from the disease last week.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 30.--Fully 2,000 people viewed the remains of a suicide found in an alley in East Des Moines this morning, but no one recognized him. When found there was a revolver by his side, one chamber of which was empty, and there was a bullet-hole in his head. His pockets were empty and there were no papers by which to identify him.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 30.--Rebecca Mullens died suddenly at 1 o'clock this morning at No. 19 Bank-street, where she was living with Aaron B. Batterson, both formerly of Norwalk, where the girl's parents reside. Suspicions of foul play caused the arrest of Batterson.
Prof. BURT G. WILDER, the eminent catperson, made an address last Friday at the convention of the Society of Naturalists on the "Preservation of the Heart and Brains."

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 31.--Nathan Cole, Jr., owner of the North-west News, of Portland, Oregon, says that great interest centres just now near Portland, in the Ceur de Alene mining region, where gold has recently been discovered.

Sophia M. Funk applied for letters of administration on the estate of the late Gen. Augustus Funk on Oct. 24. Before they were issued, Helen S. Funk protested on the ground that she was the lawful widow of Gen. Funk.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--Mr. Phelps has received from Minister Taft, his successor at Vienna, news of the serious illness of his old Secretary of Legation, Mr. John F. Delaplaine. For 20 years Mr. Delaplaine has been connected with that Legation. Educated at Columbia College, the son of a wealthy New-York merchant, he had great gifts and shone in society for 25 years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--The receipts by the Government from Customs duties and internal revenue taxes for the first half of the fiscal year Show a falling off, as compared with the preceeding year, of about $28,000,000. Of this decrease about $13,500,000 is in internal revenue taxes, and about $12,500,000 in Customs.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 31.--Color is given to the report that the Pennsylvania Railroad Company has been negotiating for the purchase of the Connotton Valley Narrow-gauge Railway by the additional statement that the Cleveland and Pittsburg Company has desired for some time to secure better terminal facilities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--The House Committee on Military Affairs, or which Gen. Rosecrans is Chairman, decided to-day to report in favor of the passage of the Fitz John Porter Relief bill, and will do so at the first opportunity after Congress reconvenes.

Mr. Bartley Campbell's new play, "A False Step," will be brought forward soon at the Union-Square Theatre, with a cast which is to include Mr. Charles Coghlan, Mr. John L. Stoddart, Mr. John Parselle, Miss Effie Ellsler, Miss Maud Harrison, Miss Eleanor Cary, and Miss Gabrielle du Sauld.
LEXINGTON, Ga., Dec. 31.--The story of the elopement and marriage of Joseph I. Stewart with his niece, Hattie Stewart, has had a singular ending.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 31.--A prominent gentleman of this city states that everything published concerning the object of the meeting of Catholic Bishops at Baltimore is incorrect. He says the real business of the meeting is to devise a system of church government which will allow priests greater liberties, and that this is necessary to prevent rebellion.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 31.--John C. Marsh, a lawyer, and his wife, James Boylin, and Reese Blair were poisoned by eating eggs Sunday morning at Beaver Dam, Union County. Marsh died, but the others are supposed to be out of danger. The eggs are believed to have been poisoned for the purpose of killing rats, and to have been put on the breakfast table by mistake.

At best the last day of the year is a period of great anxiety to fire underwriters. PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 31.--The steamer Carrie sank near Owensboro yesterday. She was valued at $24,000, and is insured for $16,000 in Pittsburg Cincinnati, Boston, and St. Paul com panies. She is owned by William Rees, Simpson Horner, and A.J. McConnell, of this city.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31.--The warrant for the hanging of the murderer John McGinnis on Thursday has been withdrawn by the Governor. There is some doubt as to the prisoner's sanity, and a respite has been granted until March 4.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 31.--Dr. M.C. Cremin has brought a civil suit against Joseph Molloy, the grocer, for slander and assault and battery. He asks for $5,000 damages. Mrs. Molloy died last September.

Emory Speer, who was appointed United States Attorney for the northern district of Georgia after the Forty-Seventh Congress adjourned, is now in town, waiting to see whether or not the Senate will confirm his appointment. He said to-day that he was not at all worried about the matter, feeling confident that he would be confirmed.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 31.--In the case of Pomeroy vs. Mills, of Morris County, in which the heirs of an estate sought to have the fees allowed the Executors by the Orphans' Court reduced, Judge Dixon to-day read an opinion asserting the jurisdiction of the Court of Errors and Appeals over the case. He directed the reduction of the fees from 3 to 2 per cent. The amount upon which the Executors have administered is $400,000.

HAVANA, Dec. 31.--The German corvette Olga, with Prince Henry on board, arrived here to-day. The authorities went on board to salute and welcome the Prince, who remained on the ship all day.

In the preliminary pool tournament yesterday afternoon in Madison-Square Hall, Leonard had little difficulty in beating Heman, 11 to 7. The contest between Van Buskirk and Dunning excited lively interest.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 31.--Big Kelly, one of the notorious gang of express robbers, was captured on the road eight miles north of this city this morning. Three of his party escaped. An officer here had been taken into a combination to rob the Cleveland express train, and a number of officers went out with him with the result stated.

The brothers in charge of the sanctuary of the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, in Thirdstreet, near Avenue A, were engaged yesterday in decorating the high altar, preparatory to the feast to-day. At 8 o'clock last evening 4,000 persons were in the large building.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 31.--The ceremony of representing the funeral of O'Donnell, who was hanged in London, took place yesterday afternoon. It was intended to make it a grand demonstration, but the Board of Supervisors and the prominent Irish organizations declined to take part and the result was a dismal failure. There were only about 300 in the procession.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 31.--A compromise was effected to-day in the now famous Johnson case by which all litigation will be dismissed and the case end, at least so far as the public is concerned.

Gibson, who committed suicide in his wife's boarding-house, on Washington-avenue, Christmas Eve. The document was dated Oct.15, and was witnessed by Frank R. O'Neil, a reporter for the Republican, and J.A. Talty, a lawyer.

Anteeo is a 4-year-old stallion by Electioneer, his dam Columbine also being one of the finest bred mares in America. She is now owned by Gov. Stanford, who purchased her from Mr. Simpson. Anteeo has been trained and driven only by Mr. Simpson.

SANDERSVILLE, Ga.,. Jan. 1.--Mr. T.G. Amerson, of this county, was wounded in the head to-day by a bullet from a pistol in the hands of an unknown assassin. Amerson was seated in a neighbor's house by the fire when some one on the outside shot him through a hole in the wall. The ball entered above the right eye, entirely destroying the sight thereof.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 1.--Four negro cabins were burned, at West Kansas City, last night, and to-day some of the neighbors discovered the body of Maggie Howard, a dissolute negress, in the ruins. There is a suspicion that the woman was murdered by her negro paramour, and that the cabin was then set on fire. The suspected man is said to have disappeared.

The attendance at the pool tournament in Madison-Square Hall was very light yesterday, both day and evening.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 1.--The Prince of Pless arrived with his valet on the steamer Samaria to-day. He is making a tour of the world. The town of Pless, over which his family reigns, is situated in Prussian Silesia.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 1.--There are a large number of politicians already in the city to take part in the organization of the House and Senate. There is unusual interest taken in this, and the seekers after places within the gift of the Legislature are unprecedented in numbers. The Senatorial contest, however, overshadows all other interests and little else is talked of.

We are informed by Deputy United States Marshal Ricketts that about three years ago a fortune, estimated at $1,590,000, was left John Spring, who died in this city a few days ago. The property and coin was left him by his cousin, Capt. Arthur Spring a merchant at Callao, Peru. Inquiries for John Spring were at the time set on foot, but he was not found until about three weeks before his death.

James Kelly and Matthew Brennan, inmates of a lodging-house at No. 207 Bowery, quarreled last night about a pipe which Kelly was smoking. Louis S. Craig, a pattern designer, was a prisoner in the Mercer-street police station last night, having been arrested at No. 8 Lafayetteplace for attempting to shoot one of the inmates. The house is kept by Mrs. Maria Higgins and Craig lives there with his sister.

The dike recently completed by the Hon. William M. Evarts, Windsor making a lake on his meadow of over a hundred acres of water from 5 to 20 feet deep, broke out recently, washing away some 50 feet of the embankment, and causing a loss of $1,000.

LONDON, Jan. 1.--Ten minor failures in the iron trade are reported in Birmingham. Other small failures in the same trade are announced in the provinces.
The grave of William Hogarth, at Chiswick, which has fallen somewhat into decay, is about to be restored. Persons from all parts of the world visit this spot.

A portly man, with a flushed face and a double chin, came out of a house in Hicks-street, Brooklyn, yesterday forenoon, and riveted a blood-shot eye upon the leisurely motions of a laboring man who was cleaning off a cross-walk.
An extraordinary kidnaping story is being investigated by the metropolitan police. The victim is a man named Joseph Meiar, a Swiss, employed at the Midland Hotel, St. Pancras.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 1.--It is snowing here to-day. The water is receding, and the trains are on time.
George Archbold, a saloon-keeper at No. 250 West Twentieth-street, ranged up and down that street last evening, thirsting for the gore of one Dick Yarwood, a prize-fighter.
According to statistics furnished by the the Fire Commissioners, there were 2,168 fires last year, against 2,001 in 1882, an increase of 167.

Praise and unstinted praise should be given to "The Bread Winners." It is a straightforward story, with sufficient dramatic incident to make it interesting. In fact, this novel, the production of an anonymous author, has that precise quality which renders it acceptable to the publisher and readers--accuracy of portraiture.

The dry goods store of Theodore Gaddis, at Pacific and Walnut streets, Newark, was robbed of goods valued at $1.700 yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1.--This evening the new wigwam for the great Council of Red Men was dedicated. The several tribes of this city and tribes from New-Jersey paraded through the principal streets, receiving a marching salute as they passed the wigwam.

PROVIDENCE, Jan. 1.--Three years and a half ago the eight Republican delegates from Rhode Island cast their votes at Chicago for Blaine, and the eight delegates who went to Cincinnati supported no less than six Democratic candidates on the first ballot.

Jacob Schun, a young milkman residing at No. 604 Johnson-avenue, Brooklyn, when the screaming of steam whistles and the ringing of church bells announced the birth of the New Year, took out his revolver and, to add to the general noise, fired off, as he supposed, the five bullets which it contained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20.--There were 27 marriage certificates signed at the ratification of the civil contract in advance of the religious marriage ceremony between Miss Hattie Key and Capt. Jean Leon Raynard, of the French army, which occurred this week in Georgetown, D.C.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 1.--Payments for duties at the Boston Custom-house for 1883 amounted to $22,730,000, a decrease of $2,000,000, as compared with the previous year.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 1.--The mills which closed down for the holidays will resume to-morrow. Most of them report enough orders on hand to run them for many weeks. A reduction of 10 per cent. in the wages of their em ployes is talked of by the tube manufacturers, but no definite action has been taken as yet.

The Russian Commission appointed to draw up a scheme for the reform of the home administration, and presided over by State Councilor Cozlianoff, has completed its work. The result will be published shortly as a supplement to the Government Gazette.
No more extraordinary billiards than that shown by John Roberts and Joseph Bennett in their recent match of 4,000 points has ever been seen at the English all-round game.

It has often been said that if a jury were to consist of Judges they never would agree. This has been proved in the case of Mr. Belt. Not only did the three Judges differ as to the verdict, but they also fell out as to the artistic talents of Sir Frederick Leighton.
A curious discussion about the descent of the greatest musical composer of our century is occupying the French and German papers.

CLAREMONT, N. H., Jan. 1.--Edward Keyes, who died in Unity, N.H., a few days ago, left to the school districts of that town $12,000, it being all his property except $45, which he gave to an only daughter.
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 1.--Winfield Heisler, of Heisler, McBridge Co., coppersmiths, had his skull fractured to-day and may die.

CALAIS, Me., Jan. 1.--The owners of the schooner John A. Lord, which six weeks ago was reported sighted several hundred miles from Halifax abandoned with her mainmast and foretopmast gone, received a cable message from London to-day announcing the safe arrival there of Capt. Joshua Thomas and crew.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Jan. 1.--The mental condition of John Osborn, the civil and hydraulic engineer, has been a matter of concern to many persons for several days past.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 1.--The colored people celebrated Emancipation Day here this afternoon, four thousand people turning out. Bishop Turner (colored) said in a speech that the "devil in hell would not make the distinctions against negroes that are made in this country."

When Brother Shinbones Smith returned, after making his New Year's calls, to his brownwood-front on the western frontier of Hoboken, it was nearly 1:30 this morning. He had started out in the early afternoon arrayed in all the glory of his best protracted meeting clothes.

A great deal has been written since the death of Lord Overstone on his many virtues, his great abilities, and unbounded generosity. His right place, according to one eulogist, would have been in the Cabinet, as no man of his time was better fitted to assist in guiding the counsels of the nation.

MORROWVILLE, Penn., Jan. l.-The "Long Hill"on the road leading from this place to Stokes's Mills, in the Elk lumber regions, 10 miles from this place, was the scene of a frightful coasting accident on Sunday night last. Stokes's Mills is composed entirely of the extensive lumbering establishments of J.G.A. Stokes Co.

SALEM, Ohio, Jan. 1.--L. N. Griffith, a farmer, living south of here, was found dead near his house this morning by his son, 18 years old, who said that his father had committed suicide. The boy has since disappered, and the indications point to a case of murder. The Coroner is making an investigation.

Mr. TUPPER has written a powerful letter to the London Times in approval of the elevation of Mr. TENNYSON to the peerage. He points out that it is the first time that a poet has been made a British peer solely because of his poetry, and expresses the hope that the good work will go on.

In the windows of one of our large Wabash-avenue stores was displayed, a few days ago, an afghan which attracted considerable attention. It is made in the crazy-quilt pattern, of bits of silk, satin, plush, velveteen, and velvet, cut from the dresses worn by Mrs. Garfield.
The third annual ball of the Joseph H. Tooker, Jr., Association, will be given to-morrow evening in Ferrero's Assembly Rooms, Tammany Hall.
The most thoroughly eloquent and effective speeches ever made in the Legislature of Texas were pronounces by two negroes, and both of much the same general import.
Two Brooklyn boys found a New Year's card-case at Columbia Heights and Pierrepontstreet yesterday noon. It was not a valuable card-case, but the boys at once quarreled for its possession.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 1.--A private dispatch states that the ship Adam M. Simpson, 1,500 tons burden, of Philadelphia, loaded with a full cargo of over 2,000 tons of sugar, consigned to various parties in Boston, was lost in Palawan Passage, north of Borneo, on the voyage from lloilo to Boston. The cargo was valued at over $200,000. and was insured in New-York and Boston offices. The crew was saved.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 1.--About 150 tobacco-growers, representing the New-England States, met in convention, in this city to-day to "further protest against the recent decision of the Secretary of the Treasury, whereby wrapper leaf tobacco is virtually admitted at the rate of 35 cents per pound, thus evading the intent and spirit of the law."

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 1.-Henry Hane, a well-to-do German, while in a drunken, jealous frenzy last night, attempted to brain his wife with an axe. He cut two fearful gashes in her cheek and arm, and then went into his kitchen and blew his brains out with a pistol.

TUCSON, Arizona, Jan. 2.--The last of the Apache renegades from Sonora surrendered at San Carlos last week. The Indians are all contented and general security is felt. There is renewed confidence in Gen. Crook's control of the Indians. There is a general revival of prosperity throughout the Territory. The mining outlook is flattering over $1,000,000 having been invested in producing mines during the last three months.

PANAMA, Dec. 24.--The latest advices from Brazil are to the effect that the boundary dispute between Brazil and French Guiana is to be submitted to arbitration. Brazil, it is said, has chosen the Emperor of Germany as its representative, while France has selected President Arthur. These nominations, however, are not official, and it is possible that, prior to debate commencing on the matter, other arbitrators will be selected.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 2.--G.L. Warshauer, representing M. E. Solomon, of NewYork, was arested here to-day for perjury, on the ground that he swore falsely to an affidavit for the replevin of 12 bales of tobacco sold to Isaac Reis, he charging that they were obtained by false representations. Warshauer was released on a bond until a hearing is given.

Mrs. Elizabeth Werner, a German woman, 51 years of age, rendered desperate by domestic unhappiness, committed suicide yesterday by taking muriatic acid at No. 137 Pittstreet. Her husband, Henry, is a cabinet-maker.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 2.--Notwithstanding the reported depression of the iron market and the gloomy outlook for trade, most of the mills of this city, which have been closed for customary repairs or otherwise, have begun operations to-day and promise to give steady employment. Iron men admit that a light supply in the market renders the prospect good for a fair demand.

KEOKUK, Iowa, Jan. 2.--George W. McCrary, Judge of the Eighth United States Judicial Circuit, embracing Minnesota, Iowa, Missouri, Kansas, Arkansas, Nebraska, and Colorado, forwarded his resignation to the President to-night, to take effect March 1. He has contracted with the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company to fill the position of General Counselor. He will have his head-quarters in Kansas City.

According to the annual report of the Pilot Commissioners, which will shortly be sent to the Legislature, there are now 133 licensed pilots in the New-York service. During the year six pilots lost their lives while in the performance of their duties.

YAZOO CITY, Miss., Jan. 2.--The preliminary trial of Octavius Thompson, Henry Schuler, and five other defendants, charged with the killing of the two Poseys, Jasper Nicholls, and Mr. Holder, commenced Tuesday morning and continued yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 2.--This morning the steamers City of Alton and Colorado, lying by in Winter quarters near the work-house, in South St. Louis, caught fire and were burned to the water's edge. Just before daylight the day watchman of the Colorado started to enter the ...

BOWIE, Arizona, Jan. 2.--Three of the Southern Pacific train robbers and murderers are in custody at Silver City. The first one, caught at Las Vegas, was a negro, who made a confession. The other two were captured in New-Mexico on Sunday and the fourth is expected to be taken soon.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Jan. 2.--James D. Champion walked from his residence to a doctor's office this afternoon. Becoming dizzy, he went out on the street for fresh air and fell to the ground senseless. He was taken home, where he died in half an hour. Apoplexy was the cause of death.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 2.--An explosion of blasting powder and dynamite cartridges occurred at the trunk sewer on Swan-street shortly before 11 o'clock last night.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, Jan. 2.--James Williams, alias O'Brian, confined in the county jail here, shot the turnkey dead at 10 o'clock this morning and escaped. How he obtained the pistol with which he committed the crime is a mys tery. Williams is a well-known desperado.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 2.--The Governor's message was presented to the General Assembly at Frankfort to-day. It contains many interesting facts and figures.

DALLAS, Texas, Jan. 2.--The Hon. James A. Slater, a member of the Legislature now here, says of the fence cutting in Medina County on Monday, that many fences were cut, and in a free fight several men were wounded.

The Stevens mansion, covering four lots on the south-west corner of Fifth-avenue and Fifty-seventh-street, has been purchased from Mrs. Adele L.S. Stevens by Mrs. William C. Whitney, for $600,000. The instrument was acknowledged in Paris, France, where Mrs. Stevens is at present sojourning.

THE TIMES has published a series of interesting letters from New-England, evidently by a skilled observer, discussing the relative strength in public favor of the more conspicuous gentlemen who are mentioned for the Republican Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--Civil Service Commissioners Caton, Gregory, and Thoman are now busily engaged in preparing their first annual report of the work of the commission, a document which will be looked for with interest by both friends and opponents of civil service reform.

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, Jan. 2.--The Mexican Government has declared forfeited the concession made to Gen. Grant for a submarine cable connecting Mexico, the United States, and Central America for non-fulfillment of the terms of the concession, no work having been done within the prescribed time.

NAPOLEON, Ohio, Jan. 2.--A west-bound express train, on the Wabash Road, last night struck a wagon near here containing five young men. Frank Long and William Rohers were instantly killed and George Arps was seriously wounded. Long leaves a widow, but the rest were unmarried. A freight train on a side track concealed the approaching train.
