A general reduction of 10 per cent. in the wages of cotton operatives takes place to-day throughout Rhode Island, in New-Bedford and Taunton, Mass., and in other places in Western Massachusetts and Connecticut.

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--A wearisome hour was spent by the Assembly to-day in the debate over Mr. Dayton's proposition to cut off what he considered certain useless committees from the list and to increase the membership of some of the more important committees.

In accordance with the usual custom, John Reilly, retiring President of the Board of Aldermen, issued a call on Tuesday evening for a caucus of the Democratic members of the new Board of Aldermen, to be held in the Aldermen's chamber yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, to consider the organization of the new board.

Stansbury, the would-be Pastor of the African Bethel Church, who was ejected from his pulpit on Sunday, appeared in the City Court to-day, to press complaints against John Norcom, Henry H. Phillips and John T. Williams for assault and battery, and for disturbing a religious meeting. Judge Deming continued the cases until to-morrow on the first charge, and to Jan. 8 on the second.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 2.--W. Irving Landell, said to have been from Philadelphia, died here last night from hunger and exposure. He reached here a few days ago accompanied by a brother 12 years old. He had only a dollar, and he gave that to a boarding-house-keeper for his brother, refusing to eat himself. He found employment as a brakeman, and after 36 hours of exposure in sleet and snow, returned here and died.

The Symphony Society of New-York will give its third public rehearsal and concert at the Academy of Music on Friday afternoon and Saturday evening of this week. James, proprietor of the Bijou Theatre, New-York, alleged was made to his deteriment as the owner of the same. No news from the disabled steam-ship Celtic was received yesterday at the White Star offices in this City. Mr. Cortis, agent of the line, said that even provided the weather had been favorable during the whole time since the Hamburg steam-ship spoke the Celtic, the latter could hardly have reached Queenstown before to-day. WASHINGTON, Penn., Jan. 3.--A company has been formed to bore test wells for gas in this vicinity, and, if successful, furnish gas to the citizens of Washington for light, heat and fuel. We are within nine or ten miles of the famous McGugin well, the gas from which is being piped to Pittsburg for manufacturing purposes. The projectors of the enterprise feel certain that success will attend their efforts.

CAIRO, Jan. 3.--The Khedive has written a letter to Haidar Pasha, Minister of Finance, urging retrenchment in governmental expenses, and stating that he has decided upon a reduction in the civil lists of himself and the hereditary Prince to the extent of 10 per cent. ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 4.--Another sensation is reported from Chattooga County. Mr. Alexander Brice, a leading planter, having a wife and two children, became enamored of Miss Mary Mosteller, daughter cf a neighbor. Last night the pair disappeared from home, and, it is reported, have gone to Texas.

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 4.--W.M. Furbush Son, piano-dealers, are reported as having failed. The liabilities are $27,000; nominal assets, $12,000. Their sales amounted to $70,000 last year. ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 4.--Henner Moore, bankers, of Morris, Minn., failed to-day. Their liabilities are $100,000; assets unknown. The First National Bank, in which the firm is a large stockholder, is not affected.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 4.--The criminal record of the past two weeks has been one of a lively character. In Dooley County Joe Mitchell was beating a woman when Elias Ferguson undertook to protect her. Mitchell drew a pistol and threatened to shoot Ferguson, whereupon the latter hastily retreated to safer quarters.

As William Arnold, a printer, ascended the steps leading to the Brooklyn bridge last evening he was tripped by John A. Williams, also a printer. At the same moment Williams snatched Arnold's watch and darted up the roadway. Officer Lammy, of the bridge police, captured Williams and locked him up in the Oakstreet station-house.

Philip Brindle died at West Paterson, N. J., yesterday, after a peculiar illness of 10 years. What it was no physician could tell.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 4.--In the Supreme Court to-day all the Wequetequock assault and perjury cases were unceremoniously thrown out.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 4.--Dr. D.G. Corlin, for many years engaged in this city in the manufacture of trusses as a member of the firm of Marsh, Corlin Co., was found dead today in the cistern at his home, in Camp Washington. It is uncertain whether be committed suicide or fell in by accident. He had been drinking heavily for some time.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 4.--Patrick H. Pepper, a noted blockade runner, died this morning, aged 65. He was an Irishman by birth. He came to Mobile in 1847 and grew rich in the dry goods business.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 4.--Last October Thomas Kennedy, aged 14, accidently and in play struck a younger companion named John Condon with a small stone. Condon's skull was fractured and he died in a few hours. Yesterday Kennedy was convicted in the Superior Court of manslaughter. To-day, in consideration of his youth, he was fined $5 and ordered to be imprisoned for two months in jail.
Joseph Quinlan and Joseph J. Murphy, sailors, arrived in this City from Belfast, Me., about three weeks ago, and put up at No. 15 Hamilton-street.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 4.--Valmore Rector was hanged at Baton Rouge to-day for the murder of Duncan Williams. Both were colored. It was a case of cool-blooded assassination. Rector crept up behind Williams without warning and drove a dirk knife through his back.

The lower part of hold No. 5, or stern hold, of the White Star steam-ship Britannia was flooded yesterday morning, at the West Tenth-street pier, to extinguish a fire which had broken out in a cargo of cotton.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 4.--Mrs. Mary Carver, in whose house at Lakeville Patrick Cartlin was found dead last Monday, while being taken to jail confessed that during a drunken altercation between Cartlin and Charles B. Staples, at her house last Sunday, the latter felled the former with a slung-shot, and he died three hours afterward. Mrs. Carver's husband had no complicity in the act.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 4.--The order given by the anthracite autocrats for half-time at the mines during January, February, and March has sent "a cold chill" through this region, and is received with great dissatisfaction by the workmen. It was expected that there would be a curtailment of some sort after a year ...
The annual meeting of the Dry Goods Mutual Benefit Association will take place in the St. Nicholas Hotel Tuesday at 8 P.M.

A well-known citizen of Washington has just been made a knight of the Order of Melusini by a Parisian lady who is the only living descendant of GUY DE LUSIGNANI, King of Jerusalem, by whom the order in question was founded.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 4.--At Stevensville, on the Grand Trunk Railway, a collision occurred yesterday afternoon. About 3 o'clock the engine of a local train, No. 10, and train No. 21 came into collision at the station.

BATH, Me., Jan. 4.--The trial of Daniel Wilkinson for the murder of Officer Lawrence was continued this morning. Detective Wood testified that Wilkinson's confession was drawn forth without inducement.
OTTUMWA, Wis., Jan. 4.--This place is much excited over the murder of Turnkey John J. Manning by the escaping burglar James Williams alias O'Brien, on Tuesday.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 4.--The NewYork and New-England Railroad's great iron transfer steamer here, the William T. Hart, which cost $200,000, has been seized by United States Marshals for a debt due Ward, Stanton Co., the Newburg ship-builders.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 4.--One of the commuters' trains on the Cincinnati Northern Road was run into to-day in the Walnut Hills Tunnel by the Lebanon express, which was following it. The rear coach, which happened to be empty, was telescoped by the locomotive. The passengers on both trains were thrown from their seats and much frightened, but there was no one seriously hurt.

ELIZABETH, N.J. Jan. 3.--A freight train on the Lehigh Valley Road west bound came in collision this morning with a Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train cast bound at Lehigh Valley Junction, near Perth Amboy. Both locomotives were wrecked and several cars damaged. Nobody was seriously injured. The Lehigh Valley flagman was reported to be at fault.
For the last 10 days a paid agent has been collecting evidence against policy-dealers for Inspector Byrnes.

LONDON, Jan. 4.--The Paris correspondent of the Times, summing up the situation in Spain, says it is doubtful whether King Alfonso, in the event of a dissolution of the Cortes, could depend for support upon the Spanish Army. Meanwhile the Zorillaists and Carlists are at work. The Times's correspondent concludes that the alternative will soon be presented of a choice between anarchy and absolutism, with the probability that independence and Freedom with succumb.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4, 1884. R.C. Hughes, of Larned, Kan., a pension attorney, who was disbarred in 1876, has been restored to practice before the Interior Department.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--Judge Smith, of the Superior Court, rendered a decision to-day declaring unconstitutional the not of the Legislature under which damages could be recovered from the owners of houses in which money had been lost in gambling. The principal reason given by the court is that the Constitution provides that each act of the Legislature shall have a title, and that only one subject is to be embraced in one act.

Early yesterday morning Hans Carlson, a drunken sailor, applied for admittance to a sailor's boarding-house kept by Mrs. W. Peterson, at No. 120 William-street, South Brooklyn. Carlson had boarded in the house some time ago, but recently went away to go on a voyage.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4.--Henry Bell, a well-known citizen, died at his residence here today from injuries received on Christmas night.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 4.--A sensation was created in this city this afternoon by the developments in a trial which was had in the Justice's court, and in which two of the best known physicians of Providence were put upon their defense for alleged illegal practice. The complainant was Annie Riley, a beautiful blonde, 17 years of age.

Capt. Benjamin T. Watlington, a shipmaster, well known in nearly every large port in the civilized world, died of old age at his home, No. 45 Douglass-street, Brooklyn, yesterday. He had not been in good health for several years and his death was not a surprise to his relatives and friends.

This is pretty severe on the young fellows whose muscles have been strengthened and skulls thickened by four or five years of college life.
LOUISVILLE, Jan. 4.--Henry Watterson left here with his wife to-night for Washington. He said before leaving that he would remain in Washington and New-York until next June.

DUBLIN, Jan. 4.--The United Ireland publishes an account of the murder of James Carey, which was written by a gentleman who received it from Patrick O'Donuell under a promise that it was not to be told as long as a chance remained to save O'Donnell's life. The account shows that O'Donnell deliberately killed Carey.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 4.--A meeting was held at the Grand Hotel last evening to make arrangements for holding a World's Fair in this city in l887.

McAlpine's man is thought to be Jim Goode.

Col. John Irwin Nevin, editor of the Pittsburg Leader, died yesterday morning of Bright's disease at his home, in Sewickley. For many years Col. Nevin had been in bad health, but it was only two months ago that Dr. Sykes discovered his malady to be Bright's disease. John Irwin Nevin was born Aug. 23, 1837, in Sewickley, and when 21 years old graduated at Jefferson College, Canonsburg.

SING SING, Jan. 5.--Detective Jackson arrived at the prison this afternoon with the notorious Frank Riley, alias Frank Harrison. With another convict, Paul Wilson, he escaped from the mess-room of the prison on Nov. 14 1ast. He remained in the woods all day and walked to New-York at night. He has been under arrest several times since he made his escape. Last night he was arrested by Detectives Valely and McConnell in Sixth-avenue, New-York.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 5.--Dr. George H. Greely, who was arrested in New-York on a charge of forgery, was brought to Syracuse tonight. He was admitted to bail in the sum of $2,000, his brother, Horace Greely, becoming his surety. Another forgery, alleged to be perpetrated by Dr. Greely, was discovered to-day. It is believed that the doctor's relatives will settle all claims againt him.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 5.--The annual report of the Boston Fish Bureau shows that during the past year the total catch of mackerel by the NewEngland fleet was 226,685 pounds, a decreased of 152,178 pounds as compared with last year. The total catch of ground fish, including cod, haddock, hake, pollock, and cusk, was 1,061,698 quintals, an increase of 162,794 quintals over 1882.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 5.--Application was made at the State Department to-day for a charter to the Pittsburg and Allegheny Central Railway Company, capital stock $1,200,000. The company proposes building a railroad from Chartiers Township, Allegheny County, to NewSalem, Westmoreland County, a distance of 40 miles.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5.--Further investigation of the alleged frauds by the Pullman palace car and the Pennsylvania Railroad conductors led to the arrest this morning of G.W. Forster, a resident of Chicago, employed on the route between that city and Philadelphia.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 5.--The Government has contracted with the Mexican National Bank for a loan of $5,700,000, receivable in weekly installments, and will repay with orders on the Custom house, receivable for import dues. The Government reserves the right to withdraw from the contract, but will admit Custom-house orders sold by the bank previous to such withdrawal.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Jan. 6.--Jacob Sharkly, John Glenter, and a child were seriously injured last night by a drunken mob in a Hungarian boarding-house. The mob attacked the house, breaking in the doors and windows. Officers made several arrests.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 6.--This has been one of the coldest days ever known in Charleston. BOSTON, Jan. 6.--Miss Elmira J. Talbot, age 19, supposed to have come from Marlboro', died at the boarding-house of Miss Etta W. Ludgate, on Harrison-avenue, on Friday. As the result of an autopsy Miss Ludgate was to-day arrested charged with having been an accessory to a criminal operation alleged to have been performed upon the deceased girl. Miss Ludgate furnished bail in $1,500.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 7.--While three beys were out hunting this afternoon near a place known as Carr's Corners, in the western suburbs of this city, they found the body of a young woman frozen solidly in the ice in a stream under a wagonbridge.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 6.--The situation of the glass lock-out is not materially changed. The strike is nearly five months old, and outwardly, at least, both sides present as firm a front as at the commencement.

WILKESBARRE, Jan. 6.--Ex-AttorneyGeneral Palmer addressed a large audience here this evening on the evils of intemperance. His subject was "What It Costs to Drink Whisky." The election of Prince Torlonia, the Syndic, as a Deputy for Rome has been nullified by the Chamber because he was under the age of 30 when elected. The case is a remarkable one. Of course, every voter knew that the candidate was under age, and that the election would be nullified, but the time was thus gained for Prince Torlonia, who is now 30 years old, and he will be re-elected.

M. Wolff Co., wholesale hat merchants, at No. 596 Broadway, failed yesterday, and the partners, Morris Wolff and Martin Kahn, made an assignment to Gustav Gumprecht. Preferences aggregating $52,043 were made as follows:

The interior of the new Metropolitan Opera-house presented a gorgeous appearance last night, draped as it was with flowers, flags, and bunting and filled with gentlemen dressed in sober black and gay uniforms and ladies in elegant and showy costumes.

The Columbia College Trustees were agreeably surprised yesterday, at their monthly meeting, by the reception of a letter from Prof. Rees, of the Astronomical Observatory, stating that Lewis M. Rutherfurd, a Trustee, had given his astronomical insruments to the observatory.

The collection of 105 pieces extracted from the studios of the painters who participate in the Artists' Fund Society differs in nothing that is material from exhibitions in former years. There are 72 subscribers, of whom all but 9 send works.

According to Mr. GLADSTONE, England's mission in Egypt is to benefit that unhappy country. Just now England is benefiting Egypt by virtually informing her that she must give up the Soudan to rebels, but, strange to say, the Egyptian Government does not seem to be grateful to its benefactor.

The will of the late Emil Justh, a member of the New-York Stock Exchange, who died in Paris, France, on Dec. 16 last, was admitted to probate by Surrogate Rollins yesterday. It is dated Feb. 10, 1883.

The disabled White Star steam-ship Celtic, which left this port on Dec.15, and was passed on Dec. 22 by the Hamburg steam-ship Gellert, has again been heard from. She was sighted on Dec. 29 in latitude 42 and longitude 53 by the Cunard steam-ship Bothnia, which arrived at Liverpool last Saturday night.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7.--The Corner's jury to-day in the case of Henry Bell, who died on Friday last from injuries received on Christmas night, returned a verdict that he came to his death by being struck by a street car or the horses attached thereto.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7.--The Superintendent of the Mounted Recruiting Service, has been ordered to cause 75 recruits to be prepared and forwarded to such points as shall be designated by the Commanding General, Department of Arizona, for assignment to the Third Cavalry; 60 recruits to such points as shall be ...
We have had female acrobats, female bicyclists, and female ball-players. That we now have a female atheist is what might have been expected.

DES MONIES, Iowa, Jan. 7.--Lynch Brothers, hardware-dealers, made an assignment this morning. They have an aggregate indebtedness, mainly to stove and hardware concerns in Ohio and the Eastern States, of $25,000, with assets footing up $11,000. The firm had given credit largely.

The funeral of Capt. James Kealy, of the Fourteenth Precinct, took place yesterday morning at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church, in East Thirty-seventh-street. A detail of 65 officers who had served under Capt. Kealy, under the command of Capt. Copeland, escorted the ...
Steam-ship Herschel, (Br.,) Braithwaite, Santos, , Dec. 13, with mdse. to Busk Javons. Steam-ship Nachoochee, Kempton, Savannah Jan. 5 with mdse. and passengers to Henry Yonge, Jr.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 7.--The house of Miss Graydon was entered by burglars last night. She awoke and gave the alarm, when she was struck a violent blow on the head with a hatchet, and she now lies in a critical condition. A negro named Cummings has been arrested on suspicion.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 7.--The name of the woman found dead near Carr's Corners yesterday it is ascertained was Fannie Gaskell. Her parents live at Watkins. She was last seen on Monday night in company with a young man named Michael Hackett, who is of unsavory reputation, ...
CHICAGO, Jan. 7.--There is great excitement among the students of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, in this city, over the developments reached by the detectives in the Sycamore grave robbery.

LONDON, Jan. 7.--William Black, the novalist, is dangerously ill. His physicians have forbidden him to do any more work or to discuss literary matters. Mr. Black is suffering from nervous debility, which the doctors say has been caused by overwork.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 7.--Gov. Foster, in his message to the General Assembly, announces that about $2,000,000 of the public debt of the State has been paid during the past four years, and that the State levy for general revenue purposes can be reduced this year by two-tenths of a mill unless some extravagant demand upon the Treasury is made.

RED BANK, Jan. 7.--The first ice yacht race on the Shrewsbury River this year took place to-day. A very large number of persons gathered to witness the contest. Only four boats of the Shrewsbury fleet entered in the race, the Dreadnaught, Idler, Scud, and Uncle Bob.

BOSTON, Jan. 7.--The Directors of the New-York and New-England Railway Company, by their action at the special meeting held here to-day, settled for the present the question of the Receivership, and no controversy over it is now likely to take place. The following resolutions, prepared by counsel of the opposing interests, were adopted unanimously:

Mrs. Mary Zimmermann, who lives at No. 17 Clinton-street, on the second floor, returned to her home at about 8:15 on Sunday evening, after a visit to her mother. Before going up stairs, she intended to enter Hop Lee's Chinese laundry on the ground floor and show him that she wore a silk necktie which he had given her on Christmas.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 7.--The Coroner's jury on the body of William Van Sickle, a hotelkeeper, of Brantford, who recently died under suspicious circumstances, brought in a verdict that his injuries were not the result of accident, but were inflicted by some person unknown ...

The matrimonial woes of Egide Willems, an aged Belgian, who keeps a beer saloon at No. 144 West Twenty-sixth-street, and his young wife, Henrietta, nee Carlson, were made public yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court, the latter having begun a suit for abandonment.

Ex-Sheriff Francis Kile, of North Wales, Montgomery County, attended the funeral one day this week of his aunt, Catherine Kile, who lived in Richland Township, Bucks County, and died at the advanced age of 98 years.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 7.--Mrs. Webb, widow of the celebrated swimmer who lost his life in the Whirlpool Rapids, Niagara River, last Summer, arrived in this city this afternoon from Boston. She said she had come for the purpose of attending to the final disposition of the remains of Capt. Webb.
Julius Caesar was a juror in Part III. of the City Court yesterday.

The lake at Central Park was thrown open yesterday to skaters for the first time this Winter, except for a few hours Sunday afternoon. Yesterday the familiar flag with the design of the red ball, the signal of skating at the Park, was raised, and the children of all ages and conditions flocked out to the ice.

During the year 1882 there were employed in German factories 123,543 persons under age, including 14,600 between the ages of 12 and 14. As compared with the previous year, these figures show increases, respectively, of 31,800 and 5,253.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7.--Henry Irving opened the season here to-night in "Louis XI." He had a large and fashionable audience, and was most enthusiastically received, getting three recalls after the first act and equally warm demonstrations subsequently. The advance sales were about $10,000, the largest sum ever realized in advance by any dramatic entertainment in this city.

John F. Spengemann, the ex-clerk of the Provident Institution for Savings, in Jersey City, who was arrested in Boston on Friday for forgery, was yesterday arraigned before Judge McGill, an indictment having already been secured.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7.--A communication was received to-day by the representatives of the Alton and the Rock Island Railroads, from Commissioner Pierson, in which he declines to accept the proposition made by those roads on the subject of establishing and maintaining maximum rates of commissions.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 7.--The sale of tickets for the entertainment of the Yale Glee Club which was to have taken place last Saturday evening at the Masonic Temple aggregated about $450.

The separate and silent system has its drawbacks in convents as well as in prisons. There is something to be said, as a matter of conventual discipline, in favor of locking up nuns and novices and schoolgirls over night.

Elise Verdier, the girl who a day or two ago murdered her paramour Weiss, on the morning of his intended marriage, and then shot herself, died yesterday at the hospital to which she land been removed.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 7.--Col. E.L. Getchel, proprietor of a sporting house in this city, was shot and mortally wounded at his place this afternoon by D.H. Chandler, a young desperado from South Carolina. No enmity existed between them, and the shooting was purely wanton. Col. Getchel commanded a Maine regiment during the war. He was a native of Bangor.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 7.--Letters postmarked Memphis, Tenn., have been received from James A. Wallace, the late Cashier of the Bank of Hopkinsville, who decamped with $50,000 of the bank's fund.

After a recess of 10 days the trial of the Feuardent-Di Cesnola libel suit was resumed yesterday in the United States District Court before Judge Shipman and a jury. All of the parties interested in the suit at the beginning were alive and apparently healthy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7.--When the Senate got to work to-day Mr. Anthony, of Rhode Island, was in his seat looking better than at any time since his recovery from his recent severe sickness.

An examination in the case of ex-Assemblyman Thomas P. Walsh, who is charged by Deputy Sheriff Mark Lanigan with assaulting him in City Hall Park on Nov. 19, was held yesterday in the Tombs Police Court, before Justice Smith.
On Dec. 13, 1883, Richard Warren entered the saloon of John Dillon, in the town of Mamaroneck, carrying in his hand a large stone. He picked a quarrel with Dillon, and was ordered out of the place.

The mystery which has so long enshrouded the fate of one of the most remarkable figures in the history of Russian Nihilism may now be regarded as definitely dispelled. I have seen and conversed with Tschernishevsky; have heard his story from his own lips. I found him at his new quarters, in a quiet street near the centre of Astrakhan.

The old and the new Boards of Aldermen met yesterday in the Aldermanic Chamber, the former at 11 o'clock and the latter an hour later. Interest centred in the proceedings of the new board, and the final clap-trap of the men who had done service during 1883 did not attract much attention.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.J., Jan. 7.--While skating on the river to-day William Wilson, a boy, was struck by the ice-yacht Frost, a fourrunner boat, and received injuries that proved fatal. After the accident the man at the tiller lost control of the boat. The boat ran into a snow bank, capsized, and was badly wrecked. Two young women who were on the boat were severely injured.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 7.--Judge Simonton has granted a new trial to William Andrews, convicted of murdering his wife nearly three years ago.
Mr. Charles Lanier, Treasurer of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following contributions up to date:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 7.--Shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon Mrs. Dunlap, wife of Dr. Joseph P. Dunlap, was instantly killed at the Townsend-street crossing of the West Shore Railroad by the train which reaches here at 2:35 P.M. from New-York.

BUFFALO, Jan. 7.--The City Council for 1884 organized to-day by electing R.R. Hefford President. Mayor Scoville's first annual message was received. It shows that the debt of the city is $7,101,581, a reduction of about $16,000 during the past year.

On a petition of a majority of the Directors of the Produce Bank, Judge Lawrence, in ing Supreme Court, Chambers, has made an order directing all persons interested in that institution to show cause before Mr. Henry J. Scudder, as Referee, on April 10 next, why it should not be voluntarily dissolved.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7.--The sub-committee appointed to consider the forfeitures of land grants met to-night and prepared a bill, which will be reported to the Committee on Public Lands to-morrow.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 7.--Alexander Turiffe, another of the men wounded in the recent railway disaster at the Humber, died to-day in the hospital.

The Bureau of Engraving and Printing is just completing its addition to the Cabinet album for the present Administration. It is a custom for the bureau to prepare fine steel engravings of each President and his Cabinet.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 7.--There is a cut and dried aspect to the Speakership contest this evening that robs it of most of its excitement. The caucuses will not be held until morning.
John Murphy was the only witness examined by Justice Duffy, yesterday, in the proceedings against Police Officer Smith for shooting and killing Thomas Fitzpatrick on Christmas morning.

The camels which were imported and used for some time in carrying goods and freight across the dry wastes of Arizona were, after the completion of the Southern Pacific Road, turned loose and allowed to roam away as being of no further use.

A meeting of representatives of Hebrew and German societies and of Hebrew congregations was held last evening in the basement of the Temple Emanu-El to make arrangements for the funeral of the late Dr. Edouard Lasker, member of the German Reichstag.

Mr. Charles Delmonico, the restaurateur, had not returned to his home yesterday; his friends had heard nothing which would give a clue to his whereabouts, and the police, after 48 hours' search throughout the City, had failed to find any trace of him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7.--A decision was rendered in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day in the patent case of Jacob Estey et al. against Riley Burdett, brought here upon appeal from the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Vermont.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 7.--A range in the residence of Robert Matthews, on Bedfordstreet, exploded yesterday, completely demolishing the furniture in the room where the explosion occurred and quite seriously injuring Mr. Matthews's two daughters. The youngest, a mere child, was badly scaled and burned, and it is feared she also inhaled some steam. Frozen water pipes caused the accident.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 7.--The cold weather of last week steadily grew worse until Friday and Saturday nights, when the mercury touched zero. Such weather in this latitude is productive of the most dreadful consequences among the poor, who are prepared neither with shelter, food, nor provisions for such a state of things.

President George Stephen, of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, has issued a circular to the shareholders, in which he says that in view of the gross misstatements that have been published as to the position of the company, the Directors have thought it well, in advance of the regular annual report, to submit a short summary of what has been done.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 7.--A blizzard has raged in Ontario for four days, with varied intensity in different localities. On Thursday night an old woman, living alone in a tumble down house in the East Ward, at Collingwood ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7.--The case of Lucius Doolittle, a farmer of Woodbridge, which was to have come before the Probate Court in this city to-day, has been amicably settled by the parties interested.

About 3,000 persons of varying shades of respectability and of no respectability at all assembled in Madison-Square Garden last evening to see Mr. Joe Pendergrast "knock out" Mr. Hughy Burns, or vice versa, in accordance with the rules of the late lamented Marquis of Queensberry.

It was stated at the Northern Pacific Railroad office yesterday that the committee appointed to nominate a successor to ex-President Villard had held no meeting.

JOHNSTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 7.--The project to dismember Hamilton County is, as might be expected, meeting with considerable opposition. It is claimed that the expense of maintaining a county government, while somewhat high for the ...
Chief-Justice Peters, of the Maine Supreme Court, has received a letter from Justice Barrows, whose term will expire March 25 next, in which he states that he would decline a reappointment.

ALBANY, Jan. 7.--In casting about for an Aqueduct Commissioner Gov. Cleveland has from the first considered that his choice should be a representative business man. He offered the vacant position to Messrs. D. Willis James and Samuel D. Babcock, both of whom declined it for business reasons.

Mayor Low's third annual message was not publicly read yesterday in the Common Council Chamber, owing to the failure of the new Board of Alderman to organize. It was filed, however, with the City Clerk, and therefore became public property.
LONDON, Jan. 7.--It is stated that Spain intends to declare Port Mahon a free port. Mr. Charles Santley, the baritone singer, was married yesterday to Miss Elizabeth Innes, a wealthy American lady.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 7.--Speaker Sheard, after being secreted for three days in Albany, returned to Herkimer to-night. Why he should have found it necessary to go into retirement at all is a puzzle.

A married woman, called Van der Linden, aged 45 years, mother of three children, is charged at Leiden with having murdered 16 persons in the course of a few years. The victims were nearly all members of her family, on whose ...

CAIRO, Jan. 7.--The Egyptian Ministry tendered their resignations to the Khedive at 8 o'clock this evening. Cheriff Pasha accompanied the resignations with a letter to the khedive explaining the reasons for this action. The Khedive accepted the resignations, but requested the Ministers to remain in office until their successors are appointed.

In the course of a lecture upon "England and America, as Rivals and Allies" at Chickering Hall last evening Joseph Cook said that one of the great questions confronting the two nations was how to rule the great cities.

Mr. Samuel D. Tilden, the Hartford merchant who, on Dec. 28, fell into the clutches of "Keister Bob" and "Spanish Joe," the eminent bunco men, and was induced to give checks to the amount of $2,850, denies that he gambled with dice or otherwise at the house in East Fourthstreet where he was taken.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8.--The hearing of witnesses on the petition for a winding up order by a certain number of the creditors of the New-York Graphic Company was commenced this morning before Mr. Justice Rainville. Mr. J.L. Morris appeared for the petitioners and Mr. Bethune for the company.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 8.--The mystery surrounding the murdered girl found near the cemetery here on Sunday deepens. It has been learned positively that it is not the body of Fannie Gaskell, as she is alive and well; neither is it the body of Mary Gaskell, of Watkins, as she was in the city this morning with her father.

FONDA, N.Y., Jan. 8.--The weather moderated this afternoon, after one of the most persistent and bitter cold snaps ever known in Central New-York. For a week the mercury has ranged from zero to 15 and 20 below, and the suffering among the people has been great. Tonight a heavy snow-storm has set in.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--The proceedings of the Supreme Court of the United States to-day were us follows: No. 179--The Quebec Bank of Toronto, appellant, vs. Max Hellman, Assignee, Argument continued.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 8.--Mrs. Mary C. Vermilye's answer to the complaint of Daniel Vermilye in his action for divorce and the custody of their child was filed here to-day. She denies that her husband is a citizen of Minnesota and says he was obliged to flee from the State in 1882 to avoid arrest for certain swindling transactions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8, 1884. It is probable that another call for 3 per cent. bonds will be issued during the present week.

Both the Democratic factions held caucuses in the City Hall yesterday afternoon, and it is not improbable that a plan has been agreed upon which may end the existing dead-lock over the organization of the Board of Aldermen.

DES MOINES, Jan. 8.--Ninety-six survivors of the Mexican war held a reunion to-day, their ages ranging from 53 to 71. They marched in a body to the executive office this afternoon and were shown through the new capitol by Gov. Sherman.

SAVANNAH, Jan. 8.--Last Summer, when the Government decided to sell the Oglethorpe barracks in this city, a company comprising 100 enterprising business men was formed for the purpose of buying the property and erecting on it a magnificent hotel.
The Fire Commissioners have decided to "double up" eight companies in the department, in addition to those companies which were so reinforced during the past year.
President A.S. Hatch announced from the rostrum of the Stock Exchange yesterday morning the fact of Julius Hallgarten's sudden death at Davos, Switzerland, on Monday.

In transmitting to the Legislature the annual report prepared by his predecessor, Controller Chapin calls the attention of the Legislature to the extraordinary opportunity now offered for a decided reduction of the burdens of taxation.
Mayor Edson yesterday completed the appointments of the Civil Service Examiners for the municipal departments. Those he has appointed are Dr. Thomas H. Burchardt, F. Tilden Brown, ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 8--Steel smelters in the employ of Hussey, Howe Co. were notified to-day that on and after Monday next they will be paid only $5 per ton for their work instead of $6 25, the present rate, giving as a reason the depression in trade and the necessity of a reduction to keep the works running.

The coffin factory of Smith, Winston Co., at Nos. 191 and 193 Chrystie-street, was destroyed by fire yesterday morning. Its' destruction was, in a great measure, due to the scarcity of water in the district, many of the fire engines summoned to the scene being unable to obtain sufficient to supply an effective stream.
LONDON, Jan. 8.--Two thousand steelworkers refused to resume work at the reduction of wages proposed by the masters.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8.--The recent developments in the medical colleges in relation to grave robberies in the vicinity of Chicago have excited general attention which was not lessened to-day by the discovery of a new case which in one way is a strange commentary on the brutality of some of the students.
CLEVELAND, Ohio. Jan. 8.--The annual meeting of the National Bank of Commerce was held to-day, and the temporary disarrangement made by the retirement of President Everett was made right.

BOSTON, Jan. 8.--The United States has brought a civil suit against Goodrich H. Bush, of Westfield, a distiller, for the recovery of $80,000 alleged to be due the Government on transactions of the defendant's distillery. The defendant was prosecuted in March last on a criminal charge and acquitted.

Twenty-six demure-looking young women in blue and white seersucker dresses and French muslin caps were seated on a raised platform in the parlor of the Training School for Nurses, in East Twenty-sixth-street, last night.

There was nothing new developed yesterday relative to the withdrawal of Mr. Ford and Mr. Buckley from their respective positions of President and vice-President in the National Bank of the Republic. Mr. Ford stated that there was not a word to add to the account published in yesterday's TIMES, as it completely covered the case.

There is generally supposed to be some great scheme afoot to secure this good land for the French. It is said that when a farm is for sale it not uncommonly happens that a French buyer is willing to give a very much higher price for it than any English buyer would feel justified in giving, and the money is said to be often obtained through one channel or another from ecclesiastical sources.

It is always gratifying to know that a man has not suffered by his devotion to the public good. And certainly we have this satisfaction in the cases of the counsel who nobly abandoned their private practice in order to bring BRADY and DORSEY to justice.

The report of the Superintendent of State Prisons for the year ending Sept. 30, 1883, was sent to the Legislature last night. It shows that the earnings of Sing Sing Prison were $237,238 48: of Auburn, $125,280 30, and of Clinton, $44,542 80.

PARIS, Jan. 8.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Henri Brisson was re-elected President by a vote of 224 out of 298 votes recorded. The Debats states that the Government will not submit the bill for the revision of the Constitution until after Easter. It will be first introduced in the Senate.

The faces of many Chinese laundrymen in this City are almost as long as their pig-tails. Desolation and the Sheriff are at their doors and sorrow, mingled with disgust, in their souls. The immediate cause of this funereal depression is found in a fact which was published in yesterday's TIMES.

No reply was received at Commissioner Fink's once yesterday to the letter sent Mr. Samuel Sloan, President of the Delaware, Lacka,wanna and Western Road, warning him to desist from making time contracts on through freight at less than pool rates.

BOSTON, Jan. 8.--The annual meeting of the Democratic State Central Committee, held here to-day, was largely attended. Noah A. Plympton, of Worcester, was unanimously elected Chairman in place of Jonus H. French, ...
LONDON, Jan. 8.--The Paris Morning News to-day publishes an editorial severely commenting on the "imbecility" displayed by the American State Department in the O'Donnell correspondence.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 8.--At an early hour this morning Miss Miller, a dress-maker, doing a large business here, committed suicide by jumping from the new iron bridge across the ravine at Rosedale, a distance of 164 feet to the ground below. She was instantly killed. She had been suffering from desnondency for some time.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 8.--Cornelius Ryan was shot and fatally wounded this morning by John Hansberry, a livery stable keeper. Ryan fired twice at Hansberry, but without effect. The difficulty grew out of a dispute about yeserday's city election.
Mr. Lawrence Barrett is at the Grand Opera-house this week, with his successful play "Francesca da Rimini."

This fell under the eyes of Sheriff King, of Monroe County, who telegraphed Sheriff Rose at Lexington to arrest the suspected man and bring ...

LONDON, Jan. 8.--The Government of the Dutch East Indies has sent a body of troops to the west coast of of Acheen to compel the Rajah, who holds in captivity the crew of the steamer Misero, which was wrecked there in November, to surrender them.

John R. Williams, a stevedore, who has for some time past held a contract for the loading and unloading of the steam-ships of the Hill Line, at the foot of Sixty-fifth-street and the North River, failed last week to pay the longshoremen who had been employed in loading the Ludgate Hill.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8.--The action of Commissioner Pierson in discriminating against the Alton and the Rock Island has had its natural effect, and to-morrow a war on passenger rates will be begun, which unless one of the parties to the fight backs down, will have serious effects.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 8.--There is considerable excitement in Granvilie, Washington County, to-day over the death of Justice Guilford, a prominent and life-long resident of that place, through an alleged mistake of a druggist. It is said that extract of valerian was called for, and the druggist, R.W. Jones thought he put such extract in the bottle and labeled it as such.

Ex-Senator David Davis is now President of the Illinois State Bar Association. A Democratic paper in South Carolina takes decided ground that in a Democratic State all its Federal officers should be Democrates.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 8.--At 11 o'clock this morning the police were notified that a young woman was on the Harbor Piers attempting to commit suicide. An officer was dispatched to take the woman in charge and conduct her to the police station.

That a sinking fund is of any great practical value in dealing with a large debt may well be doubted. It simply adds, one more promise to those involved in the debt, and is of no more binding force and no more likely to be observed than the latter.

The Dry Goods Mutual Benefit Association held its eighth annual meeting last night in the St. Nicholas Hotel. The Treasurer's report set forth that during the past year five members had died, and that the present membership was 580.

LONDON, Jan., 8.--A private telegram to the Times from Egypt states that Nubar Pasha, who was the Egyptian Minister of War in 1878, has accepted the Premiership of the new Ministry, and has appoinnted Mr. Edgar Vincent Minister of Finance.

Over 30 years ago the Chapman family, well known on the Pacific coast, had a floating theatre on the Mississippi River. Uncle George Chapman and wife were fond of relating stories of their experience in their floating playhouse.

The utterances of the Rev. R. Heber Newton in his recent course of sermons on the Pentateuch are considered by several of his brethren in the Episcopal Church as even more radical than those of a year ago, which called forth the presentation of charges against him for heresy, and they have awakened an inquiry as to what have become of the old charges.

There can be no question about the influence of music upon the processes of thought and emotion; and disease, we know, is very largely a matter of thinking and feeling. Why, then, should not disease be checked and controlled by the application of a concord of given sounds as well as by the swallowing of a prescribed course of pills or powders?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Commander W.B. Hoff has been ordered to special duty at the Navy Department; Surgeon Daniel McMurtrie to duty at the Naval Rendezvous, Philadelphia; Passed Assistant Surgeon, H.C. Eckstein has been detached from the Naval Hospital, Philadelphia, and ordered to the ...
RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 8.--To-day the second trial race of the ice-yachts of the Shrewsbury Club took place with the wind blowing at the rate of 20 miles an hour.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 8.--The Legislature convened in regular session to-day, and both houses organized. R.O. Reynolds was elected President pro tem, of the Senate, and W.M. Inge Speaker of the House. The Legislature then ad-- journed uutil to-morrorw, when the Governor's message will be delivered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7.--The city has filled up rapidly during the past few days. There are a variety of interests which may be affected by the action of Congress, and the people concerned are here to look after them.

A foundry wagon, at Fulton and Cliff streets, blocked the stream of travel flowing to the ferries about 6 o'clock last evening. As the vehicle rounded the corner three impatient men made a break to cross the street. A moment later three profane men wallowed in the mud and three derbys rolled under the feet of the hurrying throng.

BRIDGEPORT, Jan. 8.--Judge A.B. Beers rendered his decision this morning in the cases of Capt. James Bunter, John Stewart, and John Mayhew, of the Salvation Army, who were tried several days ago for a violation of the recent city ordinance by parading the streets.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan 8.--The twelfth annual meeting of the Commercial Travelers' Association of New-York was held here to-day, 400 members attending. At the morning session the reports of the officers were submitted.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 8.--The last day of the contest for the Ohio Senatorship was one long to be remembered, for Columbus has never before been so afflicted. No State convention ever met here in which the very air was so fully charged with corruption as has prevailed during the past week.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8.--The Rev. John B. Stansbury testified to-day against John F. Williams, Henry H. Phillips, and John Norcom, Trustees of the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church, who threw him out of that edifice on Sunday, Dec. 30, because he preached without their consent.

The Pinkertons here at work all day yesterday on the clues obtained of Mr. Delmonico's movements after he left his home on Saturday, but if they discovered anything the manager kept it closely to himself.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8.--Well signed petitions have been presented to Chief of Police Webster protesting against the licensing of the Jesse James Combination, which has arranged to give a performance in this city.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 8.--Thursday, last week, Charles Wright and a man named Turcott started to walk on the ice from Clayton to Gananoque. At the head of Grindstone Island Wright gave out, being overpowered by the storm, and he made for shore.
ALABANY, N.Y., Jan. 8.--The annual meeting of the State Bar Association was held here this morning. Gov. Cleveland presided in the absence of Chief-Judge Ruger, President, who is detained by illness.

Ex-Speaker John Egan, of the New-Jersey Assembly, appeared yesterday before the Essex Court of Quarter Sessions at Newark and formally retracted his original plea of not guilty to the indictment charging him with attempted bribery, and entered a plea of non vult.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 8.--The attempt to hold a Democratic caucus at Froukfort tonight to nominatd a United States Senator was defeated, leaving Williams on the wrong side of the fence by a small majority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Mr. Charles Stoughton, who tried unsuccessfully in the Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Congresses to have the Secretary of War authorized to contract with him for the improvement of the Harlem River, is already making earnest efforts to have the bill passed by the present Congress.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 8.--Ex-Congressman George West, the millionaire paper maker of Ballston Springs, Chicago, and NewYork, in a long interview on the tariff, published in the Schenectady Union, agrees with Congressman Hewitt that protection has overstimulated American manufactures, but says the result has ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 8.--Mary H. Vermilye yesterday filed an answer to the suit of Daniel B. Vermilye for divorce. She denies the accusations against her, which involved Gen. William Myers, and charges her husband with being a habitual drunkard, a gambler, and a man of disrepute. She also alleges that he has endeavored to black-mail Gen. Myers. In a crossbill for divorce she asks for the custody of their child.

For nearly six hours yesterday Judge Shipman and his jury listened to some testimony, considerable oratory, and numerous quarrels between Messrs. Bangs and Choate, who are the senior counsel in the Feuardent-Di Cesnola libel suit.

As the owner of premises on West Thirty-ninth-street adjoining those of the New-York Concert Company, John Galligan brought an equity suit in the Superior Court to restrain the company from constructing a big bay window, with an ornamental superstructure, on the front of the Casino.

The annual sale of seats at Plymouth Church took place last evening, the building being thronged despite the storm. The seats and aisle chairs in the church are assessed at $12,833. Last year, in addition to this annual rental, the premiums paid for the seats aggregated $25,338 50.
Frederick Gustav Hardtmann, a German rope-maker, 21 years old, was committed to the Tombs on Dec. 22 for attempting to shoot Augustus Gardner, a watchman at the Stewart mansion.

BOSTON, Jan. 8.--A decision in a peculiar case has just been rendered by the Supreme Court. Mrs. Hardy, a Spiritualist, was, in 1869, married to John Hardy. Subsequently, by mutual agreement and by the payment to Hardy of $5,000, he procured a divorce in Utah.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 8.--The dead-list of the Immaculate Conception Convent fire grows in size as the search continues, and it is now said that 37 women and children lost their lives by the fire.
The King County Republican General Committee for 1884 met last evening at Music Hall, Flatbush and Fulton avenues, Brooklyn, and organized by the election of David A. Baldwin as President, and ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--In response to a resolution offered in the Senate by Mr. Van Wyck on Dec. 13 calling on the Secretary of the Treasury to furnish to the Senate copies of vouchers and items audited by the First Auditor on account of expenses incurred by the Department

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--The report of Brewster Cameron, General Agent of the Department of Justice, to Attorney General Brewster shows that from Feb. 1, 1882 to Jan. 1, 1884, the accounts of 265 Marshals and deputies, Attorneys, Clerks of Courts, Commissioners, Supervisors of Election, and other Government court officers, ...

And so Brig.-Gen. JOHN COCHRANE has left us. Left us, not for the sake of a ribbon to wear in his coat, not even for a place in the Custom-house or for a mess of pottage. He has left, as his compatriots of Montgomery County would say, "Out of pure cussedness."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 8.--The granting by Judge Blandin, of the Common Pleas Court, of a perpetual injunction, asked by Socfield, Shumer Teagle against the Lake-Shore and Michigan Southern Road, preventing the defendants making a discrimination in freights in favor of the Standard Oil Company, has created unusual ...

PROVIDENCE R.I., Jan. 8.--The schooner Adrianna, ashore on Block Island, is a total loss. The Captain says the disaster was due to the variation of the compass, caused by the presence of metals. The bodies of the two men frozen to death have been recovered. That of the cook has been buried, and that of the mate sent to his late home, Gardiner, Me.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 8.--The annual report of the City Auditor published to-day gives a favorable showing for 1883. The net in debtedness Dec. 1, 1883, was $601,807 39, against an indebtedness on Dec. 1, 1882, of $631.907 35. decrease of debt of about $30,000.
A committee of the City Reform Club is engaged in preparing a bill to be presented at Albany in a few days, which will embody four amendments to the charter of this City.
Representatives of property-owners living north of West Eightieth-street occupied the attention of the Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday.
Catharine Safstrom, a woman in her forties, was a complainant, yesterday, in the Essex Market Police Court, against Christian Peterson, age 26, whom she charged with abandonment.
DES MOINES, Jan. 8.--The Cane-growers' Association met to-day, and the addresses were numerous and encouraging, all agreeing that the day of cheap and good sugar from sorghum is near at hand.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--The Senate spent most of its session to-day in debate upon the question of referring appropriation bills to various committees instead of the Committee on Appropriations.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 8.--Kitty Lenhaff, age 6, was horribly burned last night in the house of her parents in the north-eastern section of this city. Her clothing ignited while she was playing with the fire. She died this afternoon.

Among the many interesting article which are treasured up in the Cluny Museum, there is said to be a brass plate with an engraved inscription which once was fastened to the coffin of Louis XIV., and afterward, in 1793, was ...
SCHENECTADY, Jan. 8.--Jacob Henry, a clothing-dealer, who resided here 32 years ago, befriended a friendless Frenchman, Jules Carparche, and started him in business.

Chickering Hall was comfortably filled last night, notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather, with ladies and gentlemen who had come to hear the Rev. Dr. Tiffany, a member of the Geographical Society, lecture upon "Norway and the Midnight Sun."

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 8.--A large meeting was held at the Stock Exchange to-night to organize a cremation society and make preparations for erecting a crematory for the burning of the dead. Dr. Felix Formento presided, and Eugene H. Levy acted as Secretary. Plans were fully discussed, and it was determined to proceed at once.

The three Chinamen who were arrested in connection with the murder of Hop Zee, alias Loo Ling, alias Sam Sing, were brought up for examination yesterday before Coroner Martin. They seemed very scared at the proceedings, and stole surreptitious glances at one another from time to time. Loo Foon, who was thought to be the brother of the murdered man, was sworn, ...

BERLIN, Jan. 8.--It has been learned that numerous factory employes in Perm, Russia, have been arrested, and revolutionary documents discovered in their possession. Among the workmen of Perm there is a Socialist propaganda, and Socialism is rapidly spreading among the working population.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Congress now has before it two schemes looking to the establishment of a Bureau of Labor Statistics.

In the Supreme Court, Circuit, Brooklyn, yesterday, before Judge Cullen and a jury the trial was commenced of the suit brought by Bridget Cronin, a young girl of 18, against the Rev. Father Florence McCarthy, Pastor of St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church, at North Henry and Herbert streets, for criminal assault.

At the annual meeting of the Bar Association, last evening, officers were chosen for the ensuing year as follows: President--James C. Carter; Vice-Presidents--Aaron J. Vanderpoel, William Allen Butler, John E. Parsons, ...
The officers of the Oregon Transcontinental Company have, it is announced, made an arrangement for a loan of $8,000,000 with which to pipe out its floating debt.

A wooden sign, which hung over M.L. Doyle's dry goods store, at Grand and Forsyth streets, fell last night at 11 o'clock upon Moses Bernstein, who was walking in the street with his sister. The sign, which is about 40 feet in length by 2 in height, struck the man on the head and knocked him to the ground.

TROY, Jan. 8.--John F. Kane, of this city, died to-day of quick consumption, after an illness of only a few months. For 37 years he beat a bass drum in Doring's Band. He was drummer with the band in the Second Regiment, under Lieut-Col. Carr. He afterward re-enlisted as Drum-Major in the Sixteenth Regiment, NewYork Volunteers. He was 56 years of age.

In response to a communication from Chief Clerk Hawley, of the Police Depertment, Corporation Counsel Andrews writes that in his opinion the only duty of the police respecting the removal of snow and ice from the sidewalks and gutters is to see that violations of the ordinances are promptly reported to the Corporation.

LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 8.--About two miles from Andover, and perhaps five miles from Lowell, stands an old stone church that has seen a hundred years flit over its antequated roof, and in the neighboring graveyard repose the respected bones of genuine descendants of the Plymouth pilgrims.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 8.--The wife of Leo Greeley, a farmer, nine miles from Schenectady, was visiting here last night. Her mental condition is not good and she wandered from her husband in the bitter cold last night and started alone to walk home.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 8.--The body of Farrell, the pauper who was frozen to death on Friday night, having been handed over by the authorities to a medical college, some Swede acquaintances of the deceased man this A.M. swore out a writ of replevin for the corpse and secured its delivery into a patrol wagon before the scalpel had done its work. The body was decently interred.
BERLIN, Jan. 8.--Emperor William has addressed a letter in reply to the address of congratulation sent by the magistrates of Berlin upon the occasion of the recurrence of New Year's Day.

The two watchmen, Joseph Devlin and Keenan, and Herman Van Seggern, the bartender of the saloon in which the trouble which ended in the killing of Thomas Fitzpatrick occurred, were examined in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday.
The Evening Post Company, of this City, filed with the Secretary of State on Monday a certificate of reduction of its capital stock from $200,000 to $100,000.

The most carefully considered statement which we have yet had concerning the present condition of the canals of this State and the effect of a remission of tolls is contained in the financial report of the State Controller in regard to these waterways.

A dispatch from Washington last night stated that Postmaster-General Gresham had decided to permit the establishment of 100 postal stations in this City, and to allow $24 per annum for the maintainance of each.

John Duryea, the Glen Cove starch manufacturer, was charged with perjury some time ago in a suit for an infringement of a patent. When Mr. Duryea appeared before United States Commissioner Griffith for examination the printed deposition of Mr. Duryea, on which the charge of perjury was founded, was submitted.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 8.--A fatal shooting scrape happened at Covington, on the Chesapeake, Ohio and South-western Railway, about 40 miles north of this city last night, of which but meagre particulars were learned to-day.

The preliminary pool tournament was virtually concluded last night, although the tie for second and third places remains to be played off to-night. Malone defeated Dunning badly last evening, and thus completed a clean score of nine victories.

ALBANY, N.Y.,Jan. 8.--Speaker Sheard announced the Assembly Committees to-night, and the House, after listening to the reading of the list, and the list also of the Speaker and Clerk Chickering's appointees, immediately adjourned.

TRENTON, Jan. 8.--The war betweenStoney and Chapman for the Speakership began almost as soon as the Democratic clans hadassembled in the Assembly Chamber this morning. It had been arranged by the Stoney party that Neighbour should be Chairman of the caucus, but Flynn, conspicuous as a Chapman man, ...

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 8.--The following is a list of the first 50 cases on the Court of Appeals calendar for the term beginning Monday, Jan. 14, 1884: Nos. 1 to 50, inclusive--Peogle vs. McKeon, People vs. Smith, People vs. Courtney, People vs. Kelly, ...

PHILADELPHIIA, Jan. 8.--Maud Melville, the eldest daughter of Chief Engineer Melville, who without permission left the school at West Chester, where she had been placed by her father in compliance with the decree of the ...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 8.--The funeral of Ollie Major and Sarah Marsden, the two young women of Forty Fort who were drowned in the Susquehanna on Saturday, took place this afternoon, and despite the inclemency of the weather was largely attended, the church being crowded long before the hour announced for the services, which were very impressive. The bodies of the two ladies were buried in the same grave.

NEW-HAVEN. Conn., Jan. 8.--William Richardson, of Cheshire, a boyish-looking fellow 18 years old, pleaded not guilty in the Superior Court to-day to a charge of theft from the person and assault with intent to murder on the night of Nov. 29 last. Richardson, while drunk, quarreled with an old man, John Barry, because the latter would not drink with him.

FREEHOLD, N.J., ,Jan. 8.--Samuel Brower, age 70, one of the oldest farmers of Monmouth County, hanged himself yesterday at his home near Farmingdale in a fit of temporary insanity. After being missed for several hours his body was found hanging in the old log-house in which he was born.

BOSTON, Jan. 8.--The Democratic State Committee organized to-day for the campaign this year, and afterward with their guests, men of more or less distinction, celebrated "Jackson day" by a banquet, with speeches.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 8.--Another examination for admission to the Government service under the new civil service rules was held in this city to-day. Commissioner Thoman was present, but the examination was conducted by a local board consisting of William Grasser, Superintendent ...

LONDON, Jan. 8.--The London Echo was in a West End police court to-day as an interested party to one of the most ludicrous cases which ever convulsed a, court. The defendant was arraigned upon two charges.

BOSTON, Jan. 8.--For the past two or three years periodical reductions of wages have taken place among the Eastern nailers, and now the workmen have again received a notification that on and after Jan. 14 there will be another general reduction of 15 per cent.

Fire Commissioners Purroy, Van Cott, and Croker watched the working of a telegraphic and telephonic protector, yesterday morning, at the main station of the United States Electric Light Company, No. 36 Stantonstreet.

Early yesterday a notice was posted in the Produce Exchange that 253,457 bushels of wheat in Dows's Stores, in Brooklyn, were out of condition. In view of the fact that 251,000 bushels of fed wheat had been posted the day before in the Clinton Stores the heavy feeling in the market for wheat was aggravated and prices suffered a further material decline.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 8.--John J. Dunn, a well-known contractor, and Henry Hosey and Charles Kleperdick, workmen, were precipitated from a scaffold this morning a distance of 50 feet into the basement of a new building upon which they were working. Dunn was instantly killed and the others cannot live.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Mr. F.C. Morehead, Commissioner-General of the World's Industrial and Cotton Centennial Exposition, to be opened next December in New-Orleans, is in Washington looking after the interest of the proposed show.

If there is anything more disagreeable than to hear a violent barking from a dog within, after ringing a door-bell, it is to be obliged to wait on a cold and dark door-steep while some one lights the hall gas-light.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 8.--The Erie County Medical Society held its annual meeting to-day. The Committee on Legislation made a report concerning the efforts made to have a bill passed by the Legislature for the establishment of a State Board of Examiners.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 8.--The question of fence or no fence was passed upon to-day by the voters of Richmond County. The majority for abolishig fences in the county will be about 600. Pubic sentiment in Georgia is growing in favor of doing away with fences on farms and in favor of fencing in cattle and other stock.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 8.--The remains of Father Lawrence Walsh lay in state in the cathedral last night. The funeral service took place this morning. Bishop Hendricks delivered an impressive eulogy. The remains were entombed in St. Francis Cemetery.

Israel Potter, a colored man, went to the house of Mr. James C. Townsend, in the village of Oyster Bay, gesterday morning at 8 o'clock, and found it apparently closed. He supposed that Mr. and Mrs. Townsend were still sleeping in bed.
ATLANTA, Jan. 8.--Two suits have been entered on record in the courts of this county which recall a singular incident of the reconstruction days of Georgia.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 8.--Information has just been received from Stillwater that the prison yards of the State penitentiary are burning.

The annual meeting of the National Rifle Association took place in the armory of the Twenty-second Regiment last evening. A communication was received from Gen. Grant stating that "a recent accident" prevented him from presiding at the meeting.

Gen. B.H. Bristow, ex-Judge William G. Choate, and Harvey M. Shepard appeared before Judge Shipman in the United States Circuit Court yesterday to make an application for a rehearing in the matter of the appointment of a Receiver of the New-York and New-England Railroad.
The steam-ship Nutford, Capt. Torrey, which arrived from Cow Bay Sunday evening, grounded on the Springhouse Reef, near the east end of Governor's Island, shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
Mr. Rutherford's gift of instruments to the Observatory of Columbia College is valued at about $18,000.

Conrad Kuhn, a German, about 45 years old, hired Room No. 50 at the Van Dyke House, Bowery and Bayard-street, Monday night, and yesterday morning he was found unconscious in the room from inhaling illuminating gas, which was escaping from the burner.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Special efforts have been made by the friends of Congressman Willis's bill to extend the time for payment of the tax on distilled spirits now in warehouse to induce Internal Revenue Commissioner Evans to express an opinion favorable to the measure.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 8.--The saloon of Kelland Brothers, on one of the principal streets of this town, was not opened as usual to-day, and frequenters of the place were not a little surprised to find it closed. The brothers are both young and single. They lived in rooms over the saloon.

New-Jersey has a law encouraging the formation of "detective agencies," and Paterson, N.J., has been favored with several of these organizations. How they are sometimes worked transpired in a complaint made yesterday afternoon before the Recorder by Horace N. Bolton, of Hamburg-avenue, that city.

The Nineteenth Century Club, at a meeting at the home of Mr. Courtlandt Palmer, No. 117 Past Twenty-first-street, last evening, listened to an address on the American drama by Judge George C. Barrett, whose new play, "An American Wife," was produced at Wallack's Theatre a few weeks ago.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 8.--Lawrence Harrigan was elected Chief of Police, at the Commissioners' meeting this afternoon. Harrigan is known throughout the country in police circles, having been Chief of Police and chief of detectives for many years. His appointment receives

MONTREAL, Jan. 8.--A stormy meeting of the shareholders of the Montreal Loan and Mortgage Company, with which the defaulting President of the Exchange Bank, Thomas Craig, was prominently connected, and of which his brother, held a W. Craig, was General Manager, was held to-day.

There was considerable weather yesterday of various degrees of merit as the average pedestrian learned to his sorrow. The morning broke cloudy, but snow soon fell at intervals until the middle of the afternoon, when rain sprinkled down, and before midnight a storm of unusual violence was upon the City.

Hattie V. Clyde, who is 18 years old, and said that her home was a resort in West Twentyeighth-street, was a prisoner yesterday at Jefferson Market Police Court, at the instance of John R. Cummings, of No. 288 West Houston-street.

There is no better proof how small and monotonous the world is growing than the resignation of a Ministry in Egypt because it is "prevented from governing in accordance with the Constitution."

The tie between Manning and Leonard for second place in the preliminary pool tournament was decided last night by a victory for the former by 11 games to 9. Leonard played but indifferently, while his antagonist was in much better form than when he was beaten so badly by Malone the night before. This defeat gives Leonard third prize. The grand tournament will begin to-night with games between Frey and Leonard and Malone and Lambert.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 9.--The Dramatic Festival Association has been reorganized by the election of S.A. Whitfield, (Postmaster,) President, vice Gen. E.F. Noyes, resigned; Frank Alter, Vice-President; O.O. Hall, Secretary; William A. Stevens, Treasurer, and R.E.J. Miles, Dramatic Director.
CORK, Jan. 9.--It is announced that Francis Mahoney, of Blarney, County Cork, will be the Liberal candidate for the seat in the House of Commons which was made vacant by the resignation of John Daly.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 9.--The police have discovered little that throws light upon the identity of the murdered girl who was found near the cemetery here.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 9.--A bill for an injunction restraining John T. Ford and Charles E. Ford from giving a performance of "The Beggar Student," now being played in Washington by Ford's company, was to-day filed in the Circuit Court of Baltimore city for John A. McCaull, of New-York.

At its annual meeting, yesterday, the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation adopted resolutions favoring the immediate improvement of the Erie Canal in accordance with the recommendations of ex-Controller Davenport.

At the New-York City Eisteddfod, to be held on Feb. 22 next, prizes will be given for the best prose compositions, poems, translations, recitations, works of art, music, (instrumental and vocal,) and musical compositions.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange yesterday listed $2,000,000 of additional first mortgage trust bonds of the Oregon and Transcontinental Company.
NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 9.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad Company was held in this city to-day.
Joseph D. Marone was bailed in $1,000 in Jersey City yesterday, to answer to a suit for damages brought against him by William E. Greenleaf and wife.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 9.--Jay Gould's yacht, the Atalanta, arrived here from the Delaware at about 3 o'clock this afternoon, with George Gould on board. She experienced heavy weather during the passage. She remains here, awaiting orders.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9.--The cattle receipts were only a little less than for the day before. They were more than ordinarily liberal for the time of year, and, following so closely on the heels of the 9,282 reported for Tuesday, caused buyers to operate with increased caution.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 9.--W. Mara, a stock broker here, yesterday posted up the name of Priestman, the manager of Bradstreet's agency here at Stock Exchange, as a defaulter. A committee was appointed to inquire into tho matter and finding Mara correct they placed Priestman's name on the defaulter's list.

HONG KONG, Jan. 9.--An explosion which occurred at Ha-noi, on Dec. 28, destroyed two batteries of French artillery. One man was killed and three were injured. Several houses and the barracks of the battery were badly damaged.

Preparations have been completed for the reception and ball of the "Old Guard" at the Metropolitan Opera-house to-night, and all the indications are that the affair will be one of the most successful of the many entertainments ...

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 9.--Irving W. Bingham, a farmer living in Salisbury, Herkimer County, went into the woods Monday morning to prepare for drawing bark, saying he might go through to his brother's house. As he did not return Tuesday Parties went in search of him, and report is received that he was found this evening in the woods frozen stiff. He leaves a widow and family.
Bartley Campbell has begun a suit to compel Mrs. Langtry to cease using the word "Peril" as the title of the play her company is now performing at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre.

Donizetti's tuneful opera "L'Elisir d'Amore" was given once more at the Academy last evening. We had occasion to comment on the infrequency of the presentation of this work when it was produced earlier in the season.

CAIRO, Jan. 9.--Nubar Pasha assumed office to-day as Prime Minister. The recruiting of black troops under Zebehr Pasha has been abandoned. The Government is undecided as to whether it will recall Baker Pasha from Suakim, whither he has gone to arrange for a campaign against El Mahdi.

Mr. George Riddle made his reappearance here yesterday morning at the Madison Club Theatre. Although the weather was detestable, Mr. Riddle's audience was numerous and cordial. He may, without doubt, count upon success for his new and impressive course of readings.

READING, Penn., Jan. 9.--Warrants were issued to-day against Osmond Geier, who was formerly connected with several building associations, and Henry Rekenfuge, another official similarly connected, charging them with conspiracy and the embezzlement of the funds of stockholders. LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 9.--The whole family of John H. Bonesteel, of the town of Wilson, Niagara County, has been prostrated with diphtheria. Three of the children have died since the 5th inst., and both parents and the only remaining child are dangerously ill with the same disease. It has not been epidemic in any part of the county this Winter, but much uneasiness is felt lest it should become so.

Mrs. Margaret A. Meuro, of Clifton, Staten Island, died on Saturday night, aged 71 years. She had for many years kept a small grog-shop on St. Mary's avenue.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 9.--Bud Renaud, the gambler who shot and killed Kid McCaffrey, a city officer, on Christmas eve in the entrance to a gambling saloon on Royal-street, had a preliminary hearing before Recorder Ford to-day and was released on $25,000 bail. All the testimony goes to show it was a case of justifiable homicide.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 9.--The annual meeting of the Chautauqua Assembly Association began to-day, 20 Trustees being present. Postmaster Pearson has compiled his annual report of the work done in the New-York Post Office in 1833. During the past year the City carriers delivered 89,696,162 letters, 30,474,191 postal cards, and 24,913,378 packages of other mail matter. There were delivered through the lock-boxes, 67,687,136 letters; 8,589,063 postal cards, and 36,171,321 packages.

The Manhattan Beach Hotel escaped without damage from the heavy storm of Tuesday night. The same was said of the Oriental, although the water for a time poured up to and around the building. The walk along the sea was ripped up and in several places carried away.

Old Simon Rappalee, the negro who Mrs. Aurelia Townsend said tried to kill her and he husband, James C. Townsend, in Oyster Bay, has a dream last Saturday night, which he told to "Buck" Sammis and Edward Nelson while they were guarding him Tuesday night after his arrest.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 10.--In Gordon County, at a social party, last evening, John Heath was on the floor waiting to commence a quadrille. Suddenly he reeled, fell to the floor instantly and expired. Heart disease is supposed to be the cause of his death. The quadrille was then given up.

Numerous rumors were afloat concerning the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad yesterday, and a determined raid was made in the Stock Exchange on the company's bonds. Among other reports was one to the effect that the road was going to be put into the hands of a receiver.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 10.--Henry Hunter, of Oglethorpe, had a child burned to death today. The mother went visiting and left several small children in the house around the fire. When she returned she found one burned so badly that it died in a short time.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Jan. 10.--The examination of the Professors of Laval University with regard to the religious troubles which have been in existence for some time past in this Province, has been begun by his Excellency Dom Smeulders, the Apostolic Commissioner.
