J.Q.A. Ward, the sculptor, yesterday, in the Feuardent-Di Cesnola libel suit, examined in the presence of the jury a number of figures, and pointed out the places where they had been stuck together.
The Central Pacific Railroad Company has declared a semi-annual dividend of 3 per cent., payable Feb. 1. The transfer-books will close Jan. 16.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 10.--Edwin Kelland, who was beaten and robbed at his rooms in John-street, in this city, at about midnight on Monday, it is thought will die from the effects of his injuries. He has not been conscious since he was found on Tuesday afternoon by his brothers.

YAZOO CITY, Miss., Jan. 10.--The investigation concerning the shooting of the Posey brothers on Christmas Eve was resumed to-day. Several witnesses were examined, but their testimony was only corroborative of that previously given, and nothing of interest was developed. Dr. Steinreide described the nature of the wounds inflicted upon John Posey.
LONDON, Dec. 15.--The first exhibition of the Institute of Painters in Oil Colors opens in the most propitious manner and promises well for the future of this new departure from old paths.
Mayor Low yesterday signed the resolutions passed by the Brooklyn Common Council giving the Kings County Elevated Railroad Company the right to build on the following routes:

Mr. Grau's French company, whose engagement at Haverly's Comedy Theatre appears to be attended with a remarkably pleasant degree of prosperity, presented last evening Lecocq's excellent opera-bouffe, "La Princesse des Canaries." This work was chosen for the opening of their present season in this country, when ...

SUSPENSION BRIDGE, N.Y., Jan. 10.--The remains of Capt. Webb, the noted swimmer, who recently lost his life in the rapids, were to-day exhumed, placed in a fine coffin, removed to Oakwood Cemetery here, and buried under the ...
The brig John H. Crandon, Capt. Sinnett, from this City for Havana, is ashore off Bay Ridge, Long Island.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 10.--The ice yacht race to-day was the most exciting this season. The ice was in splendid condition, and the boats went very fast, although the time, owing to the adverse wind, was not as good as has been made over the course.
Mr. Charles E. Lydecker, a lawyer at No. 20 Nassau-street, has been appointed Receiver of the estate of Albert Weber, the piano manufacturer, of Fifth-avenue and Sixteenth-street.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 10.--Science secured a great triumph here to-day. For the first time in the history of coal mining in this valley a shaft has been successfully sunk through the quicksand on the banks of the Susquehanna River.

ALBANY, Jan. 10.--A proposition by Mr. Brogan, of New-York, to send to the Committee on Trade and Manufactures his bill abolishing prison contract labor led the Assembly to-day into the first discussion of party and partisan measures. Mr. Brogan's bill is in substance the Butts bill of last year, in which the State is made to assume the responsibilities of a large manufacturing corporation, and to brand all of its ...
DUBLIN, Jan. 10.--Land Bailiff Simms, while returning from the Tullamore Law Court last evening, was shot by some unknown person and is dying.

The fact that the Valley of the Congo, in Africa, is now being opened to commerce by the International African Association was brought to the attention of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. Mr. A.A. Low offered some resolutions declaring that it was incumbent upon the United States Government to insist upon the neutrality of that valley, and "that it shall be ...

NIAGARA FALIS, Ontario, Jan. 10.--The Marquis of Lansdowne, accompanied by the Marchioness, Viscount Melgund, Military Secretary; Viscountess Melgund, the Hon. Henry F. Anson, aide-de-camp; Lady Florence Anson, the Hon. Henry Streatfield, aide-de-camp, and Col. ...

Considerable excitement has been caused in Rome by one of the most cold-blooded and carefully planned double murders on record, and the excitement is the greater inasmuch as the victims, though of comparatively humble position, were well known to almost every one here.

The report that Mr. Stetson has taken the San Fancisco Minstrel Opera-house for the balance of the season is entirely incorrect. The statement has had some circulation in the City press, but is as lacking in foundation as most stage stories are.

Mr. Francis Rust says that Leigh Smith intends to resume his arctic researches on the coast of Franz Josef Land as soon as he is able to procure another steamer and fit it out. Mr. Rust, who recently arrived in this City, was a member of the Dutch scientific expedition, whose ship, the Varna, sank in the Kara Sea last Spring.

A cable dispatch received yesterday from Liverpool announced that the Inman steam-ships City of Paris and City of New-York had been offered for sale at auction. The former was withdrawn without a bid and the latter after 26,000 had been offered.
Both branches of Congress are brought face to face once more with the fact that the legislative functions of the Government are virtually lodged in the committees of the Senate and House.

The hum and bustle of business in the large trading-room of the Stock Exchange were partially silenced for a minute, just before 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, by half a dozen ringing blows from Chairman Mitchell's hammer.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 10.--There was a thrilling escape from an ice-yacht disaster on the Hudson this afternoon. Shortly after 1 o'clock Charles Lumb, age 21; William Dickenson, age 17; Jessie Lumb. 19, and Carrie Harloe, daughter of ex-Mayor Harloe, started from here ...

Political subjects are not usually well handled by playwrights, especially when the subjects are American: Yet politics are good game for the satirist and humorist. Occasionally, however, a suggestion of the right thing is shown ...

DES MONIES, Iowa, Jan. 10.--President Kennedy, of Ida County, called tho Iowa woolgrowers to order this afternoon. In his address he urged the restoration of the ad valorum duty on wool. He said the fact that sheep are increasing in faster ratio than the human population is an evidence of business depression.
John Smith, who for the past five months has been an inmate of the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island, to which he was committed on a charge of petit larceny, was arraigned before ...

BOSTON, Jan. 10.--A convention of nailers representing all the factories in the East with but one exception, met this afternoon at the Mascot House, Middleboro. The delegates present represented Wareham, Plymouth, South and West Wareham, Somersett, Weymouth, and Bridgewater.

Mr. Brewster Cameron, of Pennsylvania, who has been General Agent in the Department of Justice under Attorney-General Brewster, was to-day nominated to the Senate by the President to be Receiver of Public Moneys at Tucson, Arizona.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 10.--Information was received to-day that the five children of Thomas W. Milham, who recently removed from Schenectady, died suddenly in Dakota of diphtheria and ware buried in one grave.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 10.--The Rapid Transit Commissioners of New-York and interested persons arrived here this morning. The Commissioners appeared upon the floor of the Exchange between 12 and 1 o'clock and during the afternoon visited various point's of interest about the city. To-morrow will be devoted to a critical examination of the Chicago City Railway's cable system.

LAS VEGAS, New-Mexico, Jan. 10.--A crowd of rustlers at Seven Rivers, Lincoln County, yesterday fired into a gang of nine Mexican laborers, killing four of them. The murders were unprovoked. The rustlers escaped.

The steam-ship City of Alexandria, of the Alexandre Line, which arrived from Havana yesterday, experienced an extremely stormy passage. Last Tuesday afternoon, when off Savannah, she ran into a terrific south-easterly hurricane, which laid her almost on her port beam ends several times.

ALBANY, Jan. 10.--The annual report of the Superintendent of Public Works was transmitted this morning to the Senate. The total expenses for ordinary repairs, superintendence, c., is $589,854 for the fiscal year ended Oct. 1, 1883. There were 209 days of navigation last year on the canals.

The Metropolitan Opera-house Directors have suggested to the management of the Sixthavenue elevated road that a station at Thirtyninth-street would be a good thing both for the road and the opera-house.

Mayor EDSON'S annual message is a mild and rather barren document. Its statistical statements are, perhaps, sufficiently full and clear, but its barrenness appears in the lack of pertinent suggestions for the improvement of a very faulty system of municipal administration.

A published statement that Gen. Grant's cable concession, granted by the Mexican Government, had been forfeited by that Government on the ground of non-fulfillment on the part of the Cable Company of its obligations, has led to ...
LONDON, Jan. 10.--Court circles in Berlin are excited by a scandal, the alleged culprit being no less a personage than Prince Frederick Charles Nicolas, the nephew of the Emperor, and ...

Neither the police nor the Pinkertons nor the army of amateur detectives which have been scouring the neighborhood of Newark for the last four days have succeeded in discovering Charles Delmonico, either dead or alive, and the mystery surrounding his disappearance is almost as great as it was last Sunday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 10.--Francis York, of Lockport, aged 25, employed in the construction of the Junction Railroad, while going to his boarding-house last night, was caught in a snowdrift at Skunk Hollow and frozen to death.

ST. THOMAS, Jan. 5.--The Haytian rebellion is now considered at an end. A telegram from Kingston, Jamaica, dated Jan. 3, said that the English mail steamer Para had brought intelligence to Kingston that the town of Jacmel surrendered on Dec. 29, and that 4,000 Haytian ...

In the suit of Gen. Conway to recover $400 from the Rev. Dr. Fulton, Pastor of the Cen tennial Baptist Church, alleged to be due him for services as Assistant Pastor, the jury, after being charged by Judge Reynolds, in the Brooklyn City Court, were instructed yesterday to bring in a sealed verdict.

Mr. Oscar S. Straus delivered yesterday evening to a large audience at Chickering Hall a lecture on "The Origin of the Republican Form of Government in the United States and the Hebrew Commonwealth." Mr. Straus has the advantage of a clear voice and an excellent delivers, and treated his subject in an interesting way.

Prof. Henry A. Coppee read a paper, entitled "Coincidences of the Conquest of Mexico by Cortez and by Scott," at a general meeting of the Military Service Institution of the United States, at Governor's Island yesterday.

Michael Regan, an employe of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, who was arrested Wednesday night on suspicion of having been instrumental in causing the death of Julia O'Rourke, is held to await the result of the Coroner's investigation.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 10.--Probate Judge Matson held to-day in the case of the County Auditor against J.A. Fay Co. that the officers of the bank cannot be compelled to produce the account of a tax-payer for the information of the Auditor except for the day upon which the law provides that property shall be returned for taxation.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 10--Considerable excitement was created to-day by a fight between Judge Allen, of the Criminal Court, and Judge Ferris, of the County Court.

The death of Berehan, Sultan of Rabeita, is reported from Aden, and as few Europeans will have seen that monarch, the following description of him, contributed to the Corriere di Mattino by Signor Licata, the Italian traveler who penetrated to that far region, may be found interesting:
The annual ball of the Old Guard took place in the Metropolitan Opera-house last evening. Growing plants and ferns and Christmas trees in boxes formed a border to the dancing floor.

Mr. Belmont and Mr. Hewitt are determined, if possible, that the report recently made by Special Agent Martin, of the Treasury Department, about the alleged falsification of invoices of imported goods shall not pass unnoticed. Each of these gentlemen to-day introduced resolutions on the subject.
The Joint Executive Committee met yesterday at Commissioner Fink's office to discuss the question of the non-maintenance of rates and devise some plan whereby cutting shall be prevented.
John Newell, of Chicago, is at the Clarendon Hotel. J.H. Devereux, of Cleveland, is at the Windsor Hotel.

A few days ago seven girls, employed at a sugar factory in Balta, left that town in the evening to return to their native village at some distance. The girls, belated on the way, resolved to pass the night in the fields and proceed at daybreak.

It is said that wolves are becoming plenty in the northern part of the State. It is noticeable that when deer begin to increase in any locatlity wolves are pretty certain to follow. It is thought those which are flocking into Maine came from Canada. Years ago wolves were plenty in the northern part of the State, and the farmers had to protect sheep from them.
George Jeffrey and his reputed wife, Dolly Pollard, both colored, were lodged in the Suffolk County Jail, at Riverhead, Long Island, on a charge of having murdered her child in August last.

Assistant Commissioner Pierson announced that the trunk lines have prepared rebate tickets, which will enable them to make as low rates as may he necessary from New-York to the Missouri River and points beyond without an disarrangement of their local business.

The annual message of the Mayor, which was presented to the Board of Aldermen yesterday, is a long document and would occupy about a page of THE TIMES, if printed in full. The message opens with references to the prosperity and growth of the City; to the good order which has prevailed; its healthful condition; the opening of the Brooklyn bridge, and the universal observance of Evacuation Day.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 10.--The name of one of the men killed in the railway accident at Brinton station last night was Jacob Heidelberger, age 28.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Jan. 10.--Another legal step was taken yesterday toward establishing the relationship of John Stewart, of Johnson, Vt., to the late Alexander T. Stewart, of New-York City, and in proving his claim to a share in the estate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10.--The consideration of the proposed new rules was continued in the Senate to-day, and was the cause of a long and interesting debate, in which free trade, tariff, the merchant marine, pilotage fees, and other subjects were brought prominently before the Senate.

Mr. W.H. Knight, of Washington, met a number of electricians and representatives of vairious electrical companies, yesterday afternoon, at the rooms of the Down-Town Association, and explained the Knight and Bentley system ...
The funeral of Dr. Edouard Lasker, which took place yesterday afternoon at the Temple Emenu El, at Fifth-avenue and Forty-third-street, was attended by an immense crowd of people.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 10.--Additional details of the lynching on Friday last, at Monterey, Highland County, Va., have been received here. E.D. Atchison, the man who was lynched, was confined in jail for stabbing Sidney Ruckman, a prominent Readjuster, on Christmas Day, while the two were drinking together.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 10.--The contest in the will case of John Wilson, the miser, was begun here to-day before Surrogate Roswell C. Coleman. Wilson died last October in his eightieth year, leaving an estate valued at from $30,000 to $50,000.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 10.--The dry goods firm of Buckley Co., in this city, which has disputed with one other house the position of leader of the trade in Central New-York, made an assignment to-day to Charles S. Symonds for the benefit of its creditors.

In some places, instead of watch-meet ings on New Year's eve, "sunrise prayer-meet ings" are held on New Year's morning. The oldest service of this sort is that at Pittsfield, no person now living having a memory long enough to reach back to the first meeting.

PERU, Ind., Jan. 10.--For some time there have been rumors of certain unministerial acts on the part of the Rev. J.E. Martin, Rector of the Episcopal church of this city. The rumors became so common that the Trustees set on foot an investigation, which resulted to-day in a request for the Rector's resignation.

William H. Speer, of Jersey City, in 1867, at the urgent request of an agent, procured a policy of insurance for $10,000 on the life of his father, Abraham Speer, who was then about 56 years old, and who is yet living.

Eighty men, very red in the face and of very strong lungs, held possession of the glistening sheet of ice in Conservatory Lake, Central Park; yesterday afternoon. They were representatives of the clubs forming the Grand National Curling Club of America, and they ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 10.--Congressman Hopkins arrived here from Washington this morning. Concerning the labor is questions to come before the committee of which he is Chairman, he said this evening:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 10.--The Salvation Army gave a banquet to-night at their barracks as a farewell to Capt. Hunter, who leaves for head-quarters after nine months' work here. Major Moore, chief in command; Capt. Howe, of the First New-York Corps; Capt. Light, Arkansas; Capt. Thompson, Brooklyn; Capt. Linskey, Baltimore; Capt. Hooper, Paterson, and a score of officers from New-Haven were present.

The suggestion that the exclusion of American pork from the French and German markets should be met by retaliatory duties on the products--chiefly wines-- imported from those countries is a very natural one, and has a certain attractiveness on the face of it.
The Executive Committee of the Twelfth Ward Republican Club, of the Nineteenth Assembly District, held a meeting at the residence of the President, Mr. Frederick Mottet, at No. 207 ...

CAIRO, Jan. 10.--The new Cabinet under Prime Minister Nubar Pasha is decidedly popular. The steamer conveying the last of the rein forcements for Suakim has been wrecked in the Red Sea, near that town. The troops and crew have been saved, but the ammunition and mules have been lost.

ERIE, Penn., Jan. 10.--Early this morning Annie Offts, a young actress, was found lying in a pool of blood, having shot herself through the breast. She was infatuated with Max Doeller, and as her passion was unreturned she resolved to die, preferring death to seeing Doeller the husband of a girl to whom he is engaged to be married.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 10.--The Road Convention to-day was largely attended and several members of the Legislature participated in the proceedings.

William Menken, a young German, formerly an inmate of the Elmira Reformatory, is in custody at Police Head-quarters charged with the murder of the young woman who was found frozen to death in a creek near Carr's Corners, in the western suburbs of Elmira, on Sunday last.
A military dinner of uncommon elegance was given last evening at the Union League Club, by Major Charles S. Stott, Jr., to Gen. J.B. Carr and staff and a few other military friends.
ALBANY, Jan. 10.--Commissioner Peck, of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, submitted his first report to the Legislature to-day. The document is voluminous, covering nearly 400 pages of legal cap paper.

The Brooklyn Loan Exhibition opened last night with a collection which does great honor to the capital of Long Island. The pictures ara not so varied as those in the New-York Exhibition, but in some painters, is richer. We shall notice it in detail later.

WEST POINT, Ga., Jan. 10.--An old feud between two leading families in Heard County has for the second time resulted in the fatal wounding of one of the parties over the line in Carroll County. Robert Huckaba, together with several others was employed near Black Jack Mountain in quarrying rock for a new house.

It is alleged that the Senate of the United States consumed during the months of July and August, 1882, no less than two hundred and one thousand pounds of ice, which, according to the chalk and blackboard of our esteemed contemporary, the Sun, gave no less than three thousand pounds of ice to each Senator.

BOSTON, Jan. 10.--The cattlemen from New-Hampshire and Vermont are greatly exercised over the reported disappearance of William M. Devlin, who has been doing business in their line since 1882, and who has left several creditors behind.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 10.--A millionaire's son is in the custody of the police on a charge of forgery. Nathan Schwabacher, 26 years old, is the oldest son of Henry Schwabacher, a wholesale liquor-dealer of Peoria, Ill. Young Schwabacher took dinner on April 24, 1883, at ...

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 10.--William Allen, a farmer, aged 57, living near Brantingham Lake Lewis County, was found by the roadside half a mile from home on Wednesday badly frozen. He was taken home, where he died in a few hours. He had been at Greig, a few miles distant, on the previous evening, and started home intoxicated.
Mr. Charles MacRae has sold the brick and brown-stone residence on the south-west corner of Fifty-seventh-street and Madisonavenue, belonging to the estate of Letia A. Blackwell for $100,000 cash.

Mathew J. McMahon, of No. 150 East Ninety-eighth-street, got off the rear platform of car No. 145, of the Third-avenue line, at Ninety-eighth-street, at about 9 o'clock on Wednesday night, and, his foot slipping on the ...

Judging by the figures contained in recent official medical reports, the sanitary condition of some of the prisons of Russia appears to be as bad as when the English, philanthropist, Howard, visited them a century ago.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 10.--There is much excitement here among tax-payers over alleged fraudulent bills audited by the Supervisors. At the request of the Tax-payers' Association the County Treasurer declines payment on all bills pending an investigation. The bills of the Sheriff and deputies are alleged to contain man, illegal charges. It is said that the deputies here have used unsigned bench warrants, fictitious processes, and false vouchers.
Champion Frey opened the pool tournament last night at Madison-Square Hall with John Leonard, who took third place in the preliminary tourney.
Mr. Charles Levi Woodbury asked the Democrats at the Jackson dinner in Boston to look Gen. Butler "straight in the eye."

A new series of 5 per cent. bonds is to be issued by the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company, amounting to about $14,000,000. Horace white, the Treasurer, said that the new bonds would be issued at the rate of $20,000 a mile on all of the road now constructed and to be constructed; this will include the Palouse branch, built by the Oregon and Transcontinental Company ...

WETHERSFIELD, Jan. 10.--Within a short distance of the State prison, in an old house on Main-street, dwells the oldest person in this section of Connecticut, Mrs. Elizabeth Buck, widow of the late Daniel Buck. A TIMES reporter visited the old lady to-day, it being the occasion of her one hundredth birthday.
Mayor Low has signed the resolutions of the Board of Aldermen giving to the Kings County Elevated Railroad Company the authority to commence proceedings for the erection of their proposed lines.

A regular meeting of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence and State Medicine was held last night at the Academy of Medicine, No. 12 West Thirty-first-street. After the President, the Hon. William Barnes, had made an address ...
The Democrats of the Ohio Legislature met in caucus last night at Columbus and nominated Mr. Payne, of Cleveland, to succeed Mr. Pendleton in the United States Senate.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 10.--An action has been brought by the New-York, Connecticut and Air Line Railroad Company for the purpose of testing the corporate validity of the Hartford and Harlem Company, which is likely to result in a complicated litigation.
HATTERAS, N.C., Jan. 10.--The threemasted schooner Emma C. Rommell, Sloan, master, before reported ashore on the 9th, was from King's Ferry, Fla., bound to Philadelphia, loaded with pine lumber.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 10.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the St. Paul Eastern and Grand Trunk Railroad Company began at the Plankinton House, this afternoon, and will probably be in session the greater part of to-morrow.

The Rev. Father Pattie, Rector of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Cuurch, at Burlington, N.J., celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood recently. Mgr. Capel preached the sermon, and a large number of Church dignitaries from all parts of the State were in attendance.
TITUSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 10.--Considerable excitement has been occasioned here by the completion of a well on the Williamson tract, near Sheffield, owned by John L. McKinney and others.
There was the usual crowd of local politicians present at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, when the form of attempting to organize the board was repeated.

A suit to recover $100,000 damages for al leged slander has been begun by Daniel De Leon against David A. De Lima, in the Superior Court. Mr. De Leon is a lawyer, whose office is at No. 206 Broadway. Mr. De Lima is a commission merchant doing business at No. 68 William-street.
VIENNA, Jan. 10.--Three men entered the once of a money-changer named Eisert this evening, on the pretext of wishing to change some rubles, and attacked and severely wounded Eisert.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10.--This afternoon the funerals of several of the victims of the convent fire took place in Beileville, Ill. Out of respect, for the sad event flags were at half-mast and business was suspended. St. Peter's Church, in Belleville, which is one of the largest in the State, will seat upward of 3,000 persons.
The one railroad company which has ab solutely and persistently refused to pay any local taxes whatever to Jersey City is the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10.--The meeting of the Transcontinental Association to-day was of unusual interest and all the indications were that it will speedily be a thing of the past.
The north shore of Long Island is not occupied by mining camps nor by "settlements" like the towns of the South-west.

HONG KONG, Jan. 11.--The Chinese have blockaded the Canton River between the city of Canton and the Bogue forts, leaving only a navigable passage of 90 feet in width. Calls have also been issued for recruits for the Chinese Army.
PARIS, Dec. 22.--Paris now shows more interest in the new discovery concerning truffles. I think you can read about this discovery with composure, although you get the luxury in cans.

The Senate finished the consideration of the new rules to-day and took up the proposed joint rules for the Senate and House. Mr. Hale's amendment to rule 17, striking out the reference of the District of Columbia Appropriation bill to the District Committee, was carried, as a natural result of the decision made yesterday on rule 26. The new rules will go into effect on Monday, Jan. 21.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 11.--David Charlesworth was yesterday buried at Fort Plain in a coffin he manufactured 35 years ago for his burial. Whenever he changed his place of residence he always moved the coffin with his household furniture.
FONDA, N.Y., Jan. 11.--Fred T. Kilson, book-keeper for Rese, McAlpin Co., gloveleather dealers at Gloversville, has been missing since Jan. 1, when he left home for Poughkeepsie, ...

YAZOO CITY, Miss., Jan. 11.--The investigation into the shooting of the Posey brothers and others on Christmas Eve was continued yesterday. E. Luke testified that five minutes before the shooting he saw Eugene Smith pass ...

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 11.--The jury in the case of Ada Davey, widow of William L. Davey, against the AEtna Life Insurance Company, of Hartford, after being out 25 hours, this morning returned a verdict for $11,293 16. The case was tried in the United States Circuit Court. Davey was insured for $10,000, but upon his death the company refused to pay, insisting that death had resulted from drunkenness.

HARTFORD, Jan. 11.--This city has just been surprised by the apprehension and detection of a 12-year-old boy thief, whose luxurious tastes, magnificent purchases, and long-continued peculations, coupled with his tender years and infantile though bright appearance, furnish subject matter of a nature that fairly eclipses the plots and situations of the flashiest of juvenile literature.

A sleepy looking young man climbed wearily up the steps of the Ninth-street station of the elevated road, on the up-town side, about 2 o'clock yesterday morning.

It is unfortunate for the country that the necessity which Mr. CARLISLE felt of healing the wound inflicted by leaving Mr. SPRINGER off of the Committee of Ways and Means should have induced the Speaker to give him the Committee on the Expenditures of the Department of Justice.
The Nivison Foundling Asylum at Hamonton, N.J., will be opened in 10 days. Applications have already been sent in for the limited number of cribs which it will at present accommodate.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11.--The Board of Directors of the Zoological Society have decided not to accept the gift of $50,000 offered by Mr. Joseph E. Temple on condition that the garden should be open free to the public one day in each week.
The second of Mr. Theodore Thomas's concerts for young people will take place at Steinway Hall at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The programme is attractive.

Another meeting of theatrical people to arrange a benefit for the widows and orphans of the lost Sandy Hook pilots and Gloucester fishermen was held yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 11.--The Buffalo Historical Society has for some time had in mind a project to secure a burial lot in Forest Lawn Cemetery for the bones of Red Jacket and other famous Indian chiefs. Finally the Cemetery Association has given the Historical Society a suitable ...
The coasting accidents recorded this Winter recall one that occurred in the early days of the settlement of Colorado, and which probably has no equal, at least in this country.

Two closely contested games were played yesterday afternoon in the pool tournament. "Jumbo" Sutton vanquished Dankelman by a score of 11 to 9, and Al Lambert beat John Leonard, of Philadelphia, by 11 games to 9.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 11.--The levees on the Mississippi River at Hardscrabble, Bondurant, and Kempe, which are being built under the auspices of the Mississippi Commission by P.J. Kennedy, contractor, are in such ...

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 11.--Residents of this city who are interested in cattle ranches in Dakota, Idaho, Nebraska, and other far Western States have received news that the severe weather of last week played sad havoc with the cattle on the plains. It is said that in some sections almost entire herds were frozen to death. It is thought the damage will greatly affect the beef supply and have a tendency to send prices skyward.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 11.--John Shea, a mill hand at Georgiaville, a manufacturing, hamlet seven miles from this city, killed his wife this afternoon and then committed suicide.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 11.--The Regents of the university to-day refused to grant a charter to the United States College of Medicine and Surgery, of New-York City. It was resolved to establish teachers' classes from time to time in the academies of the State, and the Legislature is to be asked to make the necessary appropriations for that purpose.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 11.--The Iowa Farmers' Alliance to-day adopted a new constitution, its object being now to work for the elevation of agriculture, mental, moral, and social improvement of the members and their homes; ...
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 11.--The Senate today ordered that the Judiciary Committee consider the expediency of expunging from the public records certain sections of the resolves of 1855 ...
The stock of the Excelsior Water and Mining Company was "listed" at the New-York Stock Exchange in November, 1879. The capital of the company was represented as $10,000,000, fully paid.

LIMA, Jan. 11, via Galveson.--La Opinion Nacional states that a truce between Chili and Bolivia has been agreed upon, the conditions of which do not interfere with the settlement of the Peruvian question. The sum for the maintenance of the Chilian army of occupation has been limited to the proceeds from the Mollendo Custom-house.
TROY, Jan. 11.--John Manning, a constable of this city, was arrested to-day by a Deputy Sheriff on a warrant for assaulting Mrs. Sumner Dorisky.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11, 1884. The Secretary of the Treasury will prob ably issue a call for $10,000,000 3 per cent. bonds to-morrow.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., Jan. 11.--While Prof. Houghston, of Cedar Springs Institute, was going home to-night he was knocked down and robbed of money and a gold watch. He is supposed to be fatally wounded. Alfred Irvin, janitor of the institute, has been arrested on suspicion of being the guilty party.
Forty-seven thousand dollars extra pay is probably worth making an effort for, when one has already been paid more than $20,000 for a job regularly contracted for.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Jan. 11.--In a quarrel between Jeff Gilliland and John Malone, while on their way home from this city last night, Gilliland fired a shot at Malone without effect. Malone then fired and killed Gilliland. The latter, who was a noted desperado, was known as the "Jesse James of Arkansas."

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 11.--While Mrs. Cabell, the wife of Col. H. Coulter Cabell, a prominent citizen of Richmond, was dressing in her chamber this morning her clothing caught fire from the grate, and before assistance reached her she was enveloped in flames. Her condition to-night is considered critical. She is over 50 years old.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11.--On the night of Jan. 2 the bodies of four male paupers were stolen from the Cook County Infirmary Morgue, at Jefferson. The matter was kept quiet by the officials until to-day. The watchman was asleep, when the thieves drove up in a wagon and deliberately stole coffins, bodies, and shrouds. The County Commissioners offer a reward of $1,000 for the apprehension the thieves.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 11.--The breeders of Clydesdale horses effected a State organization this afternoon. There was much discussion over the defects of the awarding system at agricultural fairs and a depreciation of the evils of the credit system, but all propositions relative to both matters were tabled. It was stated that all the young stock in Iowa is gathered up by shippers at prices that are considered very remunerative.

Major William P. Rathburn, President of the First National Bank of Chattanooga, died in that city yesterday morning. Major Rathburn had been connected with the banking business and iron interests of Ohio and West Virginia for many years. He was engaged in mercantile business at Wilkesville, Ohio, previous to 1849. He was 64 years of age and was very wealthy.

BOSTON, Jan. 12.--The foreign exhibition, which was opened Sept. 5, was informally closed to-night. It has been a financial failure, the deficit being placed as high as $50,000. The exhibits were turned over to Customs officers, who are now in charge of the building.

GALVESTON, Texas, Jan. 12.--An Abilene dispatch to the News says: "Near Colorado River last night a San Angela stage, south bound, was halted by four mounted men, who robbed the mail sacks and passengers, and then delayed the coach until the arrival of a north-bound stage, which they also plundered. BALTIMORE, Jan. 12.--George S. Pumphrey, aged 71, the oldest and one of the most faithful policemen of this city, dropped dead at his post of duty to-day. He had performed all his morning duties, and soon after was attacked by heart disease and died almost instantly.

Annie Watts, a homeless woman, was thrown down a flight of stairs at No. 88 Bayardstreet by Abram Taylor, of No. 82 Bayard-street, on Saturday night, and fractured her ankle. Taylor made his escape.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 13.--The burning of the Park Theatre may prove a disguised blessing to Cleveland in the line of material prosperity.

QUEBEC, Quebec, Jan. 13.--Mr. Masson having declined to form a new Government on the ground of ill health, the Lieutenant-Governor has summoned the Hon. Dr. Ross, who arrived here to-night, and has intrusted him with the formation of a new Administration. Dr. Ross will not make known his decision until to-morrow.
The Rev. R. Heber Newton, before beginning his sermons yesterday morning and afternoon, made an announcement which was listened to in breathless silence.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 13.--The bodies of two more men, supposed to be sailors from the wrecked bark Elmina, have been washed ashore. One found near Harvey Cedars is that of a man of small stature, and the face is covered with a light red beard. The other body was picked up by the crew of Life-saving Station No. 22, and is mutilated beyond recognition.

A suit, which has been in progress in Judge Depue's Court at Newark for the last three or four days, involves the title to a large patch of the shore front at Communipaw. The parties to the suit are the West Line Railroad Company and the New-Jersey Central Railroad Company.

JAMESTOWN, Jan. 13.--The Grand Jury at Mayville has indicted Charles L. Jeffords on the charge of firing Jeffords, Baily Co.'s lounge and table factors last December, thereby causing a loss of $36,000. A great amount of interest centres in the case, which will probably not be tried until the next term of the court.

WAPAKONETA, Ohio, Jan. 13.--The failure of Mr. Better on Friday, resulting in the collapse of the Farmers' Bank, is believed to be more serious than was first reported. It is believed that Better's liabilities will exceed $60,000. Several township Treasurers had fiduciary funds in the Farmers' Bank. The Assignees of the bank are trying to raise $20,000 on the bank's collateral to enable it to resume.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 13.--A sensational case has been opened in the courts of Springfield, Mary C. Brennen, a handsome young woman, with a good reputation, has commenced a suit against Jacob Grove for $5,000 as damages caused by breach of promise. Grove had paid attention to Miss Brennen for a long time, but finally deserted her and married another woman.

PANAMA, Jan. 5.--A number of representatives of different political parties have left the isthmus for Carthagena for the purpose of endeavoring to impress upon Dr. Nunez, the President-elect of the republic, their different views on State politics. Some of them want to compel President Cervera to resign, while others wish him to retain office.
John R. Bain, for many years connected with the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church as sexton, died Saturday in the forty-sixth year of his age.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 13.--The production of syrup in South Georgia, owing to the killing of cane by the frosts, will be shorter than for several years. Stubble was the only hope for seed, and this has been killed by the late frosts. This will extend the shortness into next year's crop.

Representative Kellogg says that Louisiana will be the first State to choose its delegates to the National Republican Convention. The State Committee will meet on Jan. 16 to call the State Convention, which will probably be held in New-Orleans about March 1.

MOBILE, Jan. 13.--The cold snap has passed away almost as suddenly as it came, and the result is now definitely known. The weather was within 1 of the coldest on record, and the coldest since 1849.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 13.--The police made a descent on the Salvation Army who were noisily parading in Main-street this afternoon in large numbers, and four of the chief officers are now in the police station, shouting their joy at becoming martyrs. They will be tried in the morning.

ERIE, Penn., Jan. 13--A fatal shooting affray occurred here this afternoon. An Italian, Leonardo Giacomo, after quarreling with several companions, ran into his house, procured a revolver, and fired four shots. Pasquello de Carlos fell dead and Charles de Carlos's thigh was shattered. The murderer is in jail.

The gardener of the Duke of Devonshire at Chatsworth, a Mr. Speed, committed suicide a few weeks ago by shooting himself in a bedroom of his house in the gardens. Mr. Speed is said to have been one of the best gardeners in England. Of late he has been greatly depressed by private afflictions.

Dr. Henry Augustus Du Bois, a native of and for many years a resident of this City, died yesterday at his residence, in New-Haven, Conn., where he has made his home since 1854. Dr. Du Bois was born in this City at First-avenue and First-street Aug. 9, 1808. At the time of his birth the locality mentioned was the country seat of his father, Cornelius Du Bois.

AMERICUS, Ga., Jan. 13.--At a social assemblage in the residence of William Perdue, an altercation between jealous rivals was terminated by Mr. Boyd Williams shooting Mr. William Adams. The ball passed through the body three inches below the right nipple, and Dr. Wood pronounces the wound fatal.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 13.--There are about 20,000,000 white-fish eggs in the State hatchery in Sandusky that will begin hatching toward the end of February. They will at the proper time be transferred to Lake Erie, along the north shore, and at convenient places about the islands. Ohio has been paying a great deal of attention to fish-culture of late, and the State hatchery has been in the hands of men of experience and enthusiasm.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Jan. 14.--The departure of Gen. Hamblin, Government Superintendent here, and Col. Alexander, sub-contractor on the Government creek improvements for the national capital creates much speculation, as it is understood their mission concerns important proposed changes in the Government improvements here. The appropriation of $80,000 for creek improvements is nearly exhausted, and these gentlemen will urge upon Congress the advisability of appropriating an additional $500,000.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 14.--Sheriff John McEwan, of Essex County, has been officially notified of his dismissal from office for negligence in allowing Greenwood and Phipps, the murderers, to escape from Sandwich Jail last November. McEwan admitted that he had not inspected the jail for over two years. He has held the office for 30 years. John C. Iler, a prominent farmer of Colchester Township, has been appointed his successor.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 14.--The houses held half-hour sessions this morning, but in that brief time the members succeeded in swamping the respective clerks with floods of bills. Some of these are of considerable importance; two bear directly upon the question of tax collection, which is a particularly interesting subject in Jersey City.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 14.--The Court of Appeals met to-day in their new rooms in the Capitol. Many distinguished members of the Bar were present to witness the ceremony of taking possession.

LONDON, Jan. 14.--A dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company from Hong Kong, dated today at 10:35 A.M., states that advices from Hanoi to the 6th inst. announce that the pirates made an attempt upon Nam-dink from all sides on the nights of Jan. 1 and 2, in which a large number were killed and wounded, and many houses burned.

Woerishoffer, one of the stockholders, applied yesterday to Judge Barrett, in Supreme Court, Chambers, for the appointment of a Receiver, and ex-Judge Green was selected by the Judge.

The annual meeting of the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church took place in the basement last evening. James H. Seymour, the Treasurer, reported the receipts during the past year to have been $24,692 45; expenditures, $24,606 46, leaving a balance of $85 99 in the treasury. The financial condition of the church was stated as follows: Resources, $217,385 99; liabilities, $85,409 33, leaving a balance of $131,976 66 in favor of the church.

The safe arrival of the Celtic at Queenstown, twenty-one days from New-York, in tow of a steam-ship of the same line, indicates that it was to save a large bill for towing that the master of the Celtic declined assistance before. The passengers have undergone an experience very unusual in these days, having, indeed, made what would have been an average Winter voyage thirty years ago, or even less.

Another alleged effort to organize the Board of Aldermen was made yesterday with the same result as at previous meetings since the present Aldermen came into office. The factions of the Democracy had not come together, and, if the leaders are to be believed, no effort has been made within a week to accomplish the desired result.

At a meeting of the Citizens' League of Brooklyn last evening, at Central Hall, the Rev. S.B. Halliday reported that the Board of Managers, which is to be composed of four prominent citizens from each of the 25 wards in the city, had not yet been selected. The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher and Gen. Christensen were proposed for membership. The object of the league is to enforce the excise law.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 14.--Something over a year ago a difficulty occurred at Uniontown, Penn., between Capt. Nutt, Treasurer of the State, and N.S. Dukes, a lawyer and memberelect of the lower house of the Legislature, in which the former was killed. The trouble, it is alleged, grew out of slanderous reports started by Dukes concerning Mr. Nutt's daughter, Lizzie.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--For the first time in the recollection of the oldest newspaper correspondents at the capital, a circular was yesterday issued from the Treasury Department containing a synopsis of the Customs decisions rendered during the month up to Jan. 12. Hitherto these decisions have been withheld from the press until the end of each month, when they were issued in pamphlet form.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 15.--P.A. Schroth and Thomas Meininger, both members of the Merchants' Exchange, fought to-day over a game of cards. TUCKERTON, N.J., Jan. 15.--The villages of Tuckerton, Parkertown, and West Creek are much stirred this morning over a bold attempt at criminal assault upon Miss Marion Brown, the district school teacher at the last named place.

This dispatch was given out from the Tribune office, and may, therefore, be accepted as an authoritative statement. It is as follows:

In spite of the cold and cheerless weather yesterday a large number of ladies and gentlemen witnessed the launching of the new coast survey steamer, named after the late Superintendent of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, Carlile P. Patterson.

Much to the astonishment of every one, Champion Frey was defeated yesterday afternoon in the pool tournament by Dankelman, who has himself been beaten by every man who has so far played against him in the present tourney.
WEATHERFORD, Texas, Jan. 15.--A westbound Texas Pacific passenger train was wrecked this morning by a broken rail 10 miles west of Weatherford.

"That boy is not much over 10 years old and he's been a professional burglar for four years," said Justice Patterson yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court, to Charity Commissioner Porter, as he pointed to a small lad with a bright, intelligent face, who stood at the bar, charged with burglary. "He's an incorrigible thief, and he has been arrested four times for burglary."

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 15.--Following upon the heels of the discovery in the McKinney district, Sheffield comes with another immense well, owned by Messrs. Shank Emery, of this city. It was drilled into rock late this evening and began flowing heavily.
The twenty-fourth annual auction sale of paintings, contributed by members in aid of the Artists' Fund Society of New-York, was held last night at Association Hall, in Twenty-thirdstreet.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 15.--Gov. Murray, in his message to the Utah Legislature, says: By the laws of Congress, approved March 22, 1882, this session of your honorable body is made one of extraordinary interest to the people of Utah and the country at large.

As reported at a meeting last evening in the house of Mr. W.G. Low, No. 58 Remsenstreet, by the members of the Brooklyn Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, the total receipts thus far have been $4,604 59, or $250 more than was received last year. Several churches are yet to be heard from. Mr. W.G. Low was reelected President of the association, and the other officers were also re-elected.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 15.--A curious suit in equity has been brought in this county by Thomas King in order to establish the status of his wife and children.

Mr. Sidney Woollett follows Mr. Riddle and Mr. Cable. His readings which were heard here last Winter won for him appreciation and popularity. Mr. Woollett began yesterday afternoon, at the Madison Club Theatre, a new course of 12 readings.
BIRMINGHAM, Conn., Jan. 15.--A revival of religion is in progress here in the Methodist Church. On Thursday next the storekeepers who are connected with the church are to close ...

The residence of Alonzo Dennis, at No. 449 East Eighty-sixth-street, was broken into by a young burglar on Monday afternoon. The thief was detected by a lad of 17, named Bangs, who collared him and shouted lustily for help.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 15.--The Winter Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of North-eastern Pennsylvania opened its first session here to-day. The Rev. W.B. Morrow, of Sayre, Penn., delivered the opening address, and was followed by the Rev. J.P. Cameron, of Green Ridge, who said the church must not be permitted to die of respectability, but must shine as it never shone before to convert sinners and reform the churches of the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--Capt. William I. Foulke, Sixth Cavalry, was to-day placed on the retired list. The resignation of Cadet Jesse H. Wise, Fourth Class, Military Academy, has been accepted by the Secretary of War. The resignation of First Lieut. William B. Brewster, Assistant Surgeon, has been accepted by the President, to take effect Feb. 7.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 15.--A bogus colonization scheme, concocted in New-York, was exposed here to-day, and the originator of it is now in jail awaiting trial on the charge of obtaining money under false pretenses.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 15.--The Ohio Wool-growers' State Association met this evening. Mr. M.J. Lawrence, editor of the Ohio Farmer, read a paper entitled, "How Does the Tariff Affect the American Farmer?"

ALBANY, Jan. 15.--The Assembly spent the session to-day in discussing Mr. House's resolution to investigate the public departments of New-York, and, after amending it, passed it by an almost unanimous vote, Democrats and Republicans alike being recorded in favor of its passage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--Mr. Chittenden, of New-York, formerly Register of the Treasury, appeared this morning before the Committee on Banking and Currency and gave his views with regard to legislation to prevent undue contraction of the currency.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 15.--Over 100 new applications have been made to the court now sitting here for licenses to sell liquor in the city and county. There are over 1,000 persons now engaged in the traffic. The Law and Order Society propose to take the matter in hand and oopose the granting of the license. The Hon. H.W. Palmer has been engaged as counsel for the society, and a lively fight is expected.
John J. Doyle was convicted of bigamy in the Hudson County Court of Quarter Sessions, at Jersey City, yesterday, in having married Mary F. Brown, a widow, while his first wife was still alive.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 15.--McGinnis Tracy, shoe manufacturers, at Stoneham, have failed.

There was a solemn sermon preached in Judge COWING'S court yesterday on the familiar theme of the mutability of human greatness.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Jan. 15.--It has been discovered here that the Sheriff of Ulster County, his corps of constables, and a small army of amateur detectives have been looking for the wrong man in their search for the murderer of the Kingston saloon-keeper, Edwin Kelland.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 15.--Joseph C. Greenewald, of Bradford, Penn., and Miss Matilda Levy, of this city, both well known in Hebrew social circles in New-York, Philadelphia, and other cities, were married in the Jewish syna gogue here this evening, in the presence of a very large number of friends. Many visitors from abroad were present. The bride wore a thousand-dollar dress decorated with diamonds.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 15.--The Governor has pardoned Henry L. Hay, sentenced Oct. 8, 1875, in Cortland County, to 20 years' imprisonment in Auburn prison for the crime of rape, and has filed the following reasons:
EASTMAN, Ga., Jan. 15.--Willis Hodges, of Chauncey, some time ago had a quarrel with Lizzie Jones, with whom he was living. In a fit of jealousy Hodges stabbed Lizzie with a knife ...
BOSTON, Jan. 15.--Mrs. Valeria G. Stone, who died in Malden, a suburb of Boston, to-day, was one of the foremost among public benefactors. She gave for public purposes nearly $2,000,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 15.--The late Senator Morton's memory was honored to-day in a manner befitting the State. All arrangements for the commemorative exercises were complete, and the ceremonies attendant upon the unveiling of the monument passed off successfully and satisfactorily.

Commissioner of City Works Ropes has made the first appointment in Brooklyn under the civil service law. At the examination held some days ago Thomas C. Kelly passed satisfactorily in Schedule C. The examiners, after consultation with mr. Thomas F. Powers, Chief Boiler Inspector of the Police Department, accepted the latter's certificate of examination as proof that the applicant was a competent engineer.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 15.--The Louisiana Conference of the Methodist Church South has just finished its labors. The venerable Bishop Kavanagh presided.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 15.--The International Convention of Bricklayers, which was opened in this city yesterday, is attended by 100 delegates.

The annual meeting of the Kings County Free Trade League was held last evening in the assembly-rooms of the Academy of Music. It was decided after some discussion to change the name of the organization to the Brooklyn Free Trade League.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 15.--The troubles of the West Shore Company have caused much uneasiness among the people of Frankfort, where the company's shops are situated. Citizens of that village and Ilion, with the aid of a few thousand dollars from Utica, raised $77,000 to pay for ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 15.--The fifth annual meeting of the New-York State American Merino Sheep Association is now being held in this city. There are 75 delegates in attendance, and W.G. Markham, of Avon, is President.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15.--The present indications are that the coming season will witness a vigorous war for emigrants between Manitoba and Dakota, as a result of which the Canadian Pacific will be pitted in a pitched battle ...
"Old Heads and Young Hearts" will be presented for the last time to-night at Wallack's Theatre. It will be followed to-morrow evening by "Deception."

The New-York Real Estate and Traders' Exchange was incorporated yesterday by a certificate filed in the County Clerk's office. Its corporators are Horace Winans, John J. Anderson, John Goggin, John W. Stevens, James H. Farley ...

A dispatch from Albany, published yesterday, contained a statement that the Bar Association--but whether of the State or of this City was not made clear--was preparing charges for the impeachment of five Judges of the Supreme Court.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 15.--The past year was one of loss to those engaged in the whale fisheries, and the results were discouraging. The failure of the arctic season, with the small catches in other localities, has been the cause of the trouble.
MADRID, Jan. 15.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day Senor Castelar condemned King Alfonso's visit to Germany, declaring that it was inopportune and imprudent, betraying as it did hostility to France.
READING, Penn., Jan. 15.--A tramp named Hirst made an assault yesterday on Mrs. Koenig, wife of a farmer in the northern section of this county, during the temporary absence of her husband.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Jan. 15.--A sensational divorce suit has been commenced in the Circuit Court of this city. Mrs. Mary Garthwait, a prominent and popular member of Bloomington society, brings the suit against her husband, Louis Garthwait, a Jewelry merchant of this city, charging him with having attempted to kill her a few days ago by drawing a revolver and firing one or two shots. The bill also alleges the most extreme acts of cruelty.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 15.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following decisions were handed down: Henry M. Isaacson, appellant, vs. The NewYork Central and Hudson River Railroad Company, respondent; Horace S. Whiting, appellant, vs. John Edmonds ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 15.--At Swaines, on the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad, yesterday afternoon, Patrick Hughes, a brakeman, while engaged in making a flying switch, was crushed to death.

Chief-Justice and Mrs. Waite gave the second of their series of Tuesday evening card receptions to-night. PARIS, Jan. 15.--A banquet in commemoration of the surrender at Yorktown was given at the Hotel Continental to-night. Gen. Boulanger, the Marquis de Rochambeau, presided.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 15.--James Kay, who committed suicide in New-York, was engaged to Miss Anna Podmore, of No. 23 West-street, West Troy. The arrangements for the marriage were going on. The last Miss Podmore saw of Kay was on Jan. 6, when he made his usual call. Not calling since, the family, by inquiring at his hotel, learned that he left Jan. 7.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 15.--The marriage of Miss Maude Margaret Seymour Ingersoll, daughter of ex-Congressman Colon M. Ingersoll, and niece of ex-Gov. Charles R. Ingersoll, to George J. Angell, of the New-York commission house of Angell Co., took place to-day at 4 ...

MALDEN, Mass., Jan. 15.--A coasting accident occurred last night at Haywardville, Melrose, by which six or eight persons were severely injured. A double-runner struck a sled on which James O'Leary was seated, severing his right leg. He died within half an hour. A brother of O'Leary's, who was on the doublerunner, was hurt internally, and Charles Hayward's right leg was broken in two places. Two ladies named Hallsback were internally injured.

CAIRO, Jan. 15.--The Economic Committee recently appointed by the Khedive recommends the discharge of 1,500 native officials.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 15.--Frederick J. Siepen, employed by Weideman, Kent Co., wholesale grocers, as bill clerk, has been missing since last week, but as he had $80 on deposit in the bank and left his clothing, it was supposed he had gone off on a spree and would come back when sober.

The main floor and galleries in the Queens County Court-house at Long Island City were crowded yesterday with friends of exPoliceman Casey, the condemned murderer, to hear his sentence. Senator Covert, Casey's counsel, has filed notice in the Kings County Supreme Court that he would carry the case to the Court of Appeals. This, under the new Code, acts as a stay of proceedings.

About 400 members of the Association of Exempt Firemen attended the annual meeting of the association, in Caledonian Hall, last evening.
The third concert given by the New-York Philharmonic Club this season took place a Chickering Hall last evening, and, notwithstanding the snow-storm, was enjoyed by a large audience.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 15.--Yesterday afternoon the body of the late Father Coustarot, a Catholic priest, was brought to this city from Houma station. His death was the result of an accident which occurred at 4 o'clock Sunday morning, and which also destroyed the presbytery of the parish church at Bayou du Large, in the Parish of Terrebonne.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 15.--The interest in the Nutt murder trial was unabated this morning. The court-room was densely packed. Senator Voorhees was present, and had frequent consultations with the other counsel for the defense. Mrs. and Miss Nutt occupied seats beside the prisoner.

"You may depend upon it," Alderman Kirk remarked yesterday, "there will be no organization of the board to-morrow." POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 15.--The semi-annual examination of the different classes at West Point having been concluded, the general standing of each member of the Fourth Class will soon be made public. In this class is the last colored cadet admitted into the academy, John Hanks Alexander.

The annual meeting of the New-York and Brooklyn Association of Congregational Churches was held yesterday morning in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn. The Rev. J.G. Roberts was selected Moderator, and the Rev. S.W. Laidler was made Secretary.

The approaching close of the operatic season at the Academy of Music naturally gives rise to inquiries as to what is going to happen next. The season has been a satisfactory one so far as the performances have gone, and members of the Board of Directors have already declared through the columns of THE TIMES that financially their success has been greater than they anticipated.

At 12:50 this morning a fire broke out in A. Sartorius Co.'s bronze, paint, and oil warehouse, on the third floor of No. 31 Barclay-street. Several small firms have rooms in the building. The National Car Spring Company and the Eureka Fire Hose Company occupy the ground floor. The damage, principally by water was not over $1,500.
The Municipal Civil Service Examiners and the Mayor held a conference yesterday with the purpose of considering rules under which the examinations will be held.

TRENTON, Jan. 15.--A horseshoe of choice flowers four feet high, with a scroll of crimson roses beneath it, from "Jersey City friends," made its appearance in the Executive parlor at the State-house this morning, and was the first visible sign of the incoming of the new State Administration.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 15.--George Murgatroyd, a commercial traveler from NewYork, committed suicide at the Woodruff House here this morning by taking chloral, while temporarily insane from his losses at gambling.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 15.--The Governor's message was presented to-day. Its chief points are the recommendations of radical prohibitory legislation and the submission of woman suffrage. The Governor is in favor of authorizing the Railway Commission to enforce its decisions.

GRIFFIN, Ga., Jan. 15.--The killing of a colored girl named Hood, and the suicide of her murderer, develop features which do not warrant the claim made by the friends of the dead man that he was out of his mind.

A majority of the Directors of the West Shore Railroad Company are also Directors of the North River Construction Company. It is time that the astronomers made some explanation of their conduct in regard to the new comet. Months ago they informed us that about the middle of December they would produce a new comet of unprecedented splendor.

Again, to-day, the report is circulated that Second Assistant Postmaster-General Elmer, who has spent very little time at the Post Office Department lately, is to resign in order to go into business in New-York.

Commissioner Pierson said yesterday that he had received a telegram from Mr. McMullen, of the Alton Road, stating that the Rock Island Road had signified its willingness to settle all differences with the trunk lines and that there was no doubt the settlement would be at once carried out.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 15.--To-morrow the fishing season on Chautauqua Lake will close, and no more pickerel or bass can be taken from its waters until the 1st of June. The season the past Fall and Winter has not been a good one.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 16.--A dispatch to the Bulletin from Port Oxford, Oregon, says Jay Gould has purchased a large water front property at that place. No details are given.

The bitter fight which has been waged by the adherents of the old code of medical ethics against those of the new code has terminated as was predicted, in the formation of a new county medical organization in this City and in the beginning of an organized effort to carry the profession in this State back into the American Medical Association.

LONDON, Jan. 16.--A Hong Kong dispatch to the Times says that the Chinese expect that if Bac-Ninh falls into the hands of the French, the latter will either occupy Yu-Liu-Kan, the southern city on the island of Hai-nan or bombard Canton. The French, however, repudiate any such ideal.

The Judges of the City Court yesterday dismissed from employment under them Chief Clerk John Savage, Clerk Thomas Miller of Part I., Stenographer Stephen Haves, Interpreter John Kline, Clerk John Shea, and Court Officers Eugene Soulleyet, John Barry, and John O'Brien.

John Ennis, who was prominently idendified several years ago with six-day go-as-youplease contests, has been regarded as among the leading long distance skaters of the country. His record for 100 miles is 11:37:45, and is the best ever made.

LONDON, Jan. 17.--5:30 A.M.--A furious fire is raging in the premises of S.W. Silver Co., colonial merchants and publishers, in Suncourt, No. 67 Cornhill. The whole city is illuminated. Fire engines are arriving at the scene from all parts of the metropolis.
TRENTON, Jan. 16.--The Legislature would have been barren of interest to-day but for the announcement of the committees in the two houses.

It was reported yesterday that the NewYork Central Railroad had ordered a wholesale discharge of men and a reduction of 25 per cent. in the wages of those remaining employed along the line.

BUFFALO, Jan. 16.--Hermina Schlapp, 21 years old, a servant in the family of Louis Engel, committed suicide with poison yesterday. She was in love with a young German above her station, whom she had met casually, and had repeatedly said she could not live without him. He never paid her any attentions, and it is believed that despair finally induced her to commit suicide.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 16.--The closing sessions of the Convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Albany were held to-day. The special committee reported in favor of the consideration by committees from the dioceses of the State of the act for the incorporation of religious societies.
ALBANY, Jan. 16.--The Assembly considered in Committee of the Whole to-day the House bill for the appointment of a commission to investigate the prison contract labor system.
An examination, which lasted nearly four hours, was held in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday in regard to the killing of Joseph Ryner on Monday night.

The Senate finished to-day its consideration of the 13 proposed joint rules and adopted them, subject to the concurrence of the House. There was no debate of any kind until the last rule was reached.
A brand-new clock hung in the house of the American Society of Civil Engineers yesterday afternoon, when the members of the society met at their annual gathering to discuss uniform standard time.

The bill introduced by Senator Hoar on the second day of the session, fixing the day for the meeting of the Electors of President and Vice-President and to regulate the counting of the votes for President and Vice-President, was passed by the Senate to-day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--Taking into account the continued heavy supplies and the fact that the Eastern markets are in a by no means satisfactory condition, the sustained character of cattle prices was a surprise to the trade generally. Business was slow to open, as was to be expected, shippers seeming determined to buy the cattle cheaper.

The one hundredth representation of "The Beggar Student" will take place at the Casino on Thursday next. A beautiful and unique souvenir will be presented to those present on that occasion. The principal singers of the Grau French opera company will appear for the last time at the Sunday evening concert at this house. Mlle. Aimee, Mlle. Angele, and M. Nigri will then be heard in favorite French songs.

When Col. PRIDE concluded that there were too many Presbyterians in Parliament for the good of that body and purged the House of Commons of the objectionable element, he set the example which Mr. ROBERT B. ROOSEVELT is trying to emulate with regard to the Democratic Party in this City.
The Young Men's Republican Club held its annual meeting for the election of officers in the rooms of the Constitution Club, at No. 21 West Twenty-seventh-street, last evening.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 16.--Capt. Battram, of the steam-ship Hartville, reports having seen a comet on Jan. 13, in latitude 36 30', longitude 73 , bearing west-south-west, about 75 in height from the horizon. It was very distinct, the tail being apparently 12 feet long.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 16.--Counterfeit gold dollars bearing the stamp of 1864 are in extended circulation here. They are skillful counterfeits in everything except weight.
BRADFORD, Penn., Jan. 16.--The legislative committee appointed to investigate the Standard Oil Company met in Bradford this afternoon agreeable to an adjournment made in Philadelphia in December.

CORNING, Jan. 16.--Two years ago five young men came from the woods of Maine, where they followed the occupation of choppers, and found employment in the lumber regions of Pennsylvania, in the vicinity of Malley's Mills.
"I Puritani" was the attraction at the Academy of Music last evening, with the same cast concerned in its production at an early stage of the season.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 16.--The preliminary survey for the new Attica, Lockport and Lake Ontario Shore Railroad is being prosecuted over snowbanks and drifts such as are not often encountered in this kind of work.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 16.--The will of Ralph Sellew, who fell dead in the Lindell Hotel corridor yesterday, was filed in the Probate Court today.

LONDON, Jan. 16.--The Marquis of Salisbury was present to-day at the opening ceremonies of the Conservative Association of Dorchester. In a speech upon the occasion he deprecated the proposed extension of the franchise in Ireland.
A fashionably dressed lady and gentleman climbed the steps of the Newark city Hall just before the hour for its closing on Tuesday afternoon.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 16.--Gov. McLane sent a special message to the Legislature to-day on the labor question, accompanied by drafts of six bills, covering various branches of the subject.

The Northern Railway Company (California) has applied to the Stock Exchange to have outstanding bonds, amounting to $3,964,000, listed. These bonds represent the road completed from West Oakland to Martinez, Benecia to Suisun, and from Woodland to Tehama, aggregating about 150 miles. The bonds are dated Jan. 1, 1877, and are due Jan. 1, 1907, with interest at 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--The national convention of commercial bodies called by the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation to consider the question of the enactment of a uniform and equitable banking law met at Willard's Hotel, in this city, to-night. Eighty-five commercial bodies, representing 28 States and three national associations, were represented by delegates.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 16.--A passenger train on the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad jumped the track between De Kalb and Rensselaer Falls this afternoon. Two cars were badly wrecked and five persons were hurt, none very seriously.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--Herbert B. McCormick, an alleged defaulter, who is charged with embezzling $1,000 from B.V. Page Co., of this city, is a fugitive from justice.
Safe-burglars did a neat little job among some jewelry manufacturers in Maiden-lane on Tuesday evening, by which they obtained about $30,000 worth of merchandise.

LA CROSSE, Jan. 16.--It is now a little over a month since Louis Anderson was rescued from the hay stack under which he lay 23 days without food. The patient is enjoying good physical health, eats his food with an excellent appetite, and the process of digestion and assimilation goes on in a healthy manner. One of his feet has been amputated. It is now believed he will fully recover.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 16.--The motion for a new trial in the damage suit of A.J. Thomas, against the Western and Atlanta Railroad has been refused. The case will now go to the Supreme Court unless a compromise is made.

GLEN GARDNER, N.J., Jan. 16.--The apparition of a man with his face covered with blood, no hat on his head or coat on his back, and standing in his stocking feet, startled Edward Humphrey, the proprietor of the hotel in this little place, when he opened the door of his bedroom at 3:30 o'clock this morning.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--A general raid was made by the police to-day against the proprietors of policy shops and lotteries. Seven policy operators were arrested, two or three patrol wagons being brought into requisition to cart ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 16.--The Sugar Planters' Convention before adjourning yesterday, on motion of Col. Louis Bush, appointed a committee of nine to confer with the Republican State Convention in regard to protecting Louisiana sugar. The committee, composed of prominent Democrats, is as follows: John Dymond, E.H. Lombard, T.J. Foster, Emile Rost, Louis Bush, F.S. Kenner, T.S. Wilkinson, Andrew Price.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 16.--In the House to-day the principal topic discussed was the distribution of tickets for admission to the dedication of the new Capitol to-morrow.

BRADFORD, Penn., Jan. 16.--Prof. Faught, of Tarport, one of the victims of yesterday's railroad disaster, died to-night. Engineer Patrick Sexton is delirious to-night and is not expected to live. Others of the passengers are in a precarious condition, but the doctors feel confident of their ultimate recovery. No evidence of importance was developed at the Coroner's inquest to-day.

The experiment made by Mr. CABLE Of singing creole songs, as illustrative of the manners and customs of the people mentioned in his books, seems to have been very successful. It is a novelty which ought to furnish a hint to other public readers and lecturers, for the lyceum platform certainly needs a little novelty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--About 125 Senators and Representatives were present at the joint Republican caucus this evening, called to select a Congressional Campaign Committee. It was a significant fact that the Virginia Readjusters took part in the proceedings, and one of them, Congressman R.M. Mayo, addressed the caucus. Senator Edmunds, of Vermont, was chosen Chairman, and Representative Miller, of Pennsylvania, acted as Secretary.

The astronomical instruments given by Lewis M. Rutherfurd, to the Columbia College Observatory are now being polished, and a few of them are already at the observatory. In a few days the pedestals will be ready and the instruments mounted.
ALBANY, Jan. 16.--Speaker Sheard announced this morning the Assembly special committee to investigate the public departments of the City of New-York, Mr. Roosevelt is made Chairman of the committee.

WILKESBARRE, Jan. 16.--Political circles were much excited this morning over the fact that the Returning Board at Harrisburg failed to count the vote of Luzerne County as registered at the polls last November.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 16.--At Watkins to-day a steam boiler in an iron foundry exploded with a report which was heard all over the town. The floors, walls, and roof of the building were brought down, causing a loss of $5,000. All the workmen had gone to dinner, so that no lives were lost.
The affairs of the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad, and its kindred corporations (West Shore and North River Construction) absorbed the lion's share of attention in Wallstreet yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 16.--A committee from Hobart College, Geneva, waited on President Potter, of Union College, to-day, and tendered him the Presidency of Hobart College. He said he would consider the matter. The Schenectady Union says that Mr. Potter has also been tendered the Presidency of Griswold College, at Griswold, Iowa.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 16.--A man's body frozen stiff, was found in a car-load of wheat, which was run into the Niagara elevator here this afternoon.

The fifteenth annual competition for the Gordon medal, the emblem of the championship of the National Curling Association, began yesterday morning on Cortland Lake. A crowd of three or four hundred had assembled to view the sport, most of them on skates.

The World yesterday published an article for the purpose of showing the inequalities of assessments on property for taxation purposes. The article is pronounced at the Tax Commissioners' office to be full of glaring errors and misstatements.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 16.--George Skipper, of Suspension Bridge, lost his right leg, between the ankle and knee, by a railroad accident near that place yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, Jan. 16.--Detective Wood left Boston to-night to be present in court in NewYork to-morrow morning when the suit of Mr. Scott, a dry goods merchant of this city, against the notorious fence, Marm Mendelbaum, to recover $5,000, will be called.

BRIDGEPORT, Jan. 16.--Capt. James Hunter, of the Salvation Army here, is now in the County Jail, on North-avenue, in this city. Last Thursday evening a banquet was tendered Hunter by the ladies of Bridgeport who are in sympathy with the Salvation Army work.
ALBANY, Jan. 16.--The Assembly Committee on Commerce and Navigation spent four hours to-day in giving a hearing on the bill reducing pilotage fees at the Port of New-York 33 1/3 per cent.

BIRMINGHAM, Conn., Jan. 16.--The will of the late Joseph Arnold, for many years Cashier of the Birmingham Bank, was probated yesterday. Having provided liberally for his children, he bequeathed most of the residue of his estate to his two grand-children.

GLASGOW, Jan. 16.--Two brokers have failed here to-day, with joint liabilities of 50,000. The stock market is better, and quotations have improved.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 16.--This was the most interesting day of the Nutt trial. The attendance was as large as ever, a noticeable feature being the high character of the spectators.
