"What it will be cannot be decided until after the Everett House meeting." He spoke of the movement for the reorganization of the Democratic Party in this City.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 16.--Charles P. Stickney, one of the famous trio of forgers recently pardoned from State prison by Gov. Butler, was probably fatally burned, while his wife was burned to death here to-night by an explosion at their home caused by pouring benzine on a carpet.
A statement was telegraphed from Chicago yesterday that reports were current in that city affecting the solvency of George M. Pullman, the President of Pullman's Palace Car Company.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 16.--The deadlock in the Senatorial contest at Frankfort has come to stay. To-night the caucus adjourned at 9:35, after taking seven ballots. The sixteenth and last ballot last night gave Williams 54, Blackburn, 44, and Sweeney 23.
French clocks, bronzes, bric-a-brac, and fine fancy goods for wedding and birthday presents. Hall, Nicoll Granbery, entrances 20 and 22 John-street and 17 and 19 Maiden-lane.-- Exchange.

PARIS, Jan. 16.--The billiard contest between Schaefer and Vignaux was continued tonight, and at the close of the play the total scores for the three nights were: Schaefer, 1,800; Vignaux, 1,563; Schaefer, who made a brilliant run of 201, played 15 innings, and Vignaux, whose best run was 147, played 14 innings.

A private detective took to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday "Joe" Eaton, alias Harry Waterford, one of the most expert confidence operators in the country. He was accompanied by Dr. Thomas K. Cruse, a wellknown physician of Wappinger's Falls, N.Y.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 16.--Minnie Stypes, 16 years of age, residing at Antwerp, was burned to death last night, her clothing having taken fire from a cook stove.

The Colored Republican Central Club, which is an outgrowth of the Committee of Twenty-five appointed at a meeting held in Chickering Hall on Oct. 29 last, met to complete its organization at No. 156 Sixth-avenue last evening. The Rev. W.B. Derrick presided.

DES MOINES, Iowa., Jan. 16.--The Iowa Millers' Association met to-day. The roller millers reported four and one-half bushels of wheat to the barrel of flour, and the cost of conversion was reported as ranging from 50 to 57 cents per barrel.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 16.--Miss Lillian Grubb, a young actress of this city, has applied through the Circuit Court here to have her marriage with George Steitmatter, alias George Deberhard, declared null and void on the ground of fraud.
SCHENECTADY, Jan. 16.--Frothingham Fish, one of the additional Supreme Court Judges elected last Fall, appeared as counsel in a case at Judge Landon's Special Term yesterday.
The special committee appointed by Speaker SHEARD to investigate "the local Government" of this City gives some promise of a real investigation.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 16.--The Governor and the Committee on Prisons of the Executive Council held a conference with Mr. Comins, the failed prison contractor, this morning, at which the latter expressed confidence in his ability to make such arrangements with his creditors as to permit resumption of work in the prison shops. He will make a definite proposition on Monday, and in the meantime the convicts will be kept locked up in their cells.

The troubles which surround the North River Construction Company and the Ontario and Western Railroad Company have given rise to reports that creditors of the West Shore Road were about to apply to the courts for a Receiver for that property.

HARRISBURG, Jan. 14.--There is abundant evidence that Blaine is the first choice of a majority of the Republicans in the State of Pennsylvania, although many of them no longer believe that he can be nominated, or that, if he should be nominated, he could be elected.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 16.--Rochester Jews are discussing the question as to whether the Hebrew dietary laws are still binding, or, in other words, whether, according to the law of the church, they may eat pork. The Rev. Dr. Max Ladsburg, the most preminent Jewish clergyman in Western New-York, declares that the old dietary laws have lost their legal authority, while others claim that the Jews must not partake of the great American hog.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 16.--Richard Wagner, a maltster, 30 years old, made a peculiar and desperate attempt to put an end to his existence to-day. He has been in bad luck lately, and has been morose and ill-tempered.

The County Court rooms at Paterson were crowded to overflowing yesterday by an audience curious to hear the testimony in the famous case of Mrs. Julia Hampson against John Hinchliffe. She sued for $10,000 damages alleged to have been done her feelings by his failure to marry her according to promise.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 16.--Bloch Co., of No. 169 Elm-street, printers, publishers, and flag manufacturers, have assigned to Louis Seasongood and L.S. Levi. Their assets are estimated at $40,000, and their liabilities at about the same amount.

Mr. James F. Clay, of Kentucky, who represents the Second District of that State in the House of Representatives, and who is serving his first term in Congress, is the author of one of two bills introduced on Monday to repeal the civil service act.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Jan. 17.--A dispatch from Long Harbor, Fortune Bay, states that some 60 United States fishing vessels have loaded with frozen herring. Some of the fleet have left for home, and the others will follow in a few days. The quantity of herring in Fortune Bay is described as enormous. The Winter's catch on the west coast of Newfoundland will be large.
CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Jan. 17.--The message of Gov. Hale was read this afternoon at 2 o'clock to the Eighth Legislative Assembly. The finances of the Territory are shown to be in a prosperous condition.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 17.--The trial of James Nutt for the killing of Nicholas Lyman Dukes was continued to-day. The public interest in the case is unabated, and the Court-house was besieged all day with crowds of people eager to gain admittance to the room in which the trial is being conducted.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 17.--The Chautauqua County Historical Society held its first semi-annual meeting here to-day. The Hon. Obed Edson read a paper on the geological formation of the Chautauqua region, and Judge J.L. Bugbee one on pioneer homes. W. Mackinstry of Fredonia, also contributed a valuable paper. The society already has a large number of working members, who propose to prepare papers on all questions of historical interest to the county.

Anthony J. Bleecker, the well-known auctioneer and real estate agent, died at the residence of his son, James Bleecker, No. 100 West Fifty-sixth-street, at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, in the eighty-fifth year of his age. About two years ago Mr. Bleecker was stricken with paralysis, while sitting at his desk in his office, No. 75 Nassau-street.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 17.--Louis Stein, a ticket-scalper, was arrested to-day at the instance of the Wabash Railroad Company upon a charge of selling stolen tickets of its issue.

The grand matinee performance given at the Metropolitan Opera-house yesterday in aid of the International Charity Fund was one of the longest entertainments ever given in NewYork, as it was one of the most successful of its kind.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 17.--At a meeting to-day of the State Board of Agriculture, commendatory resolutions were passed in regard to the World's Industrial and Cotton Centennial Exposition, which opens at NewOrleans next December.

LONDON, Jan. 18.--The St. Petersburg correspondent of the Daily News says: "The murder of Lieut.-Col. Sudeikin has exercised a terribly depressing effect among the higher Russian officials. The Emperor summoned Count Tolstoi, the Minister of the Interior, and violently reproached him for lack of energy and incapacity. Count Folstoi thereupon resigned. The murderers of Col. Sudeikin wore masks."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 17.--Four ballots were taken in joint convention to-day for United States Senator without result. The last ballot stood as follows: Robinson, 21; Thomas, 16; Groome, 17; Wilson, 14; Dixon, 13; Keating, 8: F.C. Latrobe, 2; Wescott, 6; Creswell, 2; Lawson, 2; Wallace. 1. The joint convention then adjourned until to-morrow.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 17.--The striking coal miners at Beuna Vista persisted in parading again to-day The officers have gone to the works to-night and will make wholesale arrests to-morrow, and trouble is anticipated. Twentyfive strikers, principally foreigners, resumed work to-day.

MADRID, Jan. 17.--The debate on the address in reply to the King's speech was continued in the Chamber of Deputies to-day. Senor Canovas del Castillo, formerly Prime Minister, entered into an elaborate defense of the policy of the Conservatives.

Dr. Joseph Cushman, a well-known physician of this City, and who for nine years was Deputy Coroner under several Coroners, was taken to Bellevue Hospital on Wednesday last by his father, and placed in the Insane Pavilion preparatory to being taken to the Bloomingdale Asylum.

Mr. S.A.L. Bentley's Amateur Church Choir Opera Company appeared in the Turt Club Theatre last evening in Gilbert and Sullivan's opera "Patience." The performance was for the benefit of the New-York Medical College and Hospital, and was witnessed by a large audience.

COALTON, Penn., Jan. 17.--A great sensation was created in this place about a month ago by the sudden disappearance of a prominent citizen under singular circumstances, and now almost as great a one is caused by his reappearance as suddenly and mysteriously as he disappeared. The citizen's name is Uriah Wales.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 17.--The force of working men at the New-York Central Railroad shops in this city was yerterday and to-day reduced 100, and about 50 more were put on halftime.
IQUIQUE, Jan. 17, via Galveston.--Advices from La Paz, Bolivia, report a change in the Ministry. Dr. Quijarro has resigned the portfolio of Foreign Affairs.

The members of the National Vial and Bottle Association talked over the wages deadlock and the tariff for hours at the Metropolitan Hotel yesterday. Nothing was done to encourage the working men's committee, which waited patiently in the corridors, that their scale of prices would be maintained.
William Koopman, a well-known resident of Union Hill, N.J., was reported at Police Head-quarters, last night, as having been missing from his home since Monday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--Cora Wheeler, colored, swore out a warrant to-day for the arrest of the Rev. J.A.D. Podd, the former Pastor of the colored Olivet Baptist Church.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17.--Edward McLaughlin, of this city, defeated J. Randolph Heiser, of New-York, to-night at billiards, balkline game, 600 points, in the Assembly Buildings, for a purse of $250 a side.

If Italian wines on the whole do not enrich Italy and take their place by the side of Bordeaux and Burgundy--sherry and Rhine wines-- it is purely the fault of the grower. It is a curious trait of the Italian character, almost universal, not to be able to look ahead commercially and make the sacrifice of to-day's small gains to secure the greater gains of the future.

WATER VALLEY, Miss., Jan. 17.--Yesterday at Dallas, a few miles from here, a general row occurred in the store of William Harmon, during which Evans Harmon was killed, and William Harmon and Robert Lamar fatally and several others seriously wounded. The man who instigated the row and shot William Harmon is named Bishop, who escaped unhurt. He is being pursued, and, if captured, it is thought he will be lynched.

GALVESTON, Texas, Jan. 17.--A special to the News from Waco says: "The Central Trust Company, of New-York, as Trustees, filed in the United States Circuit Court at Waco last night a bill against the Texas and St. Louis Railway Company.

The Fort Greene Presbyterian Church is one of the poorest, and until recently it has been one of the most peaceful, churches in Brooklyn. Its first Pastor was the Bev. Dr. Adam McClelland, who although blind from his boyhood, was among the most successful of the better-known Brooklyn divines.

Park Commissioner CRIMMINS, ex-Alderman SHEEHY, and other citizens have asked Mayor EDSON to co-operate with them in urging the Legislature to pass a bill providing for an exterior street along the shore of the East River from Sixtyfourth street to Ninetieth.

EAST HAMPTON, Long Island, Jan. 17.-- Erastus Halsey, Collector of Taxes of Southampton, called upon Henry Jason to-day to get his taxes. Jason attacked him with an axe and cut him several times upon the head. He then took the tax-books, cut them up, and burned them. Jason was arrested. Halsey is dangerously hurt.

BUFFALO, Jan. 17.--A food deal of indignation has been excited here over statements, some of which have been telegraphed to other cities, that there is great want and destitution among the Poles, and particularly the Polish Jews living in the eastern part of this city.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 17.--Culpepper Austin and Mack Chapman, while digging a well to-day on the farm of Mark Austin, in Union County, used a dynamite cartridge in blasting. They fired the cartridge, but it failed to explode, and they returned to the well, when the cartridge exploded. Austin was terribly mangled and died. Chapman had both arms blown off and his eyes put out. He will die.

PLRIS, Jan. 17.--In the billiard contest to-night Vignaux passed Schaefer, finishing with a total score for the four nights of 2,400, Schaefer's score being 2,384. Vignaux in 12 innings made 712, including a grand run of 322, evoking much applause. Schaefer made runs of 291, 86, and 82 before the intermission for supper, and afterward made runs of 117 and 175.

The ingratitude of the Tribune is distressing. In a kind and neighborly way we spoke on Wednesday a few encouraging words about its increase in circulation from 20,000 to 24,300 since reducing its price, and in reply it thrusts out a red and forked tongue a column long.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17.--The death of an entire family from sewer-gas is causing commotion here. Five weeks ago the youngest child of Michael O'Brien, residing on the Manchester road, died, after exhibiting what looked like cholera symptoms.
John Egan, formerly Speaker of the New-Jersey House of Assembly, was arraigned before Judge McCarter, at Newark, yesterday, for sentence on the indictment charging him ...

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 17.--A solution of the troubles at Union College has probably been found in the election of President Eliphalet N. Potter as President of Hobart College, at Geneva, N.Y. Although Dr. Potter has not given an answer ...

BOSTON, Jan. 17.--The special election held to-day in the Twelfth Congressional District, to fill the vacancy caused by Mr. Robinson's electo the Governorship, resulted in the choice of Francis W. Rockwell, the Republican ...

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Jan. 17.--At noon to-day the Lykens Valley vein was struck at Bellmoore Colliery. The tunnel driven is 200 yards in length, and cost $12,000. Large sums of money have been expended at the different collieries in this district in searching for this valuable deposit, but until to-day all efforts proved ineffectual.
OURAY, Col., Jan. 17.--The people here are greatly excited over the murder of a little girl, Mary Matthews, by her foster-parents, Mike Cuddihe and wife, living 10 miles from this place.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 17.--Mr. Howe's Prison Labor Commission bill came up to-day as the special order of business in the House, immediately after the reading of the Journal this morning.

The Roman Catholic Cathedral at Westminster is to be commenced forthwith. It is to form the centre of a vast quadrangle, comprising the site of the Tothill-fields Prison recently purchased for 115,000 from the Middlesex magistrates, and a site adjoining, long in possession of Cardinal Manning.

CAIRO, Jan. 17.--The Khedive has received a telegram from the Governor-General of the Soudan reporting that the insergents have cut off the retreat of the garrisons in the Province of Sennaar, and have rendered the river Nile impassable below Deum by sinking boats in the channel.

Why young Mr. FRESHMAN broke young Mr. COWING'S nose is by no means clear, although in a matter of so much consequence it is of the highest importance that Mr. FRESHMAN'S motive should be perfectly comprehended.

The statement that Signor Garcia, the heaviest trente et quarante player of modern, on perhaps, any other, times is about to enter a monastery should stir up the recollections of many other worldlings besides myself.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 17.--An explosion occurred late to-night at the mills of the Consumers' Powder Company, about nine miles from this city. All the buildings, eight in number, were demolished, and it is supposed that the watchman, the only person about the place at night, was killed. It is impossible, owing to the lateness of the hour, to obtain full particulars of the explosion, which was distinctly heard in this city.

The recently reorganized Typothetae celebrated the one hundred and seventy-eighth anniversary of the birth of their patron saint, Benjamin Franklin, by a dinner in the Metropolitan Hotel last evening.
About 120 members of the Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen "crossed their legs under the mahogany" in Sieghortner's, in Lafayette-place, last evening.

The authoritative notice to shippers of freight by Commissioner Fink that the four lines running west from Buffalo would not accept through bills of lading issued by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad brought the Lackawanna to terms yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 17.--Interviews with members of the Assembly representing 47 of the 60 counties of the State give a variety of views upon the subject of Presidential preferences among both Republicans and Democrats.

Anthony Trollope, after relating how for 12 years his annual income from literature averaged 4,500 a year, and how in little over 20 years he made 70,000 by his pen, goes on to describe the result as "comfortable, but not splendid."

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 17.--William I. Delph, a prominent farmer living near this city, was aroused last night by a noise in his potato-patch. He took his gun and went out to investigate. Being startled by a negro's jumping up in a fence corner, Delph fired, wounding the negro, whose name was Alexander Brunson, so seriously that he died this morning.
JEFFERSON CITY, Jan. 17.--Gov. Crittenden has commuted the sentence of Emmet Jones, who was to have been hanged here to-morrow for the murder of Antoine Vaile, to imprisonment for life.
Three young men were charged in the Tombs Police Court yesterday with embezzling money from their employers, Morrison, Harriman Co., importers of dry goods and laces, at No. 503 Broadway.

The members of the American Society of Civil Engineers met at an early hour yesterday morning and proceeded to the New-York terminus of the Brooklyn bridge, where they inspected the cable system of cars. They then crossed the bridge and plunged into the science of "gripology."

Senator Edmunds and several of his associates were to-day returning from the Senate after the long discussion on the Mexican treaty the party of Senators nearly filling the street car in which they were riding.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 17.--Wesley Burse, aged 77, has been missing from Dayton since Wednesday week. It is believed he became bewildered in the dense forest and perished in the storm of last week. He had nearly $200 on his person. One hundred men spent the day searching for him. He has several sons in Michigan.

Capt. Joshua Slocumb, of the ship Northern Light, who was convicted in the United States Circuit Court a few weeks ago of malicious imprisonment of Henry Arthur Slater, one of his sailors, was fined $500 by Judge Benedict yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 17.--Social circles here are in a flurry over an approaching marriage. The groom to be is a gentleman of wealth and culture, who came to Milwaukee from Boston not many years ago, and has occupied a prominent position in the business world.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 17.--George R. Ward, proprietor of the Relay House, a prominent hotel in this city, discovered a burglar in one of the halls of the hotel this morning at 2:30 o'clock, and pursued him.

The Senate bill appropriating $1,000,000 for continuing the work of improvement on the Mississippi River was passed by the House to-day by a vote of 215 to 64.

Explanations of the workings of a new plan for elevated railroads were made before the Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday afternoon by L.J. Wing, of No. 50 Cliff-street. In this scheme the cars are suspended below an elevated superstructure, and are moved by an endless wire cable.

First District--JAMES OTIS (Republican).-- "I am for President Arthur as the Republican candidate, and I believe that he would be the choice of a majority of the Republicans of my district, although I have heard very little said on the subject yet.

It was after 12 o'clock Wednesday night before the Paferson silk ribbon weavers agreed on the schedule of wages to demand of the manufacturers. Among other things then insist that the men shall be paid hereafter for twisting in their warps and fixing their looms.

The Directors of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company yesteraay elected Robert Harris, one of their own number, President in place of Henry Villard, whose resignation was accepted at the last meeting.

The late Mr. Holloway, the English pill man, was exactly contemporaneous with the century. It has been suggested that if the century is to be remembered as the age of advertising, Mr. Holloway, more than any other man, embodied the spirit of this age.

An advertisement in a daily newspaper invites "soldiers and sailors who served in the late war, or their heirs if dead, to send their address to the Veteran Land Claim Association, Room No. 77 Astor House, New-York."
CINCINNATI, Jan. 17.--The sale of seats for the Abbey Opera Festival without premium will be begun next Monday. The festival this year will consist of 12 performances. Last year there were but eight.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 17.--The jail at Kingston, Roane County, Tenn., was set on fire this morning, about 4 o'clock, by either outside incendiaries or prisoners inside, and nearly destroyed. Five prisoners escaped. The jail has been regarded as one of the strongest in the State.

The funeral of the late Charles Delmonico took place yesterday morning at St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church, in East Twenty-eighthstreet. The church was well filled some time before 9:30, the hour appointed for the funeral, and when the procession arrived at the doors the building was uncomfortably crowded.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--The finding of the body of the young girl, Amelia Olsen, on the prairie west of the city limits, has created great excitement in the vicinity, and as the police have scarcely a clue to the murderers the mystery ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--Secretary Chandler has written to Commodore Upsher, commanding the New-York Navy-yard, in regard to the reception of the bodies of Lieut.-Commander G. W. De Long and others of the ill-fated Jeannette, which are expected to reach New-York about Feb. 15.

DES MOINES, Jan. 17.--Promptly at 2 P.M. to-day the inaugural procession moved, in the following order: Mounted police, Clarinda band, drum corps Company E, Governor's Guards; Company C, Muscatine; Company E, Looby ...

James H. Rutter, President of the NewYork Central and Hudson River Railroad, said yesterday that the discharge of men in the car department was something that occurred every Winter.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Jan. 17.--The investigation into the recent Harbor Grace affray between Orangemen and Catholics was continued to-day. Six additional witnesses for the prosecution of the Riverhead prisoners were examined. All swore that the Riverhead men fired the first shots. A dispatch from Harbor Grace states that the recovery of Bray, French, and Nicholas, three of the wounded Orangemen, is despaired of.

DETROIT, Jan. 17.--The house of Mr. Crusen, Township Treasurer of Lafayette, Gratiot County was visited last night by two burglars for the purpose of plunder. They were driven out after having fatally injured Mr. Crusen.
It is expected that the Fitz John Porter relief bill will come up in the House of Representatives to-morrow on the majority and minority reports of the Committee on Military Affairs.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 17.--In the Superior Court to-day the trial of Wesley Bunn, (white.) for the murder of Frank Cruise, (colored,) was ended, a verdict of not guilty being rendered. The case lasted two days and attracted a remarkable degree of attention.
CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 17.--The sale of subscription tickets for Her Majesty's Opera season here closed this afternoon. The two days sale netted $19,200.

BUFFALO, Jan. 17.--The women of this city who became interested in instructions in cooking through lessons given here by Miss Parloa, a few months ago, held a meeting to-day to organize a cooking school which shall act in part of its work as an auxiliary of the Charity Organization Society. It was decided to employ a teacher, and terms were fixed at $10 for 24 lessons. A good deal of interest is manifested inthe school.

PITTSTON, Penn., Jan. 17.--One of the most interesting lawsuits ever tried in this State for the right of eminent domain is now engaging the attention of the Lucerne courts, at Wilkesbarre, between James S. Slocum, of this place, and the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company. It was begun three years ago and has been fought at every point.
The Williams College Alumni Association of Boston had its seventeenth annual reunion and dinner in that city on Tuesday evening, President Franklin Carter being among the guests.
The firemen on the west side of the City were confronted last night with a fierce fire, which broke out at 11:30 o'clock in the factory building, Nos. 123 and 125 West Twenty-eighth-street.

Coroner Martin had a new interpreter on hand yesterday when he and his jury renewed their investigation into the mystery surrounding the murder of a Chinese laundryman, Loo Sing, who was found murdered on the afternoon of Monday, Jan. 7, at his laundry, No. 17 Clintonstreet.

The recent escape of a lunatic from the Surete de Bicetre, an almost unprecedented event, has led to the publication of some interesting statements about Bicetre, the French Bedlam, and its inhabitants.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Jan. 17.--The Government work upon the improvement of Hot Springs Creek was virtually suspended to-day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan 17.--At 1:30 o'clock this morning the body of Prof. Peter Voltz, a prominent citizen of Allegheny, was found at the Tenth-street railroad bridge with a bullet-hole in the right temple.

DES MOINES, Jan. 16.--The Horticultural Society convened yesterday. To-day Mr. Foster said that too little attention is being paid to the condition of the soil, mulching, moisture, These conditions enter into the results as much as does the climate.

The French steam-ship France, from Havre, which arrived yesterday, brought news of the overdue White Star steam-ship Germanic, which left Liverpool for this port on Jan. 2. The Germanic was passed by the France on Jan. 11 in latitude 47 29' and long tude 37 26'.

In chatting with Mr. Force, of Chagrin Falls, a few days ago, he told me that Garfield was a free trader when he entered Congress. Said he: "Garfield was educated in schools where the political economies favored free trade. During his first session in Congress he made several strong free trade speeches.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 17.--Andrew Collins, son of a wealthy farmer near Schenectady, disappeared four weeks ago, and it is now learned that he had forged his father's name for sums aggregating $1,000. The father repudiates the forged notes. Collins is believed to be in Colorado.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 17.--John H. Trowbridge Son, flour and grain dealers, have made an assignment. Their assets are $20,000, and are about equal to their preferences. The failure is caused by the suspension of E.W. Coleman Co., New-York.

At a meeting yesterday of the Metropolitan Industrial League a committee of 30 was appointed to meet at the Arlington Hotel, Washington, on Jan. 23, to wait on the Shinning, Ways and Means, and Post Office ...
Mr. HOWE'S bill providing for the appointment of a commission by the Governor to inquire into the subject of convict labor passed the Assembly yesterday by a vote of 74 to 41.

OSCAR P. PRICE, half-breed, from ex-GovFenton's Chautaugua district, said: "I prefer Gen. Sherman. He is talked about a good deal with us. The district would be satisfied with Edmunds, and yet a good many Republicans are feeling kindly toward President Arthur. The district is naturally anti-Arthur.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 17. -- News reached this city this afternoon that the Suwanee Sulphur Springs Hotel, probably the finest structure of the kind in the State, was burned at Suwanee early this morning. Owing to the fact that the only telegraph office in the place was in the burned building, details of the fire are almost unobtainable.

COLUMBUS, Jan. 17.--The General Assembly did little work to-day, the time being fully occupied in making arrangements for the reception and banquet to-night. The parlors of the Neil House were tastefully arranged and flowers were scattered about in great profusion, yet despite their perfume an odor of "oil" prevailed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17.--An affidavit for a capius for the arrest of the members of the firnn of Thomas Walls Sons, of Montreal and Toronto, was filed to-day by the firm of Daniel Oppenheimer Co., of London, England.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 17.--Last year a boy named John Tripcoe had his leg horribly mangled in M. George Martyn's factory, necessitating amputation at the hip. Tripcoe sued for $10,000 and to-day got judgment for $900. Martyn will appeal, claiming that Tripcoe was not employed in the factory and was unwarrantably meddling with the machinery when injured.

A telegram was received yesterday morning by Superintendent Walling from W.E. Marsh, Chief of Police of Bridgeport, Conn., asking for the arrest of a man on board the steamer Crystal Wave, who had in his possession a quantity of stolen silver-plated ware.

The Park House, a laborers' resort and boarding-house, on Trumbull-street, Elizabethport, N.J., was the scene of a tragedy on Wednesday night, in which George B. Ruher, a 16-yearold waiter, was killed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--Leave of absence for six months, on account of disability, has been granted Capt. Richard Barnett, Assistant Surgeon.

The robbery at No. 49 Maiden-lane is all the talk among the jewelers, who express a great deal of surprise that so much property should be intrusted to small, ordinary fire-proof safes that were known not to be burglar-proof.
The Massachusetts Republican State Committee will meet Feb. 20 to issue the call for the State Convention.

The Hoboken Turtle Club made an experiment last evening. The indigestible substances which go to make up a "shore" dinner in the Summer-time, for the club, were abandoned, and its members tested the food of civilization at the Sinclair House.
Justice Cullen, sitting in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday handed down a decision in the Hogan divorce case. The plaintiff, Catharine A. Hogan, was married ...

DENVER, Col., Jan. 17.--The Grand Montezuma Hotel at Las Vegas, New-Mexico, was burned this afternoon. The fire originated in the basement, it is supposed, from a gasoline machine. In 30 minutes the hotel was in ruins.

LONDON, Jan. 18.--Special dispatches from Paris state that no commercial crisis really exists there. The trade of Paris is more active than at any time during the past year, and the attempts of the socalled working men's delegates are made solely for political effect.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Jan. 18.--A strong wind last night filled the Tonawanda Branch of the Central Railroad with snow, so that two passenger trains became stalled near Pembroke this morning. One train that left Batavia at 7 o'clock this morning was 10 hours in reaching Buffalo, a distance of 40 miles.

The Senate in executive session to-day rejected the Mexican treaty. A motion was made to reconsider the vote, pending which the Senate adjourned until Monday. Beyond these facts the reports with regard to the matter are contradictory and some confusion seems to exist in the minds of Senators themselves with respect to certain features of the proceedings.

"Eddie" Kerns, alias "Hatteras," who was registered on the police returns as John Brown, and Peter Jordan, who is believed to be "Dicky" McManus, both skilled safe burglars, were arrested Wednesday night by Central Office detectives and were entered on the books as suspicious persons.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 18.--The Essex County Grand Jury came into court this after noon with a presentment recommending the establishment of a whipping-post for wife-beaters.

We wish our esteemed Democratic contemporaries would cease to persecute each other for opinion's sake. Here is the Washington Post, which says: "What a deal of political mush can be contained in one single issue of the New-York Daily Sun."
BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 18.--The Maryland Legislature to-day elected Judge Ephraim King Wilson, of Worcester County, to the United States Senate, to succeed James Black Groome.

ROCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 18.--Four men were instantly killed and seven seriously injured by the bursting of a boiler here this afternoon, at the shoe factory of Wallace Brothers. The accident happened in the engine-room. The shop is run by an engine of 120 horsepower, to which are attached three boilers.

LONDON, Jan. 18.--The Press Association to-day publishes an interview with a leading member of the French Embassy in London. BALTIMORE, Jan. 18.--The hearing in the case of Romulus A. Bonhumum, an Italian, has been again postponed until Friday next. Bonhumum is charged with swindling several parties in New-York by pretended sales of land.

Michael Tobin and Theodore F. Lindsay, a bar-tender, became engaged in a quarrel in Geraty's saloon, at Sixth-avenue and Thirdstreet, on the night of Aug. 22. Tobin picked up a bung-starter and struck Lindsay on the head, inflicting a wound from which Lindsay died.
During the Winter of 185l the Hon. William L. Marcy was boarding at the Irving House, (corner of Chambers-street.) One morning the office boy handed him a letter from New-Orleans.

The name Niagara has passed through many orthographical changes in the last 200 years. In 1687 it was written Oniagoragh. In 1686 Gov. Dongan appeared uncertain about it and spelled it Ohniagero, Onyagara, and Onyagro.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18.--Thomas S. Dando, a well-known job printer of this city, and the Secretary of the Riverton Gun Club, an organization composed exclusively of men of wealth, was married yesterday afternoon to Miss Helena D. Jones, of New-York.

A good deal is being said about the recent insanity of Gen. Mackenzie. The writer lived in Santa Fe last Winter and Spring, and saw much of the General. He was devotedly attached to his mother, a noble woman.
Frank Wiener, a real estate agent, of No. 114 Seventh-street, keeps an account at the German Exchange Bank, at Bowery and Bondstreet.

RAGUSA, Dalmatia, Jan. 18.--A hurricane passed over the southern portion of Dalmatia yesterday. It did great damage to shipping in the harbor.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Jan. 18.--Mayor Brothers Co. filed in the office of the Chancery Clerk to-day a bill of sale of their entire stock of dry goods and notions.

Two questions bid fair to become prominent in the present Congress: one the proper method of counting the Electoral votes; the other the proper method of filling a vacancy in the office of the President and of the Vice-President.
The final meeting of the Executive Committee of the Pedestal Art Loan Exhibition was held yesterday afternoon at No. 6 East Fourteenth-street to listen to the report of the Finance Committee.
Mr. Maurice Grau has an agent in NewOrleans gathering together the remnants of the Defossez French opera company for the purpose of organizing a troupe for South America.

Prof. Wiliam G. Sumner, of Yale College, delivered the first of a course of lectures before the Brooklyn Revenue Reform Club, in the Long Island Historical Society's hall, last evening. His subject was "The American System."

A man, whose face was almost livid and who shook as if he had the ague, sat in an upper room of the Nassau House, in Oyster Bay, yesterday morning. Detective John L. Wood, of Pinkerton's Agency, and Detective James W. Smith, commissioned by the District Attorney, had been in charge of him.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 18.--Coroner Shiffer held an inquest this afternoon on the body of Hallie Scholl, who died on Wednesday night from the effects of criminal malpractice. The jury returned a verdict against Dr. Bruce, of No. 1,416 Brown-street, Philadelphia, and Joseph B. Strickler, of Mount Joy, both of whom are in custody.

Capt. Evans, of the steam-ship Barraconta, which arrived last evening from the West Indies, reports that during a storm on Dec. 30 the bark St. Lawrence dragged her anchor and went ashore in the harbor of Demerara. She got off, but was obliged to discharge a portion of her cargo and to undergo repairs. The St. Lawrence was bound for Boston.
Bradstreet's reports 321 failures in the United States during the past week, 24 less than the preceding week, 4 more than the corresponding week of 1883, and 111 more than the same week of 1882.

An able-bodied father was slowly wending his way home to dinner yesterday, when his eye fell upon his young hopeful hard at work shoveling snow for an uncle, for fun. It's curious what lots of fun it is for boys to shovel snow for somebody else, and yet it is such hard work to shovel snow off the pavement at home.

The Republican voters who have enrolled themselves under the new plan in the several Assembly districts in this City were given an opportunity yesterday to vote for delegates to the County Committee, members of the Assembly District Committees, and enrolling officers.
The suit of Julia Hampson against John Hinchliffe for breach of promise of marriage was continued yesterday at Paterson.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 18.--A correct list of the insurances on the Montezuma Hotel at Las Vegas, New-Mexico, which was burned yesterday, is at present unobtainable. No one company is credited with over $5,000, and in most cases the insurance is $2,000.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 18.--A large amount of very righteous indignation is being manifested by a good class of patrons of the local theatres on account of the manner in which the sale of seats for the opera season is being conducted. It is asserted that there is hardly a bar-...

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 18.--The first Jewish temple ever erected in this city was dedicated this afternoon in the most impressive manner by the Rev. Mr. Samfield, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Isaac M. Wise, of Cincinnati, and Dr. S. Sonnescheim, of St. Louis. The structure cost $40,000, and will seat 600 persons comfortably.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 18.--A gentleman of this city, knowing Mr. Argus Dean, of Otto, Ind., to be one of the most experienced and intelligent of fruit-growers, asked his opinion of the effect on the orchards of the recent cold weather. Here is the reply:

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Jan. 18.--Advices from Long Harbor to-night report the departure of 21 addiiional schooners loaded with frozen seine herring of excellent quality. They secured their fares at New-Harbor and Recontre. Fortune Bay is still swarming with herring schools. Before Jan. 21 the whole fleet of NewEngland catchers will have sailed for home. The crews are all well and the fleet has escaped accident.
Under a law passed by the last Legislature the Trustees of common lands of the town of Gravesend, Long Island, have sold the leases of the lots on Coney Island between Brighton Beach and the Point.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 18.--Senator Gourinot, of Cape Breton, had a severe paralytic stroke this evening in the Senate Chamber. He is now lying in a private room in a critical condition.

LONDON, Jan. 18.--The Cairo correspondent of Reuter's Telegram Company says an official dispatch has been received stating that the whole country around Khartoum is in open rebellion against the Egyptian Government.
WILMINGTON, N.C., Jan. 18.--The shock of an earthquake was felt in this city about 8 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--Secretary Folger has sent to the Speaker of the House of Representatives a letter with regard to certain amendments which he thinks should be made in the bill passed last March to prevent the importation of adulterated and spurious teas.

A working model of the New-York Automatic Spring Motor Company's invention for propelling street cars was exhibited before the Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday by the inventor, D.M. Pfantz, of Philadelphia.
The Paterson Silk Ribbon Weavers' Committee of Three, appointed to wait on the manufacturers, met with very little or no encouragement in their journey.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Jan. 18.--An engine and three box-cars on the Louisville, NewOrleans and Texas Railroad fell through a bridge neat Port Gibson this evening. Sim Coates, the engineer, was killed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The general courtmartial convened at Columbus Barracks, Ohio, by special orders of Oct. 12, and the general court-martial convened at David's Island, New-York Harbor, by special orders of Oct. 12, have been dissolved; this order to take effect upon the completion of any case that may be before the court at the time of its receipt.

Patrick Gleason, of Jersey City Heights, was killed by a Morris Essex Railroad train in the Hackensack Meadows Thursday night. He was walking on the Pennsylvania Railroad when he was met by a train. He stepped on to the Morris and Essex track, which runs parallel with the Pennsylvania, and was struck by a train he had not seen.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 18.--What will in all probability prove a murder occurred last night at Port Bowkley, a small village about two miles north of this city.

Gov. ROBINSON, of Massachusetts, would like to see "concurrent action" taken by the States for the unification of the marriage laws. The Evening Post approves of the object, but suggests that it can best be attained by an amendment to the Constitution.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 18.--Mr. C.J. Hamlin, the leading man in the grape sugar manufacturing business here and throughout the country, yesterday executed a mortgage for $200,000, payable to the Rochester City Savings Bank.

The fire which broke out late on Thursday night in the factory of Smith Bell, Nos. 123 and 125 West Twenty-eighth-street, was not extinguished until daylight yesterday morning. The factory is in ruins.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 18.--County Treasurer M. Wells Bridge was overpowered by three disguised men in his office about 5:30 o'clock this evening, and the vault was robbed of about $400 in money and $1,400 in notes on which payment had been stopped.

ALBANY, Jan. 18.--Very little business was transacted by the Assembly at to-day's session. Mr. Cornelius Donohue managed to have brought into the House from the Cities Committee his Excise bill, which repeals, for the benefit of Buffalo whisky-dealers, the three-bed ...

SCRANTON, Jan. 18.--Michael Logan, of the Diamond Flats, a portion of this city, attended a ball in Oliphant, five miles distant, last night with a jolly sleighing party, and appeared to enjoy himself hugely, dancing and playing the fiddle.

BOSTON, Jan. 18.-F.W. Nickerson Son to-night received a dispatch from Capt. S.E. Wright, of the steamer City of Columbus, which sailed hence on Thursday, for Savannah, stating that the vessel had gone ashore on Devil's Bridge, Gay Head, and was fast breaking up.

A Scotch doctor who, as it is unnecessary to say, is entirely incapable of joking, claims to have discovered how to produce Italian tenors in unlimited quantities in Glasgow or even less musical towns.

BOSTON, Jan. 18.--The disappearance of Jesse Dean, the Conservatory of Music pupil, who left his home, No. 12 James-street, on Tuesday last, is still shrouded in mystery. His mother, who is grief-stricken over his absence, is, with the assistance of the Police Department, making ...

Fifty Associated Pioneers of the Territorial Days of California sat down to a dinner last night at Clark's, in West Twenty-third-street, and proceeded to wander through an elaborate menu with a relish characteristic of the old '49 days.

The public rehearsal preliminary to the fourth concert given by the Philharmonic Society this season took place yesterday afternoon in presence of an overflowing audience. The programme consisted wholly of orchestral music. The single novelty performed was a "Serenade," (which might more justly be called a "Suite,") by C. Villiers Stanford.

Counsel for Dr. Peacock and John D. Harrington, who are in custody in Jersey City for the American Legion of Honor grave-yard insurance frauds, made application yesterday for a writ of certiorari, removing the indictment to the Supreme Court for review as to its sufficiency. The argument will be heard to-day. The certiorari will delay the trial of the defendants for several months.
Senor Don Juan de Valera, the newly appointed Spanish Minister at Washington, arrived yesterday on the Cunard steam-ship Cephalonia.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18.--The jury in the suit of George R. Duncan against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to recover damages for injuries to plaintiff's property at Twenty-third and Filbert streets, this city, by the construction of an elevated railroad, to-day returned a verdict awarding $20,000 damages to the plaintiff.
A sleigh drawn by a handsome pair of grays skimmed along over the frozen snow on St. Nicholas-avenue Thursday afternoon, passing everything on runners like a flash.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 18.--Richard Delaney, of East Fishkill, has been arrested on the charge of assaulting women. It is claimed that he was the one who assaulted Miss Benjamin, the school teacher, for which crime a man named Harrington was arrested. Delaney stoutly asserts his innocence.
MONTREAL, Jan. 18.--C.F. Dewey, who pleaded guilty in Boston to having forged bills of lading and getting advances from American and Canadian banks, has refunded $60,000 of the amount.

George W. Ammerman, otherwise known as Jolly George and Allman and Anderson, died yesterday afternoon in V.L. Lewis's drug store, at Hudson and Charlton streets, of hemorrhage from a wound in the right femoral artery inflicted by James Hardie.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 18.--The Nutt murder trial still continues to be the centre of attraction for lovers of the sensational, and every available spot in the court-room was occupied to-day. Many of the ladies stood throughout the proceedings.

Williams, who owns a stoneyard at East Sixty-eighth-street and Avenue C, is one of the earnest advocates of the scheme for the improvement of the East River front, between Sixty-fourth and Ninety-first streets, by the laying out of a street and building of a bulkhead along the river-front. The ice on Conservatory Lake, Central Park, was not in the best possible shape yesterday for curling, being soft and crumbled in places. These slight drawbacks, however, were not sufficient to dampen the ardor of the large number of curlers present.

Mr. Carlisle hears calmly all the reports about the resistance the Protectionist Democrats are to make to a bill proposing to reduce the tariff, and the members of the Ways and Means Committee do not retreat from the position they have always occupied, or express any other view than that a bill correcting the injustices of the present tariff must be reported and fought for if necessary.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 18.--The trial of the Jenkins brothers for the murder of the Rev. J. Lane was begun to-day. About 25 witnesses will be examined on either side. The case will probably last many days.

The Rev. Dr. Justin D. Fulton and Gen. Conway have reached an amicable settlement of their differences, the church of which the Doctor is Pastor having rescinded their former action, and granted a letter recommending the General to any other Baptish church. The suits now pending against Dr. Fulton are to be discontinued.
The vexed question of completing the facade of the Florentine Duomo in the tricuspedal or basilican style has been referred to the Artists' Club in that city, and finally decided.

The condition of this well-known society, the American Numismatic and Archaeological Society, seems to be excellent, and both the library and cabinets have been enriched with fresh and interesting material.

The confession of TAPPAN regarding his share in the Maybee murder is evidently true so far as it goes, and as evidently it is not the whole truth. What is, perhaps, most revolting in it is the insensibility to which it testifies in its author.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 18.--Superintendent Smith, of the Alden Coal Company, today offered the miners employed by the company who have been out on a strike since the first of the year the same prices as are paid at Nanticoke for mining, but the men refused to accept the offer, stating they would not recede from their position, and demanded that the company accede to their terms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18, 1884. The members of the Missouri delegation in Congress met to-day and resolved to make every effort to secure the holding of the Democratic National Convention in St. Louis. They will communicate with members of the National Committee and present the advantages claimed for that place by its citizens.

"Just keep an eye to them things," said Barney Barry, a peddler, as he dumped three bags of oats at Officer Belger's feet on the corner of Jersey and Newark avenues, Jersey City, early yesterday morning.
DECATUR, Ga., Jan. 18.--A tragedy ocourred near this town last night in which Henry Craig was mortally wounded by Henry Griffin. There was a woman connected with it.

The Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction received proposals yesterday for some of the articles of apparel and diet that are to be consumed and worn by the army of more than 12,000 of the City's poor and the City's wicked who languish on the Municipal islands in the East River.

A singular explosion occurred in a private house in Long Island City, yesterday morning, the result of which was that one little boy was almost instantly killed, while another was very seriously, although not fatally, wounded.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 18.--The quarterly rent, of $200,000, due the city from the lessees of the Southern Railroad on Jan. 12, had not been paid at the close of business hours to-night. The leasing company is the Cincinnati, New-Orleans ...
Two witnesses were examined in the Marie-Garrison suit yesterday. They were Lewis B. F. Randolph, Treasurer of the Illinois Central Railroad, and Thomas Denney, a broker for 30 years in this City.

The practice of cremation appears to be gradually gaining ground in Germany, there being a steady increase in the number of bodies brought for this purpose to Gotha, which contains the sole establishment in the empire.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 18.--Frank Harvey's "Hidden Hand" combination, which has been playing here this week, went to pieces today for lack of funds, and everything was attached to pay their hotel bill.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 18.--George Skipper, who lost his leg at Suspension Bridge on the 15th inst., by being run over by a locomotive, died this morning from the effects of the injury. Mr. Skipper was a local engineer on the NewYork Central Railway for two years. His remains will be taken to Warren for interment.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Jan. 18.--Depositions are being taken here before a Commissioner in the case in which Prof. Fiske, of Ithaca, N.Y., contests his wife's will giving $2,000,000 to Cornell University. The tendency of the testimony is to show that Cornell University had all the property allowed by its charter, hence it could not take the bequest. Lieut.-Gov. Hill, of NewYork, appeared for the contestants, and the Hon. S.D. Halliday, of Ithaca, for the university.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The House of Representatives spent nearly its entire session to-day in discussing the Fitz John Porter Relief bill. A special session for talk on the same subject will be held to-morrow, and the prospect is that the Porter measure will occupy the attention of the House on "private bill days" for weeks to come.

Mr. Maurice Grau's French opera-bouffe company last evening presented their idea of Audran's charming opera "Olivette." The conception is so different from anything that we have been accustomed to receive as correct that it is difficult to estimate its worth.

The Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads of the House of Representatives has made a favorable report on Congressman Skinner's bill to provide for a more speedy delivery of letters in cities where the carrier system is now in use.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Jan. 18.--A decision in the matter of the validity of the indictments against Lawrence Brainerd, of the St. Albans Trust Company, was given this morning by Judge Veasey, of the Supreme Court.
BUFFALO, Jan. 18.--There is to be an effort made to form a pool of all railroads owning bituminous coal interests and of all private shippers and miners contending for business in the Buffalo market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--The Government paid for the services of detectives during the two star route trials $7,250 28. Of this amount $6,790 28 was paid to Allan Pinkerton for the per diem and expenses of his operators.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--At a meeting of the House Committee on Public Lands to-day, ex-Senator Mitchell continued his argument against the forfeiture of the Oregon Central land grant.
SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 18.--The explosion at the powder mills of the Consumers' Powder Company, shortly before midnight last night, was one of the most violent of the kind ever felt in this section.

PARIS, Jan. 18.--The billiard contest between Vignaux and Schaefer ended to-night in favor of the former. Vignaux played 12 innings and made 600 points, including a wonderful run of 328, which evoked enthusiastic applause.

WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 18.--At 7 o' clock this morning two men names Morris Mills and Francis Batterson, while walking along the beach here, saw a pair of horses standing unattended at the mouth of New Creek. Turning aside they crossed the frozen salt meadows and approached the team.

At a recent meeting of the Jersey City Board of Works a motion was made for a committee to confer with the New-York authorities with a view to the making of an arrangement by which the lower part of New-York City may be supplied with water from the Jersey City reservoirs. Mayor Taussig yesterday appointed a committee of 30, consisting of office-holders and other citizens.

The Patchogue and Suffolk County Bank, a private institution owned by Edward S. Peck, at Patchogue, Long Island, suspended yesterday. The reason for this is said to be losses sustained in grain speculation by Mr. Peck, who was drawn into it by outside parties.

Not long after Secretary Folger took charge of the Treasury Department he deprived Mr. Albert Daggett, of Brooklyn, of a contract for weighing, which was said to have yielded him an exceedingly handsome annual income.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 18.--The ice yachting season is now fairly opened, and there was an interesting race at New-Hamburg this morning between eight boats of the second class belonging to the New-Hamburg Ice-boat Club, the entries being the Halcyon, Dart, Magic, Whiff, Phantom, Whistler, Puff, and Flyaway.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Jan. 18.--In response to numerously signed petitions the Postal Department in August last announced that on and after Sept. 1 the West Shore Railroad would convey the mails along the westside of the Hudson River, between Jersey City and Albany.

The afternoon games of the pool tournament yesterday between Dankleman and Leonard resulted in favor of Leonard by 11 to 9.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 18.--For years there has been a feeling of unrest among the colored people of this State which has manifested itself at various times by organized efforts to promote emigration to other sections.

BOSTON, Jan. 18.--The hat store of Samuel Orr, at North Adams and Blackstone streets, was completely shattered by an exnlosion at midnight. The building was blown into the street and the Fire Department are endeavoring to save the adjoining building. The explosion was probably caused by gas.

It has so long since become the established belief among intelligent men that, as a rule, detectives do not detect, one need not wonder at the elaborate futility of the detective service in the star route cases.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 18.--The collapse of the Milwaukee Co-operative Cigar Factory calls attention to the disruption of the Cigarmakers' Union, which established the enterprise, and which two years ago was one of the most extensive and powerful labor organizations in the country.

A communication pointing out the urgent need of official action in the matter of international copyright has been sent to Secretary Frelinghuysen by the American Copyright League, an association recently organized by a number of American authors, and of which Mr. George Parsons Lathrop is Secretary.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 19.--The investigation into the facts concerning the boiler explosion on board the steamer Colorado in Lake Erie, on the 29th of September last, must all be made over again.

A sigh came up through the forest. A sobbing breath of the dying Summer. It stirred the leaves, scarlet, and russet, and orange, of the trees that had already begun to don their Autumn dress, and scattered the petals of a crimson-flowered creeper at the feet of a man and woman standing near.

The audience attracted to the Academy of Music by "L'Elisire d'Amore," yesterday after noon, was sufficiently numerous to indicate that but for the stormy weather the attendance would have been unusually large.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 19.--News of the wreck of the City of Columbus and the terrible loss of life was received with profound sorrow in this city. There were no residents of Savannah aboard. Deep sympathy is expressed for the calamity, which has carried sorrow to many families in New-England.

A Wall-street man who is largely interested in the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company stated yesterday that a proposition is under consideration by which that company will be able to borrow from the city of Baltimore $2,000,000 on 50 years time, but payable at the option of the railroad company.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 19.--The boiler of the saw and grist mill of Brink Elkins, at Hawsville, some 12 miles from Columbia, Ill., exploded yesterday, severely injuring several persons and wrecking the engine and engine-room. Simon Roberts and William Walker were fatally scalded. Engineer Nevins was badly scalded and had his arm broken and was otherwise hurt. Ludlow French and Mr. Head were also slightly scalded.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 19.--The boiler in the Cincinnati Corrugating Company's manufactory, corner of Culvert-street and Egglestonavenue, exploded this afternoon and set the building on fire.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 19.--A deputation from St. John, Quebec, and otherplaces in Lower Canada, waited upoc Mr. Chapleau, Secretary of the State, to request the intervention of the Dominion Government in support of their claims upon the United States Treasury Department for the recovery of certain excessive duties exacted by American Customs authorities upon large quantities of hay entered from Canada at American ports. Mr Chapleau promised to lay the question before his colleagues.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 19.--In the House of Commons to-day the Hon. Mr. Blake, the leader of the Opposition, severel criticised the Government's policy as indicate in the speech from the throne. In the course of his remarks he said that the part Canada had taken in the London Fisheries Exhibition was barren of results, and that the money would have been spent to better advantage in concluding a workable fishery treaty with the United States.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 19.--Contrary to expectation, the Assembly committee appointed to examine into the affairs of the Western House of Refuge did not to-day continue the taking of testimony, but instead the members departed to their respective homes.
WOOD'S HOLL, Jan. 19.--The first news of the disaster of Gay Head reached here this morning by the tug Storm King, of Boston, Capt. McDonald, and created the greatest excitement.

The strike of the Paterson silk ribbon weavers remained yesterday very much in the same condition as on Friday. The three largest mills in the business are those of Dexter, Lambert Co., William Strange Co., and Pelgram Meyer.

The loss of the City of Columbus should be made the subject of a thorough investigation. She went ashore on a night when there was no fog, and Gay's Head Light was so distinctly visible that the officer of the deck had no excuse for not knowing precisely where the vessel was.

LONDON, Jan. 19.--The Pall Mall Gazette, in editorially commenting upon Gen. "Chinese" Gordon's mission to Egypt, says that henceforth Great Britain has the full and undivided responsibility of the Soudan. Gen. Gordon, in going to the Soudan as the representative of the British Government, must entail, as a natural corollary, the assumption of a similar responsibility for the affairs of Egypt proper.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 19.--Seven members of the family of Henry Kendall, a resident of this city, have been poisoned by a decoction known as "Rough on Rnts," which had been put in biscuit by mistake. Mr. Randall and one son cannot recover.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19.--A new point in divorce law has been raised by a decision rendered by Judge Shepard, of this city, which threatens to put a stop to the immigration of lone, lorn women to this metropolis of divorce.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 19.--The Nutt murder trial is drawing to a close and will be concluded on Monday. All the evidence is now in. The Commonwealth offered some evidence in rebuttal this morning to show that the prisoner is not insane. SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 19.--Benjamin Russell was sentenced here to Dannemora Prison for four and a half years for attempting to kill his wife at a hotel last November. TROY, N.Y., Jan. 21.--The village gasworks at Malone, Franklin County, exploded on Saturday, demolishing the buildings and adjacent structures. A watchman and boy were severely bruised. The village will be without gas until warm weather.

Mrs. William Astor gave a ball last evening at her residence, No. 350 Fifth-avenue, which was certainly the most fashionable of the present season, and over which society has been agog for the past three weeks. The Astor entertainments have always been successes and invitations to them have been coveted by all who claim a place in society.

A meeting memorial of the late Julius Hallgarten will take place at Steinway Hall on Thursday afternoon at 4 o'clock. Prof. Felix Adler and others will deliver short addresses. The Philharmonic Society will play a choral and fugue by Bach, the funeral march from the Eroica symphony, and "Siegfried's Death," from Wagner's "Gotterdammerung."

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 21.--J.A. Rogers, a prominent young citizen, was murdered here early on Sunday morning, his head being split open with an axe. Four young men have been arrested and are in jail charged with the crime.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 21.--It is reported that the miners employed by the Cleveland, Pittsburg and Youngstown Railroad Company are again making riotous demonstrations at Bergholz. Bridges have been torn down, trestle work wrecked, and other property belonging to the company destroyed. Full details have not been received, as there is no telegraph communication with that district.
The striking silk ribbon weavers at Paterson met again yesterday morning and afternoon and adopted a revised schedule of wages, to be submitted to the manufacturers.

CAIRO, Jan. 21.--The Khedive has received a telegram from the Governor of the Soudan saying that on the arrival at Khartoum of the garrison of Sennaar, which is soon expected, the town will be able to repulse any attack.

The court-room of the Town Hall of Jamaica, Long Island, was packed yesterday with eager spectators long before the hour set down for the examination of Edmund S. Tappan, the self-confessed accessory to the murder of Mrs. Maybee and her daughter Annie.
At a special meeting of the New-York Yacht Club, last evening, it was decided to lease Municipal Hall, No. 67 Madison-avenue, for a club-house during the ensuing year.

BOSTON, Jan. 21.--In the United States Court to-day the suits of James P. Mulchay and John Shea against Charles J. Train, Theodric Porter, and Ralph Chandler were begun. WASHINGTON, Jan. 21.--The House Committee on Public Lands a few days ago agreed to report a bill declaring forfieited the land grant to the Texas Pacific Railroad Company, which grant, under the terms of an agreement made between the representatives of the two corporations in 1881, was transferred to the Southern Pacific Railroad Company.

The obstacle to the progress of the Feuardent-Di Cesnola case was removed yesterday by the appearance of Juror J.A. Lowrey, who was indisposed at the last nearings of the case.

A band of Indian boys from the Government training school at Carlisle, Penn., gave an entertainment in the Bedford Reformed Church, Brooklyn, last evening, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Indian Association.
WOLVERHAMPTON, Jan. 21.--Threats have been made to blow up the Post Office and Prince Albert's statue in this city by dynamite.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 21.--It has long been the desire of the Trustees of Franklin and Marshall College to build an observatory on its grounds.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 21.--With the reassembling of the Legislature at Frankfort today there appeared a horde of prominent citizens from every part of the State, who came as the friends of the several canidates for the Senathrship.
Alderman Kirk, who was elected from the Second District by two votes, yesterday became President of the Board of Aldermen by his own vote.

SPOKANE, Washington Territory, Jan. 11.--The excitement at Coeur d'Alene runs high. Miners daily bring in glowing reports. Last evening citizens of Spokane formed a stage line, and will send three coaches daily to the gold regions. This place is full of men going to the mines. The miners of Utah are excited over the placers of the Northwest. The biggest stampede ever known to the Pacific coast is expected in the Spring.
It might have been supposed that of all the countries in the world India was the one in which the bitterest opposition would have been offered to compulsory vaccination.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 21.--The Commonwealth was compelled to abandon the prosecution against Anthony Hale and John W. Edmunson, who were put on trial in the Court of Quarter Sessions to-day on the charge of conspiracy to counterfeit Brazilian notes.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 21.--Miss Sarah Lamb, age 49, who disappeared from Norwich on Wednesday, was traced to Hudson, N.Y., and back to Utica, where she was found on Saturday. It was decided that she was insane, and she was sent to a lunatic asylum.

The third rental of pews, since they ceased to be free, in the Brooklyn Tabernacle took place last night. One thousand persons came to attend it. Each person was given a diagram on entering to show the location of the pews by the numbers.

The Flatbush mock marriage, with the accompanying revelations of promiscuous kissing at church festivals, which occupied so much space in the newspapers some time ago, came up in another phase yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 21.--The twentyeighth annual meeting of the New-Jersey Editorial Association was held at the American House, in this city, this morning.

A general meeting of the Commanders and delegates from Grand Army posts of this City and Brooklyn to the State Encampment was held last evening at Schilling Hall, No. 364 Sixth-avenue, for the purpose of selecting a candidate for Department Commander, Gen. McMahan presiding.

The inventory of the estate of the late Mr. Coats, of Ferguslie, a well-known Scotch millionaire, was lodged with the authorities at Paisley on Friday. The personal estate amounts to nearly 1,400,000, and the stamp duty to 40,000. There is not a single charitable bequest in the will.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 21.--At the municipal election in this city to-day, D. Ward Northrop, Secretary of State, was chosen Mayor by a majority of 16 over Edward Payne, Republican. This is the first time for 10 years that the Democrats have elected their candidate for Mayor. The Common Council is Republican by a small majority.
OTTAWA, Jan. 21.--Mr. Home, member of Parliament for New-Westminster, British Columbia, states that Chinese immigration into that Province has ceased.
BOSTON, Jan. 21.--The unclaimed and unidentified bodies of the victims of the City of Columbus disaster were brought to this city from New-Bedford to-day.

The trial of the suit for divorce of Mrs. Florence M. De Meli from her husband, Edward A. De Meli, on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment, was continued yesterday before Judge William Rumsey, at the Special Term of the Supreme Court, from the point where it was discontinued a month ago.
LONDON, Jan. 22.--Robert Kettle Co., cotton-yarn merchants, of Glasgow, have failed. Their liabilities are 300,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21.--Passed Assistant Surgeon Robert Whiting has been detached from the Norfolk Navy-yard and ordered to the Colorado. Paymaster H.G. Colley has been ordered to duty on the store-ship Monongahela on March 1.
Mr. John Roach's argument prevailed with the active members of the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday, and his views, in the form of resolutions, were adopted by a vote of 24 to 11.

BOSTON, Jan. 21.--The fall in Atchison stock continued to-day, but the decline was not serious. Fully 5,600 shares changed hands. The buying was generally by strong parties, and the belief is that the attack upon it will be resisted.
UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 21.--Congressman William Dorsheimer has accepted an invitation of the Oneida Historical Society to deliver the address at the dedication of the Ariskany Monument.
LIMA, Jan. 21, via Galveston.--Senor Elmore has been appointed Minister Plenipotentiary from Peru to the United States.

BOSTON, Jan. 21.--Jesse Dean, the Oshkosh boy, who has been missing from his boarding place at the Highlands since Jan. 15, returned to-night. No particulars of his absence have yet been learned owing to the condition of his mother, who is completely prostrated.

Wood, of Philadelphia, iron-dealers, and Decker Rapp, dealers in lumber, in this City. The Messrs. Wood sue for $1,859.22 and Decker Rapp for $2,688.91.

A long-standing quarrel between the Rev. Emory J. Haynes and a large number of the members of the Washington-Avenue Baptist Church, Brooklyn, has just ended by the resignation of the Pastor. Mr. Haynes has been connected with the church in his present capacity for seven years.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 21.--In the Supreme Court this morning application was made by Hermann G. Vetterlein, of Philadelphia, for a writ of habeas corpus to obtain custody of his son.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21.--The amended Senate rules, which were put in operation for the first time to-day, did not work without friction. One of the rules provides that when a bill has been once called on the calendar and passed over it shall not be again called until the calendar has been gone through.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 22.--Major-Gen. Hancock and wife and one or two members of his staff arrived here to-day for a brief visit among friends.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 22.--William D. Ringo, of Newport, Ky., died to-day in his seventy-second year. He was an eccentric bachelor, who inherited $300,000, and increased it by judicious investments to $500,000.
TRENTON, Jan. 22.--The bill to fund the floating debt of Jersey City was recommitted this morning, only to reappear in the shape in which its friends wanted it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22, 1884. The House to-day passed the bill making an appropriation for the relief of the Greely expedition.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 22.--In the State Senate to-day, the President pro tem. presented a letter from a former employe at the penitentiary containing a series of charges of cruel treatment of the sick convicts in that institution.

Meredith, the famous lawyer, who was Secretary of the Treasury when Zachary Taylor was President. NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan.22.--Unless Gov. Bate interferes, William Easley, colored, will be handed at Jacksboro next Friday for the murder of Allen Jeffries, a saloon-keeper, on April 1, 1882.

An aged man, whose face bore the marks of many a long day's exposure to the sun, was meandering slowly down Fulton-street yesterday afternoon. It was evident that the world for him had not yet become tiresome. He found many things to interest him. He gazed into the windows and doors of the shops with an expression of awe upon his countenance.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22.--The managers of the Republican municipal campaign made a bold stragetic move to-day, which it is believed will relieve the blunders made in the nominating conventions and insure the success of the whole ticket at the polls in February.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 22.--The Democrats of this city are working very hard to get up a Randall boom for the Presidency. The district conventions to elect delegates to the State Convention were held to-day. The delegates elected are all for Randall, and it is believed that the Pennsylvania delegation to the National Convention will be solid for him.

Mayor Edson sent a letter to the Secretary of the Committee of Arrangements of the Evacuation Day celebration yesterday, stating that Gen. Shaler had protested against the payment of any bills against the committee until provision is made also for paying the bills of the military battery companies which took part in the celebration.

Delegate OURY, of Arizona, in supporting his bill for the transfer of the Indian Office to the War Department, might draw a strong argument, both for its wisdom and its timeliness, from the success which has thus far crowned the experiment of putting the San Carlos reserve under military control.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 22.--Active steps were taken this afternoon to effect a reduction in the wages of cotton operatives here.

LONDON, Jan. 22.--The Times's dispatch from Khartoum says that no order for the evacuation of that place has yet been given, nor is it known that such an order is contemplated. The total number of soldiers in Khartoum aggregates 6,100, of which 2,000 are Chaggias, who are known to be disaffected.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 22.--George M. Page has been arrested at Kent, Conn., by United States Deputy Marshal William E. Disbrow, of this city, for complicity in the recent black-mailing schemes at the Stepney Station Post Office.
The funeral of Theron R. Butler took place yesterday morning at his residence, No. 433 Fifth-avenue, and was attended by a large number of friends and relatives.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 22.--There is now standing in the main machine shop of the Dickson Manufacturing Company, this city, one of the largest wheels in the world, and the second of the kind ever made, the first having been already shipped for service to the copper mines of the Calumet and Hecla Mining Company, on the borders of Lake Michigan.

Two young Brazilians, of good family and wealthy connections, were inmates last night of cells at Police Head-quarters, having been arrested on a warrant issued by Police Justice White, in which they are charged with intending to leave this State to fight a duel. Their names are Arthur P. Ferriera Vianna and Frank Bueno.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 22.--The present contract and terms of office of officers of the Southern Railway and Steam-ship Association expire on March 1.

The body of Joseph I. Dowling, who committed suicide at the Lafayette Hotel, Philadelphia, on Sunday, was brought to his home in Brooklyn Monday night. He was a man who enjoyed in the highest degree the confidence of the entire trade in which he was engaged, and his death was everywhere the subject of unfeigned regret.

NEW-LONDON, Jan. 20.--An important New-London case has just been disposed of in the Supreme Court of Errors of this State. Seth Smith, of New-London, died in 1878, leaving an estate of $180,000, the bulk of which he bequeathed for the founding of a memorial home in that city, "for the maintenance and support of indigent, aged, and respectable females, who have been residents of New-London."

The Directors of the Lake Erie and Western Railroad, it is stated, have resolved to build 43 miles of additional road between Bloomington and Peoria, which will be known as the Lake Erie and Mississippi Railroad.

The Rev. Dr. William L. Gage resigned the pastorate of the Pearl-street Congregational Church, Hartford, Conn., on Sunday, after 16 years' continuous service. His resignation, which is to take effect at the close of March, and was offered without consultation with any one, was a surprise to his congregation, but he said he had served them as long as it was well that he should attempt to do so.

A Long Island scientific person has succeeded in conclusively showing by a series of experiments that volcanic dust has nothing whatever to do with the red sunsets. Dust is subject to the law of gravitation, and it is idle to suppose that the dust of Krakatoa is capable of floating serenely in the air for weeks and months.

A decree declaring that Annie F. Freeman was never married to George M. Lynch was granted by Judge Donohue, in the Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 22.--The case against Richard Mansfield, the actor, charged with criminal slander by Allan Hamilton, his late manager, was dismissed to-day in the Court of Criminal Correction, no one appearing to prosecute.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 22.--This was the fifth day of the Winter race meeting. The track was heavy. The weather was clear and cool.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22.--In its general features the cattle market suffered but slightly from Monday. With continued light receipts and favoring advices from the East, there was as sharp a demand as has existed at any time recently.

The Hoppe will case ended at Westminster, Md., on Monday, 21st inst., by the admission of the will to probate in the Orphans' Court, and the payment by the Executors to the Legatee. Mrs. Eliza Ann Byers, wife of John Byers, of $25,000 of the $40,000 devised by the testator.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 22.--George M. Page, recently Postmaster at Stepney Depot, is to be tried before United States Commissioner Woodward next Thursday for using the mails for fraudulent purposes. WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 22.--Lorenzo B. Chickering and his wife were arrested in Lowell yesterday on a charge of arson in burning the house and barn on the premises on which they lived, in Templeton, on the morning of Oct. 30, 1883. They were taken before Trial Justice Conn, at Gardener, today, and held in $2,000 bail each, for further examination next week.

The steamer Niagara, from Havana, came slowly to its dock at an early hour yesterday morning. Its 26 cabin passengers eagerly exchanged salutations in Spanish and Italian with friends on shore, and all appeared anxious to land as soon as possible.
