ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 22.--The Senate Finance Committee continued the inquiry into the management of the New Capitol under Superintendent Perry this afternoon. Mr. Perry testified that his deputy, James McIntyre, was appointed on the recommendation of Daniel Lamont, the Governor's private secretary.

The Meadow Brook Club, composed of young gentlemen who pursue the sprightly aniseseed bag about Long Island, met last evening in Delmonico's and held a long session over the ratification of their new steeple-chase rules. It was decided that no jump should be less than three feet and eight inches. The officers of the club, including W.R. Travers, the President, were reelected for the ensuing year.

The concert given by Mr. Sam Franko at Steinway Hall last evening, although the selections were not of the very highest order, was quite enjoyable.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22.--Lieut. J.F. Merry having passed the required examination will be promoted to the grade of Lieutenant Commander, and Lieut. J. C. Cresap, of the junior grade, will be promoted to be a Lieutenant.

LOCKART, Texas, Jan. 22.--Sam Brown, who killed an old man named Martin last Summer, was taken from jail at 12 o'clock on Sunday night by a mob of masked men and shot to death. His body was horribly mangled.

The defense in the Feuardent-Di Cesnola libel suit was concluded yesterday. Both the plaintiff and the defendant were on the witness stand. Mr. Feuardent was called to testify to the authorship of a letter published in THE TIMES in which Col. Di Cesnola's conduct in the reconstruction of the statues in his collection was criticised severely.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 22.--Specials to the News from South and South-west Georgia and Florida report that the cold of the past two days killed the oats and vegetables, but that the oranges and other fruits in Florida escaped serious damage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 269--The Crescent City Live Stock Landing and Slaughter-House Company, plaintiff in error, vs. the City of New Orleans et al.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 22.--It is now an established fact that, by the opening of navigation, the Canada Pacific Railway will have an independent route from the base of the Rocky Mountains to the sea-board.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 22.--A accident occurred on the Nickel Plate Road near Ripley, Chautauqua County, to-day, by which a snow plow and two engines were thrown from the track. One of the train hands was killed and another was fearfully mangled. Their names could not be ascertained.

JOHNSTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 22.--Considerable excitement exists in Johnstown over the contention between the Rev. Father McNulty, of the Catholic church, and his choir. The trouble originated in the introduction of gas into the church.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Jan. 22.--Articles of incorporation of the Union Stock-yard Company were filed here yesterday. The capital stock is $100,000. The shipping of dressed beef is included in the plan of the company.
ABERDEEN, Jan. 22.--The master shipbuilders of this city have informed their employes that their wages are to be reduced 10 per cent.
The Rev. Charles R. Pelletreau, for the past five years Rector of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, in Paterson, N.J., has resigned.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 22.--This was a lay of excitement not only in the Criminal Court-room but all over the city. The charge of Judge Stone last night, which was against young Nutt, somewhat weakened the confidence of the prisoner's friends in a verdict of acquittal, and encouraged the prosecution to hope they had gained a victory.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 22.--Representative Stewart, (Democrat,) in the lower house of the Legislature, to-day submitted a resolution declaring that, as grave charges of breach of official trust had been made against Senator Allison, a committee of investigation be appointed, with power to send for persons and papers. The resolution was tabled by a vote of 56 yeas to 42 nays. A joint resolution was adopted to vote for a United States Senator to-morrow.

Some very interesting Roman sepulchral discoveries have been made lately at Mayence, in the carrying out of some considerable excavations and earth-works required for carrying the Ludwigsbahn Railroad around the city. Close to the Neuthor the workmen came upon a place of considerable extent, evidently assigned to the sepulture of civilians.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan.22.--John E. Engle and wife, of Wilkesbarre, stopped at the Scranton House in this city last night, and when Mrs. Engle awoke early this morning she was horrified to find her husband dead by her side. A post-mortem examination held this afternoon showed that death was caused by a clot of blood in the heart.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 22.--A ladies' massmeeting in the interests of the observance of the centennial of American Methodism was held today at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Charles and Fayette streets. There was a large attendance of ladies not only from the various Methodist Episcopal Churches of Baltimore, but from all sections of the Baltimore Conference.
QUEBEC, Quebec, Jan. 22.--The weather here is intensely cold. An ice bridge has formed over the St. Lawrence River, on which vehicles are crossing.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Jan. 22.--Mr. Taylor, son of the head of the Mormon Church, introduced a joint resolution in the Legislature this afternoon memorializing Congress in relation to the inimical legislation of that body; also, asking that a committee of disinterested persons be sent to investigate and report upon the subject. He said that the Mormons had been misrepresented. Action was deferred.

During the races at Hempstead Plains, Long Island, last May, one of the horses that had been sent to the race-course by Mr. August Belmont, Jr., escaped from the groom and ran at full speed toward the village. One of Belmont's hostlers jumped on a pony and followed the animal. In his reckless course he ran over Derrell Tower, 12 years old, a son of Mr. J.E. Tower, a commercial traveler.

DARTFORD, Wis., Jan. 22.--The Circuit Court convened this morning and attracted an unusually large number of people, owing to the fact that the case of Mrs. Long, the Princeton murderess, was first on the docket.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 22.--Speaker Carlisle's name has been fed to the Democrats in the Legislature twice in 24 hours for the Senatorship, but the members refused to eat. In the caucus last night, notwitstanding the rule that no new man should be voted for except with concurrence of a majority, one member offered to vote for Carlisle.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 22.--The New-York State Trades Assembly began its eighteenth annual meeting in this city to-day, nearly 200 delegates being in attendance from all parts of the State.
A startling event happened at an early hour this morning in connection with the mail train from Brest, which is due in Paris at 4:50 o'clock.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 22.--The public schools closed to-day by order of the Board of Education.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Jan. 22.--Joseph Lancaster, a boarding-house keeper, committed suicide last night by shooting himself through the heart. The cause was despondency over the sickness of his wife.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22.--What was without doubt the largest and most fashionable audience which ever assembled in Chicago witnessed the opening of Mr. Abbey's opera season at Haverly's Theatre last evening.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 22.--At a meeting of the Exposition Directors here to-day, Col. Bennett H. Young was elected President, vice B. Dupont, resigned.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 22.--Two murders were committed in Lancaster County, S.C., on Saturday last. Armstrong Funderbank was shot and killed in Tradesville by a man named Gregory. In Taxahaw, a town six miles distant from Tradesville, William Copeland was shot and killed by three brothers named Gregory. Both murders were the results of the renewal of old quarrels.
The annual reception of the employes of J. Johnston will be given at Tammany Hall on Friday evening.

Anthony Comstock, attired in a dark suit, with a close-fitting Prince Albert coat, stood before a moderately large assemblage of gentlemen in Association Hall last night and related what had been accomplished during the past year by the Society for the suppression of Vice.

Long lines of light were shaking across the still surface of the East River; the roaring wheels and rushing prow of a steam-boat in midchannel found an echo against dusky walls aglow with eyes of fire; wavering streams of people hastened over the muddy crossing to Wall-street ferry: snow was falling softly.

The Board of Managers of the Cotton Exchange have prepared some amendments to the laws regulating the commissions of the members of that institution, which will be submitted to a general vote on Feb. 3.

Henry A. De Meli, affable and serene, talked for five hours in his own behalf in the superior Court yesterday. Mrs. De Meli, amiable and placid, listened attentively to all that he said, commenting occasionally to a surrounding coterie of sympathetic female friends. Owing to the difficulty in controlling the constantly shifting crowd of spectators the day before, only ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22.--The prohibition of American pork and beef from entering the ports of France and Germany was again discussed in the Senate to-day. Mr. Beck called up the Anthony resolution directing the Committee on Foreign Relations to inquire into the expediency of such legislation as will enable the Executive to protect our interests ...
PARIS, Jan. 22.--The Petit Journal states that orders were telegraphed to Admiral Courbet yesterday not to attack Bac-Ninh until he has received further orders from the home Government.

The Norwegian bark Caroline, Capt. Jaesefson, which arrived last evening from Rotterdam, was in collision with the schooner Annie Pardee at 10 P.M. last Saturday in latitude 38 40' and longitude 73 5'. The bark lost her mizzenmast, maintopsail yard, and wheel, and had her bulwarks stove in. The schooner lost her foretopmost and jibboom. Neither vessel was seriously injured about the hull.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 22.--Several plans are now pending before the Virginia Legislature looking to the reapportionment of the State for members of Congress, made necessary by the additional member allowed this State.
At the meeting of the County Democracy Executive Committee last evening it was decided to reorganize the District Committees in the Seventh and Twentieth Assembly Districts.
CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 22.--Last night, while a safe was being hoisted to a second story, the chains broke and the safe fell, crushing Renhold Rochers and William Muller, fatally injuring both.
MACON, Ga., Jan. 22.--In Coffee County, Ben Reeves, colored, was shot and killed by W. C. Aycock, white. A grudge was the cause of the shooting.

EASTON, Penn., Jan. 22.--Representatives from Stevens, Rutgers, and Lafayette Colleges will meet at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, New-York, on Feb. 9, for the purpose of forming a base and foot ball league of students in the institutions named and in one or two other colleges. The University of Pennsylvania and the Wesleyan University will also be included in the league.
Navigation in the harbor was somewhat impeded yesterday by masses of broken ice and fields which drifted about with the tide.
Three industrious bunco men wasted much time and got into trouble yesterday. Early in the afternoon Mr. James Cahill, a paper-dealer of Oakland, Cal., who is on a wedding trip and is ...
William Woodward was indicted in St. Louis last Summer for passing five-cent nickels of the latest series which had been washed to imitate five-dollar gold pieces.

FONDA, N.Y., Jan. 22.--Capt. James D. Hancock, Assistant Superintendent of Public Works of this State, will retire at the close of his term of office next month. He has purchased a farm of 165 acres in Washington County, where he will devote his attention to agricultural pursuits. The name of his successor in office has not been announced, but he will undoubtedly be a Democrat.

When Edward Duffy, who keeps a small produce store in the cellar of No.650 Hudson-street, went to his shop at 6 o'clock yesterday morning he stumbled against a body lying at the foot of the steep flight of stone steps. The body was that of a portly, well-dressed man, apparently about 60 years of age. It was cold, as though the man had been dead for some hours.

The armory of the Thirteenth Regiment, in Brooklyn, was crowded last night upon the occasion of the annual athletic games for the championship of the National Guard, given under the auspices of Company F of that regiment. The Seventh, Eighth, Ninth, Twelfth, Twenty-second, and Twenty-third Regiments were represented, and the first of these waved a ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 22.--John G. Thompson's paper, the Columbus Times, which has so long barely existed, will be sold 10 days hence in order to satisfy the mortgages and other claims against it. The paper appeared to-night in half-sheet form, and there is hardly a possibility of its again getting upon its feet under the present management at least.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22.--The leading produce markets were rather less active to-day, but much stronger. The change in tone came chiefly from New-York, which gave us inspiration for once, though of the indirect order.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 22.--In 1882 Chancellor Sims and E.B. Judson, of this city, and C.R. Adams, of Utica, were appointed a commission to negotiate a new treaty with the Onondaga Indians. Several meetings have been held since then and many witnesses have been sworn to show the licentiousness of the pagan members of the ...
The annual report of the New-York Catholic Protectory has just been published and copies forwarded to the members of the Legislature at Albany.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 22.--The following decisions were handed down by the Court of Appeals today: Ewen McIntyre, respondent, vs. William E. Strong, appellant; John Segilken, by guardian, respondent, vs. Otto Meyer, appellant. Judgment affirmed, with costs.
There are now 452 students in Cornell University, 45 more than at this time last year.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 22.--In regard to a report that the Mississippi River Commission is about to recommend to Congress a proposition to close the mouth of Red River where it enters the Mississippi and to divert the waters of the former stream into the Atchafalaya, your correspondent to-day called on ...

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 22.--The barn of Noah Blosser, near this city, was set on fire by incendiaries last night, and was destroyed, together with all its contents except the live stock. The barn was the best in the county.
The death of M. Paul Taglioni, ballet master, recalls the change which has come over the saltatory art since Maria Taglioni, his gifted sister, witched the world with her magnificent dancing.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 22.--Mr. Frank King, a prominent citizen of Woodstock, Shenandoah County, in the Valley of Virginia, is in this city. Mr. King to-day spoke to a reporter regarding the outlook for the Republican Party in Virginia, and showed that he had made a careful study of the subject.
Fifteen hundred cabmen are now on strike, and they state that they have sufficient funds for another week, by which time they think the Urban Company will be compelled to yield.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22.--Sergt. Adams and Officer Mangen, of New-York, arrived here to-day with requisition papers for the two men arrested here upon the charge of assaulting Luther Church at an elevated railroad station in New-York, on the afternoon of Dec. 31, and robbing him of $2,300.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 22.--Two very singular accidents, never known before on the Central Railroad, occurred on this branch.

MAUCH CHUNK, Penn., Jan. 22.--Judge Harry E. Packer, President of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, who has been seriously ill for several days, passed an uncomfortable night, and consequently was quite weak this morning, but he improved during the day. His friends are now hopeful of his recovery.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 22.--Alfred Richards Co., wholesale dealers in groceries and ship stores, State-street, will probably compromise with their creditors for 30 cents on the dollar, this basis having been recommended by an investigating committee.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 22.--At the semiannual meeting of the Trustees of Union College this afternoon, no reference was made to the recent troubles or to the prospect of President Potter resigning his place to accept the Presidency of Hobart College. The degree of D.D. was conferred on the Rev. George Alexander, formerly Professor of Elocution, who has accepted a call from the Park Presbyterian Church in New-York.
If the New-York Tribune, as its esteemed contemporary THE TIMES declares, is printed for the 24,600 "best people" in its Metropolis, it ought to keep them informed on all that concerns them.

At last there is a prospect that the lands conditionally granted to the Texas and Pacific Railroad Company, which it attempted to trade away when it had not earned them, and which the Southern Pacific Company has been trying to steal from the United States, will be declared ...
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 22.--The Queen of Tahiti and suite arrived here this evening on the steamer City of Papaete.
Romulus Alexandre Bonhomme, the Italian who was arrested in Baltimore on a charge of swindling, was before Justice White yesterday.

"I object," is the remark the Hon. Henry B. Payne made in the House of Representatives when a little resolution that tickled the Standard Oil Company in a tender place was offered. But Mr. Payne never had the slightest interest in Standard Oil. He objected simply to save clerk hire.

A decision was given in the Common Pleas Court, at Newark, yesterday, by Judge McCarter to the effect that the statute allowing creditors under an assignment only three months in which to file their claims was defective.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 22.--Mayor Scoville to-day affixed his signature to new rules prepared for conducting the civil service of this city. In his message at the beginning of the year, the Mayor spoke of the desirability of conducting city affairs regardless of politics and on strictly business principles, but expressed doubts about acting under the provisions of the State Civil Service Reform act.

PARIS, Dec. 7.--The Nouville Revue has published a series of letters, dated from Berlin, which will figure among the instructive documents of the present time, and in which historians will find some curious and valuable information concerning Germany, until 1866 scarcely accepted as a first class power and now the mistress of Europe.

Irwin Steno, of No. 43 Hudson-street, Jersey City, was killed by a Pennsylvania Railroad locomotive near Marion-street last night. He was 25 years of age, and had been to Newark in search of work. His wife is in destitute circumstances.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 22.--In the House to-day Mr. Dabney, Greenbacker, introduced substantially the late prohibitory amendment which indicates what attitude the Greenbackers will take.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 22.--The official returns laid before Parliament last night disclose some rather startling facts regarding the trade and commerce of the country and the increase in the national debt under the protective policy of the present administration. The debt of Canada on June 30, 1883, was $202,159,104 or $46 per capita of the population.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 22.--The Senate balloted for a United States Senator to succeed Mr. Allison with the following result: Allison, (Rep.,) 38; Hall, (Dem.,) 10; Kinne. (Dem.,) 1. One Senator, Mr. Glass, (Rep.,) was absent. The ballot of the House was as follows: Allison, (Rep.,) 52; Hall, (Dem.,) 33; Clark, (Greenbacker,) 10. Four Democrats voted with the latter, who number only six.

Judge Depue heard an application last evening for a writ of certiorari to determine the validity of the appointment of a Captain and six Lieutenants of police in Newark by the Democratic majority of the Common Council to take the places of Republican officials.

Mrs. Annie Lewis, the wife of Edgar Lewis, a lame man who manufactures banjos by hand in his one living and sleeping room, at No. 343 Sixth-street, has been missing from home since the evening of Wednesday, the 8th inst., and her husband yesterday advertised for her.

DUBLIN, Jan. 22.--An immense concourse of peasantry assembled to-day at Derrybeg, County Donegal, the birth-place of Patrick O'Donnell, and assisted in the celebration of a mass for the repose of the soul of O'Donnell.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 22.--A bill was introduced in the House of Representatives to-day allowing women to vote on school district matters.
A gentleman who has walked over the Brooklyn bridge nearly every day since it was opened for travel stopped a TIMES reporter near the New-York tower yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 23.--A telegram from Hong Kong says: "It is reported here that operations against Bac-Ninh have been postponed until the arrival of reinforcements. It is not expected that the attack will be made before the beginning of March. Advices from Canton are more reassuring. The Chinese seem generally less disposed for war."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 23.--The steamer Sam Fowler, owned and commanded by Capt. O. W. Davis, broke loose from her moorings last night at the foot of Church-street, drifted down against the Louisville and Nashville Rairoad bridge and sunk. The Steamer, which is a total loss, was valued at about $4,000.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 23.--The prejectors of the New-York and Connecticut Air Line, one of the parallel railroads, announce that they have given out the contracts for the building of their road from the New-York State line at Greenwich to New-Haven. The company, under the general railroad law, has until March 24 to begin ...

LONDON, Jan. 23.--Sir Charles Dilke, President of the Local Government Board, in a speech delivered at Kensington last evening, declared that the English Government had great confidence in Gen. Gordon's advice.

The citizens of the village of Woodhaven, Long Island, held a meeting Tuesday evening and appointed a committee to ascertain the cost of equipping a company of firemen. The meeting adjourned at 10:30 o'clock. Half an hour later smoke was discovered pouring out of the bakeroom of Charles Brickhauer's bakery, in "the ...
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 23.--A dispatch from Carthage, on the Upper Cumberland River, says that a raft was drawn into a whirlpool below that town to-day, and that nine men were drowned.

The reception tendered to President Arthur by the Union League Club last evening was a grand social success. Two great palms stood just inside the main entrance, their serrated leaves forming a double canopy that nearly covered the lobby.

MARIETTA, Ga., Jan. 23.--James McMin was employed by revenue officers to go into Gilmer County and locate the illicit distilleries. McMin has a cousin named Lazarus Shadwick, who lives four miles from Ellijay. To his house McMin went, carrying along a little boy who ...
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 23.--The hearing as to James Nutt's present mental condition took place this morning before Judge Stowe, and resulted in the prisoner's release.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 23.--Richard Zeller, a 16-year-old German boy, who wants to be a Jesse James and a raider in the Black Hills, as he told the detectives, was arrested and sent to jail here to-day.

The cast of "The Princess" is now complete, and the rehearsals of that opera have begun at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre under the direction of Mr. Mullally, who is Mr. Stetson's musical conductor at the Boston Globe Theatre. Mr. Stetson himself is in Boston, possibly conducting his own ...
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The local Civil Service Reform Association, to-day sent circulars to the heads of the Law, Health, School, Fire, ...

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 23.--The trial of John Steinhilber for the murder of Thomas Kearns, at Ashland, last November, which has been going on since Tuesday, the 15th inst., ended to-day, and resulted in the acquittal of the prisoner.

SOUTH PITTSBURG, Tenn., Jan. 23.--This afternoon, about 4 o'clock, Mrs. Martha Fortune, a very old lady, was burned to death at this place. She was living with her daughter, who was visiting a neighbor. When the daughter returned she found her mother burned to a crisp.
CINCINNATI Ohio, Jan. 23.--Health Officer Rowland issued an order to-day forbidding the importation of rags from Louisville.

Plans and drawings of a palace car for the white elephant and suite of religious attendants, which is advertised to visit this country next Summer, have been submitted to Barnum, Bailey Hutchinson, the circus proprietors.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 23.--Cato J. Jenks, age 23, a merchant of Apex, Wake County, has deserted his sick wife and three children and eloped with Varina Pearson, the 13-year-old daughter of his clerk. The girl is very delicate and is small for her age. Endeavors are being made to intercept them. Their relatives assert that they have gone to Illinois. The affair has caused a marked sensation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23, 1884. At a meeting of the select committee of the House on shipping to-day, Representative Slocum was authorized to report the bill to remove restrictions on the American merchant marine.

Prof. Straight, of Oswego, in an address before the school teachers of Hartford, Conn., on Tuesday, said: "If we can think of the little child, just born into the world, its senses just opening to the world--the eye, the ear, and the touch--of the impressions from the external world showering down upon those senses--there is the beginning.

Madison-Square Garden was yesterday converted into an immense poultry-yard. The occasion for this was the beginning of the second annual exhibition of the New-York Fanciers' Club. Over 5,000 fowls of various kinds joined in the opening chorus with which the show was inaugurated.

The case of Patrolman George Smith, of the Sixteenth Precinct, who during a fracas on Christmas morning shot and killed Thomas Fitzpatrick, assumed a new phase yesterday. The officer was discharged by Justice Duffy and the Grand Jury declined to indict him.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 23.--The result of the meeting of the Cotton Manufacturers' Board of Trade, yesterday, has caused great dissatisfaction and indignation among the operatives. The amount of reduction has not yet been decided upon, but, on good authority, it is stated that it will be 8 per cent.
Count A. Sinibaldi was among the passengers of the French steam-ship Labrador, which arrived yesterday from Havre.

NEW-BEDFORD, Jan. 23.--An attempt was made to-day to examine the wreck of the City of Columbus by means of a diver, but it proved so dangerous that it had to be abandoned. There was a strong undertow, which made it impossible for the diver to keep his footing. Once he was lowered and held on by the ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The leave of absence granted Capt. Albert D. King, Third Cavalry, has been extended two months.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 23.--Robert Roehl, the accused slayer of August Rosenberger, whose body was found in Union Creek near Egg Harbor, N.J., on last Friday, was arrested in this city yesterday by Detective Miller, and he volunteered a full statement, which was taken down by Detective Miller.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 23.--Four ballots were taken in the Senatorial caucus at Frankfort to-night without any change in the situation.

Late last night Mr. Frank Jenkins, a banker, of No. 25 Pine-stret, who lives at No. 97 Fifth-avenue, was in a sleigh and driving a team at Forty-second-street and Fifth-avenue, when a coupe driven by Frederick Zezeland, of No. 145 West Seventeenth-street, ran into his horses and one of them was injured so that it will be killed. Mr. Jenkins received a, slight injury to his left shoulder, and Zezeland was bruised in the breast.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--A cable dispatch from Forepaugh's agent, now at Gibraltar, says that the white elephant ordered by Mr. Forepaugh has been secured for him and will be shipped to America.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Jan. 23.--Information has been received from Washington that Senator Ingalls will be appointed to fill the place ...

The family of Jarvis S. Baker is one of the most respected in Flushing, Long Island, but of late years Mr. Baker's health has been very poor, and his finances have suffered in consequence. The family consists of Mr. Baker, his wife, two sons, Willett B. and Charles G.S., 23 ...
NORWALK, Jan. 23.--A new engine of war is being constructed at the Norwalk Ironworks here. On the floor of one of the rooms lies an iron cylinder 28 feet in length and 16 inches in diameter.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The Governor has reported that 449 applications for pardons. , had been presented to him during the year 1883. Thirty-nine pardons, 1 reprieve, and 17 commutations had been granted; 181 applications had been denied, and 211 are now pending.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 23.--The State Temperance Convention to-day was not as fully attended as was the similar gathering last Winter, and to-day's session did not develop the acrimony of the former.

JACKSON, Ohio, Jan. 23.--Luke and William Jones, who have been in jail here awaiting execution on Feb. 29 for the murder of Anderson Lackey, have been quiet, peaceable prisoners, and no one entertained a thought of their attempting any sensational exploits. This noon they pried open their cell door while the two ...

WASHINGTON, Penn., Jan. 23.--The fires were lighted in the Lemoine Crematory this afternoon for burning the body of Albert C. Rupe, who died of consumption at his late residence, in New-York, on the 20th inst. The body left that city at 6 o'clock this evening, and will arrive here at 11 A.M. to-morrow. Mrs. Rupe, widow of the deceased man, and her father, L. H. Meyer, will accompany the remains.

Messrs. "Sheeny Mike," (Michael Kurtz,) John Stewart, and George Howard, three NewYork cracksmen eminent in their profession, robbed the dry goods store of James Scott, in Boston, on the night of Jan. 15, 1877. Stewart and Howard have a gone to their final rest, but Sheeny Mike is still in the land of the living.
ROME, Jan. 23.--At the Consistory to be held on Feb. 21 six Cardinals are to be created.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The National Guard of the State of New-York began its sixth annual convention here to-day with a full attendance of members, New-York and Brooklyn being well represented. Papers were read by Major Farr, of Brooklyn, on "Signaling" and by Gen. H.C. King on "The Legal Status of the National Guard."
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 23.--In the Senate to-day bills were introduced covering substantially all the recommendations for new laws embodied in the Governor's message.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Jan. 23.--Two men were suffocated at the Hathorne Spring bottlinghouse this afternoon by gas which had escaped from a tank of gasoline.
The Woman's Silk Culture Association, of which Mrs. John Lucas, of Philadelphia, is President, has made arrangements to open an exhibit of the varied agricultural, mechanical, ...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--Mrs. Martha Clifton, of No. 956 South Front-street, died in the Academy of Music to-night just before the performance of the opera "Crispino" began. She was going up stairs to the balcony, when she sank down and died immediately. Heart disease was the cause.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23.--Haverly's Theatre was packed with people to-night and standing room was at a premium in spite of the blinding snow-storm, the attracticn being the appearance ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The Committee on Expenditures in the Department of Justice has made another rich find. This time it is an ex-United States Marshal, now the Governor of a Territory, who will be on the rack.

It is probable that the summing up before Judge Van Brunt, in the Common Pleas, Equity Term, of the suit of the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company against the Manhattan and New-York Companies, to set aside the modified lease of Oct. 22, 1881, will not be closed until next week.

FORT SCOTT, Kan., Jan. 23.--A convention, composed of delegates representing a combination against the Republicans, was held in the Second Congressional District last night, which nominated Mr. A. Riggs to fill the vacancy occasioned by the death of Mr. D.C. Haskell.

The vigilant door-keeper of Judge Rumsey's court created a profound sensation yesterday by challenging two of the sympathetic female friends who follow in the wake of Mrs. De Meli. Mr. De Meli took the witness stand ...
"Tom" Hadaway, the once famous comedian, yesterday celebrated his eighty-fourth birthday in his quiet little home at Stony Brook, Suffolk County.
Representative Lyman, of Massachusetts, has written the following letter:

It is not only, we suspect, hostility to royalty that actuated Senator PLUMB, of Kansas, in opposing a proposition to allow Ensign REYNOLDS, United States Navy, to receive an Austrian decoration for saving twelve Austrian lives.

That extremely gifted and brilliant, but fearfully overworked and hungry body of gentlemen, the "second panel" of the Sheriff"s jury, assembled early last evening in the great dininghall of the Brunswick, to devour the first banquet their arduous duties have allowed them to avail themselves of since they entered upon their labors for the public weal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The forteenth annual convention of the National Board of Trade began its sessions in this city to-day. Nineteen boards of trade and chambers of commerce are represented by delegates. The regular business of the session to-day was the election of officers ...
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 23.--Senator Jacobs gave a reception this evening which were present Gov. Cleveland and his private secretary, Daniel Manning, Gen. King, of Brooklyn, ...

LEADVILLE, Jan. 23.--The First National Bank of this city closed its doors after a heavy run yesterday afternoon. Preparations were being made for a disastrous run in the morning, but at midnight it was made public that the bank would not open this morning.

There would seem to be no room for doubt that the Right Rev. Horatio Potter, Senior Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New-York, has delegated all the powers of his office to his recently appointed assistant, the Rev. Dr. Henry C. Potter. NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 23.--The suit of Henry S. Armstrong for $25,000 damages against David Jackson for having assaulted and beaten him on April 2, 1883, on Canal-street, came up yesterday before Judge Tissol.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 23.--Judge Blodgett this morning decided the babeas corpus case of Herman Koerstein, the German defaulter and fugitive from justice.
The bark Batavia, Capt. Kelly, bound from Iloilo for Boston, put into this port in distress yesterday.

An injunction was recently obtained by Diedrich Fincke restraining the police from interfering with him or his agents in the sale, at lawful times, of liquor at No. 620 Grand-street. He alleged that the police had threatened to arrest his agents for selling liquor on the ground that his license had been annulled by the conviction, ...
NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 23.--A young man named William Ellis was before Judge Deming, in the city court, to-day, charged with causing a disturbance at the American Theatre on Monday evening.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The trial of E. Newton Rowell for the killing of Johnson L. Lynch was fairly begun here this morning when District Attorney Safford E, North arose and opened the case for the people. He spoke 25 minutes, devoting the greater part of the time to stating to the jury in a conversational way an ...
The Board of Education considered yesterday the budget for this year. The Board of Estimate and Apportionment had appropriated $4,431,950.
Early on Monday morning the house of Mrs. Ann McNulty, at No. 162 Fifth-street, in the Eastern District of Brooklyn, was broken into and a quantity of silverware stolen.

The Ensilage Congress met at noon yesterday in the hall of the New-York Plow Company, No. 55 Beekman-street. About 100 farmers and persons interested in stock farming were present. Dr. A.S. Heath was chosen President, and he introduced Prof. Manly Miles, of the Amherst ...

Persons living between Fifty-seventh and Sixty-fourth streets, south and east of Central Park, have for some time been complaining that the lake near the Fifth-avenue entrance was a breeder of malarial troubles. Many persons, it is said, have been led by their sufferings to sell ...
The Alumni of Manhattan College had their fifteenth annual dinner last evening at Pinard's.
The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange yesterday listed $850,000 of the bonds of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway, ...
A delegation of 50 silk weavers from Paterson and this City, who are now on a strike, met the Executive Committee of the Association of American Silk Ribbon Manufacturers yesterday ...
Information that the Most Rev. Patrick J. Ryan, Coadjutor Bishop of St. Louis, has been created Archbishop by Pope Leo was received yesterday at the office of the Catholic Review.

Mr. GEORGE BLISS has written a letter in regard to the City Government. His idea is that the Mayor should be permitted to make removals "for cause," but that the "cause" ought to be satisfactory to somebody besides the Mayor. He suggests that if the Mayor can satisfy the three Chief ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--1 A.M.--For NewEngland, increasing cloudiness, local rains or snow, winds shifting to northerly, rising barometer, preceded in eastern portion by a slight fall, generally colder weather.
A curling match between the Scotch exponents of the game and a club composed of all nationalities was played yesterday. Seven rinks contested, two at Central Park and the other five at Cortland Lake.
According to the report of the Castle Garden Labor Bureau, which will be presented at the next meeting of the German Society, 27,903 immigrants were provided with employment during the year 1883.
The one hundredth representation of "The Beggar Student" takes place at the Casino to-night.
The Grand Division of the Sons of Temperance of Eastern New-York held its annual meeting at Trenor's Hall, in Broadway, near ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 23.--The organization of Colored Coal-wheelers, some 2,000 strong, demanded of their employers last week a raise from $3 to $4 a day. The matter was referred for arbitration to the Trades Assembly, who decided the demand was not well grounded.
Gioacchino Anastasio, second mate of the barb Giovannina, was admitted, on Jan. 9, to the Long Island College Hospital, in company with Natale Lauro, a sailor from the same ship.

TRENTON, Jan. 23.--The Legislature gets stirred to its lowest depths at the close of every session over the stationery contracts. The battle has begun at the very opening of the session, and the Assembly Chamber yesterday was the scene of a violent commotion. The fight is the same with that of former years.

The agreement between the Mexican Minister at Washington and the Secretary of State to extend the time for the ratification of the Mexican treaty, together with the prospect of the action of the Senate being reconsidered, naturally reopens discussion as to the merits of the measure.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday listened to an explanation of the construction of a flexible road-bed invented by O.C. Woolson, formerly Inspecting Engineer of the New-York Elevated Railroad.

The Feuardent-Di Cesnola libel suit dragged itself wearily along yesterday morning, until Mr. Choate begged Judge Shipman to have the windows opened and the room ventilated. The Judge thought this proceeding entirely parliamentary, and the atmosphere was consequently refreshed.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 23.--From all appearances the investigation into the lottery business will be thorough and complete.

There was a stabbing affray between two cadets--William Massie and J.A. McIlhenny --at Dr. D.A. Holbrook's Military Academy, at Sing Sing, on Tuesday last. Shortly after reveille the boys were drawn up in line and the order "right dress" was given.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The description in THE TIMES of Tuesday of the wretched service in New-York City by the contractor who transfers the mails to and from the General Post Office, has not escaped attention in the Post Office Department. It was not, however, the first time that complaint had been made.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23.--The election of editors from the Junior Class for the Yale Literary Magazine took place this afternoon, Mr. Gale, Chairman of the present board, presiding. Fully 100 Juniors were present. H. D. Baldwin, of New-York; E. L. Richards, of New Hampshire; H. L. Daggett, of Ohio; C. Shipman, of Hartford, and M. H. Pitkins, of New-York, were chosen as the new board for 1884.

Arthur F. Ferreira Vianna and Frank Bueno, the Brazilians who were arrested on Tuesday on information that they intended to fight a duel out of the State, were arraigned yesterday, before Justice Ford, at the Jefferson Market court.

The will of the late Theron R. Butler was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday. The testator leaves to his widow his residence, horses and carriages, household furniture, and an income of $15,000 a year.

Travel on the Central Railroad was delayed three hours yesterday by a collision between an incoming freight train and a locomotive near the Communipaw station, Jersey City. The engines were considerably broken and two cars were thrown from the track.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23.--George A. Wheeler, a native of Gorham, Me., where he was respectably connected, formerly employed in the Rogers Company chair factory in Boston, was hanged here at 12:54 P.M. to-day for the murder of his sister-in-law, Adele J. Tillson, by strangling, in this city on Oct. 20, 1880

ALBANY, Jan. 23.--A bill to suppress the theatre ticket speculators was introduced in the Assembly to-day by Mr. Farrell, of Kings. KINGSTON, Ontario, Jan. 23.--The snow blockade prevented the sending of provisions into the Kingston timber district, and the lumbering shanties will probably be closed in consequence. D.G. Wiggins, of the Bethlehem Iron Company, is snowed in at the iron mines. The inhabitants there think he is Wigggins, the weather prophet, and refuse to shovel a path out for him. He is, therefore, in a quandary.

Through the failure of the burglar-alarm wires, on which Mr. Isidor Grunwald, a dealer in ostrich feathers at No. 85 Bleecker-street, relied for the protection of his property, to work properly, burglars were enabled to carry off $600 worth of property from the building during Tuesday night or early yesterday morning.

Cassius H. Read, who has long been one of the proprietors of the Hoffman House, is one of the defendants in a suit now on trial before Judge Van Hoesen and a jury in the Court of Common Pleas. His codefendant is Dr. Gustave E. Sussdorf, a well-known physician.

A book destined to excite much curiosity and anger will be issued in a few days by Dentu, entitled "Memoires sur le Second Empire." It is in reality a history of the 2d of December, 1851, related by M. de Maupas, Prefect of Police at that time, one of the first instigators of the coup d'etat, and one of its warmest and boldest actors.

At a meeting of the Aqueduct Commission yesterday the Mayor announced that there would be no further public discussion of the plans of the commission at present, and that notice of its resumption would be given in the daily press.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23.--There was a marked increase to-day in the cattle receipts, and at the opening of business it looked as if holders would find considerable difficulty in sustaining the advance of the previous two days.

A letter in the Baltimore Sun yesterday morning, dated Rome, Jan.10, reviews at some length the late conference of American Catholic Bishops at Rome, and points out some features of the coming council in Baltimore.
POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 23.--Joseph S. Davis, age 21, son of a well-known citizen, in attempting to board a moving coal train at Thomaston last night, was thrown under the wheels and fatally injured.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 23.--A special term of the court has been called in Forest County to try a great ejectment case and decide the ownership of a very valuable tract of oil territory situated in Howe Township, containing 600 acres.

OTTAWA, Canada, Jan. 23.--In the Senate to-day Sir Alexander Campbell stated that official notification had only been received this afternoon from the British Government regarding the notice given by the United States Government terminating the fishery clauses of the Washington treaty next year.
PHILADELPHIA Jan. 23.--The Rose ball at the new hall of the Union League Club tonight was the first event of the kind this season in fashionable society.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The goods at the store of D.M. E.G. Halbert were sold in bulk to-day by the Assignee to Jordan, Marsh Co., of Boston, for 51 per cent. of their nominal value, and will realize about $39,000.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 23.--Gov. Dawes commuted to life imprisonment the sentences of John Polin, who was to hare been hanged in Plattsmouth on Friday, and George Hart at Grand Island on the same day.
Two children, Kate Greenwald, age 5, and Florence Burke, age 4, died on last Saturday from malignant scarlet fever at No. 698 Waterstreet, which is a densely populated five-story tenement-house.

CAIRO, Ill., Jan. 23.--B.W. Mahon, a broker, was knocked down just after dark last evening, receiving wounds from which he died at 9 o'clock. Robbery was the object of the assault. There is no clue to the perpetrators.

"SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The public schools of the city will be reopened to-morrow, Mayor Ryan to-day sent a communication to the Board of Education stating that he would become personally responsible for liabilities incurred in running the schools till the end of the school year. The Mayor deposited the money in the Third National Bank, and the Superintendent of Public Schools at once issued an order reopening the schools to-morrow morning.

AUBURN, Ky., Jan. 24.--George Hardison and Harry Bronson were killed by each other in a street fight to-day. The killing was the result of a family feud dating back 16 years, when James Hardison, the father of George, killed Bronson's father with a broad-axe. The intestines of both men were cut out. Both men belonged to wealthy families. More trouble is expected.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 24.--A peculiarly sad death occurred in this city to-day, bringing to a sudden termination the honeymoon of a young married couple.

Tremendous efforts will be made to carry several States at the South for the Republican Presidential candidate, notably West Virginia, North Carolina, and Florida. Money will be freely used, and its power to corrupt is incalculably great.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 24.--The discussion of Senator Newberry's resolution requesting Gen. Mahone to resign his seat in the United States Senate was continued in the State Senate this afternoon and to-night, and a number of forcible speeches were made in favor of and in opposition to its adoption.

Amateur athletes are interested in the projected visit to England of several American flyers, who are going over in the coming Spring. They are L.E. Myers, the champion amateur runner; Harry Fredericks, a good man at long distances; Arthur Waldron, who is excellent at 100 yards and under, and Frank P Murray, whose short distance walking is remarkable.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 24.--Daniel Wells, Jr., has filed a complaint in the Circuit Court calling upon Peter McGeoch for an accounting of all money which Wells let him have to carry on his wheat and lard deals from 1881 to 1883, inclusive.

CHICAGO, Ill, Jan. 24.--One of the first structures erected in the business part of the city after the great fire of 1871 was the three-story brick building known as Exchange Block, corner of Clark and Washington streets.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--Grave charges have been preferred against Officer John G. Davis, of the Humane society. For more than five years the officer was connected with the city police. About two months ago he was detailed on duty in connection with the Humane Society.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 24.--Reports from different setions of the State indicate a bad condition of the crops. This has been the dryest season in seven years.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24.--There is trouble in Col. Mapleson's opera company, which reached here to-day. When the company arrived the Colonel, with Patti, Nicolini, and others went to the St. James Hotel. Gerster with her husband and others went to Barnum's.

COLUMBUS, Jan. 21.--The central figure in Ohio politics to-day is Henry B. Payne, the old millionaire of Cleveland. His election to the Senate, to succeed Pendleton, has disclosed the utter degradation of his party in this State, its shameless greed, its dishonesty, and its abandonment of its alleged principles.

The heavy rain of yesterday kept many people away who would otherwise have attended the reception given by Commodore Upshur and the officers of the New-York naval station yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Navy-yard.

George De Haert Gillespie died suddenly at Lakewood, N.J., yesterday morning. Mr. Gillespie was suffering from a pulmonary complaint and had been resting at Lakewood. For some time past his heart had been effected, but nothing serious was apprehended.

While the circulation of THE NEW-YORK TIMES has been increased since Sept.18 last, when the reduced charges on subscription went into operation, fully 130 per cent., that of the NewYork Tribune has increased during the same period only 30 per cent., according to the showing made by the latter journal itself.

Arnold Leo, a shareholder in the Union Pacific Railway Company, brought a suit in the United States Circuit Court against the company and Sidney Dillon, its President, to restrain the company from employing its assets in excess of its corporate powers by issuing bonds for the purpose of obtaining money with which to extend its lines.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 24.--A number of prominent sporting men have been arrested for participating in recent cock-fights in this vicinity. They gave bail to appear for examination. Among them are an ex-Canal Superintendent and a well-known hotel-keeper.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 24.--Phillip Miller, aged 21 years, died at his mother's house on Genesee-street this morning from injuries received in a street fight on Sunday morning.

The Organizing Committee of Nine, appointed at a recent meeting of the Independent Democratic faction, of which James O'Brien is the leader, met last evening at the Brunswick Hotel. Orlando L. Stewart, the Chairman, presided.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 24.--The fire adjusters in the case of the H.G. Razelle Company say the firm was on the eve of bankruptcy when the fire occurred.

The study lamp on Emperor William's work-table is a simple oil lamp of a pattern such as since the introduction of petroleum lamps can hardly be met with on the table of the humblest citizen of Berlin.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 24.--The 10 days' fair of the Foresters of the State was opened to-night in Peck's Grand Opera-house by Gov. Waller. The hall was crowded and the Governor was enthusiastically welcomed.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24.--The Democrats of this city, in convention to-day, renominated Samuel G. King for Mayor. He was chosen by acclamation.
LONDON, Jan. 24.--A dispatch from Hanoi, dated Jan. 19, says: "The French have made a reconnoissance in strong force in the direction of Bac-Ninh.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Jan. 24.--Robert Stephens and William Copley, age 13, were arrested here last night for vagrancy. The boys left Kingston, Ontario, a few days ago to seek their fortune. They stated that they had been reading "Peck's Bad Boy," a copy or which they had in their possession.
PARIS, Jan. 24.--Edmond About, the author, has been elected a member of the French Academy by 19 votes, against 14 for M. Coppee.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 24.--Foot-pads and burglars, emboldened by the immunity they have enjoyed in their petty operations in this city for some time, have evidently decided on a bolder and more profitable line of business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--The leave of absence granted Capt. Henry C. Cook, Second Infantry, has been extended one month. Leave of absence for four months, to take effect March 12, with permission to go beyond the sea, has been granted Brig.-Gen. Oliver O. Howard.

The wife of Albert N. White died at her home, No. 336 East Fifty-fifth-street, yesterday afternoon, from the effects of malpractice. From affidavits filed with Justice Power, in the Fifty-seventh-street Police Court, yesterday, it seems that Mrs. White submitted to an operation, on Jan. 5, by Mrs. Julia Nathan, a midwife, living at No. 932 Second-avenue.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--Signor Campanini was so seriously indisposed last night that it became necessary to omit the last scene of "Lohengrin" entirely.

BOSTON, Jan. 24.--The schooner Eva May, on Jan.18, in latitude 36 32', longitude 74 40', passed the wreck of a boat supposed to be either a pilot boat or a yacht. The vessel was drifting about with her masts about 10 feet out of the water, with spars and sails attached. It is thought it may be the pilot boat Columbia, which was run down and sunk a few weeks ago by an ocean steamer,
GLOUCESTER, Mass., June 24.--The schooner William J. Maddocks, of the Gloucester fishing fleet, with her crew, is now given up as lost.
Mr. Horatio Ross, the veteran deerstalker, has celebrated his golden wedding. Mr. Ross has a record probably without parallel in sporting annals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The motto of Kentuckians is to exalt one another's virtues, and to stand for one another against the world. It is a commendable trait, though sometimes rather wearisome and monotonous. A Kentuckian is always a good fellow to meet if you can continue to keep the conversation off Kentucky subjects.

ELKTON, Md., Jan. 24.--On two straw pallets in an old frame rookery on Collins-lane Mrs. William Hall, a middle-aged woman, and her six children are now lying in an almost dying condition from the effects of poison.
Superintendent Jackson, of Castle Garden, has received a letter from a man in Detroit, who wishes to know what his own name and age are.

PETERSBURG, Va., Jan. 24.--The jury in the case of Barney Jones, on trial in the Hustings Court for the murder of Woodson Dunn, came into court this morning with a verdict of guilty of involuntary manslaughter, fixing the punishment at one year in jail and a fine of $525.
John Maick, a Hungarian, came to this country in July, 1882, leaving his young wife Mary at home.
An ingenious system of robbery has just been adopted in Paris. The modus operandi is for a few well-dressed women to mix with the guests during the performance of a marriage ceremony.

A young man called yesterday at the United States Express office, in Jersey City, and inquired about a consignment of furniture. He had no sooner put his inquiry than Officers Pearson and Dalton pounced upon him, and, having led him to Police Head-quarters, locked him up on a charge of grand larceny.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--The suit of Josie Batchelder Norries against Bartley Campbell to recover $600 arrears of salary has been adjusted and the suit dismissed. Miss Batchelder had sued out an attachment against the receipts from "Siberia," which is now being played here.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 24.--Collinwood, a railroad suburb of Cleveland, was the scene of a bold attempt at burglary about 2 o'clock this morning. William Rolf, a hardware merchant, who resides next to his place of business, was awakened by a loud report.

A cablegram received yesterday by T.A. Edison from Berlin states that "in the suit between Edison and Swan, on Edison's principal patent, Edison is victorious. Swan has to pay costs of suit. The value of our patent has increased highly by the victory."

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 24.--The Assignees of George T. Comins, the State prison contractor, have compiled a schedule of his assets and liabilities. The assets will aggregate about $70,000 and the indebtedness $140,000. A meeting of his creditors will be held here Friday afternoon.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 24.--The thermometer was 30 below zero here early this morning.

BALLSTON, N.Y., Jan. 24.--In the case of Eliza Bailey against the Boston, Hoosac Tunnel and Western Railroad, the jury has given a verdict of $5,000, and interest from date of death of plaintiff's husband and 5 per cent. additional costs.

During the past six months the rotunda of the Custom-house has been infested with expert pickpockets.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 24.--The question of the representation of the city and towns in the Erie County Board of Supervisors has for a long time been the cause of much dispute. At present the city has 25 members, being 2 from each of its 13 wards, except one small ward, which has but 1.
The Royal Hand Bell Ringers will give a concert at Steinway Hall on Tuesday evening in aid of the Lexington-Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church.

LIMA, Jan. 24, via Galveston.--La Reaccion publishes a letter from Chincha stating that the remaining Montaneros of Canete, under Zeapata, attacked and captured Chincha Alta, committing great depredations in company with the Indians of the surrounding country. The same thing occurred at Tambo de Mora and Chincha Baja. The insurgents have gone to Humay. Troops will be sent to attack them from Pisco and Ica, under Col. Alarco and Senor Aquirre.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 24.--The opening concert of the season was given in the Second Presbyterian Church this evening by the college glee and instrumental clubs, under the direction of E.L. Bradley and William H. Chester. The seats were all disposed of several hours before the entertainment. The programme consisted of part songs and selections from the "College Carmina," and the instrumental pieces were by modern composers. The clubs leave to-morrow on a somewhat limited trip.
Another iron-clad corvette, built for the Chinese Government, has just been launched at Kiel, though with less pomp and circumstance than attended the baptism of its sister vessels at Stettin.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 24.--The State Insurance Commissioner this afternoon addressed a letter to the Attorney-General, requesting that the State commence action against the Connecticut Mutual Fire Insurance Company of Toledo.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 24.--Senor Eduardo Villena, lately appointed Charge d'Affaires of Peru at Washington, has been named by his Government Minister Resident of Peru in the United States of Colombia and Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--Stories are going the rounds about a "row" in an executive session of the Senate on Tuesday, which some of the Senators are qualifying or denying. An account of the scene, as described by one Senator who was present, is that it arose over the proposition to confirm the nomination of Emory Speer as District attorney for Georgia.
LONDON, Jan. 25.--The steam-ship Galileo (Br.,) Capt. Jenkins, from New-York Jan. 13 has arr. at Hull.
President Arthur returned to the FifthAvenue Hotel yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock, after having devoted the morning to paying visits.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 24.--Four weeks ago, upon information furnished by the German Consul at New-York, Herman Koerstein, residing here, was arrested for the embezzlement of 7,000 marks, at Bromberg, Prussia.

LONDON, Jan. 24.--Advices from Madagascar state that the new Queen, Ranavalona III, was crowned on Nov. 22. The Queen and Premier Taslam made speeches after the coronation ceremonies, in which they declared that they would not surrender an inch of their country to the French.

Officers of the West Shore and Ontario Terminal Company were in session yesterday afternoon, discussing the financial condition and prospects of that organization. It was stated that no definite plan of action was agreed upon.

It is what is known as the "short haul" bill, and was defeated in the Senate last year, after having passed the House after a long contest between the manufacturers and the railroads.

In his argument before Judge Van Brunt, in the Common Pleas, Equity Term, Robert Sewell, of counsel for the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company, in its suit to set aside the modified lease of Oct. 22, 1881, devoted himself to an examination of the pleas contained in the answer of the Manhattan and New-York Companies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--Controller Knox upon receiving information of the failure of the First National Bank of Leadville, requested N. P. Langford, National Bank Examiner, who was at Denver, to proceed to Leadville and make an examination of its affairs.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 24.--The golden wedding of Bishop Pierce, of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, will be celebrated at the residence of his son, in Hancock County, on Feb. 4, and will bring together a remarkable family gathering.
On the King's Bridge road, near King's Bridge, stands an old stone house still known as the Dikeman House, although it has long been unoccupied.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 24.--A dispatch from Muncie, Ind., says the trial of Seth Whitten, a lawyer of some prominence, for living in unlawful wedlock, terminated to-day in a jury disagreement.

The Association for Reciprocity in Coal and Iron Ore held its second meeting at the Windsor Hotel yesterday afternoon. The association was formed at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel on Jan. 3, to secure, if possible, a reciprocity treaty between Canada and the United States by ...

LIVERPOOL, Jan. 24.--The White Star steamer Germanic which sailed from here on the 2d inst. for New-York, and put back with her shaft broken, has anchored in the harbor of Waterford, Ireland. The Germanic will be towed to Liverpool.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 24.--An attempt is being made by a number of the leading temperance men of the State to organize a so-called Voters' Union, with State, county, and township branches.

LONDON, Jan. 24.--The Standard's financial article says that Messrs. Young Lark, Australian merchants here, have asked an extension. Their debts are stated at 280,000, with assets amounting to 420,000. The latter, however, cannot be speedily realized upon.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 24.--The Finance Committee of the Legislature heard this afternoon representatives of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company, who ask that the State abate its taxes to the amount of nearly $100,000. S.E. Baldwin, the attorney for the company, said that the more road the ...

PETROLIA, Penn., Jan. 24.--Thomas Walley accidentally shot his 6-year-old sister this morning while carelessly handling a revolver. The ball entered the base of the brain and lodged under the left ear. The child will die.

ERIE, Penn., Jan. 24.--To-day Leroy Warner presented a singular document to Judge Galbraith, stating that for a sum of money he surrenders all "right, title, interest, and claim in his minor daughter, Maggie," having sold her to Peter Wild. He asked the court to confirm the sale, never doubting his right to sell his child like other property. The strange petition caused a sensation and was ignored by the court.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Jan. 24.--To-day was the fourth day of the trial of Edward Newton Rowell on an indictment for manslaughter for killing Johnson L. Lynch. The sessions of court are six hours long, opening at 9:30 A.M. and closing at 5 P.M., with an intermission of an ...

COHOES, N.Y., Jan. 24.--A letter has been received from the West conveying the information that Samuel M. McGaffin, the missing Treasurer of the Cohoes Rowing Club and exbook-keeper for H.B. Silliman, of Cohoes, is there and well. He is leading a quiet life and working hard to remove the disgrace of his false step.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 24.--Thomas R. Ackrill, Jr., for the past two years manager of the skating-rink here and one of the most popular young men in social circles of the city, has mysteriously disappeared, leaving behind him his wife and child. About $1,000 belonging to H.H. Bigelow, proprietor of the rink, has gone also.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24, 1884. The House to-day passed the bill making an appropriation for the payment of the rebate bn the tobacco tax, by a vote of 270 to 1. The bill appropriates $3,750,000.

NEW-BEDFORD, Jan. 24.--In spite of the unfavorable weather and the high sea running to-day three divers were sent into the wrecked City of Columbus, and their discoveries settle to some extent some important points. Sevan tugs or steamers went out to the wreck. A diver to look for dead bodies in the interior of the wreck was carried out by the Storm King.

The report of Inspector Esterbrook, of the Bureau of Buildings, for 1883, was presented to the Fire Commissioners yesterday. It shows that a greater number of buildings were erected last year than in the preceding year, although the estimated cost was less.

The managers of the cotillion balls have been unfortunate as regards the weather this season. The first, which was held during holiday week, came off on a very stormy evening, and the second occurred last evening at Delmonico's.

Rumors were in circulation in Bayonne yesterday that there were irregularities in the accounts of F.T. Smith, the Treasurer of the city, by which it would lose $30,000. There is no doubt that a shortage has been discovered, but the members of the Common Council, to whom the facts are said to be ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 24.--McCully Co., glass manufacturers, have made a proposition to the green bottle men to return to work at a reduction of 10 per cent., and under the modified rules. The bottle-blowers have been idle six months, and this is the first attempt that has been made at a compromise. The proposition will be considered by the workmen to-morrow night.
TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 24.--The Provincial Legislature was formally opened this afternoon by Lieut.-Gov. Robinson.

READING, Penn., Jan. 24.--Jack Sherman, the oldest conductor on the Lebanon Valley Railroad, was caught between the bumpers of two cars near the depot this evening and almost instantly killed. He was 56 years of age, and leaves a family of five children.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24.--The light-house tender Holly this morning took the crew from the light-house at Seven-foot Knoll, in the mouth of the Patapsco, as the house was deemed unsafe because of running ice from the Upper Chesapeake. The lantern was lighted, but no fogbell was sounded during the day.

In the Spring of 1882 a trilobite, on the under surface of which were some peculiar markings, was found near Oxford, Ohio. The specimen was sent to Prof. Mickleborough, Principal of the Normal School, for examination.

The proceedings in the divorce cases of William Campbell against Anna Louise Campbell, which have been before the courts in this City and in Savannah at irregular intervals for several years, have at length reached a point that indicates an early settlement of the entire litigation. In Savannah, on Wednesday morning, it was officially announced that Judge Locke, ...
Earle's Hotel is now conducted on the European instead of the American plan.

The four-story-brick building, No. 206 East Broadway, is occupied by the Hebrew Free School Association for school purposes. It is an old-fashioned high-stoop dwelling, in which many alterations were made to adapt it to the purposes for which it is used.

The pet stock show at Madison-Square Garden assumed yesterday the appearance of a properly conducted exhibition. The work done Wednesday night and yesterday brought order out of chaos. The exhibits were properly arranged, and some adequate idea of the extent and value of the show can now be had by visitors.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 24.--One of the most fashionable assemblages ever seen in Macon witnessed last evening in Christ Church the marriage of Miss Carrie Johnston, of this city, to George W. Duncan, of Washington County, Ga.

A.E. Kaiser, a tailor, owns a tenement building at No. 38 Adams-street, Hoboken, and occupies part of it. A family named Blemlu occupy one of the floors.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 24.--J.J. Douglas, manager of the Henry County Lottery, was arrested to-day by Gen. Edgerton, Chief Inspector of the United States Postal Service, charged with violating the postal laws by sending lottery circulars through the mails. Douglas gave bonds and was released.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 24.--The Grand Jury of the United States Circuit Court at Mobile, Ala., composed of 11 Democrats and 7 Republicans, 5 of them colored, adjourned to-day after a session of 16 days.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 25.--The Committee of Twenty-eight appointed at the Republican State Convention, which last year was called by the "Silk Stocking Committee," to-day adopted an agreement and address which is expected to harmonize the factions in the Republican Party.

BOSTON, Jan. 25.--A notice was served yesterday making a cut-down in prices paid the job hands in the Waltham watch factory. The cut extends through the entire building, and ranges from 5 to 60 per cent., the heavier reductions being due to the special and experimental nature of some of the jobs.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25.--All hope of an amicable settlement of the differences between the Burlington and the roads working under the tripartite agreement is at an end.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 25.--The Rev. Mr. Stansbury who, acting under the authority of Bishop Brown, of the African Methodist Episcopal Conference, attempted to preach in the Bethel Church a few Sundays ago and had gone but a little way ...

The city authorities of Bayonne, N.J., were busy yesterday in the examination of the accounts of City Treasurer F.I. Smith. President Murphy, of the City Council, declined to give any information respecting the alleged discrepancies, beyond saying that the city would not lose anything, and the irregularities probably could and would be explained away.

It is our belief that action for the amendment of the charter of this City cannot be shirked at the present session of the Legislature without unpleasant consequences for those who may be responsible.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 25.--There are over 700 idle ovens in the Connellsville coke region. The remaining 8,937 ovens are running from three to five days in the week. The continued dull and profitless condition of the trade ...

The order granted by Judge Pratt, in Brooklyn, on Tuesday, directing the Brooklyn, Flatbush and Coney Island Railroad Company, better known as the Brighton Beach Road, to show cause why a Receiver should not be appointed, was returnable yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 25.--The suit of Daniel Wells, Jr., against Peter McGeoch is the sensation of the day, as it is a full expose of the greatest lard deal the country ever knew. McGeoch to-day filed a counter complaint against Wells, and the litigation promises to be everlasting.

Grandfather Ryan, the zealous guardian of the portal at the stage entrance of the UnionSquare Theatre, made preparations in his boudoir, that looks out upon a stone-paved lane tending toward Fourth-avenue, for a short-andearly yesterday morning.

The new iron steam-ship Gottardo, of the Navigazione Generale Italiana, arrived at this port from the Mediterranean yesterday. This vessel is the sister ship of the Indipendente, which arrived here on her first trip last September.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 25.--Thomas T. Luckett and Daniel Reiff, two of the batch of Pennsylvania Railroad conductors, and others who have been arrested on the charge of embezzling and conspiring to embezzle railroad tickets, were put on trial in Judge Thayer's Court of the Quarter Sessions to-day for alleged conspiracy to defraud the company.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25.--Coroner Bollman has completed his investigation in the case of Mrs. E.L.R. Thomson, who was found dead yesterday with a cloth saturated with chloroform over her face.

LONDON, Jan. 25.--The British schooner Luther, Capt. Stewart, which sailed from Greenock, Oct. 30, for St. John, Newfoundland, and subsequently from Troon, was wrecked yesterday during the late gale near Nevin, Wales, and four of the crew were drowned.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 25.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following business was transacted: No. 65--In the matter of the application for the final accounting of John M. Macauley , Executor of the estate of Isaac C. Van Wyck, deceased.
BANGOR, Me., Jan. 25.--John Spaulding, formerly of Newport, shot his wife this morning and then shot himself in the head. He died instantly, but the woman will recover.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 25.--The announcement yesterday that the New-York and Connecticut Air Line, or as it is more commonly called the Olmstead Parallel, had actually broken ground at Bridgeport for the construction of its road was a great surprise to railroad men and ...

BOSTON, Jan. 25.--The Captain and seven men of the Austrian brigantine Slavianka B., of Fiume, wrecked in mid-ocean, were rescued by the steamer Rochdale, Capt. F.D. Tindall, from Palermo for this port, and arrived here to-day.

CAIRO, Jan. 25.--Col. Coetlogon, commander at Khartoum, writes from that place that there is food enough there to last 6,000 men five months, and that the grain supplies are coming in as usual.
LONDON, Jan. 25.--The tugs that were sent out yesterday from Queenstown met the White Star steamer Germanic off Waterford, and are now towing her to Liverpool.

An extensive and elegant new structure on Fifth-avenue has just been finished and occupied by the Pottier Stymus Manufacturing Company. The facade is of the most beautiful and chaste design, and by reason of its materials and character every way, its intrusion into the centre of that aristocratic locality is fairly condoned.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 25.--Frank Dewalt, the defaulting President of the defunct First National Bank of Leadville, was arrested to-day at El Paso, Texas. Leadville officers are on the way there with extradition papers.

WHEELING, West Va., Jan. 25.--This afternoon, in the little brick church in Martinsburg, West Va., used by the Southern Methodist congregation of that town, two people were married by the Rev. John Leanstreet, formerly Chaplain of Jeb Stuart's Confederate regiment of cavalry.

An event of interest to skaters was the international 10-mile skating race for the amateur championship of America, that was postponed from Thursday evening, and took place last night at washington Park, in the outskirts of Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25.--Herman Korstein, a German, 38 years old, committed suicide at the county jail yesterday by taking poison. He was a fugitive from Germany, where he had committed the crimes of forgery and embezzlement ...

HICKSVILLE, Long Island, Jan. 25.--Mrs. Lealey Sprague, the wife of a hard-working farmer, who lives on the Hempstead turnpike road, about three miles from this village, was in her kitchen just before 7 o'clock this morning getting breakfast ready.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 25.--Brazier Bartholomew Highley, who was tried in the Camden County Court on a charge of murder in killing Jonas Cross, and who pleaded guilty to manslaughter, was sentenced to-day to four years' imprisonment in the penitentiary.

ALBANY, Jan. 25.--The majority in the Assembly is so quiet this Winter, and the minority so meek and lamb-like, that even the trifling political brush between the two this morning was of interest. DUBLIN, Jan. 25.--The gale on Wednesday demolished the Catholic church in Manor-Hamilton, County Leitrim.
LONDON, Jan. 26.--The steam-ship Caribbean. (Br.,) Capt. Fost, from Port an Prince Dec. 31, has arr. at Havre.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--Mr. John C. New, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, left Washington a few days ago for Indianapolis, and as soon as he had gone the report that has been circulated every time that he has left the capital during the last year or more, to the effect that he had resigned, was again heard among the politicians.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 25.--Mrs. Abe Buzzard, wife of a notorious outlaw, and three members of his gang, named Heiney, Hornberger, and Breneiser, were arrested on Ephrata Mountain this afternoon.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 25.--Further investigation into the case of Ira W. Townsend, the farmer who died mysteriously near this city on Wednesday last, confirms the suspicion that he was murdered. Townsend lived alone in a cabin three miles north of Scranton. On the 7th of this month it was known that he had some ...

There is a controversy between the Trustees of the Hackensack Cemetery Company and the First Baptist Church of Hackensack, N.J. Sam Bass for three years has been the sexton of the Baptist Church in the village, and was most highly thought of ...

BOSTON, Jan. 25.--There was a heavy slump in Bell telephone stock to-day, caused by the report that the United States Circuit Court at Philadelphia had refused to grant the injunction asked by the Bell people to restrain the Overland Company ...

MOUNT VERNON, Ind., Jan. 25.--Anderson and Snyder, sentenced to be executed here today, retired at 10 o'clock last night. During the night Anderson's nose commenced bleeding, and it became so serious that the guard was called.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 25.--The backbone of the shoe lasters' strike at Milford is broken. Some of the dissatisfied workmen have left town, while others have returned to work. The lasters who are members of the Protective Union have been out of employment about three weeks.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 25.--The ice harvest on the Hudson River is nearly completed. Since the beginning of the year the weather has been very favorable and a large crop of fine ice has been gathered. In this vicinity it is now 18 to 24 inches in thickness.

READING, Penn., Jan. 25.--A laborer, while excavating at an embankment of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, was suddenly buried in the falling earth up to his chin. His wife was coming toward him with tobacco when the accident occurred. An alarm was given and the man was extricated, badly bruised and almost exhausted.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Jan. 25.--Sadie McElroy, a patient in the insane asylum, died today from the effects of carbolic acid given her by an attendant in mistake for cough medicine. An investigation has been ordered.

"The question, Who are the best people in that comunity? [New-York,] is a very important one, if half Mr. Matthew Arnold says about the 'saving remnant' is true. It is they alone who can he saved and who can save the rest of the people.
The cause of the little disturbance between Mme. Gerster and Col. Mapleson which occurred in Baltimore on Thursday was kept a profound secret by the singer's friends in this City yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 25.--At the Horticultural Convention here to-day the Committee on Forestry proposed a resolution, which was adopted, calling upon the Government to establish in the West experimental stations in the interest of horticulture and forestry for the purpose ...
BUFFALO, Jan. 25.--A suit by Mrs. Sarah Camp against Frank Brenenstahl for $1,000 for selling her husband liquor resulted to-day in a verdict of $48.

A monument in memory of the late Dean Stanley has been executed in England, and it will soon be placed above his grave in the chapel of Henry VII., in Westminster Abbey. The monument is described as large and very beautiful.

Sixty-odd members of the Dartmouth College Alumni Association of New-York enjoyed their twentieth annual dinner, at Pinard's, last evening. Surrogate Daniel G. Rollins was a model presiding officer.

FONDA, N.Y., Jan. 25.--H.L. Siser, dry goods merchant in Fonda, made an assignment this morning. His liabilities are about $13,000, of which $11,000 is preferred. The assets are not known, but are large.
