WASHINGTON, Jan. 25, 1884. The House to-day passed the Senate bill providing for the removal of the body of the late Gen. E.O.C. Ord from Havana to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--In confirming a number of promotions in the army a few days ago, the Senate selected the names of officers who were to be promoted, vice certain other officers to be promoted to still higher grades, postponing action in the latter cases.

PANAMA, Jan. 16.--The politicians who went from Panama to Carthagena to endeavor to persuade Dr. Nunez to come and act as President of the State instead of taking that of the Union--he has been elected to both offices--returned a few days ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--The National Board of Trade began the last day of its session this morning with a discussion of the practicability of making more secure advances on bills of lading, which is deemed essential in view of the recent losses by New-York and New-England merchants of advances upon fraudulent bills of lading issued in Texas and Louisiana.

BUFFALO, Jan. 25.--A co-operative stove manufacturing company is being organized in this city with $75,000 capital. Abourt $35,000 has thus far been subscribed. The shares are $100 each, and no person is to be allowed to hold, govern, or control more than 30 such shares.

CHESTER, Penn., Jan. 25.--Isaac Rodgers, a clerk in the First National Bank of this city, was arrested to-day and held to answer the charge of falsifying the accounts of depositors to the amount of $3,700.
Bradstreet's reports 310 failures in the united States during the past week, 11 less than the preceding week, 21 more than the corresponding week of 1883, and 105 more than the same week of 1882.

Another instance of the highly peculiar service furnished by Mail Contractor George K. Otis was given yesterday in the breaking down of a mail van in Centre-street, just above Worthstreet.

Sherred Hall, the new building of the General Theological Seminary, at Ninth-avenue and Twenty-first-street, has been completed, and was formally dedicated by Assistant Bishop Potter yesterday morning.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 25.--The somewhat famous case of Henry S. Armstrong against David Jackson was disposed of to-day by the jury bringing in a verdict for the plaintiff for $2,000.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 25.--Eighty nonunion men who arrived to-day to begin work for the Birmingham Rolling Mill Company were received and taken in charge by the striking union men and are being entertained by them. From the outlook there is no prospect of the mill opening.

Wabon, of Chestnut Level, this county, who died Jan. 12, gives $3,500 to Lincoln University, Chester County, to be kept in perpetual investment by the Trustees of the university, and the income to be applied to the education of young men of color studying for the ministry.

BLOOMSBURG, Penn., Jan. 25.--George W. Suplee, Jr., of Madison Township, Columbia County, a student in the State Normal School at this place, slipped and fell from a third-story window of the school this morning, while trying to climb into an adjoining window. He fell on his head, breaking his neck and crushing the skull. The school was closed during the day.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 26.--Letters of administration have been issued on the estate of Hiram Radcliff, the recluse, to H.R. Romeyn, the tenor singer, of New-York City, his only heir. The statistics of the vintage of last year, which have just been published, show that last year's yield was the largest seen in France since 1878. In 1879 the yield was 25,700,000 hectolitres; in 1880, 29,600,000 hectolitres; in 1881, 34,100,000; in 1882, 30,800,000; and last year, 36,029,000. This is a satisfactory sign, though even this quantity is far below the average vintage of the last 10 years --viz., 45,000,000 hectolitres.

Mr. J.B. Gibbs, President of the Manhattan Temperance Association, gave an account yesterday of his interview, on temperance matters, with John Kelly, which took place a few days ago.

--The second installment of Lord Lytton's life of his father, being Parts III, and IV, of a work that will comprise six parts when completed, is not to make its appearance until the end of the present year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--There seems to be every probability that Senator Sherman, by the Introduction of his resolution to investigate the election disturbances of November last in Virginia and Mississippi, has laid the foundation for a protracted and, perhaps, heated sectional debate. If it is to come at all it will probably begin to-morrow.

TROY, N.T., Jan. 27.--There was more excitement near the malleable iron-works on Ida Hill this evening. John Crowe, a non-union molder in the employ of the above works, was coming out of his boarding-house when he was met by an unknown man, who, pointing a revolver ...
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27.--A colored woman named Sarah Thompson stole nearly $400 from her employer, Edward Barlow, of No. 136 Bowery, New-York, last week and ran away on Thursday.

LONDON, Jan. 27.--The wind blew a hurricane all last night. Much damage was done in London and many persons were injured. The glass roof of the Westminster Aquarium was demolished, causing a panic among the audience, in which several persons were hurt. A printing office in the Haymarket was unroofed, and a boy was killed by the falling debris.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 27.--Henry Rhodes, a young man employed to travel for the Henry M. Backus Oil Company, attempted suicide in this city yesterday. NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 25.--How to bring about the destruction of the abominable Louisiana State Lottery Company, with its evil associations and pernicious influence, is one of the greatest problems this community has before it.

QUEENSTOWN, Jan. 27.--The American Line steamship British Crown, Capt. Norvall, from Philadelphia Jan. 17, arr. here and sld. for Liverpool at 11 o'clock tonight.

One of the most imposing religious ceremonies ever witnessed in this City attended the celebration of the feast of the young Roman virgin whose name is so conspicuous in the martyrology, and the anniversary of the foundation of the parish, yesterday, in the beautiful Church of St. Agnes, in East Forty-third-street.
A preliminary meeting to take steps to organize a series of free concerts for working people was held in the Working Men's School, No. 109 West Fifty-fourth-street, yesterday afternoon.

BREST, Jan. 27.--A force of 255 marines was dispatched from here to-day to Tonquin. SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27.--Advices from Canton, China, state that the American Prresbyterian and the Roman Catholic mission establishments in that city were wrecked by a native mob on Dec. 16. The property was destroyed. No lives were taken.

From 100 to 120 persons assembled on Saturday night at a hotel in the town of East Chester to witness a cock-fight which was set down for 10 o'clock. Some 14 to 16 birds, owned by residents of Mount Vernon, Woodlawn, and William's Bridge, had been taken there.

Thus far the Senate has accomplished more than the House in the passage of bills of national importance. The bill to provide for the Presidential succession and that to regulate the counting of the Electoral votes are of great moment to the whole country.

Chinatown was agitated yesterday in an unusual degree. The houses were decorated with gay banners, the Chinamen were out upon the streets in their best clothes, and the juvenile population of the vicinity were in Mott and Pell streets gazing upon these unusual demonstrations with wonder and admiration.

The Rev. John M. Farley, secretary to Cardinal John McCloskey, Archbishop of NewYork, has been promoted to the prelacy by the Holy Father in recognition of his services to the church of New-York during the past 12 years.

India has lost her greatest son, Keshub Chunder Sen. His was one of the few names known not only most widely among the two hundred and fifty millions who are said to inhabit the vast Indian Empire, but familiar even to European ears.
Looking at Gen. Sherman's head and profile, bobbing up and down in a convivial assemblage, the other night, one could not fail to be struck by the Caesarlike look of the man.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 27.--An intoxicated drug clerk at the small town of Mingo, on being applied to for cream of tartar, dished out arsenic, with which a family named Sules made biscuit. The father, mother, and several children were poisoned, and it was only by prompt measures that any of them were saved.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 27.--Although the attention of the Government has frequently been drawn to the lottery swindle that is bing carried on at St. Stephen, New-Brunswick, no attempt has been made to put it down.

It is stated by oculists that since the building of the elevated roads there has been a large increase in a peculiarly troublesome affectation of the eyes. This trouble is caused by the flying chips of steel and iron from the rails and wheels of the cars.

The Chicago Base-ball Club has the best grounds in the country. Its diamond is on the lake front, and but a few minutes' walk from the business portion of the city. The patrons do not have to travel to the suburbs to witness a game of base-ball, as is the case in almost every other large city.
Any measure directed against the cigarette demands the approval of good citizens, but Mr. CLARKE'S bill forbidding the sale of cigarettes to boys under 17 seems to be a mistake.

During the past two months, the Westcott Express Company have lost three trunks, and the Dodd Express Company one trunk and three valises from the Fourth-avenue baggage office at the Grand Central Station.
WEST NEWTON, Penn. Jan. 28.--An unknown Hungarian out of work and starving committed suicide were yesterday by jumping into an air-hole in the ice. The body has not been recovered.

There was a whirl in the stock market yesterday which took most of the brokers by surprise and sent the "bears" scampering out of sight. Several operators wrere caught on the "short" side and squeezed without mercy.
Father Barry, of the Church of the Transfiguration, in Mott-street, complained to the police Sunday night that the New Year's celebration of the Chinamen disturbed the services in his church.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 28.--J.B. Wadsworth, of Morrisville, proprietor of 18 cheese factories, has failed, with liabilities of about $80,000. Beside his factories he owns a good house in Morrisville and 200 acres of land, all of which is incumbered.

The sale of the National Telegraph lines to the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company, the negotiations for which were concluded last week, was consummated yesterday, when Calvin S. Brice, President of the National, transferred to the Baltimore and Ohio the entire capital stock of that company.

Ex-County Judge Samuel A. Brown, of Cooperstown, N.Y., died yesterday morning, after a week's illness, from pneumonia, aged 49.

The Rev. Dr. Armitage presided at the Baptist Pastors' Conference yesterday and read a paper on the "Treatment of Skepticism in the Pulpit." Opinion, he remarked, was divided as to the wisdom of treating it in the pulpit at all.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Jan. 28.--The defense proceeded with their evidence in the Rowell trial to-day, examining a good many witnesses for the purpose of showing that the prisoner was deranged at the times he killed Lynch, and that there are some grounds for believing that his alleged strange actions were inherited.

It would need more time and space than are now at our disposal to rehearse the story of "Confusion," a three-act production, which was represented for the first time in this City at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre, last evening.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 28.--In the House to-day the Postmaster-General, replying to a question, said it was, not the intention of the Government to reduce the rate of postage on letters from 3 to 2 cents, as adopted in the United States.
BERLIN, Jan. 28.--The funeral services of Herr Lasker at the new synagogue to-day were participated in by 5,000 persons. The interior of the edifice was draped in mourning.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 28.--In September, 1882, Judge Gardiner, of the Superior Court, decided the case of the Chicago Galvenized Wire Fence Company against the Washburn and Moen Company.

READING, Penn., Jan. 28.--The Mellert Iron Company's Pipe Mill closed to-day for the remainder of the Winter, thus throwing 300 men out of employment. There is no lack of work, but the mill was stopped because the cold weather interfered with its worlding.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 28.--Things are a great deal brighter in Newburg, where the Cleveland Rolling Mill Company is arranging for a busy season's work. Orders are on hand that will keep the rail mill busy for the next year. The Bessemer Steel-works have started up and will be kept going hereafter. The rail mill is being prepared for operation, and the other departments will be opened in February. The Forest City Mill will also start soon.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 28.--Controller Knox has appointed ex-Judge S.G. Hadley, of Waterloo, N.Y., Receiver of the First National Bank, of this city, to succeed Mr. Elisha T. Smith, who recently resigned, owing to ill-health.

STEUBENVILLE, Penn., Jan. 28.--Fifty crimpers in the Acme Glass-works struck this morning against a reduction in their wages. The factory had been idle six weeks, and had just started up when the strike occurred.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 28.--The Union Market National Bank of Watertown, near this city, has lost, by the defalcation of its Cashier, a sum exceeding $31,000. Mr. Tilden G. Abbott, the Cashier, drew $10,000 from the Fourth National Bank of Boston, where the Union Market kept its funds on Thursday last, ostensibly to ...

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 28.--A man named Webb became involved in a difficulty in Jackson County, Ala., to-day, with three brothers named Wilburn, and killed two of them and fatally wounded a third. The quarrel began about a trivial matter.

C.P. Huntington stated yesterday that C.W. Smith, of Richmond, General Manager of the Chesapeake and Ohio, would probably be appointed to the same position with the Kentucky Central Railroad. Mr. Smith will therefore manage both roads, which, as Mr. Huntington remarked, will work in entire harmony, although possessing distinct organizations.

Mr. Bartley Campbell's new play, " Separation," which was presented last night at the Union-Square Theatre in the presence of a large audience, tells a simple and, on the whole, rather ingenuous story. This is it: Benton Blair, who is described as a "man of prejudice," is married to a young and charming woman.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 28.--Emil Trumpeter, who has been twice convicted of the murder of Anthony Delano, once in the second degree and the last time in the first, was arraigned for the third time time to-day. He pleaded guilty to the general indictment leaving the court to hear testimony and fix the grade of the crime.
The Justices of the City Court have designated Judge McAdam as Chief-Justice. The General Sessions Grand Jury had before it yesterday Excise Commisioners Morris, Houghton, and Mitchell.

CINCINNATI, Ohio. Jan. 28.--Hughes and Cathcart have been awarded the pool privileges of the two meetings of the Latonia Jockey Club at Covington at their bid of $26,250. Last year when $18,000 was bid it was thought to be a high amount.
The Court of Special Sessions on Saturday sentenced John Keating, for assaulting a grocery clerk, to a term in the penitentiary on a charge of assault and battery.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28.--The Grand Jury this afternoon found true bills of indictment against William B. Barrett and Edward J. Cattell, charging them with conspiracy in the rehypothecations of bonds belonging to Augustus Boyd, and a true bill was also found against Barrett charging him with the embezzlement of $3,000 worth of property of Augustus Boyd, growing out of the same transacaion. The defendants have acted as brokers for the prosecutor.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 28.--The first blue ribbon of the session was fastened to-night upon the lapel of Col. Tremper, of Ulster. It encircled the veto which Private Secretary Lamont brought into the Assembly from the Governor.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 28.--The will of Dr. John R. Lee, who died in this city recently, makes the following bequests: To the American Missionary Association, $10,000; ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 28.--The general merit roll of the Fourth Class, corps of cadets, at West Point Military Academy, has just been made up. This is the only class corps that is given a January standing, and it is composed of cadets admitted in July and September last.

Dining out the other night, I came across the best Winter salad I ever ate. It improved on the hackneyed mixture that Sydney Smith has perhaps immortalized in verse, inasmuch as there were added anchovies, truffles, and olives; and the sauce was the ordinary mayonnaise.
ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Jan. 28.-- Three distinct shocks of earthquake were felt last night at Rothesay, nine miles from here. In one house a box was upset.

There was an unusual throng of spectators at the exhibition of the New-York Fanciers' Club in Madison-Square Garden yesterday morning, but when the storm began in the afternoon the attendance fell off, so that even the ferrets and the cats had the blues, not to mention the officers of the club.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Jan. 28.--Alfred Philby, of this city, went down into a manhole of the public sewer here this evening to clean it out and was suffocated by gas. He was 24 years old, and leaves a widow.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Jan. 28.--Last night the Brigham Young Academy at Provo City, Utah, Mormon school, with 400 students, was destroyed by fire. The loss is $30,000; uninsured. No lives were lost, but there were a number of narrow escapes. A quantity of nitroglycerine was fortunately removed from the laboratory before the fire had gained much headway.

The Mestayer and Barton company appeared at the Star Theatre last evening in a musical farce entitled "Wanted, a Partner." The production is after the style of "The Tourists," and is so arranged as to give each member of the company a chance to show his or her peculiar specialty.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Jan. 28.--The Gloucester Fire Insurance Company to-night voted to close up its affairs.

The Cuban residents of this City held a mass-meeting last evening at Clarendon Hall to protest against the arrest of Col. Carlos Aguera on the complaint of the Spanish Government that he was a bandit.

LONDON, Jan. 28.--The rowing match between G. Bubear and W. Elliott, for 400, took place this morning. The course was on the Thames from a Putney to Mortake. Bubear was the victor by four lengths. Elliott kept ahead as far as Rosebank, a mile and a furlong from Putney. At that point Bubear gained the lead and won an easy victory. His time was 30:38.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States today in the patent case of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway Company, appellant, vs. the National Car Brake Shoe Company.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28.--The possibilities of peace appear to be getting more distant, for the Western trunk lines and the roads working under the tripartite agreement have at last got to fighting among themselves.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 28.--Andrew Mango, of No. 60 Guthrie-street, has buried four children from diphtheria during the past few months, and to-day his fifth and last was burned to death while stuffing shavings into an open grate. His mother, on hearing of the loss of the last of their little ones, became a raving maniac, and had to be restrained by force to prevent her doing mischief to herself.

James Alexander, dealer in millinery and fancy goods at No. 323 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, made an assignment yesterday to J.E. Doherty, giving preferences for $24,000.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 28.--Fire in the Springfield Watch Factory, just before time for stopping work to-day, created a panic among the female operatives, several of whom jumped from the second and third story windows. Three young women had their legs broken and one an arm broken. About 1,100 operatives were at work at the time. The fire was quickly extinguished. The loss will not exceed $100.
AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 28.--Petmecky, the murderer of Mrs. Froitzheim, was sentenced today to be hanged on Friday, March 1. He received the sentence without any emotion.

ROSITA, Col., Jan. 28.--Frank Williams and John Gray, who shot and killed Orion Kurtz in a saloon row yesterday morning, were taken from jail at 2 o'clock this morning by a masked mob and hanged to the rafters of a log shanty near by. Gray died game, but Williams pleaded for mercy, claiming that he shot in self-defense. A Coroner's jury returned a verdict that the "hanging was done by parties unknown."

An alarming epidemic of black measles, a type of the disease which is so malignant as to be often mistaken for small-pox, has swept through the hospital department of the alms-house during the past week.

Secretary Teller sent to the Senate to day copies of two letters on file in his department relative to the Yellowstone Park, which were inadvertently left out of the lot sent in some time ago in response to a request from the Senate.
The thirty-first anniversary meeting of the Young Men's Christian Association was held in Association Hall last night, and was largely attended. The President, William W. Hopper, Jr., presided.

The annual charity ball for the benefit of the Children's Hospital was held at the new armory of the National Rifles this evening, and in brilliancy and substantial results surpassed several of its most successful predecessors.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Jan. 28.--J.F. Fogg, who came here recently from California and purchased a half-interest in a liquor store, was assaulted last night by his partner, William Wood, and beaten so badly with brass knuckles that he will die.
ELIZABETH, Penn., Jan. 28.--Harvey Slacker, aged 25 was found dead near here this morning. He left McKeesport, seven miles below, to skate here on Saturday night, and was not seen alive afterward.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 28.--Last night the Chief of Police arrested P. Rosenberg and two associates for selling counterfeit money. Rosenberg has been employed at intervals as a heater in the mills. His associates are residents of Youngstown. One of the prisoners, when locked up, confessed. He said that Rosenberg is President of a society for manufacturing bogus money. No counterfeit money or tools were found.

As Mr. T.A. Edison and his midnight co-workers were coming out of the Edison Company's offices in Fifth-avenue, last night, E.H. Johnson dropped behind to listen to the application of a beggar. "What's up?" said Mr. Edison.

Charles H. Rugg, the mulatto who is charged with the murderous assault on Mr. and Mrs. Sealey Sprague, at East Meadow, on Friday morning last, yesterday made a full confession of his crime to Jailer Murphy and Detectives Wood and Smith, at the Queen's County Jail, in Long Island City.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan, 28.--Argument was heard here to-day before Judge Spear to dissolve the corporation of Brown, Bonnell Co, the largest iron concern but one in the country.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 28.--The County Commissioners to-day brought suit against Squire John P. Frank and Constable Frederick Struck, of Columbia, before Alderman Fordney, of this city charging them with conspiracy to defraud the county of money.

The investigations which the Democrats are preparing to make into the various departments at Washington would be more likely to be fruitful if they were directed to some definite reform of the mistaken or bad methods which undoubtedly exist there.
RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 23.--An exciting ice-yacht race was sailed to-day in a heavy snowstorm. The list of starters comprised the Dreadnaught, Scud, Uncle Bob, and Cyclone.

An accident occurred in the engine-room of the East River bridge, in Prospect-street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, which resulted in the instant death of Patrick McBride, who was engaged in oiling the machinery, and the tearing of his head completely from his body.

The special committee of the Assembly devoted itself yesterday to an effort to discover the amount of fees received yearly by the Register of this County, and what proportion of them is retained by that officer as compensation for his valuable services.

A sketch artist took an active interest in the De Meli divorce proceedings in Judge Rumsey's court yesterday. The amiable plaintiff, the serene defendant, the talkative lawyers, the complaisant court officers, and the smirking band of faithful females were accurately portrayed on paper.
The first message by Morse's telegraph was sent from Baltimore to Washington, and returned, on the morning of May 24.

WHEELING, West Va., Jan. 28.--Nail City Lodge of the Amalgamated Association of this city this morning subscribed $700 per week to the striking nailers of the Oakland (Cal.) Nail Mill during the continuance of the strike there.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 28.--Jerry M. Canfield this afternoon swore out warrants against Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ralston, this city, for black-mail. Canfield moved to the city 10 years ago from the country, having $30,000.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 28.--A well-dressed man and woman have recently been traveling over many of the railroads, he representing himself as an officer of the Central Vermont Railroad and thus obtaining passes from General Agents and Superintendents of roads.

United States Deputy Marshals Grimes and Smith went to St. Louis recently on business, and on their return to this City yesterday narrated their experience with a fellow-passenger coming East. A man boarded the train at St. Louis with them, and his conduct immediately excited surprise.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 28.--The telegram from New-York, ordering a 50 per cent. reduction of expenses on all the Gould lines in Texas, created something of a sensation in local railroad circles.

Mr. Sidney Woollett will recite "Mac beth" this afternoon at the Madison Club Theatre. "Fun on the Bristol," which has been seen on many occasions and at many theatres in our City, was revived last night at the Comedy Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28, 1884. The conference committees upon the Greely Relief bill have had a meeting at which the Senate conferees receded from the amendment made by the Senate. The bill would have been reported to the two houses to-day had they remained in session.

Murray's telegram to Mr. Springer declaring that the statements before the Committee on Expenditures in the Department of Justice reflecting upon his official conduct while Marshal of Kentucky are wholly false and malicious, do not dispose of the case against him as it stands before Mr. Springer and his associates.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 28.--The huge vertical boiler of the Newbern Gas-works exploded at 7 o'clock this evening with terrific violence, going through the roof and falling within 30 feet of its original position. The engineer miraculously escaped injury.

A decision declaring that Samuel Raynor Co. and Berlin Jones, manufacturers of envelopes, in this City, have been for the past four years infringing upon patents owned by Mrs. Marie A. Reay, Executix, has been given by Justice Hoyt A. Wheeler, of the United States Circuit Court. In 1863 patents were issued upon the Reay envelope machine, and in 1880 additional patents were issued upon several improvements.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Jan. 28.--The brigantine Lorne, which sailed from this port on Jan. 12, for Porto Rico, with a cargo of fish, has been wrecked on Anegada, one of the Virgin Islands, north of Porto Rico. She is insured here for $5,500 and the cargo for $8,000.

PARKHILL, Ontario, Jan. 28.--The Parkhill Salt Company, formed about six weeks ago, began boring here a few days ago, and, at a depth of 1,100 feet, last evening struck what appears to be a prolific salt-bed of the best quality. The discovery has caused some excitement.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 28.--Eleven prisoners escaped from jail at Buena Vista yesterday and have not yet been apprehended. Henry Nenemeyer, who last Summer wounded City Marshal Stingley, of Salida, and killed a Deputy Marshal, is among the number.

Ladies at Nice are using sunshades covered outside with live flowers on a silk surface. Violets with a border of jessamine and white and scarlet geraniums arranged together are popular designs. At the longest these designs last only three days.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 28.--In the Legislature to-day Representative Odon declared that in dealing with the fence problem there was a prevailing disposition to discriminate against the interests of West Texas, and that if justice was not done all sections he would be willing to see the State divided.
PARIS, Jan. 28.--The Chamber of Deputies to-day debated an interpellation offered by M. Langlois regarding the economical policy of the Government and questions affecting working men.

It is to be hoped, in the interests of Humanity and party politics, that, as soon as Mr. SHERMAN'S investigation of Southern outrages on negroes is finished, Senator BUTLER will move for an investigation of the outrages on white men on Long Island.
Three inventors waited two hours for an audience before the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday afternoon, but went away disappointed.

Mr. James W. Wadsworth, of NewYork, who met with a severe accident by the overturning of a Concord coach just before Congress met, was in his seat to-day for the first time since Congress assembled, and was congratulated by a large number of his friends in the last House.

TORONTO, Ontario. Jan. 28.--Annie Cole sister of the little girl who was scalded to death last week, has lost her reason from grief. She blamed herself for the fatal accident. On Saturday morning she left her father's house without hat, boots, or jacket, and has not since been heard of.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 28.--There is a prospect that police affairs may become muddled here as they have been recently in Troy. To-night Police Commissioners Richard B. Rock and Jacob P. Cook, the Republican members of the board.
LONDON, Jan. 28.--The Marquis of Lansdowne, Governor-General of Canada, has been appointed a Knight of the Grand Cross of St. Michael and St. George.
George K. Otis, the contractor in charge of the transportation service in New-York, has been here to-day to explain to the Postmaster-General the charges of inefficiency in carrying out his contract.

The Second Patriarchs' ball attracted a large number of fashionable people to Delmonico's last evening. There were 300 persons present, who began to arrive at 10:45, and some of them remained until after 3 this morning on the dancing floor. The decorations were pretty.

Since Lawrence Barrett's arrival in this city last week to take the part of Lanciotto in "Francesca da Rimini" it has been noticed by the mutual friends of the actor and the author of the play, George H. Boker, that the gentlemen in question did not speak. Social relations between them are wholly suspended.

HILLSBORO, Ill., Jan. 28.--Since the indictment of Orrin A. Carpenter for the murder of Zora Burns, his friends have had daily disputes regarding the luxuries and privileges to be allowed the wealthy prisoner.
To-day being the Chinese New Year's, the Chinese Minister had an informal reception at his residence in H-street, which was largely attended by both ladies and gentlemen.

A gang of ruffians, six in number, who hail from the neighborhood of First-avenue and Sixty-third-street, known as Battle-row, yesterday went into the liquor store of John Fincken, at Sixty-third-street and First-avenue, and, after partaking of drinks, refused to pay for them.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Jan. 22.--Charles Salene's child, aged 3 years, yesterday poured a quantity of carbolic acid down the throas of her sister, aged 14 month. The little one lingered in great agony until to-day when it died. Its mouth and intestines were horribly burned.

The Western Distillers' Association is preparing to make a strong fight against the proposition of the glucose manufacturers to establish distilleries for making spirits out of the waste matter left after glucose is made.
We were informed yesterday of the occurrence at Glen Grey, about 12 miles from Queenstown, of a phenomenon which, while it lasted, nearly terrified the white and native population out of their wits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28.--Senator Hoar reported to-day from the Committee on the Judiciary an anti-polygamy bill which embraces the principal features of the Edmunds bill, introduced during the present session of Congress, and adds to them other provisions originating with the committee.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 28.--From a Parliamentary return it appears that the total Dominion revenue from July 1, 1882, to Jan. 20, 1883, was $19,981,368, and for the same period in 1883-4 $17,869,137, a decrease of $2,112,231. The expenditures for the first named period were $15,421,657, and for the second $16,406,869, an increase of $985,212.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 28.--The annual report of the Water Commissioners of this city was made public to-day. It states that for the first time in their history the water-works may now be considered self-sustaining, and they are also in excellent condition.

Several hundred persons who gathered in the Senate galleries to-day to listen to the expected lively political debate on the Mississippi and Virginia outrage resolutions offered by Senator Sherman, went home disappointed. The resolutions were not mentioned, and there was no debate of any kind.

MINERAL SPRINGS, Howard County, Ark. Jan. 28.--The citizens are indignant at the Supreme Court decision granting an appeal in the cases of the three rioters sentenced to be hanged. Justices Eakin and English were hanged in effigy Saturday night on the scaffold prepared for the prisoners.

A warrant of removal was signed by Judge Brown, in the United States District Court, yesterday, for "Bill" Moran, alias "Dice" Moran, a burglar who was indicted in Washington some time ago. The man had been arrested here upon the supposition that he was John Lyden, who committed a murder in that city about 10 years ago. The Washington officer, however, identified him as the burglar and not the murderer.

The nomination of the next Surveyor General of New-Mexico is due on Feb. 4, and the subject is attracting more attention and is more important in all its bearings than any similar event of recent occurrence.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 28.--At the trial to-day to set aside the indictments for forgery against Aggie Hill and William Neilson, in the celebrated Senator Sharon divorce case, the Grand Jurors were committed for contempt of court in having refused to divulge the secrets of the Grand Jury room.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Jan. 29.--The steamer Circassian, from New-York for Glasgow, arrived to-day with the band of her propeller loose. She will be repaired at once by divers.

Carver Co., wholesale merchants of Livingstone, have levied an attachment on certain property of the National Park Improvement Company to secure a bill of large amount. ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 29.--In the CattonCarter billiard-match here to-night Cotton scored 1,000 to Carter's 696. The other 1,000 points will be disposed of to-morrow and Thursday nights. The match is for $1,000, and the betting is now two to one on Catton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29, 1884. A resolution was adopted by the House to-day providing that the funeral of the late Representative Mackey, of South Carolina, be held in the Hall of the Representatives at 1 o'clock tomorrow.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 29.--The sixth day of the Winter meeting was clear and pleasant. There was a fair attendance, and the track was heavy.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 29.--The Directors of the Long Branch Iron Pier Company met here this afternoon. It was decided to rebuild the pier, and Warren Leland, Jr., was authorized to confer with the contractors.

FONDA, N.Y., Jan. 29.--A cock-fight occurred in the suburbs of Amsterdam last night between fowls from Amsterdam and Rock City. Amsterdam won four battles and Rock City two.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29.--The safe in the Post Office at Blue Island, one of the south-western suburbs of this city, was blown open by burglars last night. In addition to the stamps and money of the Post Office which were taken, some of the township's funds stored in the safe were also carried off. The value of the plunder secured by the thieves is placed at $2,000.

SACO, Me., Jan. 29.--The trial of Mrs. Barrows, indicted with Oscar Blaney for the murder of her husband, Thomas Barrows, at Kittery, on Nov. 14 last, was begun to-day. Blaney will be tried separately, owing to differences among counsel regarding the line of defense.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Jan. 29.--Edward Scott, while visiting his brother-in-law at NewAlexandria, Ohio, this morning, committed suicide by shooting himself. The deceased man leaves a wife and two children. No cause is assigned for the deed.

BATH, Me., Jan. 29.--Messrs. Goss, Sawyer Packard launched to-day a steamer, not named, of about 950 tons, built for the Oregon Improvement Company, and designed as a passenger and freight steamer for the Oregon coast.

The sale of seats for Mrs. Langtry's engagement at Niblo's, which will begin next Monday, opened at the box-office yesterday morning. The box-office is supposed to be open at 8 o'clock, but it was nearer 9 when a sleepy-looking boy raised the window.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 29.--Thomas O. Richards, Superintendent of the Bull Run Colliery, of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company, while crossing a bridge over the mouth of the slope, last evening, fell to the bottom, a distance of 200 yards, and was instantly killed.

ST. JOHNSBURG CENTRE, Vt., Jan. 29.--A young son of Dr. Newell was fatally shot in the abdomen last night by a six-year-old playmate named Heyser. The Children had obtained possession of Dr. Newell's revolver, and while in the hands of the Heyser boy it was discharged with the above result.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 29.--Reuben Springer has given $20,000 to furnish the buildings for the art school which have just been liberally endowed by Judge Nicholas Longworth in pursuance of the wishes of his father, Joseph Longworth, recently deceased. Mr. Springer's gift will be used to add two stories to the Cincinnati College building, on Walnut near Fourth street, for the use of the art school.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 29.--The House committee which was appointed last year to investigate the subject of convict labor has prepared its report.

WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 29.--A young Swedish woman was found wandering in the streets by the police at midnight and was lodged in a hotel. She blew out the gas and was found this morning unconscious. Her recovery is doubtful. She gave the name of Hansen, and said she belonged in New-York.

FONDA, N.Y., Jan. 29.--The citizens of Amsterdam have decided to apply to the Legislature for a city charter. The city will contain about 14,000 people, and will be about three and one-half square miles in extent, and will be divided into four wards.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 29.--An accident occurred at Point Narrows, south of Shell Mound, on the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway this morning.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange has refused to list $180,000 of the new issue of the first mortgage sinking fund bonds of the Indianapolis, Decatur and Springfield Railroad. The holders of the said bonds, it is stated, are about to apply to have their old bonds returned.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 29.--A train arrived here, about 1:30 o'clock this morning, on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad with 800 laborers and a large quantity of rails, sills, and lumber. The men at once began unloading the track-building materials, and in a few hours they had laid a double track between East Arch-street ...

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 29.--The officers of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Road refuse to say how much shortage there is in the accounts of ex-Paymaster Medary. His accounts were all right in September last when his books were examined. He says he has paid out money without taking proper vouchers, and that when this is corrected all will be right. The officers have no fear that the company will sustain any loss on his account.

ELKTON, Md., Jan. 29.--A second attempt was made yesterday to poison the Hall family, in that town. The mother and four children were taken ill after eating. The mother accused a daughter, who had turned out badly, of the crime, and she was arrested and sent to jail. The daughter has served a term in the House of Correction.

KENDALLVILLE, Ind., Jan. 29.--Martin Sellers, of this place, was summoned to testify against C.C. Cain, charged with murder, and now being tried at Albion. He remarked that he would kill himself rather than testify. Shortly afterward he went to his room and shot himself, dying instantly.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 29.--Justice Krautz, of Ephrata, this morning gave a hearing to members of the famous Buzzard gang of outlaws captured on Ephrata Mountain by Detective Bartholomew, of Philadelphia, Gus Buzzard, wife of the outlaw, was held in bail for trial on the charge of receiving, stolen goods, and the men were all committed for trial on the charges of burglary and larceny.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 29.--One of the largest weddings that ever occurred in this city took place to-night at the North-Street, Colored Baptist Church. The bride was Miss Lizzie Lane, a famous belle of this city, and the groom Mr. Nathaniel Parrott, an attache of the Maryland Club. The church was crowded to its fullest capacity, 1,200 persons being present. A number of fashionable carriages occupied the street for several squares.

GREENSBURG, Penn., Jan. 29.--Last night 27 citizens met and formed a secret, oath-bound brotherhood, and decided not to buy French goods and to boycott all dealers selling them until the embargo on pork is removed.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 29.--The Court of Appeals decided to-day that the act prohibiting the manufacture of cigars in tenement-houses in New-York City was unconstitutional. The opinion was given by Judge Finch and is concurred in by all the Judges.

BOSTON, Jan. 29.--About 600 farmers of New-England interested in the milk trade met here to-day to consider the best means of protecting their interests. Addresses were made by W.P. Richardson, of Goshen, N.Y., President of a milk company in that section, and by Henry E. Alvord, of Orange County, N.Y. George M. Baker, of South Lincoln, was elected President of the association, and E.P. Smith, of Waltham, Secretary.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 29.--Since Saturday night last Thomas F. Sheldon, book-keeper for Allen, Bush West, a large cotton firm, has been missing. It was reported last night that he had been found, but the family now advertises a reward for his recovery. There is no reason assigned for his disappearance. He is nearly 60 years old.

WASHINGNON, Jan. 29.--By adhering to the caucus decision to forbear and be silent, the Democratic Senators prevented to-day the heated political debate which was expected to spring up over Mr. Sherman's resolution ordering an inquiry into political outrages in Virginia ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 29.--Mme. Sembrich has renewed her contract with Herbert Gye for the coming London opera season at the Covent Garden Theatre. She will sail for England in the latter part of April.

QUEBEC, Jan. 29.--A miner named Rothwell, working at the Ascot Copper Mines, has been poisoned by his boarding-house mistress, her object being to secure a large amount of money belonging to Rothwell. The woman has been arrested and sent to Sherbrooke Jail.
Thomas Burke, of No. 242 Cherry-street, made a charge of habitual drunkenness on Monday to Justice Gorman, at the Essex Market Court, against his wife Margaret, age 35.

BERLIN, Jan. 29.--The draft of the bill for the proposed Working Men's Life and Limb Assurance scheme has been approved by the Economic Council. This is considered an indication that it will be accepted by the Reichstag in March.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 29.--Col. Bennett H. Young, recently President of the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Railroad, to-day accepted the Presidency of the Southern Exposition.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 29.--The American Lumber Company have assigned. The company had a capital of $1,000,000, was formed some years ago, and owned extensive limits and mills. The banks mainly interested are the Toronto Bank, Quebec Bank, and the Bank of Commerce.

There was a large attendance again yesterday at the exhibition of the New-York Fanciers' Club, at Madison-Square Garden. The only additions to the fish, flesh, and fowl that have been on exhibition during the week were a pair of tile-colored pug dogs that were much admired by the ladies.

Mr. Thomas W. Keene is ranked to-day among tragic actors. That is to say, he has acted in Boston, Chicago, and in many Western cities with brilliant popularity. He has worked hard upon the stage for many years. At one time he was at the head of a company in this City.

Mayor Low said yesterday that he would not file the appointments of the heads of the different departments of the Brooklyn City Government until Friday.

ALBANY, Jan. 29.--The debate in the Assembly to-day over the Van Allen bill to reduce the fees of the Sandy Hook pilots one-third contributed little or nothing that was new or instructive upon this subject.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Jan. 29.--Abbe Chubert was to-day fined $20 or two months' imprisonment in default of payment for kissing Mrs. Bezeau, his landlady, while she was in bed.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 29.--The General Assembly met in this city this morning, pursuant to adjournment, and Gov. Bourn delivered his annual message.

FONDA, N.Y., Jan. 29.--An attachment has been granted by David H. Marks and others, of New-York, against the property of Morris King, of Gloversville. King recently failed, and it was said made a fictitious assignment with fraudulent preferences to the amount of $7,000.

PARIS, Jan. 29.--Two policemen have been placed under arrest for refusing to perform their duty.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Jan. 29.--The Rev. Dr. Wilson, of St. George's Cathedral here, has addressed a farewell letter to his former congregation stating that, in consequence of the failure of all his efforts at reinstatement in his charge, on account of his firm refusal to sever his connection with the Salvation Army, he has decided to seek another field of labor.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 29.--Claflin Co. bought Gordon's stock this morning for $175,200 and sold it later in the day to Burke, Fitzsimons, Hone Co. at a less figure, but the exact amount is not made public.
WINNIPEG, Jan. 29.--News has just been received here of a terrible explosion on the Canadian Pacific Railway, east of Port Arthur. The explosion occurred on Jan. 22, ...
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 29.--At 7 o'clock this morning people passing along Pierce-street, on the south side, discovered the dead body of a man lying in a snow bank on the side of the street.
A meeting of representatives of the various liquor-dealers' associations was held yesterday in Germania Hall for the purpose of combining in one organization.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 29.--While S. Levein, the proprietor of a jewelry store on Sixthstreet, was absent this morning, and while his wife was in a room in the rear of the store, a thief entered and carried off jewelry valued at from $1,200 to $1,500. Mr. Levein, on his return, discovered a mulatto at work on the safe, who drove him back into the room at the point of a pistol. The robber escaped.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 29.--Parties from Titusville have leased 1,000 acres in Galway, Saratoga County, an inaccessible, desolate section, and are erecting derricks to bore for oil. Petroleum has been found in a well on George Isbell's farm, which led to the organization of a prospecting company.

A feeling of deep concern is being awakened in Wall-street by the proposition to remove the Stock Exchange from its present site. The members of the Exchange are very nearly, if not entirely, unanimous in their desire for more commodious quarters.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 29.--The testimony in the case of Millard F. Hildebrand, charged with the murder of Henry Eshleman, closed this morning. Speeches for the prosecution were made by B.F. Eshleman and S.H. Reynolds, and for the defense by M. Bossius and Hugh M. North. The arguments were concluded late in the day, when the case was given to the jury.

GALVESTON, Texas, Jan. 30.--In a lonely spot, on the East Bay shore, 25 miles from Galveston, Sunday evening, a hunter named Lewis Mecomb, while eating supper in a lonely cabin owned by Mrs. Barrows, with whom he boarded, was shot and instantly killed by an unknown person. Mrs. Barrows recently separated from her husband who is still living in the vicinity.

The second annual exhibition of the New-York Fanciers' Club, which has been in progress in Madison-Square Garden since last Wednesday, closed last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30.--On the application of counsel for J.B. Garrison, the so-called "living skeleton," Judge Thayer to-day granted a writ of habeas corpus, commanding Uriah Clear, the father of Mrs. Bertha Garrison, to produce his son-in-law's bride in court, the allegations being that she is desirous of returning to her husband and that she is being restrained of her liberty.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 30.--Adolph Berndes, a Swedish civil engineer, age 26, shot himself through the temple to-day while deranged by business troubles. He was unmarried. He came here from Stockholm.

Joseph R. Wood has returned to the residence of his grandfather, J.R. Roberts, of Norristown, whence he disappeared mysteriously a year ago. He was found by his uncle, Samuel Roberts, working for Thomas Adams, a farmer at Jefferson, N.J. The good news was telegraphed to his father at Huddersfield, England. He says he ran away because he feared punishment for being late at school.
The New-York State Association of Survivors of Andersonville and Other southern Military Prisons was organized about 10 years ago. The National Association granted it a charter last September.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 30.--A meeting of cremationists was held here to-night, and it was decided to organize a society instead of a stock company, so that all favoring cremation might become members.

It has been said by the more advanced of the anti-Mormons living in Utah that the only and sufficient remedy for the evils of Mormonism is the abolition of the present form of Territorial Government and the substitution therefor of a civil commission or a military Governor.
Fire, caused apparently by a defective flue, broke out early yesterday morning on the first floor stairs of the four-story brick building at No.662 Sixth-avenue, which is owned by Mrs. E. Michel.

W.H. Schieffelin Co., wholesale druggists, of No.170 William-street, took into their employ as salesman, on Dec. 1, 1883, Thomas A. Phelan, 45 years old, of No. 221 First-street, Hoboken, where his family keep a grocery store. His conduct recently has not been satisfactory to his employers, and inquiries were made about his antecedents.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30.--The Times has a special dispatch from Harrisburg, embodying a long interview with Col. Matthew S. Quay, on State and national politics. Col. Quay explains at length his interpretation of the national Republican rule relative to the election or delegates to the National Convention, about which there has been considerable controversy.
President Arthur began his series of state dinners at the White House by an entertainment this evening in honor of the members of his Cabinet.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 30--The Imperial Council will soon consider the question of forming a Russo-American company for the purpose of erecting elevators.

John Avery, of the Public Works Department of this city, but who lived at Yonkers, started from his residence at a little before 9 o'clock yesterday morning to walk down the tracks of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad to Ludlow station to take a train to the city.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 30.--The jury in the case of Millard Fillmore Hildrand, of Strasberg, charged with the murder of Henry Eshlemen, retired at 11 last night and came into court at 3 o'clock this afternoon with a verdict of "voluntary manslaughter." Suspension of sentence was asked for and the prisoner was remanded.
HARRISBURGH, Penn., Jan. 30.--The death warrants of Jesse Carter and George Jones, of Allegheny County, were signed by the Governor to-day. The hanging will take place on Thursday, April, 3.

Mr. FRELINGHUYSEN'S statement concerning the exclusion of American pork from the markets of Continental Europe is admirable in tone and temper and very nearly conclusive as an exposition of the facts in the case.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 30.--Fred Stinger, a tramp, was arrested at Chrismaro, Ill, on suspicion of being the murderer of Rose Mahan at Mount Carmel some days ago.

Engineer Adams, of the Department of Public Works, yesterday submitted to the Aqueduct Commissioners the plan of the department for the construction of the proposed Quaker Bridge Dam.
TITUSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 30.--A few days ago a stranger arrived in this city and represented himself to be J.B. Studebaker, of the firm of Studebaker Brothers, of South Bend, Ind.
TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 30.--Henry Smyth has been elected to the House of Commons for Kent County, Ontario, and W. Temple for York County, New-Brunswick, as supporters of the Government.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Jan. 30.--To-day, on the afternoon of the ninth day of the trial of Edward Newton Rowell for killing Johnson L. Lynch, the last particle of testimony was taken and the defense commenced to present their side of the case to the intelligent jury, from whom they hope to secure a speedy acquittal.
News has been received at the office of the Turf, Field and Farm, in this city, of the death of the famous brood-mare Midnight. She was the dam of the Western trotting wonder ...

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 30.--Dr. Emerson Warner was to-day elected Representative in the Twenty-fourth (Worcester) District, vice Batchelder, resigned.

There was an interesting debate in the Senate to-day over the report of the conference committee on the resolution providing for an expedition to relieve Lieut. A.W. Greely and his party, now in the arctic region.

BOSTON, Jan. 30.--In the United States District Court this afternoon the jury found Depter S. Hall, a well-known Boston broker, guilty on five counts on charges of detaining pension certificates as collateral security for loans. Sentence was postponed.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 30.--The north bound passenger train on the Erie Road due at Rochester at 6:10 P.M. yesterday was wrecked one mile and a half east of South Livonia at 4:28 o'clock in the afternoon.
Mgr. Capel lectured in Chickering Hall last evening before a fairly large audience on "Early Christians in the Catacombs" for the benefit of the Home for the Aged of the Little Sisters of the Poor.

ROCHESTER, Penn., Jan. 30.--Shortly before 12 o'clock last night flames were discovered issuing from the boiler-house of the Phoenix Glass-works, in Phillipsburg, opposite here, on the Ohio River.

The rooms of the New-York Press Club were open all night Tuesday, and scores of the friends of the late Dr. John B. Wood visited them to look upon the body of the dead journalist.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 30.--The conference committee, composed of members of the Window-glass-workers' Association and Western Manufacturers' Association, appointed several months ago to settle their existing differences, after numerous futile meetings finally arrived at an agreement this evening, and work will be resumed in all the factories immediately.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 30.--The streets of Rochester were to-day crowded with people and the places of business were gay with bunting. The occasion of the influx of visitors and the holiday display was the annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic. Not far from noon a grand parade of veterans took place, nearly 3,000 men being in line.

LONDON, Jan. 30.--At a meeting of the Society of Arts last evening, over which the Marquis of Lorne presided, a paper was read discussing the question of emigration to Canada. It was asserted that only emigrants of good character were sent to the Dominion.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 30.--The Cincinnati Price Current has made a special examination of the wheat stocks in the country, and will publish the result to-morrow.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Jan. 30.--Another of the over-due fishing vessels, the schooner Waldo Irving, has been given up as lost. Her crew consisted of 14 men, as follows: Andrew Swinson, ...
Mrs. Lydia C. Cocks was under examination and cross-examination throughout the session of Part I. of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Jan. 30.--The American fishing fleet at Fortune Bay are reaping a splendid harvest. A dispatch from Long Harbor gives a list of 20 vessels of the fleet that report from 600 to 800 barrels each of frozen herring.

FONDA, N.Y., Jan. 30.--Benjamin Filkins, a Duanesburg farmer, was killed at Port Jackson yesterday by the West Shore cars. He was leaning on a car when the train backed up and he fell under the wheels.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 30.--For several weeks the Grand Jury have been investigating the circumstances attending the killing of Michael J. Fortier and others at the Seventh Ward poll at the time of the Democratic primaries in December last.
A dispatch from Chicago says that the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company has acquired control of the Board of Trade lines, ...

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 30.--In the Senate to-day Mr. Smith introduced a bill to extend pecuniary aid to Mrs. Comila, whose husband was killed last Summer by falling down a ventilating shaft in the new Capitol.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 30.--Those gentlemen who brand themselves in public as "friends of the working man" and in private laugh at what they term their own political shrewdness in advocating his so-called interests fully vented their views in the Assembly Chamber to-day.

LONDON, Jan. 30.--Reports of the havoe caused by the recent gale in the North continue to multiply. Within a radius of 10 miles of Ayr 200,000 trees were blown down, 100,000 of them being on the estate of the Marquis of Ailsa.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30.--The municipal elections throughout Pennsylvania will fall on the 17th proximo, and the contest in this city is already warm. Three officers are to be chosen on the general ticket--Mayor, Receiver of Taxes, and Solicitor--with members of Council, and the School Boards in the different wards.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 30.--It is stated to-night that the Canadian Pacific is seeking a loan from the Government of $22,500,000, on the security of its land bonds.
Official etiquette and the question of precedence are subjects which are this season agitating social circles in the capital to an unusual extent.

HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 30.--John Smith, the tramp, who shot Conductor Failes, of the Hudson River Railroad, several weeks ago, was this afternoon sentenced by Judge Osborn to 10 years' hard labor in Clinton Prison.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 30.--The Democratic City Convention, which met last night, continued in session until noon to-day. The contest was long and exciting. There were four aspirants for the Mayoralty, and on the nineteenth ballot the Hon. Robert Liddell was nominated. He held the office of Mayor three years ago. The convention was turbulent in character but no serious conflicts occurred.
Mme. Magda Irschick, an actress of considerable repute in Germany, is at present fulfilling an engagement at the Thalia Theatre.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30.--A true bill has been found by the Grand Jury against the members of the old firm of Work Co., stock brokers, charging them with conspiracy and embezzlement, growing out of the troubles of the People's Passenger Railway. The partners who composed the firm were arrested some months ago and released on bail pending the action of the Grand Jury. There are 16 counts in the indictment.

DALLAS, Texas, Jan. 30.--Passengers arriving here from the east this evening say the strike on the Texas and St. Louis Railway has extended into Arkansas and Texas, and that it promises to become serious.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30.--Two freight trains on the Pennsylvania Railroad, going in opposite directions, ran into each other at Plainsboro this morning, and the cars were badly damaged. The road for a time was blocked. A fireman, engineer, and conductor were seriously injured.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 30.--An astonishing number of Republicans of prominence in various parts of the State unexpectedly appeared in Albany to-day, and, as if by common consent, presented, themselves for inspection to those who frequent the Capitol nowadays.

PARIS, Jan. 30.--A report was current in the lobbies of the Chamber to-day that the French forces under Admiral Courbet had recently stormed Bac-Ninh and been repulsed. The report irritated the members of the Chamber, because the Government maintained silence in regard to it. Prime Minister Ferry will be questioned as to the facts to-morrow.

DALLAS, Jan. 30.--A strange and fatal disease is reported to have broken out among the cattle in the western part of this county. Large numbers have died. The disease fails to yield to treatment. A mass-meeting of cattlemen was held at Grand Prairie to-day looking toward a movement to check tho ravages of the disease.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 30.--A 12-year-old son of David Willis, of Northwood, left home last Thursday to go to school, since which time nothing has been heard of him. He purchased a pistol a few days ago and it is feared that he has either shot himself accidentally or by design, and that the snow of Thursday's storm has covered the body.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan 30.--In the Senate to-day Senator Stanton offered a resolution of thanks to Lieut. Rhodes, of the United States Revenue Marine Service, for his gallant conduct at the wreck of the City of Columbus. Lieut, Rhodes is a native of Connecticut. The resolution passed unanimously.

Seldom has a fog so impenetrable as that of yesterday morning settled upon the city. It caused the greatest possible inconvenience to those persons who live outside of the city and come here daily to transact business.

Mr. McClure talked to Judge Rumsey for six hours about the De Meli divorce suit, yesterday, but even then, when the gathering darkness compelled an adjournment, he had not reached the charge of adultery against the plaintiff.

It is understood that the members of the State Committee who have already made up their minds who should be the candidate of the Republican Party for President, and who in the main agree on this point and on most others with the Chairman of the committee, desire a meeting of the State Convention at the latest possible moment.

The trial of John D. Harrington, at Jersey City, for the alleged frauds on the American Legion of Honor, was continued yesterday, and it drew a large crowd to the court-room despite the inclement weather.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 30.--After a heavy run the Merchants and Mechanics' Bank of Leadville suspended this afternoon. The property was immediately attached for $37,000. More attachments will follow. No estimate of the liabilities or of what the bank will probably pay is at present obtainable. This leaves but one bank in Leadville, the Carbondale.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 30.--At Akron, Ohio, to-day Fred Hamilton, a lad of 15, was fatally shot while handling a rusty and, as he supposed, unloaded revolver. The ball struck him just above the heart.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 30.--Marshal Barring to-day arrested at his home in Montrose Dr. E.L. Gardner, upon the charge of violating the pension laws in having taken from G.W. Dennis, of Binghamton, $500 for his service in the collection of a pension fee for Dennis, this amount being largely in excess of what the law allows. The hearing will be before Commissioner Little at Montrose, Feb. 9, when the United States District Attorney will attend.
Patrick H. McKeon, the engineer of St. Patrick's Cathedral, was killed yesterday by falling from a ladder on which he had been inspecting a flue.
VALPARAISO, Jan. 30, via Galveston.--A wine bodega near the Grand Theatre in Santiago is on fire, and the theatre itself is in imminent danger.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 30.--The House today passed a bill providing a punishment for fence-cutting of from one to five years' imprisonment, in the penitentiary, but a person owning and residing upon land inclosed by another who ...

Moscow, Jan. 30.--Lieut. G.B. Harber and Master W.H. Schuetze, escorting the corpses of Lieut. De Long and comrades of the Jeannette expedition, started for Hamburg to-day on their way to America. A solemn procession followed the coffins to the railroad station, where the chief Lutheran Pastor of the city delivered an address. Many wreaths were deposited on the coffins, including one from the students of the Moscow University.

Street-cleaning Commissioner Coleman will, on and after to-day, send to householders in this city violating the ordinances providing for the removal of snow and ice from the sidewalks a circular calling their attention to the laws. The corporation ordinances are sections 317 and 329 of Article XXXV, and impose a fine of 3 on every persons who shall neglect to clear the ...
Several strong links were added yesterday to the chain of evidence which the Long Island police authorities are forging around the negro Charles H. Rugg.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 30.--An incoming passenger train on the Michigan Central Railway, last-night, near West Toledo, struck a buggy containing J.G. Lewis and Miss Nora McIntyre. The latter was killed. The former was severely injured, but will probably recover.
Another of the rickety mail vans used by Contractor George K. Otis in transferring the mails about the city broke down yesterday morning in the triangular space to the south of the Cooper Union.

ALBANY, Jan. 30.--Senator Arkell, whose Senatorial district comprises five counties and covers nearly one-fourth of the mileage of the Erie and Champlain Canals, has initiated a plan for the correction of a long-standing abuse, and which at the same time will furnish the tax-payers ...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 30.--Charles and George Preston, brothers, the first a watch and clock dealer, in Pawtucket, and the second railway station agent at Longsdale, have disappeared, leaving their families. The station agent resigned his position.
On our arrival at Queenstown I found some extraordinary statements had been made by passengers who had been landed from the Argosy.

TRIPOLI, Jan. 30.--Sheikh Senoussi and his tribe, who who were recently reported to be advancing to join El Mahdi, have not only not joined El Mahdi but have decreed that he is a false prophet and an adventurer, and that Mussulmans must on no account follow him.
A real novelty has this Winter been introduced into book-binding by Mr. Elliot Stock in connection with his fac simile first edition of "The Religio Medici."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 30.--On Saturday afternoon a number of First Class men, in an unusually merry mood, went into Fourth Class man Cadet Frank Meade Russell's room and required him to stand on his head.

ERIE Penn., Jan. 30.--A stockholder in the Edinburg Savings Bank to-day entered a judgment of $20,000 against the bank President, E.W. Twitchell, a large borrower, whose financial affairs have become complicated. The action of the stockholders caused a run on the bank until its solvency was demonstrated.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30.--James E. Cavenaugh, Captain of a ward at the Alms-house, was convicted in Judge Thayer's court yesterday of murder in the second degree.

CLEVELAND, Ohio., Jan. 30.--A schoolhouse was recently built in Arcadia, a small town in Seneca County. Among the teachers employed in the school is a young woman named Askcome, of good repute, but whose father has ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 30.--Five thousand people heard Italian opera sung in this city to-night. At 3 o'clock a lady posted herself at the gallery door of McVicker's Theatre, and from that nucleus the crowd swelled, until at dark there was, a howling mob demanding seats.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 30.--For some time society people of Houston County have been waiting with interest for the marriage of Mr. W. E. Till and Miss Nina Peddy.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 30.--The Pope Iron and Metal Company have made an assignment. Their assets are stated to be worth $2,000 above incumbrances. Richard C. Pope, the President of the company, filed two mortgages last evening to John D. Perry, a banker, one of them on the company's assets for $13,000 and the other on his residence for $8,000 to secure his claims.

LEWISTON, Me., Jan. 30.--The case of the State against the Grand Trunk Railroad, indicted for causing the death of J.W. Perkins at Mechanics' Falls in 1882, was concluded this morning. The company was found guilty and fined $1,000.

Gen. Winslow and Gen. Porter said yesterday that the West Shore Railroad Company had borrowed all the money it required for its immediate wants. They declined to state the amount or terms of the loan, and refused to give the names of the lenders.

ST. LOUIS, MO., Jan. 30.--Anton Linsenmeirk was arrested here last night charged with forging Post Office orders amounting to several thousand marks while he was Postmaster at Krotzingen. Grand Duchy of Baden, several months ago. When arrested he was acting as bar-tender in a saloon.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 30.--Frank W. Hawley, of this city, was to-day appointed by the Supreme Court Sequestrator and Receiver of the property rights and franchises of the "Pfaudler Process Fermentation Company," a ...
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 30.--The ice in the river opposite here commenced moving to-day and the break, being unexpected, did considerable damage.
The disappearance of Leon Haas, of No. 108 West Forty-fifth-street, who is Secretary of the New-York Optical Company at No. 43 Maiden-lane, was reported to the police early last ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--Leave of absence for 2 months and 17 days, to take effect when his services can be spared by his post commander after Feb. 1, 1884, with permission to go beyond the sea, has been granted Capt. Ernest H. Ruffner, Corps of Engineers.
PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 30.--One of the Oriental Powder Company's mills at Windham was blown up this morning, and an employe named McKinney was killed.
Having finished a two months' tour of California and the South-west, Gen. Winfield Scott Hancock returned to duty on Governor's Island yesterday afternoon.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 30.--The Fountain George case was passed upon to-day by the Supreme Court affirming the decision of the lower court, thus decreeing that the murderer of Dr. Epphs must pay the penalty of his crime with his life. The murderer was sentenced to be hanged on the 8th of August last, but the execution was put off by the appeal to the Supreme Court.

TRENTON, Jan. 30.--The question of railroad taxation engaged a large share of the Senate's attention to-day. There are already several bills in the Legislature extending the time within which railroads yet constructing may be completed.
Mrs. Marshall O. Roberts gave a ball last evening at her residence, No.107 Fifth-avenue, which way attended by the highest rank of society people in the city.
CLEVELAND, Ohio Jan. 30.--The sudden thaw, accompanied by warm rains, has caused a good deal of uneasiness here for fear that the disastrous floods of a year ago would be repeated.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 30.--A circular signed by President Porter, of Yale College, has been issued, giving the report of a special committee appointed to inquire into the sanitary condition of the college buildings.

Henry M. Rideout, of the firm of E.G., Rideout Co., publishers of the Household Magazine, sat comfortable in his private office, on the third floor of No.10 Barclay-street, about noon yesterday, talking business with a brisk little man with mutton-chop whiskers.

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 30.--A Bowdoin Medical Alumni Association was organized at Waterville to-day with the following officers: President--F.C. Thayer, Class of '67; Secretary-- C.D. Smith, Class of '79; Treasurer--F.H. Gerrish, Class of '69.

A bill was passed to a third reading in the Assembly yesterday, after a lively debate in Committee of the Whole, providing that street railroad companies shall not exact from their employes more than twelve hours' work per day, but may obtain extra work from them for extra pay.

Prague has been deeply moved by the bankruptcy of Prince Henry Hanau. His family jewels were offered at public sale a few weeks ago, and his brother, to save the collection from dispersal, became their chief purchaser.

The curtain was down at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre yesterday when THE TIMES'S writer passed through the auditorium on his way to Mr. John Stetson's once, and sounds of Sullivanian melody drifted through the air.

George T. Batterson, of Hartford, Conn., his the paymaster of the Westerly (R.I.) Granite Company. He makes a monthly visit to the company's works to pay off the employes, and always takes with him a considerable amount in greenbacks.

LONDON, Jan. 31.--The Right Hon. John Bright addressed a large meeting at the Forward Liberal Club in Birmingham last night. He said that, after the franchise measure, the most important question for the reformed Parliament would be the reform of the land laws.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 30.--The suspense in which the cotton operatives have been kept for the past week has been finally broken, and the figures of the reduction have been made public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 260--Edward A. Smith, plaintiff in error, vs. Curtis Pierce.--In error to the Supreme Court of Vermont. Dismissed per stipulation. No. 236--John G. Killian et al., Trustees, , appellants, vs. John W. Ebbinghaus, Trustee, Argued, No. 1,138--Augustine R. McDonald, appellant, vs., Charles E. Hovey et al. Argument begun.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 30.--Advices from Australia are to the effect that the crops are in splendid condition. It is estimated that South Australia will have 18,000,000 bushels of wheat for export, and Victoria 7,000,000 bushels.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 30.--Capt. Felder, of the steamer Prinz Georg, on trial for several days in the United States Circuit Court, for failing to provide sufficient food for his emigrant passengers from Palermo, was acquitted to-day by the jury. The evidence went to show the shortage was from stress of weather and an unusually long voyage, and that he had been generous to the emigrants at his own expense.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 30.--R.H. Park was to-day commissioned by a public spirited citizen whose name is not made public to make a heroic statue of Washington, to be of bronze, 11 feet high, and to stand on a pedestal the same height, which will be presented to the city and placed in a west side park. It will cost $12,000.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 30.--The liquordealers of this city have become exasperated at the efforts to restrict their trade.

"Billy" McGlory's face wore a troubled look yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions, during his trial for selling liquor without a license on Nov. 10, at his place, Nos. 156, 158, and 160 Hester-street.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 30.--Eagle Hill Colliery, situated three miles from this city, was the scene of a distressing accident at noon today, which resulted in the instantaneous death of one man and the fatal injury of three or four ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 30.--The annual report of the Minister of Public Works submitted to Parliament contains statistics showing that so far as Government management of telegraphs is concerned a very unfortunate result has been reached in Canada.

BOSTON, Jan. 30.--Augustus Stetson, of No. 201 East Fifty-second-street, New-York, attempted to commit suicide on the steamer Bristol, of the Fall River Line, during her trip from New-York on Monday night, and he is now at the Massachusetts General Hospital, suffering from a bullet in his back.

FORT GAINES, Ga., Jan. 30.--A difficulty occurred yesterday in Henry County, Ala., between John Boatright and the Rev. J.W. Malone, Baptist minister, in which the latter was fatally cut with a knife. An old feud existed between the parties. Both are men past middle life, of steady habits, and high respectability.

The Hon. William D. Kelley, since the introduction of his Silver bill, has been referred to very frequently in foreign publications which discuss the question of bi-metallism, and has been in correspondence with some of its well-known advocates.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30.--The hearing in the Dinsmore case was resumed this morning in the United States Circuit Court. All the counsel were present, including Messrs. Gowen, Conkling, Robeson, and ex-Chancellor Williamson.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 30.--In the case of the youth James Clinton, on trial for the shooting of John McGuire, in July last, the jury, after being out all night, came into court this morning, announced they were unable to agree, and were discharged. Clinton gave bail for his appearance when called.

There was a hush of expectation in the United States District Court yesterday morning as Mr. Bangs stepped in front of the jury to address them for the plaintiff in the FeuardentDi Cesnola libel suit.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 30.--It is expected by the Southern New-England Telephone Company that the new copper wire now being extended between New-York and Boston will be ready for use in about two weeks.
Many of the Senators found on their desks to-day numerously signed petitions praying for such legislation as will prohibit the manufacture and sale of intoxicating liquor in the District of Columbia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 1138--Augustine R. McDonald, appellant, vs. Charles E. Hovey et al. Argument concluded.
PITTSBURG, Jan. 31.--An accident occurred this afternoon at the Linden Steel-works which resulted in the death of two men and the fatal injury of another.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31.--The police received information yesterday that two barrels, supposed to contain human bodies, were at the OgdenAvenue Stables, corner of Madison-street and Ogden-avenue. For two hours the detectives watched the building, thinking perhaps the suspicious casks might be called for.

The House adopted on Wednesday a resolution introduced by Mr. Beach, and reported by the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads, calling upon the Postmaster-General to transmit to the House all reports made by special agents of the Post Office Department during the year 1881, having reference to the Star Route investigations, and which have not heretofore been published and made public.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 31.--An interview between Gov. Hoadly and an Enquirer correspondent closes as follows:
The foreclosure sale of the wrecking vessel Georgiana Belle, owned by George W. Thomas, the contractor looking for the alleged Hussar treasure, was yesterday postponed indefinitely.
