PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Feb. 7.--The unknown vessel which was in collision with and sank the schooner S.C. Noyes, of Provincetown, off Block Island last Friday night, is said to be the schooner Hattie M. Crowell, of Greenport, Long Island.

MONTREAL, Feb. 7.--Clear, beautiful, and but moderately cold weather, with the bluest of skies and brightest of suns, this has been the best day of the carnival as far as the weather is concerned. The continuation of the curling bonspiel led off the programme of to-day's sports. As the weaker clubs drop out the play becomes keener and more exciting. A meeting of the representatives of the various Canadian and American clubs was held to-day.

LONDON, Feb. 7.--The Norwegian bark AEolus, Capt. Paulsen, from Brunswick, Ga., Dec. 14, for Hamburg, is stranded at Nordbye, Faroe Islands. She is full of water, but is riding with both anchors out. She has lost her foremast and mainmast. Two of the crew were rescued. They state that they were standing on the deck-house lashed to the mizzenmast without sustenance for a week. Their feet were frost-bitten.
SCRANTON, Penn., Feb. 7.--Mrs. James Stevenson, accompanied by her family physician, Dr. A. Strong, called to-day at the office of W.H. Heist, dentist, to have some teeth extracted.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 7.--A banquet was given here to-night at the Phoenix Hotel in honor of the newly elected Senator, J.C.S. Blackburn. Members of the Legislature and a number of invited guests from Louisville and other places were in attendance.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 7.--Mr. Phinney, conductor of an east-bound freight train, reported that he found a man hanging to a whistling-post one and a half miles east of Bassett, Neb., this morning. The man is supposed to be "Kid" Wade, a notorious horse-thief, who was taken from vigilantes last night by a Sheriff, who was to have taken a train this morning for O'Neil. Wade was again taken from the Sheriff and lynched.

Wheeling has thus far borne the brunt of the floods in the Upper Ohio. Smaller towns in the vicinity have suffered in due proportion, but Wheeling, which has a population of over 40,000, presents the sad spectacle of a city half submerged, and a community of which a very large fraction is homeless, and many of whose inhabitants are left destitute.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 8.--Judgment was entered and executions aggregating $84,000 were issued this afternoon against A.C. H. Kloman, lessees under the Receiver of the Manchester Iron and Steel Mills Company.

A trial of a fire-extinguishing handgrenade was made yesterday afternoon at the foot of Battery-place. A portion of a very large dry goods box was smeared with tar and kerosene, and was then set on fire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8.--The two ablest men on the Republican side of the House of Representatives are Tom Reed, of Maine, and Frank Hiscock, of New-York. They both entered public life at an early age, and they are still young men. Reed is in his forty-fifth year and Hiscock is not yet 50 years old. They are both lawyers of more than ordinary ability and great promise.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8.--The Senate spent an hour to-day in a wrangle over the proposed Greely relief expedition and succeeded in getting into an amusing parliamentary tangle. The House of Representatives sent over the joint resolution providing for the expedition, with a message to the effect that it had agreed to the report of the conference committee.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 8.--The condition of the factories in New-England attracts attention to Southern mills. One of the largest mills in the South, and perhaps in the country, is the Eagle and Phoenix, of Columbus.

The young ladies of Girton College, England, after vainly entreating Chief SHAW to form them into a fire company, have voted that he is a mean old thing, and have organized a fire company closely modeled upon those to which men belong.
MARIETTA, Ga., Feb. 8.--Burrill Brown shot and killed his brother-in-law, a boy of 15 years, near Santa Luca, to-day. The shooting was done with a pistol.

MONTREAL, Feb. 8.--The entirely unlooked-for postponement under very peculiar circumstances of a marriage in fashionable circles has caused a sensation in the highest circles of Montreal society. The contracting parties were Mr. Walter Wilson; a well-known young gentleman, and Miss Dora Lucy MacDougall, eldest daughter of Mr. D. Lorn MacDougall, a wellknown banker and broker.

Morris S. Wise, counsel for the New-York Cigar Manufacturers' Association, has issued a circular commenting on the recent decision of the Court of Appeals that the tenement-house cigar law is unconstitutional. Mr. Wise declares that the true motives which urged the enactment of that law were not desires to protect the public health, but were a part of the general onslaught of the trades-unions upon the manufacturers.

The Fire Association of Philadelphia, the license of which to do business in this State was suspended a few days ago, was relicensed yesterday by Insurance Superintendent McCall. The difficulty between the association and the Superintendent involves a question in the decision of which the Pennsylvania and the New-York fire insurance companies are specially interested.
DUBLIN, Feb. 8.--Three thousand ship-builders at Belfast have struck.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8.--The condition of the Library of Congress ought to excite the interest of every literary man and woman in the United States. For more than 10 years it has been so cramped for room that its utility has been reduced to the minimum.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 8.--The Court of Appeals took a recess of two weeks to-day after a month of hard work. The Judges are making great efforts to keep up with the increasing amount of litigation. In the past four weeks they have heard arguments on 76 cases. At this rate they would need 10 months of regular sittings to clear the present calendar. Judge Danforth has gone to Washington with his family.

CAIRO, Feb. 8.--Advises received here state that Gen. Gordon was heard of a number of miles on the Korosko route beyond the place where it was reported he had been captured. Gordon will succeed in reaching Khartoum.

Dickinson against the church Trustees, and the difficulties arising therefrom. The situation of affairs, as it was understood to exist, was described in THE TIMES of Jan. 21.

The Police Commissioners yesterday terminated the struggle for the vacant Captaincy, which had been in progress since the death of Capt. Kealy. Instead of simply filling the vacancy they made two new Captains, one Democrat and one Republican. When the board met all the Commissioners were present.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 8.--During the early morning James Graham, a well-known lawyer, shot and killed his wife as she was sleeping in bed. He then cut his throat with a razor.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 8.--The disappearance of Henry S. Church, the defaulting City Chamberlain, is still the engrossing topic here. Developments to-day indicate that the sureties on the bond given by Mr. Church when first appointed, and to which allusion was made yesterday, are liable for $5,000 each.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 8.--The revised edition of the Cornell University Register appeared to-day. The list of students contains 47l names, an increase of 64 over last year. The Freshman Class numbers 171, a gain of nearly 50.

MONTREAL, Feb. 8.--It has been snowing steadily all day in great white flakes, very pretty to look at, but rather disagreeable to face. However, it did not materially affect the toboggan slides, which continued to be visited by endless numbers of delighted sliders, whose enthusiasm was wonderful to behold.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 8.--A Deputy Sheriff of Cass County named Benington invited W.H. Sanders, editor of the People's Advocate, into his office, and after shutting the door began to abuse and then struck him. Sanders then in self-defense struck back and gave the Sheriff a trouncing. The court was in session at the time, and the Judge ordered Sanders to jail.

"The bob veal season hasn't fairly opened yet," said Mr. W.T. Romaine, one of the two meat inspectors of the city yesterday, "yet we are seizing quantities of it nearly every day. We visit a shop and if we see bob veal hanging there we say that's too young. The butcher replies: 'All right. If you say it's bob take it along. You're the judge.'

The appropriation for the Naval Academy is the same as that of last-year.

OTTAWA, Feb. 8.--The revenue and expenditure returns for seven months ending Jan. 31 show that the surplus held by the Dominion Government was only $820,000, against $4,750,000 during the corresponding months of 1882-3.

The public rehearsal preliminary to the fourth concert given by the Symphony Society of New-York, this season, was held at the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon. BUFFALO, Feb. 8.--Baptist Serano, an Italian, was dangerously cut in the neck and hip during a row in an Italian saloon last evening. A great crowd was present and a general melee occurred, but Serano, who was playing an accordion, was the only one seriously hurt. He is now at the hospital in a critical condition. Three Italians with long knives in their possession have been arrested.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 8.--John Hennington, a farmer, living six miles west of Frankfort, in a sparsely settled district, went to town on Tuesday last with a load of hogs, returning home that night. He was not seen again until to-day, when his lifeless body, with that of his wife, was found in the barn on the premises. The hired man in Hennington's employ is missing, together with a horse and saddle.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 9.--At a meeting of the State Board of Health, Lunacy, and Charity, to-day, the Hon. Thomas Talbot resigned the Chairmanship and withdrew from the board, and Charles F. Donnelly, of Boston, was chosen his successor.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 9.--The revival of the earthenware business in Georgia is one of the curious results of the local option movement. The high licenses at first adopted limited the sale of liquor to country towns, and the adoption of local options by several contiguous counties forced a good liquor trade upon the nearest market town where it was sold.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9.--There is an interesting fight in progress between the President and the Attorney-General. It has been going on for some time, but both parties to the contest have sedulously endeavored to keep all knowledge of it from the public.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--On Tuesday night the Democrats of the House will meet in caucus. So far as can be ascertained the caucus will do nothing but organize its caucus committee. But it is considered probable by many Democrats that this gathering may be taken advantage of to discuss the order of business, and so lead to a free interchange of views upon the Morrison tariff proposition.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 10.--N.S. Appelby, a prominent member of the Methodist Church and ex-member of the Ontario Legislature, has been attested and lodged in jail, at Belleville, charged with having forged the name of the County Registrar to a registration certificate of a deed.

The former associates and companions of the late Mme. Josefine Gallmeyer united yesterday at the Thalia Theatre in a novel and impressive tribute to her memory. The interior of the theatre was heavily draped in black, and the auditorium was hung with festoons of crape and black cloth, and a draped portrait of the dead actress was suspended from the right-hand stage box, in which were seated Mme. Geistinger, ...

ALBANY, Feb. 10.--The friends of President Arthur are now beginning to count noses. Then claim that he will have a majority of the 68 district delegates, together with the four delegates at large to be elected at the State Convention, or altogether close upon two-thirds of the New-York delegation.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Feb. 10.--A collision on the Pittsburg Southern Division of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad occurred this morning at Zediker's crossing, the engine of two construction trains coming together. One of the engines, two cars, and a caboose were badly wrecked. The workmen who were on the cars damaged jumped just in time to save their lives.

Gangs of men with shovels, hoes, and coarse brooms took advantage yesterday of the lull in every-day traffic and worked on a few of the down-town streets from 7 A.M. until dark. Broadway, from Union-square to the Produce Exchange, was as clean as a tidy housewife's doorstep.

TROY, Feb. 10.--Alfred W. McKinney, son of William McKinney, of this city, died at Crescent City, Fla., of heart disease, on Feb. 6. The body was placed in a coffin, the doctor's certificate attached, and the outside box addressed to D.W.B. Smart, of this city.

Joseph H. Townsend, one of the oldest and best known builders of Brooklyn, has been absent, from his home about a month, and the creditors whom he has left behind him are somewhat anxious. Mr. Townsend had been engaged in building in Brooklyn for 25 years, and had always been fortunate in his business.

NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 10.--This afternoon F.V. Conant, Alfred McClellan, and a friend named Button took a drive through the city. On returning to Conant's home, on Elizabethstreet, Button drove the horse away to the stables, while Conant asked McClellan to go to a shed near by to see a pony.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 10.--The Saloonkeepers' and Liquor-dealers' Association of this city at a meeting last week agreed to consult its attorney, Senator Robert C. Titus, with reference to the advisability of opposing the proposed high license legislation now being considered by the Legislature.

No subject is discussed with more animation or intense feeling among society people here than that of who shall go in first with the President to dinner, or who shall stand nearest to the lady of the White House during receptions.

There was trouble yesterday morning in the Baptist Tabernacle, at Clinton-street and Third-place, Brooklyn, of which the Rev. Dr. F. R. Morse is Pastor. That gentleman at the usual time was not in his place in the pulpit, and another unusual thing was that the organ had the loft all to itself, the organist and the quartet having failed to put in an appearance.

Forty survivors of the Thirty-sixth NewYork Volunteers met yesterday afternoon, at No. 161 Avenue B. and organized a veteran association. Capt. James Houstin was elected President, Ephraim A. Arnold Secretary, Thomas Nortan Treasurer, and Daniel McKnight Sergeant-at-Arms.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10.--About 50 dealers at the Chicago stock-yards, who last year handled $200,000,000 worth of cattle, have forwarded to Washington a protest against the bill before Congress to establish a bureau of animal industry. They deny the existence of pleuro-pneumonia west of the Alleghany Mountains, and express the belief that the passage of the measure could have only the effect of making places for an army of office-holders.

BOSTON, Feb. 10.--Fred E. Abbott is a pension agent at Worcester. He has been arrested on a chance of receiving illegal fees for obtaining pensions. The legal fee for obtaining a pension is $10, and at the May term, 1883, Abbott was convicted of charging one Patrick Bannon $100 and was fined $50.

Though he has reached his sixty-sixth year, the Prince de Joinville is more eager for sport than many of his juniors, and especially affects that which alone in France offers an element of danger--namely, boar-hunting.
The Casino concert last evening was attended, as usual, by a large and appreciative audience. The programme was interesting, though perhaps not quite as strong as those of the two concerts previous.

The question of how many hours shall constitute a day's work promises to become one of the most important issues in the labor movements this year. Reports from trades unions in various parts of the country favoring the shortening of the hours of labor are being received every week.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 10.--Owing to a reduction of 5 cents on each case of boots, about 40 men in Gokey Son's boot and shoe factory are on a strike. The firm says it can save 20 cents a case by employing machines, but prefers to give the men work. The difficulty will probably soon be adjusted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--James G. It may be taken as a favorable or unfavorable sign, according to the view of the observer. It proposes to appear henceforth, not once a week, but once every two weeks.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 10.--Both parties in Delaware County showed wonderful judgment in making their nominations. L.G. Hershey was selected by the Republicans, and A.N. Smith, a native of Hinsdale, N.Y., was nominated by the Democrats.

PIPER'S POND, Penn., Feb. 7.--Uncle Andrew Piper gave the back-log a savage poke, and a million bright sparks went dancing up the cabin's wide stone chimney. Presently the fresh hickory "chunks" blazed up, and the shadows found no resting place in any corner of the room.

CAIRO, Feb. 10.--The report of Gen. Gordon's arrival at Berber was premature. The report arose from the receipt of a telegram at Cairo from Berber signed by Gen. Gordon, which he had sent in advance by fast camels. It is expected that he will arrive at Berber on Tuesday. The Arabs whom Gen. Gordon met after leaving Korosko were friendly.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 10.--It has rained during the greater part of the afternoon along the whole length of the Ohio Valley, and the storm still contiues. Dispatches from several points say the rain is coming down in torrents. At 10 o'clock to-night the river was within 1 foot of last year's mark, and rising at the rate of nearly an inch an hour.

Prof. Felix Adler talked to a very large audience at Chickering Hall yesterday morning about Wendell Phillips. The great quality of Mr. Phillips, the speaker said, was his supreme disinterestedness. There never was a life so sample in its purpose as his.

The condition of Mr. Thomas Kinsella, the editor of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle, remained unchanged up to an early-hour this morning. He is still very low, and attending physicians say that he cannot live more than 12 or 15 hours at the most, and that he may die at any instant.

There was some very dull and inconsequential talk in the Senate to-day over the Beck resolution to inquire into the discharge of a colored messenger by the Sergeant-at-Arms. Mr. Riddleberger, who had offered an amendment making the resolution one of application both to the House and the Senate, was in his place ready to talk.

It has frequently happened that vessels have run into icebergs, but the Notting Hill is the first steamer ever run into by an iceberg. The Captain asserts that on a dark night an immense iceberg suddenly struck the Notting Hill on the port side, and, rebounding, struck her a second time.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 11.--The Governor has pardoned George C. Crager, convicted in the County of Oswego of bigamy and sentenced by the Court of Sessions on Sept. 20, 1882, to two years' imprisonment in Aluburn Prison.

Seventy-five men employed by a contractor named Goodenough in shoeing the horses of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company struck yesterday for an increase of wages. Non-union men were employed in the places of the strikers.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 11.--The Denver Tribune, one of the leading newspapers of the West, was sold to-day to a syndicate of New-York gentlemen for $100,000. O.H. Robbacker continues as editor-in-chief, and F.J.V. Skiff as manager.

BOSTON, Feb. 11.--At the annual meeting of the proprietors of the Boston Athenaeum today the following officers were elected: President--Samuel Eliot; Vice-President--Charles Devens; Treasurer--Charles B. Bowditch; Secretary--Charles H. Williams, and 15 Trustees. The Treasurer's report showed an income during the year of $35,778; expenses, $35,163; total value of property owned by the association, $1,029,674; number of volumes now in the library, 139,159, an increase during the year of 5,107.

The eighth annual Children's Carnival and Ball was given at the Academy of Music last evening. The proceeds, which were large, were, as usual, devoted to the fund for building the Western Dispensary. The spectacle last night was enjoyable to those who did not choose to take into account the worn faces of the children. The curtain rose at about 8:30 and displayed a brilliantly colored tableau.

SOCIAL CIRCLE, Ga., Feb. 11.--Saturday night was prolific of casualties to colored men in this county.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Feb. 11.--The second week of the strike among the cotton operatives here commenced with no perceptible change in the situation of affairs.
BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 11.--Gov. Robinson to-day discovered a discrepancy of over $17,000 in the accounts of Gen. George W. Cram, State Surveyor General of Lumber.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 11.--In the second ice yacht race for the Dr. Barrow Cup this morning the starters were AEolus, Icicle, Jack Frost, Jessie B., and Flash. Jack Frost won easily, and, having thus won the cup the second time, it becomes the property of her owner, Archibald Rogers.
LONDON, Feb. 11.--It is reported that 300 Christian catechists have been murdered somewhere in Tonquin.

George Thonneis, a German painter, 44 years old, hanged himself yesterday at No. 510 West Thirty-ninth-street. He was one of the first men drafted in this city for the war of the rebellion, and he served in a New-York regiment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11.--The leave of absence on Surgeon's certificate of disability granted Major Joseph S. Conrad, Seventeenth Infantry, has been extended two months on Surgeon's certificate of disability. The resignation by First Lieut. Douglas A. Howard, Ordnance Department, of his commission as Second Lieutenant, Third Artillery only, has been accepted by the President, to take effect from Jan. 16.
BIRMINGHAM, Conn., Feb. 11.--Thomas H. Minor, a horse doctor, of Shelton, was arrested in this place yesterday charged with cruelty to animals.
On Christmas Eve the chief streets of St. Petersburg were for the first time illumined by electricity, the brilliant light, according to Russian papers, turning night into day.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 11.--Another version of the existing border troubles is that Manual Rodriguez was slain at Eagle Pass, Texas, by one Thomas Lackey.

Under an act passed by the Legislature of Arkansas in 1872, the Memphis and Little Rock Railroad Company was reorganized. It retained the same name and succeeded to the property and franchises of the road, under the foreclosure of a mortgage of the original corporation and a conveyance under the decree of foreclosure.

Mr. THOMAS KINSELLA, the editor of the Brooklyn Eagle, and Mr. THOMAS CHENERY, the editor of the London Times, died yesterday. The coincidence almost forces upon the minds of readers of newspapers in New-York and Brooklyn the difference between the conditions of journalism in England and in America.

SANDWICH, Mass., Feb. 11.--A trunk mystery is now exciting the citizens of Cape Cod. All sorts of conflicting stories are afloat as to the trunk and what it contained. Many of the village people are confident that it held the spoils of some smuggler, who landed on the Sandwich shore one year ago from a sailing craft and buried his treasures, while others believe that it contained the remains of some unfortunate victim.

LONDON, N.Y., Feb. 11.--Brought together with Oswego County in one Congressional district for the first time in its history. Wayne County has no exact information as to the prejudices or purposes of the Oswego County politicians. It may be true that they believe by combining with Wayne they may procure two Arthur delegates from the Twenty-seventh District.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11.--Under three charges of obtaining money by false pretenses and forgery of mortgages Rex Magee, until June last a conveyancer at Fifth and Market streets, but since then a fugitive at Binghamton and a Wall-street operator in the Villard stocks, was committed to-day to Moyamensing Prison by Magistrate Smith in default of $7,000 bail.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 11.--A nice-looking fellow, giving his name as A.H. Bentley, and claiming to be a representative of the Fremont Manufacturing Company, of Lowell, Mass., played a confidence game on a number of persons here last week, securing on bogus drafts and checks some $200 from several parties here. He left town on Saturday, and has not been heard from.

A stream of anxious property-owners poured into the rooms of the Rapid Transit Commission all day yesterday to protest against the building of railway lines through certain streets and private properties and to inquire into the power and future action of the board. Most of them seemed to think that elevated lines would be built on the new routes at once, and that property-holders would have no chance to protest.
The announced sale at the Exchange yesterday, Monday, Feb. 11, by Louis Mesier of the brick dwelling with lot, No. 440 Pleasant-av., south-east corner of 123d-st., was adjourned until the 13th inst.
The inquest in the cases of Thomas Collier and his wife was continued yesterday. A number of witnesses were examined, but nothing of importance was elicited.

BOSTON, Feb. 11.--By the will of the late Stephen Williams, of Roxbury, the Hampton (Va.) Normal School will receive $20,000; the Home for Little Wanderers, Boston, $20,000; the Home for Aged Men, $5,000, and the Home for Aged Women, $5,000. The remainder of the estate is to be equally divided between the Roxbury Home for Children and Women and the Roxbury Charitable Society.

Ridgeway, of Kings County, has unearthed a criminal conspiracy within the last week, which involves a Supreme Court clerk, a number of lawyers, and others, and which has ramifications extending all over the country. TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 11.--Thomas Flack, a well-dressed youth, made his first appearance in Belleville about six months ago. Thomas was a commercial traveler, as he himself put it, or, in the language of others, a "coughdrop peddler."

CLEVELAND, Feb. 11.--It has rained steady throughout Northern Ohio since 12 o'clock last night, and it still continues to rain. It will not cause any further damage in this immediate vicinity, but in sections where streams have not been cleared of ice there is still great danger. In North-western Ohio the Maumee River and streams tributary to it are full of ice, which with steady rain cannot hold much longer.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 11.--This city is filled with alarm at the encroachments of the flood. The river has been rising half an inch an hour for 18 hours, and the Signal Service Department predicts that the flood will exceed the mark of 1883 all along the Ohio.

On Sunday night there was a loud explosion that shook every house in Hunter's Point near the Standard Oil-works and shattered many windows.

In the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, before Justice Cullen, a motion was made to punish Joseph M. Billings, an ex-Lieutenant in the navy, for contempt in failing to pay arrears of alimony amounting to $2,765 to his divorced wife. Decision was reserved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11, 1884. The House Committee on Appropriations to day finished consideration of the Military Academy Appropriation bill. The amount recommended is $306,989, being $76,271 less than the estimates, and $11,669 less than the appropriation for the present year. The bill appropriates $500 for renewing furniture in section-rooms, and $5,000 for reflooring the Academy building and cadet barracks.

SCRANTON, Penn., Feb. 11.--A fraud on a grand scale has been unearthed in this city, in which an attempt has been made to inflate the registry lists of the next election with dead and departed voters to the number of about 700.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11.--A month ago, if one attempted to draw members of Congress or other politicians into conversation about Presidential candidates, it was ten chances to one he would get a reply that would give the impression that there was absolutely no concern in anybody's mind about who should be the candidate for President in the next campaign, or, in fact, as to who should be the next President.

A joint resolution passed both houses of Congress yesterday authorizing the President to expend $300,000 for the relief of sufferers by the overflow of the Ohio River. The resolution called out no debate and no opposition in the Senate.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 11.--Gov. Crittenden's peculiar policy has again triumphed, and the people of Missouri are balked in their desire to do justice to the last of the James boys.

TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 11.--S.H. Appleby, who for some years represented East Hastings in the local Legislature, has been arrested on a charge of forgery. Mr. Appleby has carried on business as a miller in Shannonville.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Feb. 11.--The Hon. Mr. Taillon, Attorney-General of Quebec, in a speech to the electors here to-day, warned the Dominion Government that the refusal of an increased subsidy would cause the secession of the Province of Quebec from the confederacy.

LONDON, Feb. 11.--The Queen's new book, which was distributed to the press this morning, consists of a disconnected diary from Aug. 21, 1862, to September, 1882, with a long gap from October, 1879, to the final date, covering the period of transition from the administration of Lord Beaconsfield to that of Mr. Gladstone.

Hugh Wallace, a work-house immigrant from Ireland, arrived last Sunday on the White Star steam-ship Republic, but he will be sent back to Ireland by the Commissioners of Emigration.

Anton Singer was found dead yesterday morning in his cell at the New-Lots police station, having hanged himself with his handkerchief. Singer had been arrested on Sunday evening for assaulting a Mrs. Rapp.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 11.--The investigation into the City of Columbus disaster was resumed this morning. Hiram A. Phillips, first assistant engineer of the wrecked steamer, testified that he was on watch at the time of the disaster.
CAIRO, Feb. 11.--Gen. Gordon has arrived at Berber. He has asked for robes of honor and swords to distribute to local dignitaries.

BRADFORD, Vt., Feb. 12.--Chancellor Rowell has decided to instruct the Receiver to sell the mining property at Ely, Vt., for the benefit of the bondholders and creditors, on motion of the Vermont Copper Mining Company made in January. The property is valued at $1,000,000.

The trial of John Walker for the murder of William Frasier, on Nov. 25 last, which was begun at Paterson Monday morning, was finished yesterday afternoon, and the case will be given to the jury this morning.
The next reunion of the Army of the Potomac, which will take place in Brooklyn on June 11 and 12, promises to exceed in numbers and brilliancy any previous reunion of the organization.

No greater financial calamity ever befell any country the size of Scotland than the failure of the City of Glasgow Bank. The relief of the sufferers by such a misfortune obviously called for unexampled effort on the part of the community, and that effort was made.

Mr. George G. Ward, for the past 10 years General Superintendent in this country for the Direct United States and the French Cable Companies, has resigned his position, and will hereafter be connected with the Bennett-Mackay Commercial Cable Company.

WHITBY, Ontario, Feb. 12.--J.P. Beale, a well-known commercial traveler of Montreal, jumped from the Montreal fast express train today, and was so severely injured that he died in a short time. The train does not stop here, and when Mr. Beale jumped from it it was going at the rate of about 20 miles an hour.

CINCINNATI,, Ohio, Feb. 12.--At 9 o'clock to-night the river had risen to 68 feet 10 inches. This is two and a half feat higher than the previously unprecedented flood of 1883. Since noon the rise has been at the rate of three-quarters of an inch per hour.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 12.--A part of the first section of a freight train on the Cincinnati Southern Railroad broke loose last night on a heavy grade between Emory Gap and Oakdale Junction.
LONDON, Feb. 12.--Mr. Bradlaugh has applied for the "Chiltern Hundreds." His request has been granted and he has started for Northampton.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 12.--The payment of all bills by the city except those for police service was stopped last night by order of the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--The following is the text of the bill introduced in the House today by Representative Potter, of New-York, and referred to the Ways and Means Committee, to refund the bonded debt of the United States at 2 per cent. interest, It is intended as a substitute for the bill providing for 2 per cent.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Feb. 12.--The $200 fine imposed by law on a clergyman marrying a couple without the publication of the banns or the production of a marriage license was paid to-day by the Rev. W.G. Lane, against whom an action was recently taken for such illegal performance of the ceremony.
Horace Greeley's slippers, made from rattlesnakes' skin, are still in use, but there is no one on the New-York Tribune they'll fit.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 12.--An application has been filed here for a charter for the Western Pennsylvania Telegraph and Telephone Company, with a capital of $100,000. The business is to be confined to the western counties of Pennsylvania and portions of West Virginia, Ohio. New-York, and Maryland. The chief office will be at Pittsburg.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 12.--The excited condition of the community at Hot Springs, cansed by Saturday's tragedy and the partisanship of the adherents of the hostile gambling factions, resulted to-day in the quiet formation of a military company, composed of law-abiding citizens. Sixty stand of arms, sent by train by Gov. Berry this afternoon, are now in the company's possession.

The fourth concert given by the NewYork Philharmonic Club this season occurred at Chickering Hall last evening. LONDON, Feb. 12.--Telegrams received here report that the Egyptian rebels have captured Sinkat. The Cabinet has been summoned to a council for the purpose of discussing the Egyptian question.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 12.--The Republican State Central Committee held a session here today, which was attended not only by the members of the committee, but by prominent Republicans from all parts of the State.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Feb 12.--A young man named Thomas Boyd was stabbed in the abdomen here last night by Cornelius Boyle, a molder. Boyd walked to the office of a physician, where his wound was dressed.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12.--The war against the lottery agents has resulted in at least one victory for the newspapers. Indictments were found against a number of the agents, chiefly through the detailed evidence of three Tribune reporters.

The residence of Mr. and Mrs. D.H. McAlpin, No. 673 Fifth-avenue, was bright with flowers and lovely costumes last evening on the occasion of the marriage of their daughter, Miss McAlpin, to Mr. James Pyle. The decorations were of roses, smilax, and maiden hair ferns.

Arthur Leary was appointed Receiver of the New-York City and Northern Railroad in May, 1882, in proceedings by the New-York Loan and Improvement Company to recover money loaned. Recently the Central Trust Company, as Trustee, began suit for the foreclosure.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 12.--J.M. Jones Sons, car manufacturers in West Troy, have made an assignment to E.C. White, of NewYork, with preferences of $67,000 to M.M. White Co., of New-York. Their assets are not known.

Nicholas Judd, a ragged man is a sleeveless shirt, was taken before Justice Duffy, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, and arraigned as a tramp. "Commissioner Brennan is a relation of mine, he married my second cousin," said the prisoner, as he braced himself against the bar.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Feb. 12.--The striking weavers at the Barnaby Mill will return to work to-morrow morning on an agreement that the overseer shall be removed and a reduction be made in the amount of the fines for bad work.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 12.--Mr. Thayer (Democrat)was to-day elected Mayor of Binghamton by 900 majority. The Board of Aldermen will be entirely Democratic.

READING, Penn., Feb. 12.--The Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company having completed lines to this city from Philadelphia, a test was made to-night to all connecting points, which proved satisfactory.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 12.--The annual election of officers of the Young Men's Association took place to-day. For the first time in its history there was no contest on the Presidency.
JACKSON, Mich., Feb. 12.--Judge Crouch was arrested last night charged with attempting to murder Detective Brown. He was afterward released on giving bail in the sum of $5,000.

MERIDEN, Conn., Feb. 12.--At the annual meeting of the Lincoln Club, composed of leading colored men of Connecticut, resolutions indorsing Gen. John A. Logan as a Presidential candidate were adopted. After two trials and two trips to the Court of Appeals, the suit of Brewster Co. against Rufus Hatch has been dismissed. The suit was to recorder $445 42 for repairs to Mr. Hatch's carriage and harness.

A committee was appointed by the bridge Trustees on Monday to examine the question of the rates of toll and their effect on the revenues. The receipts from vehicles have fallen off greatly. They were nearly $9,000 in June. They were only $4,200 in January, or less than one-half.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 12.--The relief work has been put upon a broad basis to-day, and the committees have been enlisted and organized for work during whatever period the suffering may continue. The Board of Trade Relief Committee met at 11:30 A.M., and resolved that the best way to conduct the relief work is to hire a boat and to fully equip it with food, clothing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--The Secretary of War is taking active measures looking to the relief of the sufferers from the overflow of the Ohio River and its tributaries, in accordance with the act of Congress appropriating $300,000 for that purpose.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., Feb. 12.--The "Cape Cod Folks" case of Lorenzo L. Nightingale against Alexander Williams and others was put on trial here to-day.

The dinner of Brooklyn Republicans on Washington's Birthday will show the machine in New-York and throughout the country the spirit and purpose which will decide the Presidential election of 1884. There will be no threats and no denunciations. But there will be a very plain forecast of the way to Republican victory.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Feb. 12.--Walter Wilson, who disappeared on the eve of his marriage to a young lady here, and who is now in New-York, has sent no explanation to the family of his fiancee. The indignation felt in the city against him for his heartless conduct is very intense. The young lady is ill, and is under medical treatment.

ALBANY, Feb. 12.--An important hearing was given this afternoon by the Assembly Committee on Internal Affairs on Mr. Roosevelt's high license bill. The Assembly Chamber was crowded with interested persons from all parts of the State.
BOSTON, Feb. 12.--William Hayes has been arrested and held in $1,000 for an alleged at tempt to blow up the house of Frank Farnham by means of a can of atlas powder.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 12.--George Halstead, of Maltby, a small village about six miles from this city, visited his brother-in-law, William Hepler, at Sturmerville, a few miles distant, to talk over some business matters, when an altercation ensued. Hepler seized a shot-gun and fired at Halstead, a portion of the charge taking effect in his skull, and inflicting what is thought will prove a fatal wound. Hepler surrendered himself to the police.

OLEAN, N.Y., Feb. 12.--In the arrangements of the preliminaries " for the separate popular delegate convention," some of the friends of President Arthur in the new Thirty-fourth Congressional District have felt piqued at the unexpected turn which events have taken.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 12.--An unfounded rumor caused much anxiety among the depositors in the Dime Savings Bank to-day, and a run on it was the consequence. The bank paid over $30,000 in small amounts. It has $150,000 in cash not invested, and is prepared to meet all possible demands. These facts becoming known the panic subsided and the run ceased.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 12.--Thomas A. Coons, a cartman, aged 32 years, died this morning from a dose of rat poison, which he took with suicidal intent. He attended his brother's funeral yesterday, and became very despondent, and while in that frame of mind took the poision.

HYANNIS, Mass., Feb. 12.--The brig Confidence reports that when near Iucconnesset Light-ship this morning a flag was observed in her rigging, Union down. Upon arriving alongside it was learned that Capt. Berry, commanding the ship, was crazy and had been tied by the crew. The Confidence offered to take him off, but it was decided to telegraph the Light-house steamer Verbena to land him at Hyannis. which was done.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 12.--Serious trouble is apprehended among the iron-workers of Milwaukee and entire country before June 1 next. The difficulty may be similar to that experienced at about the same time last year when the scale of wages was in dispute.

A young lady residing in this city had a narrow escape from death by poisoning. While at work in the morning he grew hungry, and went to his dinner-pail to get luncheon. Taking a piece of pie from his can he began to eat it, but it was so unpalatable that he threw it away.
LONDON, Feb. 14.--A banquet was given at the St. Stephen's Club last night in connection with the unveiling of a bust of the late Earl of Beaconsfield.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 13.--Some excitement was caused to-day by a run on the City Bank. Over $50,000 was paid out. The bank is a creditor to the extent of $100,000 of the Jones Car Company, which suspended payment. The run continued till noon. Other banks tendered aid. It is believed that confidence is now restored. The bank was organized under the State law, with $100,000 capital, and it has deposits amounting to $400,000.

LONDON, Feb. 14.--Mr. Gladstone was this afternoon the subject of an unpleasant experience. He was walking in Bond-street, unattended on his way to the House of Commons. It is asserted that the man made the attack on a wager.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 14.--It has been told and clear here to-day, and the river has probably touched its highest point. It rose steadily during the night, the rise becoming slow by daylight and scarcely perceptible two or three hours later. At noon it was reported stationary, at 71 feet and three-fourths of an inch. During the afternoon it held its own, but at 8 o'clock to-night had fallen one inch.

There is disaffection in the Seventy-first Regiment between a majority of the line officers and their Colonel, which promises to create a number of vacancies in the organization. The trouble was brought to the surface on Wednesday, when Acting Adjutant Frank Whitney received the resignations of 15 line officers, which include the Captains and Lieutenants of all the companies except A and C, the two largest and best officered companies in the regiment.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 14.--Senators Hoar, Cameron, Frye, Saulsbury, and Jonas reached here this afternoon, and will begin in the morning their Mississippi investigation.

ST. JOHN, New Brunswick, Feb. 14.--Cable dispatches received here report the wreck of the ship Stowell Brown near Waterford, Ireland. The vessel was 11 years old and of 1,370 tons register. She was owned at St. John and Liverpool and was insured here for $22,000.
James Quigg, the sexton and undertaker, who on Sunday tried to kill himself with oxalic acid at No. 204 East Forty-eighth-street, cut his throat yesterday and soon died.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 14.--The St. Valentine Society, of Augusta, celebrated Valentine's Day with a grand ball to-night, attended by nearly 1,000 people.

There is no doubt that the weather on the North Atlantic has been very severe this year, and that to some extent the accidents that have occurred to the transatlantic steamers have been due to the weather. The Notting Hill was not, however, lost through stress of weather.
The annual meeting of the American Institute took place in its rooms in Cooper Institute yesterday. The usual opposition to the regular ticket was manifested.
SUAKIN, Feb. 14.--The news of the dispatch of British forces is spreading rapidly, and the rebels are dispersing.

BELLEVILLE, Ontario, Feb. 14.--Mrs. J.C. Moynes, a well-known and highly respected lady, has been missing from here since Monday. She became insane some time ago through illness, but recovered her reason and health. It is feared that she has relapsed into insanity and wandered off into the country, where she has perished.

HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 14.--An up-bound freight train, standing on the track taking water at this city this morning at 7 o'clock, was telescoped by an extra freight train, also bound north. The engine was damaged, the caboose destroyed, and two cars were burned, involving a loss of $15,000. No one was injured. The accident was caused by the fog and was due to culpable carelessness. All trains and the mails were delayed.

At the recent 100-yard dash between Kittleman and Harmon in San Francisco, which the former won, it is claimed that the best time on record in this country was beaten. Owing to several false starts the official time-keeper was unable to time the men accurately. Several bystanders agree, however, that the distance was completed by both men in less than 0:10.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 15.--The river here is at last at a stand, with 46 feet 7 inches registered. To-day has been clear, sunny, and cold, and all fear of more rain has passed. The steamer Mattie Hays, having on board $25,000 worth of food, left this morning for down the river in charge of Major Burke, United States Army.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 15.--The oil market to-day exhibited all the features of a panic, though the decline was not more marked than that of yesterday. The last three days has seen a decline of 7 cents per barrel, and to-day only 1 cents stood between the market and the dollar line. An element of the break was the exaggerated reports from the Porter well.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15.--The late Dr. Beverley Livingston, of New-York, a graduate of the Sheffield Scientific School in 1874, requested before his death, last year, that his scientific collections and certain other property should be given to the school.

The Citizens' West Side Improvement Association, which has been formed for the purpose of protecting the interests of property owners west of Central Park and between Fiftyninth and One Hundred and Tenth streets, held a meeting last evening at No. 408 West Seventy-first ...

WORTHINGTON, Minn., Feb. 15.--The mystery surrounding the death of Martin Riley, a farmer, residing near Adrian, whose body was found in a hay-stack in some time ago, has been cleared up by the confession of Riley's 13-yearold daughter, who declares that William, the 16year-old son of the dead man, committed the crime in retaliation for punishment inflicted by his father. The boy has fled.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 15.--R.G. Banks and Henry Parker were elected to the State Legislature from this city last Fall. The Legislature decided their election illegal, and they were unseated.

The horse of Dr. D.E. O'Neil, of No. 471 Hudson-street, was sick yesterday, and he hired one which was warranted sound and safe, and he went his rounds with his boy. At 2 o'clock, when the doctor crossed Fourteenth-street at Eighthavenue, the horse was attacked with staggers, and plunged wildly around.

Officer Patrick Stapleton, of the Thirtyfirst Precinct, met a very disconsolate young woman, well dressed in black velvet, furs, and a sealskin cap, in Seventieth-street, near Tenthavenue, yesterday morning.

About 70 interested property-owners met at Clark's, No. 22 West Twenty-third-street, last night to devise measures to prevent the building of a railroad through Twenty-second-street, as recommended by the Rapid Transit Commission.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 15.--At a meeting of the State Board of Agriculture to-day it was decided to introduce in the next fair some new features in the speed department by having long races for running horses.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 15.--The Assembly investigating committee visited the State Asylum to-day, spending the afternoon in the wards occupied by men. The committee conversed with and examined informally a large number of the ...

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 15.--At Duanesburg, to-day, the 4-year-old son of Silas Van Patten, while coasting, was unable to stop his sled at the foot of the hill. He plunged into the swollen creek and was swept away.

SUAKIN, Feb. 15.--The principal chiefs of the neutral tribes met at the Well of Handouk, situated about three hours's distance from Suakin, and decided to request Osman Digna, the leader of the rebel forces, to respect their territory or they will march against him. The rebels have invested Kassola. Tents for 1,000 men have been sent from Aden to Suakin.

SHAWNEETOWN, Ill., Feb. 15.--This morning the telegraph office here was invaded by the water, and communication was cut off for some hours. Subsequently the instruments were removed to the second story of a neighboring building, and no trouble in the future is apprehended, unless the poles are washed away and the wires break between here and the high lands.

Persons who assumed to speak by authority started a report in Wall-street yesterday that Mr. Vanderbilt had taken steps to prevent the consummation of the sale of the Nickel Plate Telegraph line to the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company. This line forms part of the National Telegraph line, which was recently sold by the Seney syndicate to Mr. Garrett.

The large hall of the Cooper Union presented an appalling array of empty seats when Chairman Quinn, of the meeting held under the auspices of the stone-cutters of New-York, introduced Victor Drury as the first speaker. Mr. Drury devoted his time to an exposition of the evils under which the stone-cutters of this State labored.
Some rather interesting but not very novel information is to be found in THE NEWYORK TIMES'S correspondence, which appears in another column.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 15.--Judge Landon has appointed E. Nott Schermerhorn Receiver for Jones's Car Company and directed him to pay $400, workmen's wages, due since Jan. 1. The men refused to work unless paid. The business will be resumed to-morrow, with 400 men, and the company will probably be reorganized.
Nathaniel Bloom, a dealer in fancy goods, at No. 473 Broadway, returned from Europe Thursday, after a business trip lasting six weeks.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 15.--The Mississippi River Improvement Commission is in session here arranging routine matters and making allotments of the $1,000,000 recently appropriated by Congress. So far they have allotted $400,000 for Plum Point Reach, the same amount for Lake Providence, $90,000 for Memphis, $50,000 for general service, and two small amounts for minor points.

The debate in the Chalmers-Manning contested election case was resumed in the House to-day, and continued at great length. ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 15.--The St. Petersburg Journal, in discussing the submission of the tribes of Merv, says: "Russia's relations with England are based upon the mutual recognition and just appreciation of each other's interests, which are perfectly reconcilable."

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 15.--A cable dispatch from Malta announces the safe arrival there of William F. Weld, Jr.'s, yacht Gitana; all well. It is expected that Naples will be reached Feb. 23.

It is alleged by the Canadian press that a Canadian father, wishing to discourage his daughter's lover, set a rat trap in his front yard--presumably near the front gate.

Mr. James D. Warren, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, reached this city yesterday and took rooms at the Gilsey House. He was accompanied by his wife, with whom he expects to start this morning for Richmond and other Southern cities on a brief pleasure trip.

ALBANY, Feb. 15.--Owing to the absence of many Senators engaged in investigating committees there was a thin attendance in the upper house this morning, and, after a session of 15 minutes, some one moved an adjournment to Monday evening. The Lieutenant-Governor declared the motion carried, notwithstanding the vote was three to one against it.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 15.--The trial of William F. Harig, indicted for assaulting with intent to kill James F. Busey, took place to-day in the Criminal Court. A number of witnesses testified for the prosecution and defense.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 15.--The Delaware at this city has risen 10 feet since noon, and is still rising. No damage has been done, although large quantities of ice and drift-wood are passing here to-night.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 15.--The Junior Class of Cornell University gave their annual ball in the armory this evening. The large hall was tastefully decorated with bunting and banners and was lighted by electricity. The Fifty-fourth Regiment Band of Rochester furnished the music for the occasion. A large number of Professors with their wives were in attendance, together with many of the leading citizens of Ithaca.

DEADWOOD, Dakota, Feb. 15.--Information was received here a few days ago that an attempt would be made by cowboys to rescue Jesse Pruden, arrested for horse stealing at Miles City, Montana, and en route for Deadwood.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 15.--Three persons at least lost their lives by the accident at the Southern Central Railroad bridge over the Seneca River, near Weedsport, on Thursday afternoon. The train was in charge of Conductor Charles O. Hart, and was returning from Fair Haven.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Feb. 15.--Under the recent decision of the Supreme Court of the State of Louisiana, to the effect that Quarantine fees were legitimate charges against the vessels trading in this port, the Cromwell Line of steamers will have to pay to the New-Orleans Board of Health $8,480 and the Morgan Line $14,385.

CUTHBERT, Ga., Feb. 15.--Thursday night George Dunaway was shot by his wife. During the night one of his children commenced fretting, when he got up to quiet it. He whipped it a little, and his wife becoming enraged, got up in the dark, and after a few words, got her pistol, walked close up to her husband and fired. The ball struck the lower rib, and, glancing upward, inflicted a fatal wound.

Among the total of 4,635 students inscribed at the Berlin University for the Winter term there are no fewer than 354 foreigners, of whom 23 are Austrians, 54 Hungarians, 74 Russians, 52 Swiss, 80 Americans, 6 Swedes, 6 French, 8 Japanese, and 3 Africans. Of English students there are only 5.

KEOKUK, Iowa., Feb. 15.--Train No. 2 of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Road was fired into at a point between Belfast and Sand Prairie yesterday afternoon while passing a high bluff. Buckshot was used. One charge struck the baggage car and the other shattered three windows in a passenger coach. No one was injured. The train was stopped and a search made, but the person who fired the shots could not be found.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 15.--An ice-boat, on which Frank McConnell and a man named Smalley were sailing on the Hudson this afternoon near Marlborough, struck a weak spot in the ice and broke through, throwing the men off on the broken ice with terrific force. McConnell had his scalp torn off and his jaw broken and was otherwise injured. Smalley was only slightly hurt.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 15.--The proceedings in the suit of Mrs. Mary S. Prendergast against Mrs. Fargo to recover possession of the Fargo twins were resumed in the Superior Court of this city to-day. The return to the writ of habeas corpus and the answer to the return were read.
The Manhattan Athletic Club's games at the Madison-Square Garden this evening promise to be the best series of contests ever given in the Winter in this city.

Baldwin, formerly Paying Teller of the bank, to recover $50,000 on the ground that the defendant profited by the thefts committed by his half-brother, Cashier Oscar Baldwin, a verdict was rendered yesterday in favor of the defendant.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 15.--The courtmartial is still occupied with the case of Naval Cadet Maxey. Naval Cadets Snow, Wills, Decker, Allen, and Burage, all of the Fourth Class, were examined in behalf of the prosecution.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 15.--At Chichester, this county, to-day, a young married man named T.S. Anery cut his wife's throat and then cut his own. The woman is dead and the husband is in a critical condition. Family troubles and jealousies are said to have been the cause of the act. They had been married one year.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 15.--The City Controller to-day returned the street-cleaning warrants without his signature. In a letter giving his reasons for this course he declares that the streets are a disgrace to the city and dangerous to the health of the people.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 15.--The people of this town have commenced to talk about the "prospects" for the fashionable season of 1884. It cannot be said that the outlook is very good. A few cottages have been rented at prices which will compare favorably with those received last year.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 16.--John Kelly, who was pronounced guilty a week ago of the murder of Jacob Lutz, was arraigned this afternoon for sentence. His counsel moved for a new trial, and the court reserved its decision until next Saturday.
JOLIET, Ill., Feb. 16.--Elizer Sage, a wellto-do farmer of the town of Channahon, in this county, died at his home yesterday. He was the twin-brother of Russell Sage, the NewYork millionaire.

Wiggins, aged 22, wife of an undertaker in Rome, committed suicide in her room in the new Osburn House, this city, early this morning, by shooting herself through the head. In accordance with the recent letter of the Pope concerning the daily recitation of the holy rosary in cathedrals, the Cardinal has directed that the holy rosary shall be recited in St. Patrick's Cathedral every day after the 8 o'clock mass, and on Sundays after the vespers, which are sung at 4 P.M.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 17.--The question of wages threatens immediate trouble in the Connotton coal region. A scale has been submitted by the operators, which the miners refuse to accept. Some of the men insist that Winter rates shall be continued, while others demand 68 cents per ton, instead of the 65 cents offered. An attempt at adjustment has been made, and if that is unsuccessful a strike will follow.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 17.--The heavy iron roof of the retort-house of the Charleston Gas-works fell in this morning, killing John McGann and injuring Cornelius McGowan and Edward Clarkin, firemen, who were engaged in the building at the time of the accident. The damage to property is $10,000. There will be no interruption in the lighting of the city.

When the Indian lacrosse team was in England last Summer a lady wrote asking the names and addresses of each red-skin, as she wished to send them a little gift. The Indians expected something very material, but last week the parcel arrived by mail, and contained a num ber of little volumes printed in English, called "Weighty Words from the Scriptures," being selections of texts from the New Testament. The Indians are all Roman Catholics.

For two years Jamestown was under no license rule, but last year there was limited and high license. The Republicans elected the remainder of their ticket.

Julia Hatcher, who lives near Salisbury, in England, has been awarded the Order of St. John of Jerusalem for bravery in saving the life of James Lodder, a boy who had been several times gored and tossed by a bull. The medal has an inscription stating that it was awarded "for service in the cause of humanity."
A party of masqueraders, male and female, in Hoboken, met a baker as they were leaving a ball yesterday morning, and immediately made an attack on his broad-basket.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 19.--Dr. J.J.S. Doherty, Registrar of Vital Statistics, was arrested tonight upon complaint of Enos Warner, of Hamden, for having willfully and knowingly issued a marriage certificate to his son, Le Grand Warner, for marriage with Miss Amelia Baker, both being under 21 years of age.

ERIE, Penn., Feb. 19.--This afternoon Giacomo Leonardo was convicted of murder in the second degree, and was sentenced to 12 years at hard labor in the penitentiary. Leonardo shot Pasquale Decarlos, a rival suitor-for the hand of a young woman, a month ago.

Mr. George W. Cable has recovered his health and resumed his public readings. The Washington Park Club, of Chicago, has sold the pooling and book-making privileges for its inaugural meeting at $4,405 per day.

MORRISVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 19.--In the Haight case the morning was spent in the reading of 50 letters from Mr. Haight to his wife, written between June, 1881, and Feb. 14, 1883.

HANCOCK, N.Y., Feb. 19.--Benjamin Smith, a teamster, was driving up a steep hill near this village, on Saturday, with a load of bark. When half way up he tied his sled to a tree by a rope to rest his horses. He climbed on the load for some purpose, and while there the rope broke.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 19.--The Hon. John Costigan, Minister of Inland Revenue, has resigned his portfolio, it is believed, on account of the Canadian Pacific loan.

COSHOCTON, Ohio, Feb. 19.--A terrific wind and rain storm struck this place at about 8 o'clock to-night, doing great damage to trees and buildings. The roof of the steel works, the largest manufactory in the place, was blown off and a portion of the walls was demolished. All the telegraph poles were blown down, and it is feared that much damage was done throughout the country.

The Chicago and Atlantic Railroad Company has applied to the Stock Exchange to list $2,500,000 of second mortgage bonds. First mortgage bonds to the amount of $6,500,000 issued by this company were listed in January, 1883.

Steps were taken yesterday by McGinnis Brothers Fearing--the brokers who were obliged to suspend on Monday--to get their accounts in shape for an immediate liquidation. Counsel and friends of the firm stated that the prospects were good for a speedy resumption of business.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19.--Amos Williams is one of the oldest and most respected residents of Middlefield, near Middletown. He owns a valuable farm and is possessed of enough other property to place him foremost among the well-to-do farmers of his town.
LONDON, Feb. 20.--The General Transatlantic Company's steam-ship St. Simon, Capt. Durand, from NewYork Feb. 7. has arr. at Havre.

BOSTON, Feb. 19.--The Republican State Committee will meet to-morrow to name the time and place of the State Convention to choose delegates at large to the Chicago Convention, and on Friday the Democratic State Committee will meet to name the time and place of the Democratic State Convention.

The fire which broke out in the Erie Building, at Duane and West streets, early yesterday morning is believed to have originated in the office of the freight agent of the Erie Railway, on the second floor, on the Duanestreet side.

Thomas Fitzpatrick, of No. 244 Firstavenue was drunk yesterday at Eighteenth-street and Broadway, and Officer C. Albertson, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, came up just as he had closed with a stranger who had declined to fight with him.

HANCOCK, N.Y., Feb. 19.--Silas Gray lived a miserly life near Walton, Delaware County, for many years.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 19.--A heavy rainstorm during the afternoon has increased tonight into a high wind that threatens to do much damage. South of the Ohio the wires are all down, which leads to the belief that the storm has been most severe in that direction.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 19.--John Devine, the 12-year-old son of Bridget Devine, of No. 28 Chatham-street, died on Monday night. The boy alleged that he had been struck by John Miskey, a stoker at the gas-works, with a shovel. Miskey was arrested on Feb. 9, while at his work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--Pottery and glassware, two well-protected manufactures, were talked about to-day before the Ways and Means Committee, the representatives of domestic production as well as the importers being heard from.
MITCHELL, Dakota, Feb. 19.--Post Office Inspector Pulcifer to-day removed the Postmaster here and placed the office under the charge of his bondsmen, as the result of an examination of the office.

"Rugg has been seen in the Hyatt's woods," he said excitedly; "come up quick with all the men you can." Almost at the same instant a messenger boy came in with a dispatch from Constable Michael Quis confirming the news.
The new steam-ship Santa Rosa, of the Pacific Coast Steam-ship Company, was thrown open for public inspection yesterday at the foot of East Ninth-street.

Senator Philetus Sawyer, or Wisconsin, was "raised" in St. Lawrence County, N.Y., "bought his time" of his father and started out for himself when 17 years old. He had in his belt $1,200 and $99 to pay his expenses on his way West.
The New-York Chorus Society will present at Steinway Hall this evening Brahms's German Requiem and Mendelssohn's "Midsummer Night's Dream" music.

SUAKIN, Feb. 19.--The latest advices from Tokar state state that 200 of the garrison made a sortie, attacked the enemy, and killed and wounded several of them. They also captured a number of cattle and camels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--Mr. W.P. Graves, (white,) a commission merchant of Danville, and an intelligent benevolent-looking gentleman, 63 years of age, was the first witness called in the Danville investigation to-day. He said he took little interest in politics except to vote.
Thomas Feeney and John Britton, the black-mailers arrested on Monday night, were remanded in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, as Mr. Oelrichs did not appear against them.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Feb. 19.--Justice Mathieu decided an important point in a life in surance case to-day, giving judgment in favor of the Phoenix Mutual against the heirs of the late W.A. Charlebois, who had invalidated his policy by taking to drink after it was taken outcontrary to the terms on which it was issued.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 19.--The Board of Railroad Commissioners of this State, in a decision rendered Jan. 1, 1884, prescribed a system of reduced local freight rates for the entire Atchison system of railroads in Kansas.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 19.--A Tribune special says that three out of four stages due in Lamoure, Dakota, yesterday have not been heard from, and it is believed that the drivers and passengers perished in the blizzard.

LONDON, Feb. 19.--The strike of the weavers has come to an end everywhere throughout East Lancashire.

Gen. Herman Haupt, late General Manager of the Northern Pacific Railway, has addressed a letter to the President and Directors of the company, which was not intended to be made public, but a copy of which fell into outside hands. In writing the letter he desires to place on recorda review of operations under his management.

Capt. James Ashcraft, of the fishing smack A.A. Rowe, reported yesterday to the Pilot Commissioners that last Thursday afternoon he fell in with a sunken wreck about 15 miles south by west of Barnegat, some of the spars were sticking out of water.

There have been numerous additions today to the Democratic visitors who hope to decide for the Democratic National Committee where it shall ask the National Convention to meet. Thirty-eight representatives from St. Louis arrived this forenoon, and a dozen more are due before Friday.

The action of the Republicans in the House of Representatives on Monday night and yesterday morning was quite justified by the circumstances. It was the best possible way to call the attention of the country to the schemes for emptying the Treasury of which the so-called Mexican Pension bill is but one.

There was a large attendance last evening at Delmonico's of gentlemen interested in the preservation of the Adirondack forests, the Produce, Maritime, and Mercantile Exchanges, the Chamber of Commerce, and other bodies being represented. Dr. Ferdinand A. Seeger presided.

The Board of Managers of the Cotton Exchange held a protracted meeting yesterday in reference to the report of the Supervisory Committee, in the matter of the alleged frauds by the firm of J.P. Billups Co. After careful consideration the board, by a vote largely in excess of the necessary two-thirds, decided to expel Mr. Billups.

The Queens County Jail, from which the murderer RUGG escaped, is, on the whole, the most imbecile and exasperating specimen of architecture in the United States, and not even a negro murderer could remain in it with any self-respect. The management of the jail appeals to be as unique as its architecture.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 19.--Patrick Casey, who claimed to have been robbed in a Hoosick Falls saloon, was so affected by the loss of his money and failure of the Grand Jury to indict the person accused that he became insane to-day and had to be taken to an asylum.

Col. Paine and Superintendent C.C. Martin were discussing, yesterday afternoon, the two stoppages which during the morning relieved the monotony of bridge traffic. The first of these occurred at 7:30 A.M., and caused a delay of 17 minutes.

MACON, Ga., Feb. 19.--John and Tobias Burnett, brothers, went this morning to H.C. Turpin's place of business and demanded a retraction of epithets applied by him to John Burnett.
BOSTON, Feb. 19.--The House to-day passed a bill to furnish text-books and all other school supplies free to pupils of public schools. These heretofore have been supplied by pupils or their parents.

A Sheriff's jury decided last night that John F. Van Dyke is a habitual drunkard and has been such for two years. The petition of his wife for the appointment of committees of his person and estate will therefore be granted by the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20, 1884. The Secretary of the Treasury has appointed George Garfield as Superintendent of the public building at Pensacola. Mr. Garfield is a first cousin of the ex-President.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 20.--A preliminary session of the American Institute of Mining Engineers was held last night. Many delegates were absent. The Hon. J.D. CARMEL, N.Y., Feb. 20.--The case of exJailer Chester W. Merrick, charged with the killing of a prisoner named James Byrnes in the County Jail here in November last, was taken before the Grand Jury at its present sitting, and to-day a bill of indictment was found against him of murder in the second degree. He was brought into court and pleaded "not guilty."

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Feb. 20.--Gustav Reummele, of this city, proprietor of a mineral water manufactory, committed suicide to-day by shooting himself in the head. Financial embarrassment was the cause. He was 65 years of age and leaves a family.

LINCOLN, Ill., Feb. 20.--Excitement has been wrought to a white heat to-day by the arrest in St. Louis and the bringing to the jail here of J.H. Hall and David Long by the Pinkertons, charged with being the murderers of Charles McMahon, Robert Matheny, and John Carlock near Mount Pulaski, in August, 1882.

Dr. Rufus W. Peacock, of Jersey City, who was charged with defrauding the American Legion of Honor, was arraigned yesterday before Judge McGill, who had appointed that time for deciding the application made by prisoner's counsel for an arrest of judgment.

NEW-CASTLE, Penn., Feb. 20.--At a meeting of the Ohio Valley Base-ball Association here to-day the schedule of games was arranged and the name of the association changed to the Iron and Oil Base-ball League. The championship season will open on May 1.

Bids were opened by Controller Grant yesterday in the presence of the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund, for stocks and bonds of the City of New-York worth $800,000, exempt from city and county taxation. For $250,000 assessment bonds, bearing 3 per cent. interest, payable ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 20.--The Copiah County investigation was continued to-day. Judge R.H. Ware, of Jackson, was the first witness. He testified as follows: "I was in the Confederate Army. I am now Assistant United States District Attorney for Mississippi.
Joseph McDonald, a driver on the ThirdAvenue Railroad, was sleeping in the drivers' room at One Hundred and Thirtieth-street, Tuesday night, when he was set upon by Thomas ...

The Grand Army of the Republic of Kings County has established a bureau of employment for the purpose of securing work for deserving soldiers and sailors of the late war. The bureau is under the charge of the Memorial and Executive Committee of the county.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Feb. 20.--Details of yesterday's storm show it to have been of a harrowing character. It formed in the Gulf and, striking Chattahoochee Valley, swept up through Fort Gaines until it struck this city, where its destruction cost $10,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 20.--The Roosevelt Aldermanic bill passed the Assembly to-day, receiving 70 votes, or 5 more than the requisite number to send it to the Senate. When Renegade Reformer John J. O'Brien with Bernard Biglin left here for New-York, last night, he gleefully predicted that the bill would not pass.

LIMA, Feb. 20, via Galveston.--The Nacional states that Puga has withdrawn his troops from Salaverry and Pacasmayo, and is concentrating them at Trujillo. He has issued an address to the inhabitants of Trujillo and the Provvince of Libertad proclaiming himself political chief of the northern departments.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 20.--The Orange County milk producers held a meeting at Goshen to-day and adopted a resolution requesting every milk producer in the county wishing to ...
MORRISVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 20.--Mrs. Haight was on the stand all the morning, and continued the story of her life up to the time of the shooting. On that day she claimed to have been entirely helpless.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 20.--Meyer Sondheim, a clothier, doing business in Hazleton, is in the hands of the Sheriff. Executions were issued against him this afternoon by NewYork and Philadelphia firms, amounting to nearly $10,000.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 20.--Eleven members of the committee appointed at the Cooper Union meeting to urge the progress of the Roosevelt Aldermanic bill arrived here to-night.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 20.--Contrary to expectation, the House adjourned at 1:40 A.M. without voting on the Canadian Pacific resolution, Mr. Costigan having moved an adjournment of the debate, which the Government, after considerable hesitation, agreed to.
BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 20.--The majority of the first branch of the City Council met this evening and suspended the rule which requires two-thirds (14) of all the members to constitute a quorum.
The Prison Labor Ccmmission submitted a preliminary report to the Legislature yesterday asking for time in which to give full consideration to the important subject referred to it.

The second concert given by the NewYork Chorus Society this season occurred at Steinway Hall last evening. The programme included Brahms's "German Requiem" and Mendeissohn's music to "A Midsummer Night's Dream," and these numbers enlisted in their interpretation Miss Helen M. Ames, Mrs. Minnie ...
Prosecutor Keen, of Essex County, N.J., has interested himself in the disappearance of Ex-Judge Finley A. Johnson, and in the forgeries of which he is said to have been guilty.

Packages and cases of wool littered the table of the Ways and Means Committee to-day, and the room was occupied by many persons who came to give reasons why the wool-growers of the country were opposed to the 20 per cent. reduction of the wool tariff.
A verdict of 320,000 damages, the amount sued for, was rendered yesterday by a jury in the Superior Court in favor of James S. Flynn against the New-York Elevated Railroad Company.

The Alumni of Hobart College, in Geneva, ate their third annual dinner, with the assistance of numerous friends, at Sieghortner's, in Lafayette-place, last evening. John N. Whiting presided at the table, and the Rev. Dr. W.A. Matson said grace.

Since the wreck of the City of Columbus New-Bedford children have been frequently noticed playing "wreck," as they call it. Recently, as several little ones were so engaged, using a box to represent the wreck, at little girl got into the box and held up her hands to be saved, whereupon a little boy shouted, "Go back, go back: not a woman or child was saved."
For the first time in five years, a jury in a case tried before Chief-Justice McAdam, of the City Court, were unable to agree on a verdict, on Tuesday night.

The trial of "Ed" Goody, the leader of the butcher cart thieves, who on Dec. 31 last assaulted and robbed Luther Church at the One Hundred and Eleventh-street station of the Second-avenue elevated road, was begun yesterday afternoon, before Recorder Smyth, in Part I. of the Court of Special Sessions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 20.--The World's Fair Committee have prepared a memorial to Congress asking an appropriation of $2,000,000. A communication has been sent to all the Governors of States and Territories requesting them to appoint Commissioners to visit the fair.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20.--The following proclamation was issued to-day:
The Aqueduct Commissioners met yesterday, and received from the Commissioner of Public Works an estimate of the cost of constructing the new aqueduct on the line of the modified Hudson River route.

The Shakespearean scholar, liquor-dealer, and lawyer, John H. McKinley, who occupies room at No. 81 in the Moffat Building, No. 335 Broadway, will be arraigned at the Tombs today, on a warrant granted by Justice Duffy, on a charge involving black-mailing.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 20.--Much interest is taken here in the finding of Referee H.S. Cutting in the matter of the petition of the NewYork, Lackawanna and Western Railroad for the appointment of Commissioners to appraise certain lands of the Union Steam-boat Company.

"Did you ever hear of a man's standing on top of Niagara Falls without losing his life?" asked Mr. C.P. sherman, yesterday. "Well, I did. You have heard of the magnificent icebridge below the Falls. Having business at Buffalo I ran up to look at the ice gorge.
The Nineteenth Century Club listened to a discussion of the objects and limits of science last evening at the home of Courtlandt Palmer, in East Twenty-first-street.

TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 20.--The examination of the case of alleged forgery by Harry L. Lee, of Cincinnati, was continued before Judge Boyd this morning. The accused man was engaged as book-keeper for Woodrough McParlin, of Cincinnati, and is charged with having, while in their employ, forged checks.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 20.--Clear and cold weather has succeeded the blizzard, and trains which were badly delayed, and in several cases abandoned, have been resumed and telegraphic communication restored.

A French philosopher has been collecting the statistics of divorce and lecturing on the theories with which they supply him. The results are interesting, and in some respects singular. Some well-worn theories are quite upset by his facts and figures.
Henry Hale, of No. 730 Third-avenue, went in the jewelry store of John H. Johnston, No. 150 Bowery, Tuesday night and asked to be shown some diamond ear-rings.

In October, 1873, Police Captain Jeremiah Petty, then in command of the Seventh Precinct, accompanied by Detective Robert A. Pinkerton, several other assistants, a jimmy, and a search warrant, went to the vaults of the Stuyvesant Safe Deposit Company, at Third-avenue and Seventh-street.
